movie_review_blurb: Halloween (1978) is a genuinely scary, stylistic and tasteful, extremely well-crafted slasher/horror classic from young film director John Carpenter
West Side Story (1961) is an energetic, widely-acclaimed, melodramatic musical - a modern-day, loose re-telling of Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet tragedy,
The classic and much-loved romantic melodrama Casablanca (1942), always found on top-ten lists of films,
The plot twist at the conclusion is a knockout surprise.
The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957), the memorable, epic World War II adventure/action, anti-war drama, was the first of director David Lean's major
movie_title: The Bridge on the River Kwai (1957)

movie_review_blurb: The Killing Fields (1984) is based upon a true story, and follows the historical events surrounding the US evacuation from Vietnam in 1975.
Gun Crazy (1949) (aka Deadly Is the Female), the forerunner of director Arthur Penn's Bonnie and Clyde (1967), is considered by many to be the ultimate B-movie
Pygmalion (1938) is the non-musical film version of George Bernard Shaw's 1912 stage play, a socio-economic drama based on the Cinderella story,
Sons of the Desert (1933) is a classic Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy comedy - the fourth of their full-length feature films, and possibly their funniest
Jolie is pretty much perfect for this sort of role, virtually wordlessly despatching assassins with machine guns, grenades, fists and -- in one particularly wince-inducing scene -- with a taser.
Clunky exposition and some decidedly wonky acting (Hassan's the best thing about it) slowly bleed the lifeblood out of a leaky plot.
Not the easiest of watches but remains compelling thanks to Mendelsohn's sure evocation of a man whose life has been buffeted by the past.
Sweet and satisfying.
While it appears all-too-obvious, there's an awful lot going on with fully filled out characters abrasively rubbing along.
Breillat's simplistic, spare approach pays dividends, particularly harnessed to sympathetic playing from the two girls, particularly Creton.

Played straight, it's initially amusing but swiftly outstays its welcome as the piranhas develop the ability to fly like fanged double decker buses and the whole caboodly tries just a bit too hard to be knowing.
It's an intriguing watch with just enough black humour to keep its quiet desperation at bay.

There's a winningly playful nod to Dirty Dancing (Duris even manages to repeat Patrick Swayze's moves) and the whole caboodle glides effortlessly towards a denouement you knew was coming but rather look forward to anyway.
It seems that Allen -- who hasn't needed to prove himself in an age -- is now happy to settle for, well, whatever works.
Wand-erful stuff.
The plot is as predictable as they come but it's the gentle playing that elevates this from formulaic kids' fare to a genuinely enjoyable family yarn.
Beautifully played and sharply-written, the pleasures on offer here are apparently throwaway but the authenticity of the characters freights the story with a light-hearted realism.
Forte plays it commendably straight as a malfunctioning Chuck Norris while the cliches of the genre - obsession with manhood, a gurning megalomaniac and maverick methods - are soundly nailed.
There's plenty to get your teeth into - just a shame you've got to wait so long for the main course.

It's an intelligent, original piece of work that totally flouts Hollywood formula while delivering killer lines with the sort of casual abandon that suggests a director totally in control of his material.
It's a solid, workmanlike sequel which could easily have been bolted onto the original to provide horror buffs with three hours of non-stop carnage.
Don't dismiss it as a cheap Brit copy of Save The Last Dance -- this stands on its own two feet and more.
For a film that limply purports to lift the lid on the sordid world of Soho sex trafficking this dismal offering is chock full of rank misogyny.
It doesn't always work but when it does it brings a refreshingly original spin to genres deadened by formula.

Without political preaching or providing traditional social commentary, Maoz has crafted a rare human drama, one that gives real insights into the horror of war. An uncomfortable ride...but one worth every penny.
You'd think you'd have the basis for a half-decent comedy. You'd be wrong.

Despite a heavyweight back story that would break the spine of most action crowd-pleasers, Scott's sure-handed way with a narrative means that the action never lets up, culminating in a spectacular medieval D-Day landings setpiece.
It's well-made and rattles along at a fair old pace, predictably leaving the way open for another 130-odd deaths in the inevitable glut of sequels.
There's a wretched tiredness and dull reliance on formula and, hard as the cast may try, a powerful whiff of desperation not helped by the ikky prospect of Bill and Emily getting jiggy.
There's plenty of bangs for your buck -- check out the dynamite-heavy ambush of a steam locomotive in the opening sequence.
Heigl's always watchable and it's a pleasantly undemanding effort even if it's premise is worryingly close to the 2004 TV film Raising Waylon.
There are few surprises but the blood-spattered action is handled with aplomb and Reno manages to keep a straight face when obliged to deliver the occasional lecture on morality.
While not up there with The Hangover, this delivers a respectable rate of gags-per-minute, largely thanks to the comic timing of the two leads and some occasionally inspired dialogue.

If you can get over the impossibly glamorous lifestyle of the immaculately groomed Zoe and the pumped-up pecs of the good guy goat farmer then Will & Grace screenwriter Kate Angelo's script will strike a few chords.
Comparisons have been made to Ricky Gervais' comedy of embarrassment, but this is sober, subtler stuff, played less for laughs and more for effect.
Pitts is at pains not to make an overtly political drama but his decision to keep the action spare and bleak means it becomes irritatingly obscure and, well, dull.
Writer-director Daniel Simpson ratchets up the tension, fully acquainting viewers with the soon-to-be victims before letting fly with an all-daggers-stabbing orgy of violence...

It's an appalling indictment of family dysfunction but there are shards of optimism, particularly the noble actions of the self-sacrificing couple who acted as foster parents for the adolescent Lorraine.
Even if the narrative winds up at a predictable destination it's been a journey well worth making.
It's what Pixar might come up with if their characters found themselves off the rails.
A curiously humourless affair that never really takes flight.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Director Robert Schwentke adapts Warren Ellis and Cully Hamner's darker graphic novel and colourfully retools it as a sort of thinking man's Expendables.
It seems to have brought out the best (well, better) in serial spoof merchants Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer, who have never been so focussed in their mickey-taking mash-ups.
The finale may come out of nowhere -- you probably won't see it coming -- but this can (un) happily join The Blair Witch Project and Paranormal Activity as superior horror.
The attention to detail that have been lavished on the models hasn't been applied to the script and the final plot swerves reeks more of desperation than a satisfying conclusion.
It's rare teenage audiences get the chance to clock a metaphysical mystery when they could be watching a vampire fight a werewolf for the hand of a sourpuss.
Perhaps he's worth listening to? Well, up to a point.
It's the action sequences, including a splendid scene when Chan mounts an ox to rescue his reluctant partner, that will keep audiences thrilled.
movie_title: Little Big Soldier (Da bing xiao jiang) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Rizvi keeps the humour broad (this doesn't have the metropolitan sharp sophistication of Chris Morris) but the premise is so strong that pithy satirical points are neatly scored.
Not since the peerless Monster House will kids enjoy getting scared out of their developing minds.
Further proof that Affleck -- after the professional doldrums of the Bennifer years -- is fulfilling the promise of Good Will Hunting and is a writer/director totally in command of his subject.
For the romatically inclined, it's just right.
Make no bones about it, this is first-rate stuff.
All we can report is that half the audience were rolling in the aisles while the rest looked like the voluntarily childless trapped in a kindergarten.
It's a gaping cut above your normal formulaic remake fare.
Basically, it's Barbershop with bigger bucks.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: First-rate stuff.
A trip into a pagan heart of darkness, this is certainly not for everyone but it's consoling to find a director who tries to do things that little bit differently.
We've seen this a hundred times before...only better.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Debut writer-director J Blakeson has craftily put together a taut, claustrophobic thriller where nothing and nobody are quite what they seem.

Andrew Thompson and Lucy Bailey's elegant film - much of it shot illicitly to avoid government thuggery - is a humbling chronicle of a good man squaring up against evil, for evil is what Mugabe's regime is.
It's never less than a compelling watch as the trio of turbo-charged troubadours swap anecdotes.
This lame family-centric comedy desperately wants to be Little Miss Sunshine but ends up - by virtue of the bizarre cast of unfunny characters - like Invasion of the Body Snatchers.

A premise this barking was never really going to work - Heppell and Treadaway's romance plays out like a Byker Grove tryst relocated to a Hartlepool knocking shop - and some of the all-too-authentic night vision scenes will struggle to find an audience.
At two-hours plus, it goes on a bit but Ritchie appears in his element working from someone else's script and Downey Jr brings real verve to role previously known for its starch and conformity.
Diehard fans will lap it up...but it's difficult to see it winning any new converts.
movie_title: St Trinian's II: The Legend of Fritton's Gold (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Director Rob Marshall's handsome adaptation of the Broadway musical - based on Frederico Fellini's travails while shooting 8 1/2 - piles an awful lot of drama onto a paper thin plot. It's certainly no Chicago.

Writer-director Lynn Shelton has crafted a richly rewarding script that enables the viewer - with a minimum of effort - to buy into an idea which in lesser hands would flail impotently. As the guys say "it's beyond gay."
The showdown has the feel of Mission: Impossible remade for the ICA crowd and what might have been a cheeky distraction for 90 minutes is just plain tedious approaching the two-hour mark.
Never less than engrossing, this is one trip you won't want to make.
The action pans out pretty predictably but such is the verve of the story and the impressive visuals you may find yourself heading off course to catch Planet 51.
This is a superlative piece of film-making. Terse, raw and unadorned, there are no cheap tricks to devalue a story of unconditional love.
Grey holds the attention for the whole film, imbuing the label-obsessed courtesan with an icy edge that subtly hints at emotional damage.
It's the pure, device-free performances of the talented cast of children that makes this a winner and that rare thing - a Christmas movie that actually captures a pocketful of its spirit.
Don't watch it alone or, if you're of a nervous disposition, don't watch it all.
A lightweight yet likeable cross between The Insider and Catch Me If You Can.
For a story with so many sub-plots it's to Bazancon's credit that he keeps the psychological plates spinning without mishap.
movie_title: Le Premier Jour du Reste de ta Vie (The First Day of the Rest of Your Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There's no doubting Haneke is a masterful film-maker, but it's difficult to warm to his cold worldview.
[Earhart's] trajectory from bubbling wannabe to national treasure is never less than compelling thanks to a no-nonsense performance from Swank.
[Caine is] never less than watchable and lifts what threatens to be yet another derivative revenge yarn into something better.
This shrugs off the musty restraints of costumed stereotypes and concentrates exclusively on the slowburning affair as Keats finds himself "dissolving" as love draws him in.
Sometimes the richness of the visual banquet threatens to leave viewers with Christmas afternoon indigestion yet never stops you feeling hungry for more.

Picture a knackered jalopy misfiring on all cylinders, lurching from one pile-up to the next and spewing foul fumes as it lumbers inevitably to the breaker's yard. Then think of the cinema equivalent.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's an impressive, thoughtful version with Reeves' reverence for his source material winning through and the performances of his two young leads well up to snuff.
A tender and intelligent glimpse of a life enriched both by her nascent talent and the affectionate devotion of Uhde's protector.
Slight and occasionally clunking, it wins through by its sheer good nature and some particularly strong playing.

Serkis perfectly captures the roguish "raspberry", a swaggering troubador and calipered master of lurid stagecraft whose intricate wordplay was sublimely welded to the jazz-tinged tunes of his writing partner Chaz Jankel.
This is a mess of unconvincing characters, doolally plotting and dumb flag-waving - the one honest character being an Iraq vet forced to join the others in their brain-dead scam.
Death can't come quickly enough.
Ancient history never looked so good.
The whole cast deliver convincing portrayals of idle, Twitter-connected youth even if their lack of moral parameters are a cause for some concern.

Filmed in cold, steely greys and blues, it's at its best during the numerous action setpieces, particularly close-quarter, hand-to-hand combat where the butchery of axes, knives and spears is shown in all its gory glory.

Polanski never lets things get too self-regarding, liberally sprinkling the script - co-written with Harris - with some nice touches of humour from the novel and the change to the ending actually ties things up more neatly.
You're not here for sharp dialogue or character development and you don't get it. But who's complaining?

Occasionally, the dialogue clunks but a winningly vulnerable performance from Marinca goes a long way to building up a picture of a compromised world of political horse-trading where even war criminals can get away with it.
Violence this in-your-face needs a witty, quip-laden script to sweeten the bloody pill and this doesn't deliver.
It's an immensely likeable and very British comedy that makes some pertinent points about how families connect. A loud cheer for the big bang.
It works like a dream -- a particularly vivid one -- with only an actor of Carrey's energy having the ability to pull it off, even if this reduces McGregor's passive partner to one dimension.
The perfect watch if you don't fancy a challenge. Any sort of challenge at all.
Not your usual post-apocalyptic fare then. Even if it does get a bit daft towards the end (thanks, Malcolm McDowell) this is superior action fare, neatly shot and whip-lashingly edited.

What really strikes is the steel meld between bone-jarring action scenes and the all-too-believable political chicanery from the sort of people who will be on nodding terms with Halliburton in the form of Kinnear's sharp-suited ultra-rotter.

At well over two hours, it could have done with some judicious pruning but Scorsese still manages to keep the story rattling along with a wry sleight of hand and a masterful manipulation of the narrative.
A light, cheery metropolitan take on what it's like to be left holding the baby.
OK, it's pulpy... but it's also guiltily enjoyable once you appreciate it's little more than a B-movie with an A-list cast.
If it could be bottled up, the label would read "watch me."
Adams shone in the superlative Enchanted but the quality of writing on offer here isn't going to give James Joyce at his most lovey-dovey much lost sleep.
Possibly the biggest medical poser on offer is why Brendan Fraser had to put on 20lbs to play the role.
Preposterous, knockabout stuff but prevented from being genuinely enjoyable by a nasty undercurrent of racism.

There's no denying its visceral punch, delivered convincingly with unsteady, hand-held camerawork and profanity-spewing dialogue that makes The Thick Of It sound like Yes Minister. It'll leave you breathless alright.
If you can buy into the improbable, this ultimately pans out as a wise and rather poignant story.
The bulk of the fight sequences take place at bed-time so it's difficult to see exactly what's going on - it's like putting a colony of bats in a Magimix. In the dark.
Visually sharp but dramatically flat, The Boys Are Back plays like a montage of Kodak moments that engage the eye but rarely the heart.
This is splendid stuff, directed with verve and humour by Banksy who - aghast at Guetta's artistic triumph -- announces he will never make another art film. Shame.
An inexorable dread holds the attention (if you've seen Moodysson's disturbing Lily-4-Ever you'll know what to expect) and as tragedy moves ever closer it's difficult too look away.

It's a downbeat, low-key peek into the thankless task of climbing the greasy entertainment pole and you're rewarded - not with laughs - but a grim insight into quite how unfunny the comedy world can be.
Adapted from Marie-Sabine Roger's novel, this is a modest heartwarmer enlivened by subtle performances and a colourful supporting cast.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's all about the characters and - thankfully - they're good ones. In fact, you're glad they're not Gone in Sixty Seconds.

John le Carré's 1974 novel - most famously served in the BBC's seven-part series with Alec Guinness in the Smiley role - is machine-tooled down to a lean two hours by Swedish director Tomas Alfredson.
It's not nice...but it's not bad.
Wiesen's gossamer-thin tale asks a lot of Highmore, who could unkindly be referred to as the missing link between child stars Nicholas Boult and Haley Joel Osmont.
It's hardly In The Realm of the Senses, but the point is, er, rammed home that love is more important than sex.
A perfectly enjoyable - if bloody - sword'n'sandals set-to.
It's the work of a director firmly in control of his subject and shows that - when he wants to - there are few subjects that he can't tackle with flair.
Assured and well-written, it may totter uncertainly in the third act but it's a pleasure to listen to a script with such an ear for shocking insult and knowing offence.

Director Bier and her regular screenwriter Anders Thomas Jensen construct a believable series of events where notions of Western civilisation as opposed to Third World moral disarray are put to the test.
This is a shoddy affair with anodyne first-timers Blanchard and Cook almost as annoying as Ricky Gervais's phoned-in voiceover of an animatronic terrier with a poop obsession.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cooper plays the vicious rotter in the manner of an enraged Freddie Mercury auditioning for Alvin and the Chipmunks.
It all ends pretty predictably...but it's been an amiable experience.
There's not much for mums and dads - this doesn't attempt any cute Pixar-style adult-pitched gags - but younger audiences will revel in the mischievous manipulations of a negative role model.
A lack of consistent tone means it all ends up a bit of a mess.
A comedy miracle that is the mirthful match for any so-called fun-fest that has emerged from Hollywood this year.
Occasionally sudsy but always watchable, director Bertrand Tavernier's adaptation of Madame de La Fayette's novel wears its two-hours plus running time surprisingly lightly.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Wilson's disengagement often seems motivated by genuine lack of interest more than smouldering impotence.
Director David Schwimmer's cautionary tale of the very real dangers posed by manipulative paedophiles grooming young kids on the internet scores some direct hits.
It certainly questions the honesty of the hackneyed phrase land of the free.
A story that's efficiently told if hidebound by its worthiness.
Unfortunately, none of the characters is particularly sympathetic...
A veritable banquet of awfulness.
A rubbish sex romp.
It gives people a platform to speak...and then just gets on with it.
Seth Gordon rolls up his sleeves and shows the comedy pretenders exactly who's boss.
One of the funniest films of the year.
It's a bit of a mess but there's enough inspired writing and outrageous plot twists to keep you heading for the exit.
A provocative, engaging tale utilising clever use of extended flashback and showcasing an intriguing twist.

Plot-wise it's a meandering, stuttering mess with tsunamis roaring into life only to mysteriously disappear, a fistful of plot strands meaninglessly loitering about and any sense of danger immediately undermined by all-too-obvious solutions.

Paquin - a 29-year-old playing a teenager - is outstanding as the bolshie adolescent doggedly pursuing a mawkish retribution, exquisitely delivering Lonergan's drily painful bon mots while trying the patience as flakey torch for truth...if not justice.
The premise may err on the daft side but it's played with conviction and an atmosphere of bleak dread is carefully evoked if not maintained until the final credits.
It's the collision of Shannon's reality and dementia that's the driving force propelling a drama that is dark with foreboding.
Davies fans will be used to his unique style but his slow-motion narrative could have unfamiliar pundits bewailing the fact the Battle of Britain went the other way.
Gupta, working from novelist Owen Sheer's screenplay, isn't tempted by big bangs and action setpieces, preferring to keep the narrative subtly human scale.
Snowtown brings cold comfort.
Movingly written and exquisitely played by the three leads, this never gets bogged down in sentiment or lazily opts for easy answers.
If there's any justice, Nic might want to take a long break.
Yes, it's a mess.
There's enough happening in The Awakening to keep you awake.
A Christmas cracker.
I've seen The Future...and it's not bad at all.
This machine gun preacher offers lots of noise but casts little light.
An effective thriller...but it's offering nothing new.
Tight as a drum and smooth as a snakeskin suit, this is a movie that harks back to golden days of the conspiracy thriller yet remains totally credible as a chronicle of ruthless political ambition.
Kids will enjoy the day-glo pyrotechnics and mums and dads can revel in some of the most impressive CGI spectacle committed to celluloid.
Lean and fast-moving, Soderbergh ratchets up the tension without straining credibility while the days tick away and the body count rises.
Young buck Lerman never convinces; you feel that a sharp clip round the ear would put him in his place. And his romance with lady-in-waiting Gabriella Wild has all the fizz of damp gunpowder.

Updating the quarter-of-a-century old original with a more racially representative cast and hipper street moves, Brewer also trumps his predecessor with a zinging script and some likeable performances...
Mann is definitely one to watch.
Browning's performance as the ludicrously passive sex object has been described as "brave", which is normally shorthand for the fact that she takes all her clothes off.
Director David Mackenzie's refreshing take on the disaster plague genre goes for the personal rather than the pandemic...
Make no mistake, this is a hard and challenging watch.
Firmly old school in its feel, this has plenty of hide-behind-your-hands moments...

Like that little itch after a one-night stand, this could have been something more.

A thing of biuty.

The movie unfolds at the same pace as Johnny's languorous life, a slow, seemingly pointless blurring of the days, but one that arrives at a touching moment of self-realisation.

Thanks to a top-notch cast, which also features Thewlis as a stoned luvvie and Friel as Mitchel's sluttish sot of a sister, plus a wry script, this stands head and shoulders above recent geezer fare.
A hit.

Less a hangover and more a mild irritation.

movie_review_blurb: It's a true win, win.

It's a moving and emotionally draining docu-drama...

This one's got it's heart in the right place...but little else to recommend it.

Like Hepatitis B, this is one of those movies you just hope will go away.

movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

It might not be much easier to buy than a 1950s True Detective comic, but this is as slick and explosive as a barrel of high-octane hair oil.
Spectacular to look at and often poignantly beautiful to listen to, this won't disappoint the millions who have sighed at the stage play.
There have been some fatuous claims to girl empowerment here...but this is really on a feminist level with The Spice Girls wielding a surgical bone cutter.
It may appear undemanding...but there are deeper themes swirling beneath the surface to which Hoffman shows a sympathetic ear in this pleasing debut.
The Orphanage director JA Barona deals in a different sort of horror in this wrenching account of the lethal tsunami which struck the Thai coast at Christmas 2004.
Face it Billy, this isn't that funny.
See it...then travel back in time and see it again.
It's never less than watchable and confidently made...but you get the impression there is a bigger, better story waiting to take off.
A clever, intricate thriller with a killer twist.
It's amiable bordering on lazy as opposed to rivetting - it's difficult to see the point of The Watch.
Even at a relatively modest 110 minutes Brazilian director Fernando Meirelles's sprawling ensemble piece tiresomely outstays its welcome.
Worth a watch for some stunning scenes - particularly an extended shot entering the dark heart of Kronos's lair - and retina-blasting setpieces.
Debut director Danny Donnelly's thriller settles snugly alongside similar geezerish fare such as Kidulthood. Which is to say it isn't very good.
Transferring Victorian's England's inhumanely rigid class pecking order to the equally infexible inequalities of the Indian caste system works a treat.
At times, it's almost as funny as Four Lions. The trouble is, it's not meant to be comedy.
It's an uneven affair but fans of the style will find it comedy nirvanha.
Eschewing the slick vapidity of Glee, this champions a let's-do-the-show-right-here philosophy while lightly touching on heavier issues of race and gender.
A convincing picture of a principled man prepared to become a jailed martyr if that's what it took to rally the people behind him.
It just goes on and on - the cinematic equivalent of watching sand pouring through an egg timer that takes well over two hours to empty.
It's good to see a dirty cop that doesn't come clean.
Although running the risk of slipping into mawkish melodrama by the end, this still has the power to move.
While the premise is quite promising, the dead hand of Valentines Day co-writers Abby Kohn and Marc Silberstein supplant the human interest potential with a mawkish rom-com sensibility.

Although essentially a series of genuinely impressive dance set pieces linked by no more than adequate dramatic interludes, this scores thanks to its sly acknowledgment that street dance can take itself a little too seriously.
Ultimately, it's a good-old fashioned action romp - there's no mystery about it.
It's an effective chiller in the grand tradition of British horror with a couple of icy-bucket-of-water-down-your-neck moments.

Youngsters will be enthralled by the adventures of the troublesome trio while mum and dad may find themselves singing along to a Matthieu Chedid's score, a rich pastiche which sweetly drives the narrative along.
The last, touching final frame is worth the entrance price alone.
It's a qualified success...but what Fiennes the director does next could be even more intriguing.
This version of the 1930s cause célèbre would make an efficient TV movie but Madonna bizarelly insists on distractingly tacking on a lame parallel story.
An awkward re-hash of any number of superior movies ending in a risible liaison with a CGI submarine that would look unrealistic in an episode of Bagpuss.
It's a slick, well-made film about a catastrophic set of events that were catastrophic to everybody but those who actually caused them.
A solid affair which thankfully avoids any Disney-style anthropomorphism and - bearing in mind its mainly teen audience - avoids graphic bloodletting.
It's a worthy film...with no happy ending.
Michod provides little insight into his lethally purposeful avenger, save a rueful musing on the value of guilt and the need to dwell on your sins...when he's not blazing away with fatal abandon.
It's probably quite a few people's idea of hell - being trapped on a desert island with Alvin and The Chipmunks for ear-drum-testing company.
This year's Winter's Bone?
Some of the violence may be a little much for younger viewers but the unconventional story plus carefully considered characters make this a must.
There's no glib emotional grandstanding with the cast - particularly the excellent Cardellini - unshowily inhabiting their roles and underlining the assertion that it really could happen to anybody.
Use your head...and hunt it down.
A spare script and lean dialogue lend genuine power to the taciturn youngster's unswervable quest for justice, a single-minded obsession that results in some truly bone-crunching violence.
It may be the most "Disney" of Pixar's efforts but it's a rousing tale, imbued with a fresh maturity - a brave new world.
Beautifully rendered and charmingly told, this family animation packs more of an environmental punch than most kids' fare.
A fairy that can't quite cast a spell.

This may be a familiar tale - rough-around-the edges dissenter against a barbaric system - but it's well told and the icy wastes of the island provide a chilling backdrop to the cruelty dealt out to the boys.
It's diverting even if it never cranks up the tension much further than the odd jolt.
This succeeds thanks to Lodge's extraordinary central performance, a terrifyingly mesmerising study of a woman in diabolic torment
The powerful vein of black humour that runs through it never renders the violence gratuitous while the characters are a rich mix of venality, lust, revenge and low IQ.
Seth Grahame-Smith's source novel was barking enough...but in director Timur Bekmambetov's hands the story spins off into a dizzying maelstrom of madness.
Black - or indeed any audience - gagging from Tyler Perry's sugary depiction of Afro-American middle classes will welcome director Tim Story's wittier approach to the shifting sands of courtship.
Paints a compellingly authentic picture of the mentally gruelling life on the job.
At the end of a long night, it's an effective thriller that could have done with sticking to its strengths.
Things only pick up in the final reel with Alan Drakes's 80s rock fan and community police officer given full rein to deliver the best jokes so far. But it's too late.

Extremely violent, unflnchingly recording the beating of a rebellious prostitute by her Russian handler or a naive teen getting drilled between the eyes after he fatally got out of his depth with the big boys.
It's definitely a story worth telling.
It's been ten years...but it's been worth the wait.
It's a quietly thoughtful film that eschews cheap sentimentality and - through the assured performance of Rahim - demonstrates that good can come from the most unlikely places.
Madchens in tight blouses, space travelling stormtroopers, - was ist not to like?
Where it sings are the searing action sequences, sublimely choreographed setpieces engagingly linked with a narrative choc-full of lippy one-liners.
It's good day-glo fun with a satirical edge whose playfulness never allows proceedings to get too earnest.
Ultimately, it's a bit of a point-to-point nag rather than a Derby winner.
Resolutely downbeat, this tale of Victorian gender-bendering scores thanks to skilful performances, particularly from Close and McTeer, and a exhaustive attention to period detail.
Cassel is well cast as the virtuous priest and director Dominik Moll resists the temptation to ramp up the action, preferring to keep the devil's work insidious and quietly all-consuming.
It's a rom-com worth catching.
What really grabs the attention are cinematographer JA Ruiz Anchia's staggeringly beautiful Bolivian vistas, the riotously colourful backdrop against which Blackthorn tries to outrun his pursuers.
It's big and noisy...but it's also fun.
Ultimately, it's only Boyle's supremely assured style that saves it imploding into a overcooked stew of half-memories and untrustworthy recollections.
A ludicrously enjoyable sci-fi thriller salted with some sharp lines caustically delivered by Pearce as a sort of thinking man's Jason Statham.

As a director, Korine certainly has visual style (most of it seemingly knocked off from MTV Beach Party) but doesn't seem overly concerned with fleshing out any his buff bodies with character let alone dialogue.
Time to check out (or into) The Grand Budapest Hotel.
Liam Neeson's twilight purple patch as a creaking action man - Taken, The Grey, Unknown - gets firmly off the ground in this enjoyable hijack caper high above the clouds.
[A] hyper-realistic blockbuster, the first Russian film to be made for an IMAX audience and also shot in 3D.
A barkingly enjoyable ride.
Tough, poignant and ultimately life-affirming, this is the way Woodroof's tale deserved to be told.
Ultimately, it's a monster movie that's the sum of less than its parts.
Ultimately, it's not just Armstrong that emerges as the villain of the piece - the whole sport looks pretty grubby too.
This is one awkward moment that runs for 94 minutes.

A relentless, raw and visceral condemnation of a viciously racist regime that condemned its victims to a life of hard labour with random cruelties thrown in and justified by a skewed interpretation of the Old Testament.

Russell's unerring ability to take the careworn components of a story and fashion them into something unique and poignant reaches its peak with an exuberant caper that satisfies across the board - from love story to switch-backing crime yarn.

This is a far more purposeful affair, mostly devoid of the longeurs that often drained momentum from An Unexpected Journey and winningly unafraid to depart from JRR Tolkien's text to enrich the mix of characters.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Fans of the first outing will not feel they've been stabbed in the back.
There's no doubting the sincerity and there's little point in offering up cynical resistance to an all-singing, all-dancing, all-emoting gospel finale.
This undercooked cartoon caper about a rogue turkey heading back in time to get his compadres off the menu for the Thanksgiving Day dinner fails to ruffle anything like a feather.
Those with a ravenous appetite for the cruel and the kitsch will find plenty of nourishment in the second instalment of the film adaptation of Suzanne Collins' teen trial literary trilogy.
In a bravura performance, Gordon-Levitt sleazily revels in the role of bad boy...but it's a character undistinguished by light or shade and becomes wearing, a sex drive that ends up a cul-de-sac.
Glorious.
Larson is one to watch.
If you can overcome Wilde's physical distractions, there's much to savour in a romance that plays out convincingly ...
Often grim and disturbing, it's not an easy watch but one that grows to resonate and seduce with its brutal honesty.
Ultimately, the far-fetched plot is its undoing, crippling what could have been a compelling insight into the dirty works of the security services without recourse to over-familiar action setpieces.
It's a familiar tale but one which is never condescending or patronising: fans of Billy Elliot will be dancing with delight.

The joyous thrust of this thoroughly entertaining - and often poignant - comedy thrives on the sparkling chemistry between Gandolfini and Louis-Dreyfus, a romance pitched at that often overlooked demographic - the middle-aged divorcee.
For the financially savvy Arnie'n'Sly it's not so much escape plan...as pension plan.
This rom-com-dram take on The Big Chill isn't quite up there with Lee's sparkling debut but it never succumbs to the grim sudsiness waded through in Tyler Perry territory.
Trejo - despite his headliners in the Machete series - is not a leading man. But that doesn't mean there isn't some dubious fun to be had.
The acting is uniformly excellent and writer-director John Butler has an ear for dialogue yet the resulting mild diversion never does more than quietely amuse.
Jonathan Glazer's loose adaptation of Michel Faber's novel tightens its hellish grip thanks in no small measure to Mica Levi's shuddering electronic score ...

The always affable Johnson ably fills the sandals of this particular take on the Hellenic hero and wryly holds court over this hugely enjoyable nonsense while wearing a lion's head apparently sure in the knowledge that it doesn't look ridiculous.
A psychological thriller aiming to avoid the straitjacket of formula.
A visual banquet the ankle-biters will be happy to feast on.
movie_title: Thunder and the House of Magic (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The best kind of food for the soul is served up in writer-director Jon Favreau's mouth-watering story of a jaded chef and hopeless husband rediscovering his appetite for life.
This grim depiction of a seriously damaged Athens family dispenses with any feel-good niceties to deliver a no-holds barred blow to the senses.

There's little that's unfamiliar about director Jonathan Sobol's switchbacking caper so he winningly cashes in on the strength of his cast, particularly Russell's world-weary con and a scene-stealing Stamp as the languidly insolent Brit.
It's a beautiful treat...that's not that nourishing.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Flanagan has constructed an ingeniously compelling thriller, cleverly using his protagonists' shaky grip on what is really happening to submit them to some really nasty moments.
Belle - while never slipping into fiery polemic - makes its political points solidly, careful to couch its righteous invective in a compelling narrative inspired by a true story.
Coogler's spare, sombre style serves the story well, skillfully avoiding cliche and formula to soberly rage against a grave miscarriage of justice.
There is not one jot of emotional engagement.
It all looks grand (thanks to Loach's regular cinematographer Robbie Ryan) but the lush greens and russet reds tweely disguise any red-bloodedness. This is minor Loach.
Despite the potentially sparky dynamic of the super-heated menage a trois the tension-free narrative lacks depth ...

Director Richard Linklater has wisely stayed with the structure of the 1976 classic (with Walter Matthau in the Butterworth role) but populated it with dialogue from Bad Santa's Glenn Ficarra and John Requa.

Subtle and wryly amusing, this is a sympathetic glimpse into the ever-musing mind of an off-kilter genius...but how much it's an accurate reflection of the real Chris Sievey (who died of cancer in 2010) it's difficult to say.
There's plenty to guiltily savour - most of it unintentional - in a revenge yarn that unspools like End of Watch played for laughs.
Unfortunately, in these days of uniformly high-quality kids' fare this - with its lumbering voiceover and slack plotting - looks like it belongs on children's TV.
If you can look beyond the preposterous nature of this cartoonish retread, there's fun to be had thanks to a series of inventive action setpieces ...
Hardly pioneering.
It could descend into maudlin self-pity but McDonagh's story - with comedy turns from a fast-talking rent boy and Moran on splendid form as the boorish banker - stays just the right side of the line.
It all pans out like an incredibly well-told single joke.
Goldner carefully builds up the tension by creepy increment, neatly switching from Gray's geezer spiel to an all-pervading sense of dread to inextricably draw the viewer in.

You have to admire novelist Nick Hornby for his bad taste premise and there's lots of comedy mileage to be extracted from a - surprise, surprise - gallows humour as one of life's greatest taboos is made sport.
Even if it's not what you expect from the director of Juno, there is much to enjoy in the richly-detailed performances. Labor Day is anything but hard work.
There is very little real substance here and clothes horses will be frustrated at the lack of insight into an industry that makes no sense to anyone outside it.
Cumberbatch is handed his meatiest role yet and delivers ...
Even at 107 minutes, it outstays its welcome...and it's difficult to see Machete Kills cutting much ice with an audience that doesn't consist of damp-palmed teenage boys.
The story speedily soars towards an impressive finale and is sure to enchant a legion of youngsters ready to move on from the original Sleeping Beauty.
More sudsy than a tsunami hitting a Proctor & Gamble factory.
A rewarding mash-up of Last of the Summer Wine and Goodfellas.
A sequel that actually manages to improve on the original and establishes Gru & co as richly-detailed personalities who can be trusted to carry the franchise on.
For those who witnessed Jesse and Celine's tentative getting together as inter railing students almost twenty years ago, it's reassuring to see them still in love.
Ultimately, it's a competent, if uninspired, chronicle of an intriguing community hamstrung by that worthily reverential approach that afflicts British film-makers.
Unfashionably un-cynical, it's a labour of familial love from first-time writer-director Josh Boone whose simple style well serves a story of sweetness and wit.
Although always watchable, there's a dynamism missing, handicapped in no small measure by a dialled down performance from Tautou, who is far too old for the role of a young free spirit.
Ultimately, it's a workmanlike sci-fi thriller that never really manages to erase the stain of Hollywood nepotism.
Time to Wolfpack it in.
Ultimately, it's far from a literary adaptation...but as a movie it makes you want to join the party.
It's pure formula...but will give Fast and Furious fans something to drool over until the next F&F instalment comes skidding around the corner.

Eschewing hard boiled action for an authentically gritty approach, director Tobias Lindholm creates a fuggy atmosphere of claustrophobic dread aboard the ship juxtaposed with the airy hi-tech steel and glass HQ of the shipping line.

This richly rewarding work lightly wears influences as disparate as Huckleberry Finn and The Hustler but ultimately emerges as the unmistakeable work of Nichols, one of the rare breed of genuinely exciting directors working in Hollywood today.
Ultimately, it's a blockbuster that pretty much follows the story-telling arc of its compadres in the superhero world...yet Star Trek's not just living well. It's prospering.
It's a well-worn formula - a gang of youngsters have to form a dance troupe to put on a show that will save their local youth club - but what it lacks in budget it makes up for in bravado.
A disappointingly by-the-numbers revenge yarn unspieled at great length ...
Simply put, with friends like these, who needs enemas?
All in all, it's an enjoyable third instalment that keeps the Marvel juggernaut on the road...and also underlines who's the real (metal) star.
Benissimo.
A compelling glimpse into a world of corporate chicanery where unscrupulous business giants casually toss decent chaps like Butler into the fray to take the, er, frack.
Light years ahead of the half-cocked horror coming out of Hollywood, the mounting dread provides the requisite amount of chair-jolting shocks.
A gung-ho flag waver that would give even the most ardent American neocon repetitive strain injury.
Cast yourself into oblivion.
Richly detailed and labyrinthinely plotted, the switchback narrative is populated with carefully delineated characters without recourse to cumbersome exposition.
This is a flaccid affair ...
It's not afraid to deal with darker issues - that childhood isn't forever - and Adams plays it just the right side of mawkish while Hedges makes sure it's anything but a smooth ride.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The last reel appears compromised by Hollywood's generic demands..but what has gone before is a refreshing lesson in how to make a thriller that's genuinely thrilling on a human scale.
If you can ignore the eulogising of Google as a pinnacle of corporate altruism, there's fun to be had ...
A refreshing departure from the current glut of slasher movies that make the mistake of thinking more gore can ever replace the feeling of icy dread that you've been played by a madman.
'Bula' is apparently the Fijian for hello...but after 90 minutes of this you'll be desperate to know what goodbye is.
A glossily superficial yarn that elicits a shrug and a resigned 'meh' rather than awed incredulity.
As usual, Emmerich doesn't know when the shameless, popcorn extravaganza should stop...but you don't really want him to.
An accomplished follow-up that doesn't feel like some lazy studio financier-instigated cash-in.
It's a striking debut...and one which marks the arrival of a major talent.

Peter Morgan's script, an object lesson in soberly effective economic writing, lends what could become two rigid stereotypes a pulsing emotional dynamic that Hemsworth and Bruhl flesh out to keenly dramatic effect.
The superb Servillo - who, when he doesn't have the look of Dennis Norden, is the spit of a lusty Sid James - is the perfect match for Sorrentino's wry vision ...
[A] gut-wrenchingly gory horror yarn from Asian director Ryûhei Kitamura.
Director Jeanie Finlay's entertaining documentary begins as a bit of a light-hearted wheeze but then grows darker ...

Labelling a Michael Bay movie thoughtful is like calling Transformers cerebral...but this is a lot more stimulating than we've come to expect even if reverts to shoot 'em up type by the end of its pumped up running time.
It's a tense, taut thriller that only eases off the tension in the final reel.
Wingard amusingly blends a vicious household dynamic - grim sibling rivalry in train with neurotic parents - with a straight-down-the-line home invasion thriller feeding off family hatred.
Seyfried is a revelation as the blithely trusting Linda, initially under the sleazy spell of Chuck and latterly terrified of his physical and mental abuse.
It's a decent enough watch and you can't fail to warm to the band for their honest relish of a success that didn't seem likely when they rolled in third on the X-Factor.
It's Miller time.
You won't die laughing...but it's a pleasant enough diversion.
It's by no means a bad film...but there's not a trace of Del Toro's compellingly off-kilter dabs on it.
In a disappointing season of bloated blockbusters, Elysium stands tall, a first-rate sci-fi thriller given extra heft by a heartening moral core.
A supremely entertaining adventure that might threaten to fall over a couple of times but always regains its balance.
Espinosa raises the emotional ante by placing this trio of misfits in a human context.
A lean and mean horror set in a shattered city that is both all-to-recognisable as broken Britain while also feeling totally alien.
It's a strikingly authentic chronicle of forbidden love and one that never lapses into melodrama or hits a false note.
Smurf-ophiles will love it but the unconverted still won't be feeling the blues.

Less an ensemble variation of Bourne and more Carry on Killing, there's much to enjoy in a sequel that finds laughs in the blase attitude of its anti-heroes to the grim business of inconsequential death.
Fans will spend their happiest 90 minutes this summer...and those yet to fall under his spell will get a crash course in 22-carat hilarity.
After a dispiriting run of dumbly routine thrillers - Stolen, Trespass, Justice - Nicolas Cage raises his game with this workmanlike police procedural.
Ultimately, in the film, Carter delivers the goods to die-hard fans.
It's a fascinating behind-the-scenes look at politics - as long as you're a Democrat.
Quote not available.
Only a writer as talented as Mikal Gilmore could tell a story that punches you in the gut about every five seconds and yet leaves you hoping for more.
It's [Johnson's] first film (it shows), but he strikes gold by getting the kind of access to his peers no one else could.
It's impossible to overstate the excellent casting here.
A movie that feels like a documentary at times, a cheesy docudrama at others and some kind of slapped-together film that wants to be taken seriously as well.
movie_title: Seal Team 6: The Raid on Osama Bin Laden (2012)

movie_review_blurb: 84 minutes of rolling musical back beat and supercharged cartoon warfare. It's also, clearly, great fun.
Not particularly scary, not particularly funny, this little-pilot-lost doesn't quite get there, despite an impressive pedigree.
Credit the Science Channel with figuring out that this story had the kind of smarts and scientific elements at its core to be a great fit and perfect fodder for its foray into scripted material.
The Normal Heart manages to work both sides of the issue - the anger at inaction and those complicit in turning a blind eye, and the personal toll the disease took.
The Christmas miracle of this movie is that Grumpy Cat's Worst Christmas Ever isn't the worst Christmas movie ever.
It was a night where Williams and Walken, at disparate ends of the live performance, gave a lot to their roles and to the success of the night.
It's delightful and winning, both sad and funny and touching on so many levels. Welcome this little gem into your arms if you can.

Let's just say that Agatha Christie's The Witness for the Prosecution isn't like anything you'd expect as it adds a layer of psychological hopelessness to the whodunit -- nor is it anything you should miss.
Mamet will succeed in planting doubt (reasonable or not) in viewers' minds in this account of the murder trial of the larger-than-life Spector, brilliantly embodied by Pacino.
This sequel ends up feeling a bit like cinematic road kill, neither exciting nor comic enough to get anyone's motor running.
Paul Rudd and Jennifer Aniston are fitfully funny, but this R-rated comedy badly miscalculates exactly how hilarious nudists, hallucinogens and free love really are.
Diverting but disposable, this overheated, underdeveloped mystery-thriller goes through its paces without generating much tension or suspense.
Though ambitiously mounted and sporadically enthralling, the live-action debut of Pixar filmmaker Andrew Stanton is a sci-fi spectacle that's just not very spectacular.
Despite a few flashes of inspired brilliance, this goofy curio just isn't consistently funny, opting instead to coast on the novelty of its premise.
The Hunger Games certainly doesn't lack for ambition, and although it's mostly successful, one can't help wishing the film could have better integrated its different tones and agendas.
Treat it like a wobbly, precocious demo from a 24-year-old with mighty aspirations, filled with hints of what he would become, and you'll be properly enthralled.
A romantic comedy that represents a clash between a very likeable cast and a rather unappealing storyline.
Big dumb fun is the chief objective of Lockout, so it's a pity that this sci-fi action flick only consistently delivers on two-thirds of its promise.
The Vow flirts with several interesting themes, but too easily this romantic drama sticks to a formulaic narrative that loudly preaches love conquers all.
A very entertaining, very intelligent dissection of horror movie cliches.
You'll laugh intermittently, but more often, you'll notice where you're supposed to be laughing and aren't.
None of these people resembles any teen anybody really knows. And thank god for that.
Proudly, gleefully stupid, The Three Stooges may not be witty or subtle, but it's pretty darn funny.
This uber-stylish treat may have low nutritional content, but the kinetic hand-to-hand combat fight scenes and Soderbergh's lethal skill are simply seductive.
This thriller isn't an outright embarrassment, but it nonetheless suffers from wobbly dramatic tension and an overlong running time.
A modest but emotionally potent study of addiction and recovery.
Despite those reservations, the film ends up generating a tremendous amount of charm and good cheer once it gets over its own supposed shock value.

It's hardly a devastating insight to note that brilliant artists don't always make the best husbands or fathers, but director Rachel Leah Jones's Gypsy Davy takes that truism and wrings something thought-provoking and melancholy from it.
Psychologically astute and brilliantly executed, "Compliance" is a challenging film that cuts to the heart of difficult ethical questions about the nature of power.
For the first several reels, The Muppets is nearly perfect with its winningly dopey musical numbers and joyful humor.
Spreading tidings of good cheer -- along with the occasional joke about coked-up toddlers -- this 3D sequel is a manic, uneven comedy that just barely hits more than it misses.
This is a party you can't wait to be over.
Fueled by Tom Cruise's propulsive, sometimes literally death-defying performance, this fourth installment is arguably the strongest of the series.
Monstrously skillful and powerfully engrossing. This is a taut thriller that sadly overstays its welcome with an extended finale that isn't nearly as satisfying.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film will mostly appeal to the youngest of viewers, who probably instead should be reading a book or playing in the fresh air.
Human suffering reduced to visual showmanship.
Doesn't even have the pulse-pounding excitement of a second-tier Scooby-Doo mystery.
Takes two steadfast horror tropes - demonic possession and the gimmick of "found footage" - and does very, very little new with them.
A passion project from executive producer George Lucas that's curiously lacking in passion.
Doesn't lack for furrowed-brow seriousness, but ultimately the depths being explored aren't nearly as incisive or startling as its makers think.
A well-meaning but muddled drama.
The blood flows, the decapitated heads roll and the muscles glisten. Unfortunately, Tarsem doesn't seem as interested in the souls within those bodies.
Works perfectly fine as a traditional fight-for-survival chiller, but the underlying gender issues give this would-be midnight-movie offering an extra jolt.
A coming-of-age comedy/drama that unfortunately doesn't have much new to say on the topic of coming of age.
The film's slow, relentless emotional manipulation eventually becomes insufferable to anyone who hasn't already bought into Nicholas Sparks' soapy formula.
Despite a few alterations to the well-worn found-footage format, there's a visible sense of strain as the filmmakers struggle to top themselves.
Like too many of Jason Statham's recent star vehicles, "Safe" is an adequate solo act in need of better accompaniment.
Like the film, Jordin Sparks is decidedly too wholesome and earnest to leave much of an impression.
If "Hit and Run" ultimately proves too slapdash to recommend, it does provide Dax Shepard with a fine platform for his likeably nonchalant sensibility.
Director Ole Bornedal deserves some credit for his restraint and tonal control, but there's only so much he can do for this latest twist on the moldy exorcism drama.
A clever entertainment that segues from thriller to drama to romance without breaking a sweat or offering much depth.
"Keep the Lights On" is both warm and a bit inscrutable. It feels like the work of a man who's in a better place but still sifting through past heartache.

This character drama succeeds largely thanks to Gyllenhaal and Pena's camaraderie as partners who are able to mock each other's cultural differences but still be as close as brothers.
The film is diverting fun in fits and starts but can't quite achieve a coherent whole.
A movie about family and baseball that throws every pitch right down the middle, "Trouble With the Curve" is a gentle but rather obvious drama.
A character-driven drama with the soul of an existential thriller that asks more questions than it answers about the nature of identity and the possibility of second chances.
While Tyler Perry no doubt envisions "Alex Cross" as his opportunity to branch out, the actors around him rightly regard this pedestrian effort as just another gig.
The inventiveness and exuberance of "Holy Motors" is immensely enjoyable, and yet there's something truly, weirdly heartbreaking at this film's core.
Kevin Spacey gives a typically soulful performance, but otherwise the film falls far short of being as inventive or confident as its main character.
An absorbing, intelligent character study anchored by one of Denzel Washington's most layered performances.
The title is a play on those Lonely Planet travel guides, but it's also a fair description of the desolate space in which each of the movie's three characters resides.
"The Expendables 2" is imposingly violent, dramatically clunky, and more than a bit cynically conceived -- and, despite all of that, it's also shamelessly entertaining.
That a Hollywood summer comedy starring two 60-year-olds is the year's most daring sex film is astounding. And also kind of sad.
Wiseman shows more care in laying out his bleak future society and action set pieces than trying to unearth the existential anxiety that his film's storyline provokes.
Graceful in their movements, wooden in their emoting, the film's stars dance with such propulsive confidence that one is almost willing to forgive the story's many cliches.
A smart, incisive examination of how every love affair eventually comes with strings attached.
Though sporting director Tim Burton's usual visual flair, the film nonetheless suffers from the same lack of narrative focus that has haunted his other recent offerings.
It's a pleasant surprise that Under African Skies not only draws attention to the controversy surrounding its subject matter but digs into it a little.
The film is consistently amusing, if never quite shocking or hilarious.
The enchanting sweetness of "Fantastic Mr. Fox" has been transplanted into "Moonrise Kingdom," a delicate period love story whose slightness is mitigated by its deep feeling.
Most summer blockbusters are lumbering, exhausting exercises in endless payload delivery. "Battleship" is that rare $200 million movie with a twinkle in its eye.
The so-so "Chernobyl Diaries" feels like the sort of horror movie that "Paranormal Activity" was meant to replace.
Though overlong and inevitably burdened by the need to juggle so many protagonists, the film is robustly entertaining and manages to maintain a playful, crowd-pleasing spirit.
This lively but decidedly overlong film showers the audience with kitsch at the expense of characters.
Historical accuracy and narrative subtlety be damned, this agreeably ludicrous action-horror film starts off over-the-top and simply proceeds from there.
A film about the importance of putting away childish things, "Ted" is itself an immature comedy that boasts a clever premise but a rather sour spirit.
Anchored by Andrew Garfield's heartfelt performance as the lovably nerdy Peter Parker, this "Spider-Man" may not be amazing, but it's certainly good enough.
It's hard to think of a movie in which Steven Soderbergh has loved his characters as much as he does in "Magic Mike." The affection is contagious.
This ambitious, unwieldy, operatic film sure isn't boring but also, sadly, isn't very good.

You get the sense that the Duplass brothers know in their hearts that their characters are hopelessly immature. But you also get the sense that the filmmakers understand their characters in a way that probably makes even them uncomfortable.
The film suffers a bit from a glut of new characters but is helped along by Nolan's continued insistence on emotional resonance over mindless spectacle.
Whether it's Rebecca Hall's unconvincing performance as a ditzy Florida gal or the story's meandering tone, "Lay the Favorite" is one gamble that doesn't pay off.
Proves to be every bit as effective as the previous installments, providing a consistent level of tension that's aided by some solid performances and a few fresh surprises.
Louis may superficially resemble movies of a bygone age, but it lacks their essence: masterful effortlessness.
Despite starting off as an intelligent, realistic treatment of the traditional haunted-house thriller, the movie gets progressively more ludicrous as it goes along.
The filmmakers adroitly sidestep the cliches of the insane-asylum genre. However, the determinedly low-key style requires a patience that isn’t always rewarded.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Ten years after debuting their hopelessly juvenile reality stunt show on MTV, the people behind Jackass still haven't grown up at all -- and thank god for that.
Looking to dramatize the daily hardships of African-American women by focusing on nine diverse black females living in Harlem, this melodrama drowns in soap-opera theatrics.
The sequel repeats the original's formula, but its improved acting and plotting help counteract the lack of conceptual freshness that's inevitable with a second go-round.
The adventurous will be treated to a film that builds to a beautifully calibrated emotional climax.
Aspires to be a lightweight pleasure but only sporadically possesses the necessary charm or magic.
Two acts of muddled character study and a final act that's a taut, extended cat-and-mouse chase: This is what awaits viewers in The Next Three Days.
Campy, sexy and shameless in all the ways one would hope, Burlesque demands viewers acquiesce to its frothy, strutting tone, and those who do are in for a hoot.
Trying to marry a stylish B-movie revenge actioner to a more thoughtful exploration of forgiveness and guilt, Faster ends up a well-intentioned muddle.
A fun, thimble-deep, romantic thriller with big stars and not an ounce of nutritional content.
Genial but instantly forgettable, Yogi Bear takes the beloved Hanna-Barbera character and shoehorns him into an all-too-familiar kids' movie.
Brutally unfunny, Little Fockers is one more go-round of cheap physical comedy and wan dysfunctional-family gags.
A country music drama with a big heart but not enough focus, Country Strong tackles fame, artistic expression, addiction and love, although none of them deeply enough.
A mediocre knights-and-witchcraft B-movie that's somewhat cheesy, somewhat intriguing, and ultimately just not all that involving.
A superhero movie with the soul of a bromance, The Green Hornet is consistently mildly amusing but never quite as fun as it should be.
Thick with moral ambiguity, Stone proves to be a character drama that confuses heavy brow-furrowing for an insightful dissection of several ethically slippery individuals.
Despite the stars' warm chemistry, Life As We Know It is an involving but ultimately mediocre mixture of domestic melodrama and opposites-attract romantic comedy.
Sassy but also sincere, Easy A is an immensely likeable high-school comedy powered by an appealing lead performance from up-and-coming actress Emma Stone.
This potentially thoughtful, poignant relationship film quickly loses its nerve.
The film's visual and structural boldness only underlines the story's predictable trajectory and muddy characterizations.
Despite a heartfelt approach and some capable performances, Night Catches Us is a collection of thoughtful ideas in search of a screenplay.

An homage to old-school kung fu movies that ends up being more fun in theory than it is on the screen, "The Man With the Iron Fists" boasts some giddy, bloody action sequences and a whole lot of dull genre cliches the rest of the time.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This live-action adaptation of an animated children's fantasy series is a leaden, joyless ride that represents another major misfire from the once-promising filmmaker.
So if delicious nastiness isn't Despicable Me's thing, what is? Rampant, merciless cuteness.
Great Directors doesn't tell you a lot about its great directors, but as a roadmap on how to live artfully, it's rather inspiring.
The effects are spellbinding in The Sorcerer's Apprentice, but otherwise this Nicolas Cage fantasy film isn't particularly magical.
Touching on taboo themes like rape, incest, and kinky bedroom exploits, Burning is a series of five Los Angeles-set short films that are only superficially provocative.
Inception is an extraordinarily ambitious work. It's a bit overlong at 148 minutes, but I couldn't tell you what I would have cut out of it.
At a time when most advocacy documentaries aim for righteous fury, Tomoko Kana's Beautiful Islands is so gentle that it's practically radical by comparison.
A fizzy blast that may not offer many lasting rewards but certainly generates an impressive headlong rush along the way.
Lightly amusing but doggone derivative, the film bombards the audience with jokes, action and effects to produce an overstuffed experience that rarely enchants.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's fast-paced and engaging, and at 91 minutes it doesn't overstay its welcome. But director Lucy Walker follows the documentary formula with too much maniacal fidelity.
A sincere but gamey mixture of cornball sentimentality and faux-period (not to mention faux-regional) detail.
This likeable romp through cop-movie conventions is sporadically funny, although director Adam McKay hasn't fully capitalized on a fertile comedic conceit.
Leaning very heavily on style and attitude, the film won't win a single point for originality, but director John Luessenhop keeps the action rolling along at a steady clip.
Director Phillip Noyce's return to major-studio filmmaking maintains a workmanlike competence throughout but lacks inspired chase sequences or diabolical smarts.
Overlong yet quite affecting in parts, The Rum Diary ends up an arresting snapshot of Puerto Rico in 1960, even if its story is only sporadically compelling.
Despite the dependably uber-cool presence of Jason Statham, The Mechanic doesn't wield enough inventiveness or attitude to fix its overriding sense of familiarity.
This Mandarin-language remake of the 2000 Mel Gibson blockbuster rarely rises above a genial likability, lacking sufficient comic or romantic brio.
Amusing and appealing, but only rarely cuts deep enough in its examination of a kindly small-town Texan who murdered the elderly widow he took care of.
A few minor adjustments notwithstanding, Transformers: Dark Of The Moon is very much the same bucket of bolts that audiences have come to expect from this franchise from its first two instalments.
Suffused with feeling but dramatically wobbly, this modest character piece's embrace of life's emotional messiness ends up hurting more than helping the proceedings.
Kevin James' average-Joe appeal doesn't go very far in a film that's noticeably low on charm or playfulness.
Captain America has a decent amount of heart and retro appeal, although neither can compensate for what is otherwise a rather ordinary comic book film.
A comedy-drama that pretends to be a honest look at relationships when it's really just burdened with simplistic characters and sitcom set-ups.
The Smurfs contains such moments of sweetness and heart that it's all the more unfortunate that it's otherwise a numbingly ordinary kids' film.
Blessed with a wealth of verite intimacy, this is an affecting and sobering portrait of America's crumbling lower class.
Despite its title, The Change-Up does precious little to switch up the formula for the R-rated studio comedy.
A taut, emotionally satisfying origin story that may not be as action-packed as its fellow summer tentpoles but is far more rewarding.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A sports film whose promise of a more nuanced take on familiar genre tropes ends up battered and bruised.
Audiences hoping for something in the vein of Paranormal Activity won't be disappointed, although the film can be faulted for sticking too close to a familiar formula.
Snakes On A Plane at least displayed a commitment to its magnificent ridiculousness. By comparison, Shark Night 3D just gives dumb movies a bad name.
You can't escape the impression that the actual events the movie dramatises are far more compelling than what's on the screen.
Nature lovers and animal activists will find much that speaks to them in this slender, resonant tale.
Despite a winning aw-shucks performance from Ryan Reynolds, the film can't overcome its thinly drawn characters and generally hokey execution.
While other filmmakers have been inspired by Spielberg to push the envelope, J.J. Abrams seems happy to try to make one like they used to, except not as successfully.
Substituting action for charm, the sequel is a visual treat but not a sufficient comedic or narrative one, taking only modest advantage of Jack Black's game voice work.
A new director and some key cast changes do little to right the ship for the oversized fourth installment in this decreasingly entertaining franchise.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, this year's nonfiction crop largely underlines the limitations of movies with big subjects but compact running times.
The live-action entries are a more diverse mix.

Writer-directors Andrew Ruhemann and Shaun Tan elevate a familiar storyline into something exceptionally moving that touches on friendship, loneliness, and the tragedy of how getting older numbs us to the wonders of the small oddities around us.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films: Animation (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Its insistence on furthering the Bieber brand makes the movie feel more like a well-honed presidential campaign than an insightful look into the teen sensation.
Trite and formulaic, Beastly is an inoffensive snooze.
Mars Needs Moms is so rambunctious that it snuffs out much of the story's potential charm and pathos.
A good-old-fashioned courtroom thriller, The Lincoln Lawyer offers modest but sturdy pleasures, chief among them a strong cast and a page-turner of a story.
This romantic comedy suffers from a pervasive sitcom-level sense of humor and spotty performances.
The bunny's cute, but the story's mangy in Hop, a forgettable family film that may play well to young tykes but won't hold the interest of parents or older siblings.
Despite a sympathetic performance from Sex and the City star Kim Cattrall, there simply isn't much life or surprise in this tepid indie.
Although unquestionably indebted to its influences, writer-director Max Winkler's feature comedy debut has more than enough heart to overcome its familiar ingredients.
A screwball comedy without nearly enough zest or wit.
A treatise on personal survival and new beginnings that is eloquently delivered by star Kristin Scott Thomas.
Despite its ambitious tonal sweep, The Beaver ends up feeling like pieces of a lot of different films, making it a movie that's more interesting than it is great.
Despite a large, lively cast, director Salim Akil's comedy-drama doesn't have anything new to say about love, family, or race.
The film longs to be a hip skewering of noir and monster movies but instead is kneecapped by mediocre effects, indifferent performances and a generally dull design.
The script's relentlessly puerile humour eventually begins to feel monotonous.
A stirring portrait of Abraham Lincoln but, perhaps more importantly, a quietly compelling look into the nitty-gritty process of democratic government.
It's one thing that Grown Ups 2 is unfunny -- what's really galling is that Sandler and his cohorts can barely come up with a good reason for its very existence.
Bigelow's commitment to a dispassionate, stripped-down approach results in a film whose impact sneaks up on you, leaving you blindsided by its visceral final reels.
Tore Tanzt is a hard movie to watch on occasion, but it's powered by some fundamental questions.
How To Make Money Selling Drugs turns out to be a far more sobering and substantial piece of work than one might expect.
movie_title: How To Make Money Selling Drugs (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The sobering "Dirty Wars" speaks directly to Americans who believe that their country's behavior overseas has improved appreciably since the election of President Obama.
A dark allegory that never justifies its central conceit, dooming all that follows.
Where "Wedding Crashers" was naughty yet sweet, "Internship" is pseudo-edgy and safe. It's like watching two aging frat brothers convince themselves they haven't lost a step.
"Twenty Feet From Stardom" may follow the template of so many rock documentaries before it, but the movie's breezy execution makes the familiarity go down smoothly.
The film doesn't lack for spectacle, but after a while its emphasis on grand gestures and unwavering gravitas stops feeling heroic and begins to seem like overkill.
For an anarchic, R-rated comedy, "This Is the End" exudes a kindness and generosity that's quite touching.
Much like this film's main character, you can't quite explain what's got you so afraid -- you just know that you are.
Pixar once trained us to expect a little magic. Nowadays, we're just grateful when one of their films is good enough.
Rattling the nerves while drawing out its palpable sense of dread, "The Conjuring" is a proudly old-fashioned horror movie that tells its story with sophistication and care.
Draws much of its modest power from the notion that other people's romantic relationships are even more baffling than our own.
Channing Tatum has the right earnest-but-silly attitude for this latest Roland Emmerich disaster blitzkrieg, but the movie lets him down.
Jason Statham clearly doesn't just want to be a guy who cracks skulls, but his restrained, grizzled performance isn't enough on its own to justify this moody misfire.
Unfortunately, beyond the gender shift, The Heat's principal characters aren't particularly funny creations.
The stakes may not be particularly high in Only Lovers Left Alive, but that's part of Jarmusch's point.
The film has plenty of combustion, but it's almost entirely devoid of charm or genuine excitement.
Even if the plotting is a trifle trite, that doesn't mean that Haroun can't find ways to surprise.

The critical consensus from Cannes about Nebraska is that it's "minor Payne." I think it might be more accurate to call it a transitional film, with one foot in his old techniques and one tentatively standing in new ones.
There's plenty of ravishing cinema in Only God Forgives, but almost nothing of real life.
What makes Sarah Prefers to Run so touching is that we're not quite sure what the resolution will be for Sarah. She isn't, either. But she just keeps running.
movie_title: Sarah préfère la course (Sarah Would Rather Run) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Don't be afraid of the darkness: [Claire] Denis makes it seductive.
It's a stunning commentary on why our collective belief in might makes right continues to prevail.
While a clinical approach doesn't disqualify a movie from being riveting, the straightforward, unflashy style can sometimes be draggy rather than revelatory or engrossing.
Like Father, Like Son... may be utterly conventional in some ways, but its surging emotional power eventually proves too overwhelming to deny.
It elevates what could be just another ballad-of-a-hooker drama into something far more mysterious.

The Past has all the strengths of a good play-incisive dialogue, effortlessly natural performances, close-quarters intimacy, and a rich sense of themes and intent-so it's little wonder that Farhadi's background is that of a playwright.
It's an intriguing notion, but one wishes Coppola wouldn't pound on this single point for her movie's entire running time.
Unfortunately, this playful yet serious and occasionally quite moving drama bites off far more than it can chew.
For all the horrors Heli reveals about modern-day Mexico, it's stubbornly lacking in insight about the characters that live there.
A trite sci-fi adventure that's probably too intense for younger viewers and not sophisticated enough for adults.
"The Kings of Summer" boasts some of the deadpan melancholy one associates with Wes Anderson's best work, but it doesn't have quite the same bite or insight.
Sexual desire, jet-black comedy, kinky mischievousness, an air of tense claustrophobia: It's all there in Venus in Fur, and even if the movie isn't particularly deep, it's a constant playful delight.
A beautiful, wise, erotic, devastating love story.
Such a beautiful movie -- and so cold, too.
Considering the star-crossed band it documents, there should be no surprise that "Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me" has a melancholy tinge to it.
movie_title: Big Star: Nothing Can Hurt Me (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Immensely likable but a little too tidy in its emotional payoff, the movie benefits from its charming, empathetic ensemble.
A dopey, earnest and occasionally visionary sci-fi action film that keeps being dragged down by its drab characters and indifferent performances.
Genre movies often get described as disposable, but something as paper-thin as "Paranoia" isn't even sturdy enough to warrant such a dismissive description.
"Jobs" gets tripped up by the same old biopic problems: it's too much of a greatest-hits overview, not enough of an incisive dive into its subject.
"Drinking Buddies" ultimately may not be that revelatory in its depiction of love and commitment, but it observes its characters with a lot of compassion.
Like many reunions, "The World's End" is based on memories of past glories, when all of this seemed a little more fresh. Still, it's nice to see the old gang back together.
A run-of-the-mill thriller elevated just enough by the intelligence of its cast and makers.
"Getaway" has but one task -- deliver nonstop primo car chases -- and it can't even do that right.
Proves both melodramatic and undernourished, although this ensemble piece is grimly compelling throughout.
This nonjudgmental, opaque drama conjures up the emotional landscape of its troubled titular character but intentionally provides little insight into her thought process.

The character work seems perfunctory, whether it's the mediocre exploration of Assange and Domscheit-Berg's dynamic or the shallow investigation into Assange's past to hint at what drew him to be so antiauthoritarian.
An intriguing genre experiment, "Sapi" conjures up plenty of unease but doesn't have much in the way of story or character to drive its message home.
A mature and assured examination of an unusual but highly functional family unit.
