As is Linklater's custom, Boyhood is profound in such a casual way that its weighty themes feel nonchalant, effortless. This movie might make you cry for reasons you can't quite articulate. You won't be alone in feeling that way.

The film's confident tonal control is a compliment to Corbijn's skill, but it's also recognition of Philip Seymour Hoffman's wonderfully controlled central performance. You don't realize how stunning the whole experience really was until it's over.
A sensuous, ravishing collection of images that occasionally give way to murky plotting and dull characters, "Blackhat" is a minor (but palpably hypnotic) film from a major American action auteur.
Ultimately Wild Card isn't sharp enough to execute its modest ambitions, leaving one with the impression that a lot of stylishness has been flaunted without much to show for it.
Strange Magic is rambunctious without being lively -- and "magical" without being very magical.
A well-meaning disappointment, striving to say something about family and motherhood but mishandling the execution.
The film's thematic shortcomings ultimately don't matter too much: When you're too busy being enraptured by The Witch's dark elegance, nitpicking doesn't really enter into the equation.
Boasts a strong cast but not enough focus.

Featuring minimalist, expressive turns from its only three actors - Chiwetel Ejiofor, Margot Robbie and Chris Pine - this quiet but evocative drama has a slow-burn effect, leaving a tart aftertaste that's hard to wash away.
A thoroughly delightful bauble about female friendship and the double-edged sword of getting to know someone who seems far cooler than you.
Ewan McGregor's dual performance as Jesus and his demonic tormenter ensures that Last Days In The Desert never loses track of its grace and humility.
"True Story" doesn't seem to fully capture what's fascinating about the material.

Dope doesn't seem like it has much discipline or focus, but its frantic forward momentum and haphazard mixture of styles, although demonstratively entertaining, shouldn't distract from a rather pointed political message about race in America.
"Selma" wisely sidesteps predictable inspirational-movie cliches: Deep down, this film knows that the more things change, the more they stay the same. And there is still much work to be done.
This is a stunning encapsulation of a life, effortlessly hitting upon universal themes of creativity, mortality, love and our lasting worth on a planet that will keep spinning long after we're gone.
Though always meant to be a fairy tale, this new "Annie" comes across as especially materialistic and shallow, an endless parade of high-priced trinkets and fancy clothes.
"Inherent Vice" isn't quite a magnificent as "There Will Be Blood" or "The Master." But that just means you'll only want to rewatch it several times, as opposed to dozens.
"The Better Angels" is a striking attempt to show us Lincoln's childhood in a fresh way, which is why its miscalculation is all the more disappointing.
What begins as a compassionate look at a woman balancing career and motherhood soon evolves into something far more nuanced, thoughtful and troubling.
With his third feature, writer-director J.C. Chandor continues to cement a reputation for making distinctive, intelligent films of which no two are alike.
"Big Hero 6" does everything you'd expect from an animated adventure designed for families: It's big and funny and friendly and cute and exciting, and at the end it makes you cry.
Tone trumps all in The Gambler, an exercise in studied cool that's commendably idiosyncratic, although ultimately not to any great effect.
"American Sniper" doesn't break much new ground when depicting the chaos of combat, but it's more astute in examining the mind-set of those who willingly put their lives on the line for others.

This film is too subtle-and, frankly, too strange-to explicitly make some simple, overarching, grandiose statement. And yet, it gets at the complicated, unresolved nature of American life almost subliminally.
A modest but probing character piece that's rich in the secret language that all long-term couples speak.
Dumb is perfectly acceptable - uninspired is another matter entirely.
Though tonally inconsistent, "The Homesman" is one curious, ornery creature. The strangeness Tommy Lee Jones brought to "Three Burials" lingers here in the margins.
Stepping away from the worlds of fantasy, horror and science fiction for the first time in 20 years, director Tim Burton delivers one of his most thoughtful and accomplished works in far too long.
This is the way modern-day blockbuster franchises are designed: You watch the new film so that you know what's going on in preparation for the next one
"A Girl Walks" suggest a filmmaker who knows how to let her strengths compensate for her shortcomings. Think what might happen if the shortcomings get addressed.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Mistaking massive amounts of CGI and epically dour performances for historical gravitas, "Exodus" wants to tell the story of Moses with the scope of a blockbuster but the soul of a gritty character drama.
The final chapter proves to be very much of a piece with the trilogy's first two installments: It's robustly entertaining, occasionally affecting, sometimes thrilling, not exactly groundbreaking.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Rock has said that he worked on the screenplay during his downtime while co-starring in "Grown Ups 2." If that's the case, then we finally have a reason to be grateful for that atrocious Adam Sandler debacle.
Well-made and entertaining, "Red Army" is also slick and too superficially diverting to linger in one's memory.
This comedy-drama never puts a foot wrong. And yet, its stakes are so low, its setup so familiar, that the film's generally effortless flow starts to become a hindrance.
This bittersweet film miscalculates how much comic mileage can be accrued by following two older men as they traipse though nature bonding and grousing.

Me And Earl And The Dying Girl travels into familiar dramatic terrain - the offbeat coming-of-age story, as well as the terminal-cancer drama - to deliver something that feels handmade and also heartfelt.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Though "Montage of Heck" is undoubtedly geared to fans, it gives them reason to be grateful for this guy and this band all over again.
Fans of Melissa McCarthy can rejoice: With "Spy," the very charming, deeply lovable, potently funny actress finally gets a role worthy of her talent.
The Zellners may have their missteps as storytellers, but without question they're consummate image- and mood-makers.
Despite the film's tightly constructed reserve, Hausner saves one last trick for the end: As unknowable as these characters are, you may be surprised how much you miss them.
The documentary may skimp a little on the man, but his art is proudly front and center -- which, one suspects, is perhaps how he'd prefer it.
"White God" isn't the first film to suggest that humanity's cruel treatment of others will one day come back to haunt us. But it certainly makes its point with potent force.
Little more than a dutifully compiled collection of genre conventions, "Last Knights" is such an undemanding vengeance tale that it's almost charmingly pedestrian.
"Get Hard" wants to be a brash, unapologetic look at race and class but only wrings a few laughs from those topics, mostly spending its time floundering around in a dumb plot.
A drearily sincere movie about faith and tolerance, Little Boy boasts plenty of good intentions but very little else.

The directorial debut of Gren Wells isn't very funny or touching, but what's worse, it can come across as patronizing, treating debilitating conditions as merely grist for offbeat jokes and superficial pathos.
An undistinguished romantic drama that takes few risks and offers wish-fulfilling escapism with bland dutifulness.
"Lost River" is no misunderstood masterpiece, but at its best it makes you hope Gosling takes what works here and develops it into something stronger next time.
Richard Raymond's feature debut never overcomes a sluggish solemnity, the film's political points dulled by performances from Freida Pinto and Reece Ritchie which overvalue glum earnestness.
A consistent charmer, the Indian omnibus Bombay Talkies is vibrant and colourful, that rare portmanteau film where the whole is more than the sum of its likeable parts.
Director Lee Toland Krieger hits all the expected emotional beats but doesn't take many risks or glean sufficient insights about our fascination with the double-edged sword of eternal youth.
Not without its bluntly funny bits, this nasty, programmatic comedy wants to be outlandish but, oddly enough, it's the movie's lack of realism that really hurts it.
If the film's value as an exposé is limited, "Going Clear" is nonetheless sterling as an official record of condemnation.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Run All Night" is the very embodiment of the rental recommendation: If you lower your expectations sufficiently, you'll be fine. But why lower them that much?
Sunshine Superman captures both the awe and terror of the sport [Boenish] loved until the day it brought about his death.
There's something depressingly predictable about Gerry and Curtis, well-meaning gents who can't stop screwing up. If their lives were more original, they wouldn't be in the mess they're in.
Without a doubt, Jupiter Ascending can be powerfully intriguing because it's such an unfiltered, ill-advised misfire, but this long-delayed project is an epic folly that will inspire plenty of snark.

To be sure, this is a rich, multifaceted life, but at just over 100 minutes, Miss Simone? merely scratches the surface, hitting the main talking points without digging deeply enough into any of her different chapters.
McFarland, USA risks nothing and, therefore, ultimately achieves little.
For a film featuring witches, dragons, shape-shifters, cleavage and Jeff Bridges, Seventh Son sure isn't much fun.
Accept this genuinely sexy, somewhat silly, relatively timid romantic drama on its own escapist terms and you'll find sufficient pleasure.
In love with old-school John Carpenter scares, this film will unsettle you from its first moments. Some of its ideas are just as chilling as its shocks.

This umpteenth film about a class reunion cuts a little deeper and gets a little edgier than its peers, finding plenty of humour and a surprising amount of chemistry by pairing Jack Black and James Marsden.
This is world-class action filmmaking at the service of a smug, soulless story.
A stylish, consistently diverting romantic caper that, nonetheless, leaves you feeling that you've been jerked around without sufficient payoff.
Why play down to the basest tenets of a genre when it's clear the filmmaking aspires to something smarter?
Mortality and the possibility of fresh beginnings remain at the forefront of "Second Best," but the novelty of the setup has drifted away.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Chappie is a bucket of bolts, Blomkamp's desire to say meaningful things outdistancing his ability to say them compellingly.
As a dreamy yet concrete evocation of lives beset by unseen anxieties and dwindling resources, Western has a mythic quality in keeping with its totemic title.
A sad case of wasted potential.

The documentary's mixture of speculation and wonder ought to make it a comfy fit for art houses, especially appealing to sci-fi fans who enjoy pondering the big questions of existence that often underpin the genre's best stories.
movie_title: The Visit: An Alien Encounter (The Visit) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "'71" is a claustrophobic experience, as gray and imposing as the film's muted color palette.
An ineffective horror movie that draws most of its minimal shocks from familiar genre conventions that feel even mustier than usual.
This loose, even shallow, structure is a deliberate strategy.
Fantastically incoherent at times, yet it manages to be entertaining and thoroughly unpredictable.
There's an astonishing amount of good, solid acting.
The precision of slow revelation is the focus, and Shimizu makes good use of it to cloak a skinny plot and vague characters in enduring suspense.
A product of precision engineering, a compact model of bare-bones efficiency.
Dispassionate to the point of resembling a kitchen appliance, this meandering dissection of suburban angst answers no questions and offers naught for substance.

What to make of a film that introduces Chloë Sevigny happily beheading chickens with an axe, has her beheaded herself by the killer, then immediately produces a twin sister to deliver a single item of exposition before never being seen again?
The film dares to be ambiguous, but ambiguity is a bad fit with the current critical mood that art must be prescriptive rather than reflective.
Apart from Ben Mendelsohn's weaselly Orson Krennic [and perhaps Donnie Yen]... the faces are unmemorable and the characters unexceptional, their meaningful glances unearned.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Robert Redford's often bloodless, slow-grind direction actually works for him here.
Mandelaís trials and triumphs, personal and political, are more than enough to keep this crowded but never overstuffed biopic clicking.

Dwayne Johnson's Hercules isn't great cinema, but it is rock solid. It is a well-made B-movie that conjures memories of classic adventures like Captain Blood and Spartacus, and more recently the Pirates of the Caribbean films.
Dolphin Tale 2 lacks a bit of the dramatic heft of the first film, but that's a minor complaint given the satisfaction this sequel generates.

Peter Jackson's equally exhilarating and exhausting Hobbit trilogy comes to a rousing, if not totally satisfying, conclusion with The Battle of the Five Armies, a war-ravaged adventure that is by turns breathtaking, beautiful, brutal, and boring.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A slight but immensely charming romantic comedy that is perfectly performed by a regal cast headlined by Maggie Smith, Tom Courtenay, Billy Connolly, and Pauline Collins.
The film, which runs a scant 83 minutes (and that includes the opening and closing credits), feels like it's just getting going when it abruptly ends.
A rousing crowd pleaser about an underdog track team that can proudly takes its place among these other fine sports films.
The prolonged live-action sequence is great fun, but ends too quickly. It seems like a lost opportunity.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Mitchell is much more interested in creating an atmosphere of absolute dread that builds and builds, until your nerves are rattled and shattered. And that uneasy sense of foreboding will linger long after you've exited the theater.
An abysmal would-be comedy that sees the quickly falling star delivering a performance that's as hammy and unfunny as it is dull and embarrassing.
Finally we have a female lead character who is strong without being brutal, appealing without being objectified, and confident without being female-chauvinistic.
IF you're up for some solid intellectual stimulation and don't mind having to work hard for it, this one will really give you something to discuss with friends afterwards.
So much is conveyed in what isn't said: the half-finished words, the broken syllables, the inarticulate noises, even the silences.
Joss Whedon, with his demonstrated ensemble cast-wrangling expertise, is the only director who could have pulled this off. And he has set a new benchmark in doing so.
More dark comedy than rom-com, perhaps a little too honest, like someone who is telling you something funny but then overshares just a little too much and spoils the moment.
Much like pizza and sex, even when a Tim Burton film isn't great, it's still pretty good, it's never really "bad".
Breaking down some stereotypes and making you think about a common issue in an uncommon way, this is a smart little flick, with some top acting and fine humour to boot.
It's funny enough, even hilarious at times, but is it really being incisive and intelligently manipulative, or is it just ignorant, offensive drivel? I can't tell.
Not bad but not memorable, it seems to only exist as a kind of nostalgic revival piece, a belated attempt to wring one last curtain-call from a long-dead series.
Feels confused, directionless and overstuffed, with an uneven pace and a tone that lurches from dark gothic horror to candy-coloured fairy garden to epic fantasy battle.
A solid performer, keeping its target audience in its sights much more firmly than many of its big studio contemporaries.
Something Webb does very well is to build and capture the emotion of this story, even if his handling of plot and action leave something to be desired.
Hollywood is obsessed with strip-mining old TV shows and movies for remake fodder these days, but 21 Jump Street is an example of how it can be done well.
Let's face it: it's Nazis from the Moon invading Earth in flying saucers, if you're expecting anything other than abject absurdity, you're in the wrong movie.
John Carter is a product of a simpler time, when sense of adventure was paramount, and the film has this in spades.
A movie that needs to be appreciated for its finer aspects and deeper meaning if it is to be appreciated properly, which is noble enough but could feel exclusive to some.
I can see why some might find the film sickly or overly sentimental, even a little forced, but it worked well enough on me to have me wiping away a few tears.
The action is so immersing that I dare you not to cheer for the mighty Atom in the ring as he takes a lickin' and keeps on tickin'.
The Thing definitely owes a lot to John Carpenter's 1982 cult classic but as a whole, it is a pretty darned good little shocker.
Breaking Dawn Part 1 is such a slow-moving, overstuffed chore of a movie, it is barely even worth calling a "bridging film." All you do is wait and wait and wait.
The twists and shocks of this story are delivered with emotional precision, each one landing like a heavy punch to the stomach, making every minute crackle with intensity.
HEY LOOK, IT'S A CELEBRITY CAMEO! HEY LOOK, IT'S A CELEBRITY CAMEO! - See how annoying that is? Adam Sandler doesn't.
Puss in Boots is a highly amusing little diversion that will mesmerise the kids and hopefully give the adults a naughty little cackle as well.
The less said about THAT ending, the better. But as a brief, brutal and nasty vignette showing the naked weirdness of an "authentic" exorcism, it's not sooo bad.
Unapologetically enthusiastic and simple, The Adventures of Tintin is an unpretentious, guilt-free thrill ride that finds strength in its populist, uncomplicated nature.
The intimate symbiosis between the loosely defined concepts of good and evil is a vital element in Batman lore and something that Christopher Nolan understands very well.
This is a thick, heavy, dense movie that will require your full attention and concentration for two hours. Probably best left for the really hardened spy and intrigue fans.
It is fun in the middle but it is bookended by a tediously slow first act and an asthmatic wheeze of an ending.
Director Josh Trank does an impressive job of capturing the elation of three young men in the ecstatic throes of discovering they literally can do just about anything.
While the film does have its flaws story-wise, the killer dialogue with its uniquely Australian style of wit makes it a true joy to watch.
Imagine the Dude from The Big Lebowski if he had been raised on a dude ranch.
The broader strokes of Moriarty's plan become evident a little too easily, dropping like a grand piano rather than a penny. But the finer machinations make the story a delight.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Come for the half-naked hunky guys, stay for the expertly crafted story and gorgeous direction. No, I said "direction", now get your mind out of the gutter.
The film is never flippant, never disrespectful and always approaches Mark's hobby with eyes wide open and no agenda other than fascinated admiration.
An Aussie film with real mainstream chops, not a film you watch out of patriotic obligation, but one you watch simply because it is a top-quality, enjoyable and affecting flick.
What better analogy for our place in the universe than a couple of scared creatures stranded on a precarious liferaft in the middle of a vast nothingness?
Hitchcock's playful yet slightly dark tone makes it an easy film to watch and the insight into Hitch the man will be a hoot for any fan of his work.
There is no Team America-style, flag-waving bravado behind this story - it is quite the opposite.
A remarkable performance by Daniel Day-Lewis is the glue that holds Lincoln together. Without him, this would be a very unremarkable film.
Between the screenplay by playwright Tom Stoppard and the direction of Joe Wright, Anna Karenina is a stylistically fascinating film.
While this movie easily has more charm than the cynically produced Twilight films, it somehow lacks the charisma.
THE Hobbit occupies that same awkward spot in popular cinema as the Twilight movies in terms of balancing good cinema against fan-service.
For a long, sprawling, high-concept, philosophical, stylistic mash-up of a film, Cloud Atlas is impressive and thought-provoking without ever being pretentious.
Liking Goddess is easy - this Aussie musical comedy is undeniably charming and its leading lady, Laura Michelle Kelly, is captivating.
Remember those Mr Magoo cartoons where the doddery old bald guy would blunder around various locations, leaving chaos in his wake while constantly insisting "I'm on vacation"?
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Croods is simple enough in its story and structure that its emotional honesty and touching message will catch you quite off-guard.
To call this an unlikely love story is an understatement, but it is precisely this level of weirdness that makes the romance between R and Julia so surprisingly touching.
I recently saw a guy on TV having his scrotum nailed to a table in front of a laughing studio audience ... and Fast & Furious 6 is still the dumbest thing I've ever seen.
Stay home. Paint something. Watch it dry. It'll be more rewarding.
Something that stood out (so to speak) was the sheer amount of cleavage being exhibited by the movie's three witches - I thought Disney had a rule about this kind of thing?
Bekmambetov knows his way around supernatural movies very well but he just doesn't seem to have the sense of humour needed for this one.
Whatever its agenda might (or might not) be, Rise of the Guardians is a surprisingly rousing tale with a story that resonates easily, if not deeply.
Sometimes the old ways are the best. This is a theme and repeated line running throughout the new James Bond film Skyfall and never has it been more true.
It falters a little bit and it's really just an effort to keep a lucrative franchise alive without its iconic star, but it still seems to have plenty of life left in it.
By exposing audiences to the stark realities of bullying, Bully just might encourage people to take it seriously instead of perpetuating the old adage "it's just kids being kids".
At about the two-thirds mark, the film starts to wander off on its own, seemingly without really caring if the audience is following along or not.
The dialogue has moments of blistering wit but even these brief flashes of gold are squandered with lame pay-offs and running gags that are just boringly repetitive.
In terms of writing and direction it has an almost indie-film feel to it, but with that Hollywood gloss to make it palatable to mainstream viewers.
Well-constructed narrative, looping back on itself, spiraling willingly into its own paradoxes and dealing with all the weird overlaps in a way few movies dare to bother with.
The Perks of Being a Wallflower is funny, nostalgic, heartfelt and sweet, and so vivid it will practically make you feel the warm summer wind in your hair.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It had me in its spell from start to finish and I ran the gauntlet of every possible emotion along the way. Outstanding.
Oliver Stone isn't known for making pretty films but ugly is something he does very well.
Argo will make you say "wow" not because of anything big and flashy but purely for its well-told story.
A comedy with an almost cruel level of honesty that explores not just the weird dynamics of long-term friendships but the deeper forces that operate inside each individual.
The First Fagin is a great example of how true stories are often more extraordinary than fiction.
Seven Psychopaths is almost certainly not the movie you'll be expecting it to be, but as long as you stick with it, this is one of its greatest strengths, not a weakness.
The Twilight Saga has finally ended, not with a triumphant roar but with the self-satisfied mumble of an inconsiderate lover rolling over and breaking wind as they fall asleep
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Don't expect to be carried along by big action and cliched dialogue, Lawless expects you to do some of the work yourself by immersing yourself in this richly textured world.
A true Tasmanian gothic tale: one man against indomitable nature; the lone form of Martin hiking through buttongrass plains, vulnerable and alone yet strong and defiant.
Aside from having a title that turns me into a puerile, sniggering teenager every time I talk about it, The Beaver is a heartbreakingly good movie.
Not every gag in Johnny English Reborn is predictable, obvious and unfunny. Some of them are established and then ignored completely.
I'm sure I could find a fault somewhere in this film if I really tried, but it wouldn't be significant enough to matter. The King's Speech is perfect.
TRON: Legacy is shallow but beautiful, thrilling but unsatisfying.
What is a villain if not someone who has been pushed too far in life and has started to push back? And with nothing to push against, what do they become?
M. NIGHT Shyamalan has churned out a few stinkers of late, but his new thriller Devil could mark his return to form.
The initial setup is a bit of a stretch and the ending feels unfinished but most of the stuff in between - bog standard as it is - works pretty well.
Deathly Hallows Part 1 is a damn fine piece of film - if I had the faintest idea what was going on in it, I might have enjoyed it even more.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Monsters, by first-time English director Gareth Edwards, begins where most alien invasion movies end.
If aliens ever invade Earth, it will be to stop us from making another movie as bad as Skyline.
The worst job in the army isn't cleaning latrines or disarming roadside bombs, it is being back home telling people that someone they love has been killed.
Just how much of the story is really true is anyone's guess but the brilliant script and Eisenberg's performance make it worth seeing in any case.
The Loved Ones doesn't pull many punches, director Sean Byrne exercising an expert balance of tactical restraint and outright savagery.
If Paranormal Activity's domestic brand of spookiness worked on you the first time, you will find a lot to like in this sequel.
Let Me In is simultaneously a joy and a disappointment.
The sensation of confinement is so powerful that after a while I had an overwhelming urge to try and claw my way out through the side of the cinema.
Dinner for Schmucks might start out as an exercise in laughing at idiots but it turns into something much more rewarding.
Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps is a potent critique of American corporate culture in the aftermath of the global financial crisis. But as a human story, it falls flat.
Every teenager - and probably a lot of older people as well - should see Easy A.
Almost more action movie than zombie movie, World War Z is less about the zombies than it is about the effect the outbreak has on the world. And it works.
Knight and Day is a bit like a booze-filled night out with a bunch of strangers you don't quite trust.
If you don't know the original 1987 classic Predator line-for-line and inside-out, you will probably miss half the gags in this one.
Eclipse reinvigorates the Twilight saga, giving the fans what they want as well as being good enough to keep casual viewers interested.
Toy Story 3 is equal parts hilarious, touching, insightful and exciting and anyone who doesn't come out smiling probably isn't human.
Inception made my brain hurt. And it hurt in the most wonderful way.
Director Darren Aronofsky does a spectacular job of drawing the audience deep into Nina's neuroses, making the viewer feel every uncomfortable twist of her mental instability.
Ignorant, culturally insensitive and unfunny, this is simply the equivalent of a Wiggles concert for the ``I love shoes'' set.
It is a beautiful thing to watch, even if the pacing feels a bit lopsided.
Scott Pilgrim vs the World could well become a cultural touchstone for the Tetris generation.
Where a good thriller rewards you with satisfying "aha!" moments when you figure them out, Salt gives you the much less rewarding payoff of "oooooookaaaay..."
THE most surprising thing about Vampires Suck is that some parts of it almost work. Almost.
Tomorrow, When the War Began works best when none of the cast is talking.
The Sorcerer's Apprentice is what you get when Jerry Bruckheimer produces Harry Potter.
Me and Orson Welles is a potentially wonderful film damaged by the presence of a lacklustre Zac Efron.
Bridges' performance as Cogburn is so good you can almost smell the whiskey as he growls and drawls his way through the script.
Sanctum would have worked well as one of those novelty 3D eye-candy shorts, but I didn't care about any of the thinly drawn characters or anything that happened to them.
The Way Back is an epic adventure with enough humour to keep it from feeling dour but enough realism to make it really feel like everything is at stake.
As it turns out, fart and poo gags ARE universal, as demonstrated by the mostly female audience completely losing it during some of the more off-colour scenes.
Julia's Eyes stops just short of being an amazing thriller but...some excellent camera work heightens the experience of fumbling through the mystery from Julia's perspective.
Seeing the new Transformers movie was a little like agreeing to go on one more date with someone who has hurt your feelings twice already.
While Feret ably conveys the dejection caused by being treated as nothing more than breeding stock, she doesn't quite sell the simmering rebellion of her character.
The Tree of Life is either a triumph of artistic cinema or an almost inscrutable load of film wank. I'm still not entirely sure which.
The only thing more beautiful than the music is seeing those simple, subtle moments that nobody could possibly script.
Everything about Super 8 harks back to simpler times, the music and technology of the era evoking something nostalgic and comforting without being flippant or facetious.
If these movies have done nothing else, they have shown great skill in playing directly to a target audience, never swaying from that mission, and doing it exceptionally well.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cowboys and Aliens isn't the self-aware, campy romp I was expecting...This movie plays its ludicrous idea dead straight and pulls it off with firm conviction.
The audience is teased with fleeting glimpses of the threat lurking in the shadows and its first real appearance is played so well it is a thing of horror poetry.
I've always considered DC's Green Lantern to be one step too far over the line into "come on, that's just silly" territory. (Fresh, but only just)
Friends with Benefits is raunchy, funny and ultimately quite sweet - fluffy enough to stay fun and smart enough to stand out from the herd.
A fun, lively chemistry between Nick, Kurt and Dale keeps this snappy story whipping along from gag to gag at a merciless pace.
Tabloid is a documentary that proves conclusively that the truth really is stranger than fiction.
The story is predictably thin and the jokes suitably unsophisticated, but the clever characterisations help this paint-by-numbers comedy limp over the line to "watchable".
Abduction is a brilliant action/thriller spoof that had me laughing from start to finish. Unfortunately, it is supposed to be an action/thriller.
Instead of being all about people discovering or earning their new powers, X-Men: First Class is all about the relationships. And it is a much better movie for it.
PIRATES of the Caribbean 4 is a welcome return to the fun and frivolous form of the original.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: For all the clever writing buried in the Gnomeo & Juliet script, the end result is a bit disappointing. But I couldn't hate it.
I Am Number Four runs a bit like this: OK, OK, ho-hum, yawn, YAY WOW! ... meh.
The movie is worth seeing just for the discussions you'll have afterwards with friends about the illusion of free will and what might happen if you try to bilk your fate.
Rango is a precision-built, artistically rich and intelligently entertaining movie that deserves to become a hit and a classic.
For all its (many) flaws and derivative story elements, Battle: Los Angeles still has all the mindless fun and excitement of a really good high school food fight.
Once it finally gains momentum, it's not too bad. It's a bit like an old-fashioned whodunit but with werewolves. If only it knew what it wanted to be.
The makers of The Hangover Part II have pulled off one of the most blatantly lazy acts of filmmaking in recent memory. And it still works.
As predictable as it is, there's a simplicity and honesty to it that make it surprisingly enjoyable. And it actually made me like Jennifer Aniston again. (Fresh - just)
Simon Pegg and Nick Frost are two guys who know what they like and whenever they turn their hands to writing a script, you can feel that enthusiasm in every line.
There is a healthy dose of cheese in this slightly campy superhero flick and it does well not to take itself too seriously.
This is far from a sophisticated movie but the simplicity of the story allows it to have a lot of fun playing with the outrageous characters and silly sight gags.
Even when I thought I had the whole thing figured out early on, the movie allowed me to feel smug for a while before shooting me down. Brilliant.
Sitting through Snowtown is a kind of torture in itself. This isn't really a movie you enjoy watching; it's a movie you subject yourself to and must endure.
Water for Elephants has a distinctly daytime movie feel to it, shot in soft, golden tones with an unchallenging plot.
The story's true "sucker punch" is the way it lures its audience in with the promise of simple eye candy but then hits you in the guts with something deeper and more complex.
It'll be controversial, but to hell with it: Michael Shannon is a better General Zod than Terrence Stamp. There. I said it.
All I know is I laughed myself silly. Judge me if you must.
Whedon's legendary talent for dense dialogue and wrangling sprawling casts of strong characters into engaging stories has never been put to better use.
Inferno feels like a retread of the Da Vinci Code, just with an emphasis on clumsily teaching the audience all about Dante instead of Leonardo.
I think I'd recommend Storks more highly for parents than children, because the mums and dads will definitely get the biggest laughs out of the film.
A disarmingly tender-hearted comedy that has a lot to say about loneliness, human connection, dreams and terrible pub music.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: So many different shades of wrong all wrapped up in one movie that, even as I sit to write this, I'm unsure whether I was howling with laughter or begging for it to stop.
A long way from perfect but still a joyously deranged action flick that was great fun to watch, despite some iffy plotting and under-written characters.
I almost forgot it was Matt Damon in the movie after a while. He doesn't really get to do much acting, per se, he is just in centre frame for all the action scenes.
What happens when you let a comedy screenwriter and a director of bonehead car action movies get together and steer a Star Trek movie? Something pretty amazing, actually.
As much as the original was a product of its era, so is this: making fun of hipsters, trashing those awful ghost-hunting TV shows, and even referencing that current phenomenon of rock star sceptics.
If I wasn't choking back tears, Finding Dory had me laughing until I hurt myself. Oh yes, and it looks amazing, too.
They aren't cops, they're just scumbags of slightly different shades. But the odd-couple dynamic is straight out of the Lethal Weapon playbook and it still works a charm.
Ironically, the thing that vexed about the X-Men comic books as a kid is the exact same thing that I love so much about the movies as an adult: shades of grey.
As a film, The Angry Birds Movie is an okay kids' flick, no more no less, but as a video game adaptation it is actually remarkably well done.
If the first movie was all about the ludicrous excesses of the frat-house lifestyle, then this one is all about shining a light on the inherent misogyny of the same scene.
Seriously, DC Comics and Warner Bros. need to consider just outsourcing their movie production to Marvel/Disney from now on so they can do it properly.
Disney's live-action reimagining of The Jungle Book might not be quite as small-child-friendly as the 1967 animated version, but it is still a solid family movie.
RIDDLE me this: how do you put three of the greatest comic book superheroes of all time into one big-budget movie and still make a mess of it?
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Much like George Orwell used animals as an allegory for communism and social inequality, Disney has used Zootopia to deliver a story about prejudice and intolerance.
A boxing movie made me cry. There, I said it.
By about halfway I had stopped counting the cliches, tropes and derivative lifts because there were just too many and it was starting to distract me from the thready story.
From the sound design to the spectacular cinematography, everything combines to create an uncanny sensation of being there.
Sicario is a big brooding beast of a movie. Like some sort of dark thing that lurks in a corner glaring at you but not moving to attack you. Yet.
Definitely only a movie for devoted genre fans and who can appreciate the charms of unapologetic B-grade fare. It's silly, crass and meaningless. But damn, it's funny.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Honestly, the most disappointing thing about the entire Hunger Games series is that I never got a single chance to pan any one of them for anything.
There's a hapless kind of charm to it, I guess. It's a harmless comedy, it will make a good Sunday night flick on a commercial TV station at some point.
I felt like I'd gone 12 rounds with someone who recited bad poetry while hitting me with a wet sock.
There are no midichlorians. There are no fart jokes. No sequences that blatantly scream "I AM A VIDEO GAME CONCEPT!" No Gunguns. And it's all wonderful.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Makes exquisite use of silence, with minimal musical score and many scenes where the only sound you hear is clumps of snow falling off trees or ice cracking.
Right down to the delicate touches, like the ways two different people's hands linger on Therese's shoulder, everything is constructed with minute attention to human detail.
Jobs' insistence on a "closed system completely incompatible with anything else" is a convenient metaphor for the character we see on screen here.
He swears like a sailor, he fills every conversation with sexual innuendo and generally behaves like a hyperactive teenager. But utterly oozing with charisma.
There are few rom-coms out there brave enough to give us anything like a happy ending devoid of a last-minute taxi ride to the airport and a marriage proposal.
It plays everything pretty safe, but through the direction of Ron Howard it still elevates itself to be a very enjoyable adventure epic with a nice twist on a well-known tale.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: TRAINWRECK is a blisteringly funny rom-com that is only let down by the fact that it is not as subversive or as transgressive as it aspires to be.
Doctor Strange gets in, tells its story, thrills you, makes you laugh, and then gets out before you get a chance to get sick of it. No stretching, no padding, no wasted space.
I couldn't help but feel there was something a bit cynical in the production of a New York-based Harry Potter spin-off.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Trey Parker and Matt Stone once joked that if Team America had been performed with actors instead of puppets, it would have been a Bruckheimer movie. Enter 12 Strong...
A terminally slow-moving spy flick that would have been more thrilling if its less-than-mind-blowing twists had been played out with a bit more pace.
Didn't wow me quite as much as some of the other Marvel superhero movies, but that is because this movie that puts story and solid character development ahead of spectacle.
I, Tonya wears its complete disregard for the truth quite proudly and is still probably a better portrait of the reality than anything we saw in the news at the time.
The trailer is one great big fake-out and, after the second act, the film lurches off in a completely different direction. And despite its tonal issues, it is very watchable.
This chapter relies so much on its call-backs and references that it all feels a little bit too safe. But still a damn fine movie, pushing the story forward in style.
The irony is that this farcical comedy just might win the Oscar Wiseau always coveted. I'm sure Wiseau will take credit for it if it happens. And we won't mind.
Nobody's heart was in this thing, not even the extremely talented cast, who weren't even phoning their performances in, they just sent a quick text from the toilet.
Despite the narrative we are conditioned to expect, this film isn't all about Auggie. It is in the overlapping narratives from his peers that we see the true message.
The characterisation is a bit lacking in places, and the Big Bad Guy feels a tad bland, but it finally feels like the DCEU knows where it is going. Good fun.
For all the admirable world-building and faithfulness to the style of the original, the story is almost a let-down and the soporific pace of the film makes it a tough slog.
The feelings mother! provokes are quite profound and intense, even if the message is difficult to decipher. Maybe you only take from this film what you bring with you.
The relentless grotesquerie and deeply unsettling tone are the closest match I think I've ever seen on screen for Stephen King's particular brand of horror.
In the case of American Made, the "true story" is more of a serving suggestion, but the fully embellished film is still great fun.
Christopher Nolan has created a true masterpiece here: experimental in structure, gripping storytelling, haunting in tone, and more terrifying than most horror movies.
As a storyteller and filmmaker, Edgar Wright has an uncanny knack for teasing the beautiful and whimsical out of even the most unlikely subject matter.
There is a lot going on in this film, in terms of plot, themes and tone, and director Joon-Ho Bong shows himself to be a master at holding it all together coherently.
It's a pale imitation of the original, a pretty good retread at best, but it's still a pretty funny one. You just can't recreate the shock value of the original.
Saved from unfunny oblivion by its cast. There are plenty of laughs to be had but without the clear skill and timing of these actors, none of the material would work.
Trolls is cinematic junk food, but not just some sloppy greasy cheeseburger. It is one of those exquisitely pretty little cakes you find in really nice patisseries.
Really, this is the prequel that should have been made 10 years ago instead of that dreck that George Lucas defecated into the world.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: All the way through, Sing is a lively, life-affirming and uplifting experience to watch. And the sheer delirious joyousness of the final act is tear-inducing.
What is most disappointing about it is that such a cinematic and narratively clever game could be turned into such a second-rate movie.
While it is well acted and well written, the execution does sometimes have a Hallmark-Movie-of-the-Week feel to it, heavy on the portentous drama and intrusive score.
Collateral Beauty certainly has something to say. And it is a worthy something. It is just a shame to see it wrapped up in the form of an Oprah Winfrey Movie of the Week.
Visually amazing but more care could have been taken with the human side of things: a bit more focus on the ghost, a bit less attention to the shell, if you like.
I didn't feel the comedic elements always sat well with the rest of the film but that's a small issue with an otherwise gripping, intelligent and suspense-filled thriller.
In a lot of ways is is a fairly predictable movie, hitting many of the same notes as its predecessors, despite its alleged efforts not to. But still a fine horror movie.
This Wonder Woman will be inspirational to a new generation of young girls looking for a role model who is both physically strong and endlessly compassionate at the same time.
The plot has more holes than Ahmanet's wrappings, the tone is all over the place, and the ending is a wreck. This is a terrible movie, yet somehow still kinda fun.
Michael Bay's latest big robots action movie is partly based on the King Arthur legend because, well, why not take a big steaming dump on that story as well?
She's a funny girl, that Belle, but she's no precious snowflake.
The balance is just right: hanging a lantern on the silly stuff but not dwelling on it for too long, while making sure the plot feels high-stakes and the characters believable.
The franchise that probably should have gone quietly into the night. A roller coaster ride is not a story.
There is a fine line between clever homage and lazy lip service. This film trips over that line, spills its drink, and pukes in the cab on the way home. But I had fun.
Scorsese seems to have mixed every genre and every tone from all his previous work together in one big three-hour character-driven opus. And the damn thing works.
To its credit, Robocop tries very hard to be as good as the original but it lacks the satirical finesse and isn't as smart as it wants to be.
Now, weight loss does not equal acting, but in this case it forms a central part of McConaughey's remarkable dedication to completely inhabiting this role.
It probably warrants a second viewing, just to see if it all holds together under closer scrutiny once you know its secrets.
It looks amazing, the acting performances are perfect, the story is engaging, and its themes and tone combine to create a rewarding movie about an iconic Australian character.
Fiennes is magnificent, his droll wit and a "keep calm and carry on" delivery occasionally peppered with highlights of profanity and fire. Comedic timing perfection.
If Judd Apatow had directed this, it might have made a very good comedy, but in Jonze's hands it is beautifully philosophical and heartfelt. Utterly, devastatingly beautiful.
What should have been a brain in a vat just became a brain in a blender.
There seemed to be two separate movies running in parallel, and I couldn't shake the feeling that these two halves just didn't fit together properly.
Gareth Edwards, who directed the genre-twisting film Monsters, knows how to turn a monster flick into something more thoughtful while still maintaining an exciting exterior.
This is Mystique's movie. The filmmakers are obviously making the most of Jennifer Lawrence's current star power by putting her right out front for this one.
The familiarity of the setting and everyday items clashes with the Armageddon atmosphere and the eerie soundtrack to make a strangely creepy setting.
22 Jump Street is not just a sequel, it is a 112-minute running gag about sequels, including the adaptation of the title.
AT the centre of our galaxy is a supermassive black hole. Not even light can escape from its powerful gravitational pull. And not even that sucks as much as this movie.
Davis gives possibly the performance of her career in The Babadook, portraying this emotionally destroyed woman with an authenticity and honesty that is punishing to watch.
Not a great movie but still one of the funnier iPad commercials I've seen lately.
While it might lose some of the finer detail and plotting of the book, it more than makes up for this in the sensuous way it recreates its setting and its engaging characters.
It might be remade almost shot-for-shot, but times have changed since the `70s, and I personally think Peirce's clear agenda for updating its dominant themes is a welcome one.
If Fast and Furious 6 was stupid in the bad way, This is the End is stupid in the best and funniest way.
A fairly solid stand-alone story that embraces everything that has preceded it and mostly keeps the momentum going in the lead-up to the next X-Men film, due next year.
The weakest film in the three, which is a disappointing way to wrap up a trilogy, but once it stumbles past its lumbering first act it warms up considerably.
Abracadabra! The character development has vanished! But the flowers are still standing!
Its parallels with present-day asylum-seeking are obvious, and while the analogy might be a little heavy-handed, it still hits its mark and makes its point very well.
RED 2 plays it pretty safe, carefully emulating the style and tone of its predecessor, so if you enjoyed the first one, RED 2 should tick the same boxes for you.
I thoroughly enjoyed the experience of watching the movie, but I felt a bit disengaged with the story, as if it only existed as a device to hold the big pretty visuals together.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It was nice to watch a movie that had no delusions of grandeur, a simple flick that both plays to its strengths and makes light of its own weaknesses.
It's not...quite...about empowering women, but there is certainly something surprising and interesting going on here.
Machete don't text, but he does seem to have jumped a shark. The first film was great fun, but Machete Kills seems to have misunderstood its own joke.
This sequel once again defies the odds, director Alan Taylor improving on the already solid foundation built by Branagh to deliver a movie that is as self-assured as it is fun.
The Counselor is a chore of a movie to watch and even the cast's collective talent can't save it from its brain-numbing dialogue.
Less violent and less mean-spirited than Jackass, Bad Grandpa is a funny little diversion and that's about it, but that's okay.
There is no law of diminishing returns here. The Hunger Games: Catching Fire is every bit as potent and gripping as its predecessor and a real triumph of entertainment.
It may sound like an odd recommendation but A Hijacking is brilliant precisely because of the skilful way it makes you feel engaged, unwell, anxious and terrified all at once.
With repeated themes of emotional trauma, running from your demons, and facing the consequences of your actions, Hercules is a deceptively textured and layered action movie.
The stunning vista of the Earth spinning below, the scale of the emptiness, the distances, the astronauts and wreckage tumbling through the void...This is what 3D was made for.
An environmental, post-apocalyptic, revolutionary-uprising sci-fi action movie on a train. Sub-genres don't come much more specific than Snowpiercer.
The repeated references to nonviolence form an especially powerful theme, a reminder of what can be accomplished not through simply taking revenge, but by staying your hand.
Basically, it's Cinderella, complete with sparkly dresses and a magical sky person telling poor Cinders she is actually very special. Truly awful.
Quite frankly, the story was trying my patience for a while.
The emotional power of Chappie's portrayal makes it stirring to watch but it just doesn't feel like enough care was taken with the rest of the film surrounding the robot.
The score by Danny Elfman makes it sound a little too much like a romantic comedy at times but Big Eyes is a smart flick with a lot to say and many talking points to present.
The emotion and humanity of the characters is so raw that at times it almost feels like a documentary. The director has honed a fine skill for profiling a character.
In the same way Shaun of the Dead became an almost perfect zombie movie simply by sending up the genre, Kingsman just might have done Bond better than Bond.
Proves an action movie can have it all: smart without being convoluted, flashy without being shallow, fun without being hollow, and exciting without being dumb.
Lesbi-honest (nope, I'm not even sorry for that), it doesn't quite reach the same lofty heights as the first one, but this sequel comes pretty close.
Woman In Gold is one of those films that might not challenge you too much with an artful story, but still appeals on some deeper emotional level.
I've seen some pretty good comedies lately that didn't make me laugh this hard.
The feature-film debut for UK director John Maclean, Slow West is a strange beast that looks like the Coen brothers and Wes Anderson teamed up to shoot alternating scenes.
I laughed, I had fun, but there is something annoyingly non-committal about the direction and tone. And why not just call it "Tonto" and be done with it? Who are we kidding?
These Final Hours is tragic, sad, thrilling and tense, a triumph of cinema that tells its gut-wrenching tale in under 90 minutes - take note, Hollywood.
To be able to tell a story from entirely within the narrative limitations of a few windows on a computer screen is actually quite an achievement.
For a film that seems to have its heart in the right place, it certainly botched the delivery of its otherwise quite worthy message.
This is how an action movie should be: gutsy, unapologetic, relentless, artful, well-written, full-throttle and, above all, spectacular. Destined to be an Australian classic.
Crowe's directorial debut is a call for tolerance and understanding, pacifism and reason, and, above all else, compassion ... for everyone affected by every war.
The humour and drama of Birdman are a slick delivery vehicle for a philosophically detailed existential crisis story, with life imitating art imitating life.
What We Do in the Shadows is a sharp little character-driven comedy that gets its laughs not so much from the plot but simply from its cast of weirdos.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Kinda fun and enjoyable despite its dubious pedigree, not because of it. I got the distinct feeling this movie deserved a better treatment than it got from its makers.
There are clues scattered throughout the story that point towards the ending, which would be clever if they weren't plonked in so loudly.
Gone Girl is so expertly crafted that its 150-minute running time flies by - this story is worth every tightly-wound second.
If you're considering seeing Fury but you're reluctant because you don't want to watch a "tank movie", don't worry, because it isn't.
Christopher Nolan can do whatever the hell he likes. He's earned that right now. And if he uses that clout for films like Interstellar, we all win.
With some good acting performances, some very horror-movie sensibilities, a good mystery and a solid dystopian aesthetic, The Maze Runner trilogy is off to a great start.
Certainly not your average crime flick, The Drop has much more subtle sensibilities than its equivalent British or Hollywood contemporaries, and that is assuredly a good thing.
To be honest, Mockingjay Part 1 is probably the weakest of the three so far, but if this is as bad as it gets, that is still something of a triumph.
Nightcrawler paints a pretty grim picture of modern society and the logical outcome of our collective insatiable thirst for information, bigger shocks and faster delivery.
Whether you are religious or not, you must admit, the epic scale of the biblical Exodus is a fantastic story.
Horrible Bosses 2 is mostly a good laugh with some comic moments that really sing. But, here's the thing: rape jokes are not funny. And this one left a bad taste.
This is a human drama that invites you to think, not just about the technicalities and the philosophies behind code-breaking, but also the social and psychological themes.
This enthralling documentary ... is at once playful and haunting, an in-depth portrait of an iconoclastic artist who was fundamentally unknowable even to his closest friends.
We grow to genuinely care about the people of XX/XY, and their romantic troubles are portrayed with a refreshing, open honesty.
When it's all said and done, this pæan to the losers, misfits, outcasts and obsessives of the world proves to be nothing less than haunting.
Favors us with plenty of color, a feast of eye candy. As food for the soul, however... there are always her paintings.
Never less than clever and often digs down into some uncomfortable realities about the strange lives of that odd species known as 'movie people.'
It's never cheap, but it's also never quite as scary as it thinks it is; the buildups invariably lead to letdowns.

It certainly feels unique, and sets itself apart from most American gangster films in its stark refusal to paint the lead gangster as likable or indeed anything other than the vicious socio-psychopath he is.
This is Cult Movie Central -- and there's no livelier tour guide than Michael Winterbottom.
It still manages to slide by, but barely, and only on the strength of its two leads.
A reasonably intelligent adult comedy.
Capra has been embalmed and larded with prefab sentimental glaze, a synthetic 21st century Hollywood idea of what Capra the director stood for.
A gripping experience, and often downright sickening.
The most wondrous love story in years, it is a great film.
As a study of how the current corporate idiocy impacts one man's art, it's priceless.
movie_title: I Am Trying to Break Your Heart (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Certainly worth looking into, but it feels a little too repressed for its own good.
It's getting difficult to watch this old dog trying so hard to pull off the same old tricks; Allen is becoming a caricature of himself, a cartoon, before our very eyes.
It's a compelling and horrifying story, and The Laramie Project is worthwhile for reminding us that this sort of thing does, in fact, still happen in America.
In all, Tautou is the most adorable Frenchwoman to grace movie screens since we first laid eyes on La Binoche in The Unbearable Lightness of Being.
Blends The Rules of the Game, Upstairs Downstairs and Ten Little Indians into a rich feast that will have adult filmgoers licking their chops.
To borrow an icon from another legend of English origin, this is the Holy Grail. The big one has finally been delivered to us, and it is a beautiful thing indeed.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: He's no easy mark, Derrida, but trying to keep up with him as he reasons his way through even the most simple questions makes for a rewarding experience.
While the film succeeds as a visceral testament to all the servicemen who fought in Mogadishu, particularly the nineteen who lost their lives, Black Hawk Down is more punishing than anything else.
Quiet and slow-paced, as all the finest French films are, Time Out modestly redefines the psychological thriller.
At least it's better than Return of the Jedi. If that sounds like faint praise... then line up and find out for yourself.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The raw sexuality sometimes clangs loudly against the glib comedy, but by the end On_Line makes you love it.
Everything you've heard: sad and funny, revealing and compelling, entertaining, devastating.
Quitting offers piercing domestic drama with spikes of sly humor.
Though we sometimes feel we're missing bits of crucial backstory here and there, the characters are so relatable that we're with them all the way, sympathetic to the end.
movie_title: Under the Skin of the City (Zir-e Poust-e Shahr) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: You will either despise what you've experienced or support Pascal Laugier in creating a masterpiece that transcends the genre and leaves the viewer drained and breathless.
Almereyda is tripped up by this grab at cosmic profundity, and lands in a sticky puddle of pretension.
While Braff's script may suffer from long-windedness, his direction -- of both cast and camera -- is so confident that this debut could well mark the start of a major career.
Newcombe is clearly as troubled as he is talented, maybe more.

As a piece of acting, The Quiet American represents a fitting capper to Caine's illustrious career; his portrait of a jaded sybarite whom history nudges into conscientious action is among the year's most moving.

Wes Anderson simply has a unique way of looking at the world, and through him the ridiculous is made sublime. He has a hell of a distinctive style for someone his age. It would appear he might even be some kind of goddamn genius himself.
Moore is simply...wonderful.
A film to savor and to be thankful for.
A riveting account of this demented and scarcely believable American story.
movie_title: Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's dark, it's intelligent -- it's also humorless and a bit pretentious.
The result will stand as one of the most intense, in-depth, warts-and-all rockumentaries ever made -- VH1's Behind the Music cranked up to 11 and beyond.
Music fans of every stripe should kill to see this film, one of the very best music documentaries in recent years. Then, get thee to a record store.
movie_title: Tom Dowd and the Language of Music (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A sci-fi thriller of uncommon creepiness, One Point 0 makes inventive use of a low budget, and clever story and a terrific cast.
Generates laughs while teaching valuable lessons about how we can all, in small but significant ways, make the choice to 'leave a light footprint' on our imperiled planet Earth.
Gershon and her cohorts make it all swing.
Is anyone else out there getting tired of the whole slo-mo, double-pistoled, ballistic-pyrotechnic Hong Kong action aesthetic?
It is about treasuring life -- sometimes even cheating death -- and it manages to warm hearts in its own uncompromising way, rarely cheating and never belittling.
Green and Siegel have crafted a breathtaking portrait of one chapter of the '60s story that hasn't been done to death.
No 'star rating' has been applied above because conventional indications of 'good' or 'bad' simply do not apply to this film.
Rather than tying together into a satisfying whole, the fragments seem to fly off in any number of directions, and a sweet, simple tale of young love dissolves into a mishmash.
Humorless, self-conscious art drivel, made without a glimmer of intelligence or invention.
A genuine mind-bender.
Shivery and seductive, May is a delicious little creepathon.
It is impossible to care for the Joes, so cursory is their characterisation, so bland are the actors. It is all so uninvolving, and for that the computer-generated effects are greatly to blame.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Watch this and you will long remember Burma - and briefly join a revolution.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film is desperate to be edgy, but its attempts at adult humour are woefully misjudged.
Unfortunately, a good deal of Touch the Music is devoted to vacuous interviews with Glennie, who seems positively incapable of saying anything substantial.
The performances -- welling, unified and multidimensional -- are beyond praise, as are Bergman's visual images.
Somewhere in amongst the mystery/thriller/horror/sci-fi/drama genre-bending shenanigans something gets seriously lost.
What makes Canary sing is Leni's pioneering mix of spooky expressionism and light comedy, fabulous camera work, and nice turns from Laura La Plante, Creighton Hale, and Martha Mattox.
One of those rare horror films that induces discomfort by showing practically nothing.
[The film] may be slow-moving by Hollywood standards, but Record of a Tenement Gentleman rewards patience with rich sentiment that's never mawkish.
movie_title: Nagaya shinshiroku (Record of a Tenement Gentleman) (1947)

movie_review_blurb: In Annie Hall, Allen again writes, directs and stars with Diane Keaton in a remarkable recreation of a spent love affair, which is both sad and hysterically funny.
This story of angels is really an examination of what it means to be human -- in the most profound sense but via the smallest, most trivial details.
Does it live up to the hype? For the most part, yes.
Despite our knowing where the story goes, Sith keeps your attention through its 140-plus minutes. And that says something about Lucas's skill and the power of the universe he created.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Visually, Finding Nemo is spectacular. The animators render theses scenes with exquisite detail and vibrant color, reaching beyond mere CGI-wizardry to artistry.
Silly comic fluff with as much substance as a scented resume printed on pink paper. But this movie is deliciously funny.

When an actor has just hit a career low -- as I think Steve Carell did in the desperate Dinner for Schmucks -- it's a relief to see them bounce back with a performance that clicks, in a hit film that really needs their services.
The director of Takers, a try-hard heist movie of clomping unoriginality and self-regard, is labouring under the embarrassing delusion that he's Michael Mann.
The Heigl/Duhamel hostilities are so persuasive their entire movie balls itself up into a shrill domestic nightmare.
It feels like a halfway house towards mainstream recovery for a career blighted by studio frustration, but it offers something close to a career-best opportunity for Rhys Ifans...
Sadly plumps for lowest-common-denominator idiocy of the let's-put-Hitler-in-a-frilly-dress variety.
Bounces around with a hyperactive dementia that somehow never flags.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's not much on this movie's mind but photogenic healing, and making all the girls go ga-ga at the sight of Efron mewling with grief.

Fashioning the book's secrets into thriller-ish twists would have been the absolute worst decision Alex Garland's screenplay might have made, and it's much too smart and controlled for that. Still, it's possible to wish it were a little more radical.
It's almost fascinatingly awful, nailing the moony tedium of its target franchise with something close to suicidal exactitude.
The terrain of grief is well mapped-out in American art movies, but Rabbit Hole finds some subtle new pathways through it.
We're left with something gorgeous, turgid, and emotionally impenetrable -- less a movie, more an Imax screensaver.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Elliot is a talent eccentric enough to make Nick Park look like an office drone, and the serious sadness underpinning his vision only makes the humour work better.
It absolutely whizzes by.
Schwentke must think his audience is very easily pleased.
A nifty prequel to a nifty original, albeit one which depends for its impact on our once-bitten, twice-shy inklings of what's in store.

Jackie Chan has made plenty of cracking films in his native tongue, but Little Big Soldier, a rambunctiously tragicomic martial epic set during China's Warring States period, is regrettably not one of them.
movie_title: Little Big Soldier (Da bing xiao jiang) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's a ghoulish historical comedy about the notorious Edinburgh body-snatchers. Wait, did I say comedy? Watching it, I was stricken with doubt.
Admirers of Todd Solondz's cinema of discomfort will find much to cringe at in this excellent dark comedy from Sweden.

There are moments of genius in this film, jumbled up with the kind of excess Boyle can't help but indulge. His response to the constricted task before him is to break out with more unbridled style than ever.
There's next to no context, save for one central section in which Kiefer answers questions posed by an art historian, leaving us, to be honest, little the wiser.
movie_title: Over Your Cities Grass Will Grow (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Offhandedly touching and safe as houses, it's the breeziest film you can imagine about risking everything for a fairer slice of the pie.
Giddy wirework and occasional flurries of poor 3D don't come to the rescue of a turgid, anti-climactic plot in Yuen Woo-ping's chop-socky extravaganza...
Williams keeps his head above water, and a giddy climax recuperates some of the original energy -- enough, at least, to make this director's next project one worth rooting for anew.
It's all about the moves, and I count the film's moronic perkiness as a plus: it could be the dumbest thing all year that I have to admit enjoying.
It's beneath any cat to be sprayed repeatedly with a water bottle, or completely shaved, let alone dubbed by Bette Midler.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's nothing if not easy on the eye, and the acting's engaging and sympathetic.
The suspense is as skimpy as the swimwear...
The movie struggles to find a main attraction that's worth the bullets it's printed on.
Better than Cats & Dogs, but praise hardly comes much lower.
Delightfully esoteric doc about Steinway's piano-tuner-in-chief, Stefan Knupfer, and his selfless quest for perfect sound.
A must.
The transformation of Ben Affleck from busted A-list star to surprisingly useful journeyman director continues in The Town his follow-up to the uneven but fascinating Gone Baby Gone.
As low on scares as it is on sense, good acting, musical numbers or other recognisable merits.
There's something lacking in this respectable, effortful Scum-like drama from French director Kim Chapiron...
Like being sat on by all your least favourite school bullies.
A tart, thoroughly engaging and often suspenseful mixture of psychodrama and social satire...
[A] Babel-ish drama about the malaises wrought by globalisation, how we're closer than ever, and yet, if I'm not mistaken, farther apart. Unfortunately, you've seen it already.
You can't fault the crusading spirit of this controversial Bollywood satire, just the blunt, one-note, entirely obvious execution.
A high-calibre Hollywood prestige drama, sharp and sobering, with top-drawer work from Lancaster, Clift and Sinatra.
The taut set-up is enjoyable all by itself, but it's the rising tide of three-way recriminations and despair that gives this film emotional clout.
The ancient Chinese philosopher, he say Chow Yun-Fat no good at playing him, no good at all, in this painfully dreary epic biopic.
A plasticky and often grating family comedy...

Curtis and Weaver put on their game faces, but the script is consistently intent on embarrassing them, and it doesn't spare Kristin Chenoweth, forced to trot out her sparkly-pixie routines from Glee as a super-duper wedding planner.
The drawing is magnificent, with ravishing, detailed cityscapes of Havana, New York and Las Vegas.
A parochial French time-passer which waddles along amiably and then ends unforgivably.
movie_title: La tête en friche (My Afternoons with Margueritte) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Probably great if you're three, but quite an endurance test if you're not.
Not enough films hit the sweet spot that Burlesque does between ridiculous, flagrantly decrepit and yet game enough in spangly execution to sweep you along.
The stench of plague is all around, unless that's an aroma emanating from the script.
As a self-help sitcom, it feels both glib and icky. Glicky?
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Witness a rare sighting, like an albatross over the Scottish highlands. It's Keanu Reeves, acting in The Cherry Orchard.
The Green Hornet isn't a Michel Gondry film, but a Seth Rogen film to which Gondry has been strapped and forced to say the word "Action!", seemingly at gunpoint.
College-fraternity stunts go past the point of no return, which is also the point where we cease to be convinced or care.
The cast ... commit themselves beyond the call of duty, and, in Juliette Lewis's case, virtually beyond the call of sanity.

Just when you thought British cinema was in danger of stalling in its default mode - classy crowd-pleasing, with award-worthy millinery - along comes Neds to give it a rude and vital kick up the rear.
Morning Glory stays firmly on the launchpad, doing increasingly desperate run-ups, but collapsing in a gawky heap whenever it tries to take off.
A suspenseless marathon of misguided male loyalty. Nothing's funny. Nothing's real.
A romance with songs, and none of them thankfully sung by animals.
Oppressively bleak, intermittently powerful, a loud lunge at themes better quietly pondered, it's a heavyweight dramatic experience in good ways and bad.
Life, death, the beyond... Ah, the beyond. Such a minefield for respectable filmmakers.
The casualties pile up in this moderately engaging 3-D adventure about a cave-diving team trapped underground and struggling to survive.
It's stunningly assured, suspenseful, emotionally truthful and tough.
The scenario pauses to congratulate itself too often, but Anne Alvaro is superb as Dujardin's anxious and besotted housekeeper.
movie_title: The Clink Of Ice (Le Bruit Des Glacons) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Jaw-droppingly mawkish and offensively trivial about confronting one's mortality.
So much is muddled and just messed up, the fruit of uncertainty rather than bold vision.
He's insane! He's irrepressible! It's like a bad dream you keep hoping will stop.

We get some watchable flurries of hunt-'em-down suspense between the interminable kvetchings of the human prey, but the only salient reason to see this is the creature design, by those HR Giger-inspired wizards Alec Gillis and Tom Woodruff Jr.
A disaster area, pure and simple.
The film begs lots of questions about how, and when, it became clear any of this was worth documenting, but it certainly was.
Formally exacting and sonically immersive, Madsen's approach is so hypnotic you emerge as if roused from a troubling dream.
Grau uses his rigorously grim scenario to mount a slightly studenty thesis about an underclass feeding on itself.
How is the film anything other than its own besotted yet savage review of cinema?
Pang Ho-cheung's slasher gives a new meaning to "Homes Under the Hammer", but it's in deadly earnest as wannabe satire.
A curious, elliptical little film about people cocooned in their own romantic notions: at barely over an hour, the lethargic pace is easy to live with.
movie_title: Eccentricities of a Blonde-haired Girl (Singularidades de uma Rapariga Loura) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The shores of Buzios in Brazil beckon in a drama about infidelity and sexual awakening which mainly settles for being easy on the eye.
The general dead air and creepy ending make it hard to see who, beyond members of the Winstone/Howman clans, might be interested.
It's too abstruse for its own good, and often boring.

Tony Scott has been applying hyper-coloured flash to movies for three decades, but Unstoppable, his two-men-against-a-runaway-train logistical rollercoaster ride, is the first in some while where style and concept get on a treat.
Much of it still plays like bad Thomas Harris...
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's spare and meditative in that way that one viewer responds to as profound artistry, while his neighbour (that would be me) feels shushed into submission, and almost guilty for questioning its tactics.

It's a gorgeous and unsettling ride, a road movie about an almost-romance, with the threat of the unknown hanging in the air, and an ending, both beautiful and elegantly scary, that sends shivers down the spine.
A feeble smut-fest of impressive tonal weirdness, which had me sniggering with it, at it, and in spite of myself.

Showing off your stars, ogling the Grand Canal and draping everyone in Colleen Atwood's glamorous threads is not enough in itself to pass as Hitchcock homage, unless your favourite Hitchcock film is To Catch a Thief.
Excruciating when it's bad, which is far too often, but a brave failure in lots of ways.

Coppola knows she's treading water here, but she's smart enough to make that in itself her film's subject, spinning an extra variation, perhaps this one last time, on the adage to work with what you know.
Thoroughly grim but original and commendable indie-Scot-horror about deadlocked necromancers, played by Kate Dickie and James Nesbitt.
There's committed work here from Joanne Froggatt as a soldier returning from Iraq and struggling to readjust, but the film lets her down...
It's a hugely energetic and appealing film, with a saucy wit and melancholy caught on the fly.
An alarming head-scratcher, but hopefully a blip for this still-promising creative team.
When it's good, it's hilarious, shocking and weirdly plausible.
Everything about it is deliberately, winkingly atrocious -- killing the fun for those, like me, who think unwitting schlock is the juiciest kind.
The fascinating last half hour, an involved thicket of private resentment and moral quandary, is worth the wait.

Cooper's film may not make all the right choices, but it's got Bridges, and it's always got the songs, among which Ryan Bingham's The Weary Kind stands out for its haunting, choked melancholy. It's an experience you want to indulge, and that isn't hard.
Everything here is pumped up, lousily shot and malevolently brutish. Iâ(TM)m all for trash pleasure, but itâ(TM)s hard to come by when the companyâ(TM)s so obnoxious.
This feels like his version of a Guy Ritchie movie, laying on slapsticky violence and tiresome mugging around a disconcertingly tactless vendetta plot.
It's quickly clear that this is textbook pseudo-heft, a creeping case of pompous bloat disguising a thoroughly hackneyed core.

Quite what Neil Jordan thought he was doing is hard to say, beyond hooking Farrell up with a mail-order ingénue and unveiling the least lustrous visuals ever composed by Chris Doyle who very possibly spent the shoot asleep in a puddle of Guinness.
