Directed by Christian (Pandorum) Alvart with a crazy bevy of random overhead shots, it wins 2010's first genuine place in the so-bad-it's-good honours list.
The movie is close to a guilty pleasure but it is also a very silly, crummily-scripted mess with no idea how to get from one sequence to the next in that way they call... storytelling?
Robert Pattinson's hair will get the teens in for this mopey New York romance, but goodness, do they have a shock in store.
A stuffy non-starter of a prestige picture with more putative class than intelligence.
It's a model of low-budget candour and bite.
The slicing and dicing is unsparingly full-on, but it's the gruellingly slow pace which really does this in.
Being a film critic is a wonderful job, but there are weeks when the bad film delirium strikes and we'd all be better off in straitjackets.
Bright, ambitious, and almost terminally self-conscious.
The nagging implausibilities of the story keep stifling its emotional potential.
Real inmates are extras, real cells provide the scenery: it has the desperate vitality of something barely made-up.

Mark Millar's source comic, which I haven't read, is very possibly a smart and subversive treat. But Vaughn's movie is hollow, glazed, and not quite there, like a teenager who has spent too much time in his bedroom.

Tilda Swinton is ridiculously enjoyable to watch in the Italian drama I Am Love, dressed in colours you want to drink, and exploring her puzzled, porcelain allure in ways that make the screen fairly quiver.
Fundamentally harmless, though it rather tramples on its own period authenticity -- why all the Steven Soderbergh-esque funk-scored heist sequences? You may be nonplussed.
Breathless, yes, but oddly disengaged, in the first Greengrass project yet where you feel he's delivering just on par.
The film feels less like a thriller than an aesthete's tease, and one with a disappointingly stiff, Europuddingy flavour.
Funny, real, poetic and frightening, not the gruelling tract about neglect you might expect.
The plot doesn't so much thicken as curdle with every heebie-jeebie encounter -- we've taken a U-turn at the terrific Cape Fear and wound up at Cape Folly.
No one's calling it great art. But as an indulgent confection, it's more filling and less embarrassing than we had any right to expect.
It's The Apprentice with obligatory torture, and a damp squib of an ending.
If you lack empathy with them at the start, you won't by the end.
It's a shame Australia's Spierig Brothers opt to turn it into just any old noir-future chase movie - roughly Blade meets Minority Report, without the production flair.
Chan and Valletta have the opposite of chemistry.

Hard as Winstone visibly tries, he can't stop them stealing the movie, a plum actors' piece which both gains and loses points by soberly stalling its own plot. A thoughtful anticlimax is ... well, still an anticlimax.
Whatever disturbed and previously untapped audience this is meant to find, it's certainly novel.

The Hughes Brothers intend this doomily pompous multiplex-filler as a futuristic western, but its feet are firmly planted in a big bucket of po-faced messianic cement. You wonder what Washington saw in it.
Structurally a little jumbled, it's still a worthy addition to the angry eco-doc subgenre.
There are good riffs about how to track down Nazis in Brazil, and Dujardin trying to spit-roast a crocodile is good value. But it's too often crass and laboured, this time.
movie_title: OSS 117: Rio ne répond plus (Lost in Rio) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A story that's not just dauntingly square but massaged to the point where you can't trust it at all.
Hicks's hand with these relationships is more than sure enough to guide this unexpectedly observant movie over its occasional rough spots.
The film feels like a spirit-sapping tour of duty: lightweight stars doing Big Emotions.
Atom Egoyan is up to his old tricks with this fractured, elusive drama, resembling but never measuring up to the ones which launched his career.
This tumble towards knee-jerk revenge makes a brutish mess of a once-intelligent piece of storytelling, as if Charles Bronson had bagged the Ralph Fiennes role in The Constant Gardener.

Intermittently appealing and great to look at, this doesn't add up to classic Disney, but it's heaps better than the gruesome Home on the Range, which looked to be the last gasp of these old-style toons. It proves there's life in dem bones yet.

The splicing of old home videos, archive footage and new interviews is handled with real finesse, and in the band's mad-eyed, quixotic guitarist Wilco Johnson, the film has a tirelessly charismatic ringmaster.

The many mysteries of the human heart aren't solved by Garry Marshall's Love Actually-style ensemble romcom. It's more like an all-star perfect teeth and hair convention you could cheerfully firebomb.
A slab of market research in search of an actual movie.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Gervais and Merchant may offer less ambition or novelty than meet the eye, but being cosily shepherded to their feel-good destination never feels like drudgery.
This reasonably polished slice of Skins-style youthsploitation makes such a fake and undangerous lurch into pills-and-vandalism melodrama.
The tick-tock of the biological clock might be a real enough subject, but actual parturition is the grossest thing this movie can imagine, except when Lopez herself gets round to it.
Possibly the war film of the year, Lu Chuan's picture about the Rape of Nanking has a lacerating immediacy and a true artist's gravity and tact.
This is the rare one with unisex appeal - it's sweet and it's raunchy, and it has an underdog male lead of huge oddball charisma in Jay Baruchel.
What's Woody Allen's worst film? Look no further.
Though it's unlikely to announce his return to the grand stage of big-budget cinema, the movie is graced with touches of the old Coppola magic.
Veteran French director Alain Resnais, now 88, certainly keeps us guessing. Who knew he had this fiercely odd yarn of competing obsessions still in him?
The actors, every one of them new to their craft, make the everydayness of the picture indelible and real.
Lacks a single legitimate laugh, despite engineering the humping of Forest Whitaker's leg by a priapic goat. Don't ask.
Killers goes wrong so quickly and obviously it's almost hard to believe -- did collective deafness strike on set?
A promising and attractive film from Benoît Jacquot that devolves into an oddly unchallenging arthouse remake of Under the Tuscan Sun.
It's an eye-opener, if a blatantly chauvinistic one: Rock's main beefs seem to be that men have to pay for it, and upkeep of such a coveted accessory is a barrier to intimacy in the bedroom.
Relentlessly bloody and just as relentlessly idiotic deathtrap thriller for the Saw crowd.
Both exasperatingly vapid and easy to sit through.
A train wreck romcom.
The director's use of blatantly artificial devices - characters gliding along the ground, fast-breaking dawns - detaches her film from its strongest sources of turbulence and despair.
As far as its own multiple personalities go, Shelter gives you your pick of exhausting, grim and absurd.
Even Penn's more indulgent flourishes seem to enhance the film's keen feeling.
It's overlong, often gratingly cacophonous, and sentimentally hacks Tchaikovsky about as if slicing onions under your nose.
The fact that it manages to be both unmissable and maddening doesn't kill the immediate buzz, since half the film's thrills consist of simply keeping up with it.
I won't make great claims for Raymond De Felitta's film - it hardly makes them for itself - but I will say this for it: as an ensemble acting workout, it exceeds expectations from the top down.
As a canvas for Rohmer's ideas, it's crucial in making them feel as crisply distilled and newly debatable as the day they were aired.
movie_title: My Night at Maud's (Ma Nuit chez Maud) (1970)

movie_review_blurb: The effect is something like Dirty Rotten Scoundrels done by Wes Anderson in a morose mood, much as its creator would presumably resist the latter comparison.
Fond memories of Saturday teatimes spent with Hannibal Smith and the rest of The A-Team? Prepare to have them squelched.
It brings me no joy to say it, but Clarke's filmmaking is like a narcissistic strut from someone who needs to brush up on walking.
A rare disappointment from André Téchiné...
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The message is unclear, unless it's to think twice before ordering chips in Lima.
movie_title: The Milk of Sorrow (La Teta Asustada) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Chinese arthouse fixture Jia Zhang Ke looks at the closure of a state-owned factory in Chengdu, combining real interviews with awkwardly am-dram mock ones.
The film's behind-the-scenes hero is its cinematographer, Philipp Blaubach. His command of space and close-ups sustains all the tension visually that's sometimes dribbling out of the script.
The film exerts a steady grip without charging head-first into thriller territory: there's a cool, cosmic irony to the way fate wheels around.
The film-within-a-film starring Sam Rockwell tanks quite badly, but Hess's affection for fantasy kitsch shines through brightly enough to generate real feeling.
Race to see Agnes Varda's exquisite 1962 New Wave masterpiece, about an hour and a half in the life of a gorgeous, possibly dying chanteuse.

The whole movie feels extrapolated from the five-second clip of a scheming chipmunk on YouTube, bulked out with shots of Fraser being thwacked with some generic crunch noise and falling backwards with his feet in the air.
Though not as turbo-charged as the original, it's funnier and less politically off-putting.
Starts confidently, before panicking itself into potty melodrama.
Has a certain grim integrity, but it's also criminally boring for long stretches.
As Nicholas Sparks adaptations go, this one's both endearingly join-the-dots and surprisingly un-crass.
What saves the movie, which is quite flawed but still Scott's best in nearly a decade, is its majestic feel for the English landscape.
The story might fascinate if it weren't plunged into a stylistic deep freeze -- when your best sequences are chunks of greatest-hits newsreel, you're clearly in trouble.

As off-puttingly quirky as it all may sound, it's held together with great confidence and a ton of energy. When the dots are finally joined, the sugar-rush of storytelling kismet is pretty exhilarating.
The alternating of multiple cameras allows for a bit more innovation in the story this time, and the supernatural twists in the last reel pay off nicely.
It has the plastic, disinfected aroma of something straight off the assembly line.
The Losers is a ho-hum scraping of the comic-book barrel, which feels particularly needless with both The A-Team and The Expendables on their way.
Hansen-Løve's film is about coping, its focus practical and utterly unsentimental, its energy somehow both busy and serene.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A limply-organised multi-story snoozefest from Jonas Pate.

This is a marginal improvement on the mangy 2007 British farce it's derived from, but it's still stuck with Dean Craig's irredeemably crass script, an anchor of unfunniness (and blatant homophobia) tied around its legs.
Its funniest single line is a reference to the incest documentary Capturing the Friedmans. If nothing in that last sentence makes any sense to you, stay well away.
It's amiable in spots, but making half the characters American gives it an unfortunate am-dram feel, replacing the local flavour we want with a cheap sort of additive tang.
Thanks to the guiding hand of director Kelly Asbury (Shrek 2) and sweet voice work in the leads by James McAvoy and Emily Blunt, it's not bad at all.
Midnight in Paris is a breeze: a bauble, but a jolly one.
Once you've seen the remake of Footloose, it really doesn't seem like such a bad idea.
Broomfield goes at the subject with his customary dogged stoicism, which is never less than good fun, but this is one Columbo episode where the culprit barely needed help being brought to task.
Blazing interviews with Angela Davis and Stokely Carmichael supply stinging and unforgettable rhetoric: it simply can't fail with footage this wild.
Gomez, looking every bit the child bride, keeps strutting her actressy ambitions like a pushy diva hogging the dress-up-box.
Ever the cerebral essayist, Soderbergh isn't in this for edge-of-your-seat thrills - his approach is more cold sweat than burning fever.
Herzog is so unendingly sincere he's able to press emotional buttons that your average documentarist just wouldn't get away with.

movie_review_blurb: For all the brutality of the confrontation with knife-weilding, car-nicking local scum - think Stanley knives gouging out tongues - it's never far off ludicrous.
The disinterring of corpses makes this film almost too ghoulish for its own good, but Iceland's top director Baltasar Kormákur wraps it up in his distinctive frostbitten style.
To describe this holistic-healing comedy as anything other than terrible would be gross dereliction of duty, but I'll make one concession: it's kind of meant to be.
Dour and schematic drama about disenfranchised factory workers.
Full of folksy humour but next to no urgency, it's a strangely exasperating slice of humdrum world cinema.
movie_title: El Baño del Papa (The Pope's Toilet) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's as precious and disarming as Weber's films always are, albeit with even more slo-mo shots of wet mutts at the seaside than usual.
In a tale of passion, don't we want passion? Instead of Rivette's painterly pose-striking tableaux, would we not like some madness and modernism?
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Shot in luminous, high-contrast black and white, it has the rugged if faintly self-important authority of a Hemingway short story.
Hauntingly photographed by Robbie Müller, it's one of this hugely uneven filmmaker's crispest, finest moments.
movie_title: Alice in den Städten (Alice in the Cities) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: The end of a golden run for Judd Apatow.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Such a big grey blanket of misery it should have been called "Eternal Cloud Cover".
At best the movie's an unpretentious pile-up of B-movie clichés, but why "Requiem"? Time to give it a rest now.
A generous portrait of a community, past and present, reflecting on their unexpected contribution to the cinema.
Watchably silly at best, it's the political thriller as an unintentional comedy of errors - 24 meets Noises Off.
This is hardly a new idea by now, and Romero does it to death with ponderous musings about camcorder culture and the ethics of stopping to look, not to help. Intermittent fun, though.

All credit to writer-director Oliver Parker for trying to broaden his CV, but Danny Huston is a terrible bore as Welles, Paz Vega continues to be incomprehensible in English, and the murky mystery plot limps along unrewardingly.
The redeeming thing - and it's really all in Heigl's performance - is that Jane knows she's a silly cliché, and spends most of the movie inwardly wincing at her own haplessness.
A war drama about waiting, and the director, Joseph Cedar, does a terrific job hanging danger and crushing tedium in the air, side by side.
Astonishingly sexist.

Based on yet another Marvel series, Iron Man has plenty of things going for it, the main assets being an enjoyably sardonic Downey, his hardware, and the downturned mouth of his new metal visage - a warning that this self-styled messiah means business.
Made of Honour, as well as flaunting one of the most useless titular puns in the history of cinema, is rubbish.
The movie gets plain silly, but at least it's lively, and young girls will enjoy Nim's lifestyle in her eco-friendly and frolic-packed tropical paradise.

There will surely come a point when the mythology around Salford's most famous rock group will run dry, but it hasn't yet: this superbly made documentary by Grant Gee deserves to sit on DVD shelves everywhere as a companion piece to Control.
I approached with a mixture of dread and resignation. And was promptly charmed to pieces.
The movie is prettily done in a fairly obvious way, but there's little insight into the emerging nationalist movement, which remains at best a shimmering backdrop in soft focus.
It never fully convinces you that he deserves a movie.
Needlessly cruel comedy.
Across the Universe is much too literal-minded to be the far-out, visionary folly she may have intended - not so much cinema on LSD as the ravings of an earnest hippie in a recovery programme.
Like Foster's character, Erica Bain, the movie makes a tortured show of conscience, then trades it in for a leather jacket and a semi-automatic.
A bona fide work of genius.
We may wonder if happiness can be bought this way, and whether the film being sold to us isn't a slightly suspect package, but Smith, sublime and moving, sells it regardless.
If only all reputed turkeys gave us such a trip.

Few of the characterisations could fill the back of a matchbook, and, in refusing to see RFK as anything other than a liberal messiah, the film meanders through its political context with a white stick and a dopey smile.
The Italian denim company Meltin' Pot paid for Rankin and Chris Cottam's unendurably pretentious stab at gangland street spirituality. Why?
Suspenseful, eventually, but the first half's a snooze.
This mechanical cash-in fails to explain how the young Hannibal Lecter became the monster we know.

Sorry? If Cole Porter put his name to Barrymore's "Figuring out you and me/Is like doing a love autopsy..." he'd surely have been thrown out of the Waldorf-Astoria in disgust, whatever he was wearing.
Guest goes for big, crude laughs every step of the way, and only a few of them come off.
A machine might have directed this, but it has a few more welcome touches of comedy than the first one.
Eastwood has made one of the most quietly devastating war movies of our time.
Carrey tries hard to parlay his usual mad mugging into serious mad mugging, but Joel Schumacher isn't the director to get him there. Count Schumacher's films - 23 really is a bad number.
As a grotesque parody of the hillbilly-terror genre, it has a real wit and energy.
Wearily spins straw out of its none-too-original premise.
It's as silky, chic and instantly forgettable as a perfume advert.
A decent enough calling-card picture that swaggers even as it stumbles.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: You know you're in trouble the second you take a look at Bruce Willis's fake liver spots.
It's impressively adult, sure-footed filmmaking, and that Best Actor nod was definitely deserved.
The problem isn't that it's painful to endure, but that it's a rather easier watch than it should be.
Like the most heavily-effects-budgeted shoulder shrug in history.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A sincere but doomed attempt at a sort of Alzheimer's love story.
Yes, it's grappling with grown-up subject matter, but did The Interpreter have to be quite so lifeless?
The wrath of Brad looks more like a migraine.
Anton Walbrook is on peerlessly maniacal form.
It's exciting to see a British horror film with intellectual ambition -- it's not often you get to hear Noel Clarke quoting Rilke -- and some superb, eerie compositions.
There aren't many British horror films you could call Bergmanesque with even slim justification, but Christopher Smith's Black Death is out of the ordinary.
The choreographed routines and editing have such dizzy energy they carry it aloft.
Quote not available.
We expect more than just craftsmanship from Fincher -- we expect bite.
Playfully subversive and oddly life-affirming.
Deeply serious, sombre, long and humourless, it reeks of integrity. Eastwood's best since Unforgiven? Maybe, but it's the one I'd least like to sit through again.
A perfectly executed illustration of what is not, quite, great about the Coen brothers, which is a kind of grandstanding, and another kind of weirdly alienating insincerity.
A standard-issue spy game with all the layered complexity of Ludo.
Bounces around like the smarter and weirder older brother of Spielberg's Catch Me If You Can.
Anomalous and mesmerising.
Another probing case history of male pathology from one of the most consistently interesting American film-makers alive.
Joltingly funny.
Has the pointless verisimilitude of an expensively rendered computer simulation.
Gibson wears a rictus of distaste which seems more suggestive of dodgy on-set catering than the horrors of combat.
A vast repository of hoary, honour-code clichés.
Should have the late O'Brian beaming in his grave.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Demonstrates to us all that it's possible to touch the void and bounce back unbroken.

There's no denying that Million Dollar Baby packs some unexpected wallop in its latter stages. But Hawks and Siegel would never have put their name to anything this pretentiously sombre from start to finish.
It's a wisp of a film, touchingly earnest but light on point.
Lee Tamahori's ludicrous thriller is as straggly and ill-judged as Cage's rotten crop.
Dogs swimming aren't scary.

Director György Pálfi is a talent to watch with your fingers over your eyes, but he's also a proper filmmaker, fascinated by his characters' hereditary fetishes and finding consistently clever ways to surprise us with his camera.
The story's handled at a reasonable clip, and there are some good, if uniformly bearded, supporting performances.
It is endlessly imitated and spoofed; it is also an august pinnacle of high-risk, high-art filmmaking, and one with a reputation for being far more forbidding and humourless than it actually is.

No one would argue that this slight six-hander is one of Resnais's greatest movies, but it's far from an embarrassment, and even its strained comic business is enclosed within a prevailing atmosphere of wistful resignation.
It may sound like cute family entertainment, but the dog's no good - he's unappealing and looks depressed.
An amusingly tense saga of literary con-artistry.
David Lean paints heartbreak with perfect decorum.
Like watching the back-story of Harry Potter's shy Japanese cousin.
A film at odds with itself.
The passage to ex-rental DVD bins will be swift for this lethally pretentious bit of low-rent schlock.
Low-budget with a subtle script and real, rounded characters.
There are shades of the excellent Brian De Palma/John Travolta thriller Blow Out (1981) in this eerie little effort.
A great example of that time-honoured genre, the biopic so silly it plays like a spoof.
Lead couple Lily (Loren Horsley) and Jarrod (Jemaine Clement) are such unoriginal, checklist misfits that there's little about them to celebrate or even stomach.
Ali Larter plays an amazingly bitchy actress sent to Bollywood. They hate her, then they love her. I didn't quite get the love bit.
Set aside any lingering preconceptions you might have about Lawrence, and prepare to be entranced.
Messages, as Sam Goldwyn famously advised, are better left to Western Union.
What justified filming Dominic Leyton's play Collision is hard to see, but the decisions taken in opening it out are what truly wreck Gary Love's misbegotten attempt to do so.
Part folk musical, part occult chiller, and quite mad.
This is no biopic, but pure fantasy, a sort of "Molière in Love" infused with the bittersweet romantic spirit of the playwright's work.
It's crisp and engaging, and bodes well for all involved.
Dumont (L'humanité, Twentynine Palms) mounts the brutish combat sequences with undeniable small-scale skill, though his constant see-sawing between images of sex and death verges on the masturbatory.

there's something about its overblown stormy-night atmospherics and reliably dismal dialogue that's bad in almost a fun way. I'd rather laugh through this kind of harmless, rickety schlock, any day, than grimace through Saw III.
Country rapists have their way with Gillian Anderson and poke Danny Dyer's eye out. The duo want payback.
It's the poor man's Police Academy VII: Mission to Moscow.
This is well worth investigating.
Engaging and stimulating.
Every scene in Bujalski's films is a little awkward, and just right.
The kids are good; the effects are appalling.
Empty and narcissistic New Wave homage from the unashamedly pretentious Christophe Honoré .
Doesn't hold many surprises.
Quite, quite ludicrous in every way.
Has a script faxed in with spotless fidelity from Planet Unfunny.
Faux-documentary masterpiece
movie_title: The Battle of Algiers (La Battaglia di Algeri) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: Kit out the Bates Motel with surveillance cameras, replace Anthony Perkins with the ineffectual Frank Whaley, and you'd have the location for this irritatingly cheapjack snuff-horror thriller, starring Luke Wilson and Kate Beckinsale as a depressed couple
A much better showcase for his talents
Quite the worst supernatural thriller ever made starring Jeff Fahey. This is saying something.

Diane Kruger hopes for a moment of ultra-low-budget indie cred as the title character, an emotionally fragile model whose catwalk days are numbered. The ferociously ugly digital photography shares her pain, while making the thing borderline unwatchable.
The film of the week is 30 years old and hasn't aged a day. It's John Cassavetes's Opening Night, a truly mesmerising study of anxiety and identity crisis in theatreland.
Gamble on the movie, by all means: it has its low-key pleasures. But perhaps safer to fold, and hope Hanson deals us an ace again soon.
Captivity is an abomination, and perhaps a new low in the torture-porn genre: a film I liked even less than Hostel.

You know where you are with Bruce Willis. Unlike Schwarzenegger, he won't be moving into namby-pamby politics any time soon. He differs from Stallone these days in managing not to resemble an aborted experiment at Madame Tussaud's
If it's a relic you're determined to catch at the movies this week, check out Edmond.
Letting things slide into a sort of low-calorie moral vacuum, Mackenzie hasn't so much nailed LA's culture of skin-deep gratification as produced an advert for it.
Dull historical epic set during the Indian massacres of 1947.
As it bounds along with its pumping rock playlist, you start to realise that the movie is predictable and slightly scared, and that it doesn't really make sense.

It's Leo, with her pained and battered magnetism - half-pleading, half screw-you - who shakes the film out of its occasional glibness, notching up the performance of her career in thrilling, hungry style.
The more recurrent noise towards the end was me groaning with disappointment, that a movie which had struck gold with its central matchmaking was succeeding so ruthlessly in taking the shine off.
If anything, you wish for a bit more bite and artistic daring.
The film's best hope is black comedy - it's certainly impossible to take seriously - and yet crazy amounts of it are socked over as bombastic, overedited melodrama.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Not what anyone would call playful, this film's passion for weaponry and covert ops springs from a disturbingly sadistic and joyless place -- all it lacks is waterboarding.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: They fight, and look rubbish, and one eats an aircraft. Is bad the new good? I wish. Sometimes bad is just tacky.
I have my doubts about Cassel in this role, but the movie peaks with enough brute urgency to stoke your hopes nicely for part two.
Directing with a wink and some style, Jaume Collet-Serra (House of Wax) knows that it's possible to be totally absurd and witty with it -- he has that trash touch.
This self-penned adaptation of his 1994 short story collection - a period piece set in 1983 Los Angeles - has supposedly been cut to ribbons, and it shows.
Originality is perhaps the major missing component, but this still stacks up as a nifty debut with ideas and ambition to spare.
This adaptation of Larry Doyle's bestseller is too soul-starved and lethally bland to warm the cockles.
It's like a pre-teen Pulp Fiction.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Broken Embraces is a riddle, wrapped in a mystery, inside a slightly overindulgent parade of gushing film references.
The film has some obvious problems - it sprawls, and goes on too long. But it's funny in such a thoughtful, rounded, adult way, and deflects sentimentality so confidently, that it won me over anyway.

An ideal version of this film would be painful and playful, and a good deal less cluttered. But the one we get certainly has delightful moments. After any exposure to this year's unfailingly smelly mainstream romcoms, it's a breeze.
Beyond mildly risqué bisexual assignations, the filmmaking isn't terribly adventurous, but cinematographer Roger Pratt gives it an inky opulence, and it's quite watchable.
Arnold works wonders almost everywhere in this film: the drip-drop drabness of kitchen-sink drama is stilled, alive, and newly dangerous.

An almost perfect atrocity. It is a towering K2 of bobbins... the most mangy, noxious, charmless, sexist, racist, unfunny, infantile, stomach-turning, grotesque, clueless, inept and stupid film of the year.
It's hard to take your eyes off Moschitto's bulldog-like antihero - with his dangerous lips and furtive power plays, he makes Vincent Cassel in Mesrine look like Dale Winton's camper twin.

It's not fair to say that the film runs out of steam towards the end, because it remains crisp and unpredictable, but it does have the feel of an addictive Outer Limits episode finding ways to stretch itself over the feature-length mark.
Sure, this threequel is more plasticine than Pleistocene, but as a zippy summer diversion it'll do more than nicely - in fact, it's comfortably the best of the series.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: How long can a numbskull comedy about primitive dudes sustain itself before the laughs run dry? Year One has the answer: about ten minutes.
Hate the songs. What a lot of hair they have. Don't ask me the names.
We're in the twilight land of the sensitive indie ensemble piece, something American stars gravitate to for reasons of range and prestige, but which ends up being more cathartic for them than for us.
The diabolical m.o. in these things is never really satisfactory, and even the fun of the conceit is somewhat muffled by the film's lurid colour design and headachey close-ups.
Plays out with such daunting high-mindedness it makes The Reader look like Transformers.

Last Chance Harvey is a funny little thing - a perfectly sincere July-to-September romance with barely an ounce of irony in its DNA, just a lot of optimism and good-humoured smiling. It's refreshing, in its unforced way.

Sugar, winningly played by the complete newcomer Soto, isn't a cut-out ingenu but a testy, competitive, driven but fallible person. The road he follows is modest, but the film is beautiful and searching in letting him find it for himself.
An eerie, caustic, surgically calm film about the skull beneath the skin of genteel English life.
This French thriller hurtles along with hardly a pause.
It's a good deal too stagey to work as a thriller, but the location shooting on desolate mud-flats is resonant and the twist has a sick verve. Addictive stuff.
It's lively, sturdily mounted, just ever so slightly jejune.
Tiny things happen oversignificantly in this indulgent British effort set in 1960s.
His period war spectacular Red Cliff may be better than several of his American blockbusters, but it falls some way below the absurdly entertaining Face/Off.
The cast bring a level of reality to this that's surprisingly impressive.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Hangover serves up a steady stream of big, dumb laughs, but you may feel a gnawing sense of guilt right afterwards.
"On the piss. On the pull. On the menu", quoth the poster, but munching on Dyer looks like it might pose a health risk even for the undead. Hideous, all of it.
This is shocking, it suggests David Fincher's The Game shot by crackheads running around with cheap DV cameras.
Bay's is a cinema on steroids, pursuing a body-builder's dream of eternal growth -- it must bulge constantly outward, veins popping like twigs from its ever-flexed biceps.
It's frightfully sincere and the sex scenes are a whole new level of unconvincing.
The Disappeared makes you jump once or twice, but it's a dubiously overcooked horror-thriller.
What an unexpected treat this turns out to be - as messy and riotous as a kindergarten food- fight, with teacher tied up in the corner.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Tristan Loraine has grand schemes in the pipeline, but this absurd stab at sub-Tom-Clancy conspiracy thrills won't help his credentials. When Craig Fairbrass is your closest thing to a badge of quality, be afraid.
movie_title: 31 North 62 East (Too Close to the Truth) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The advances up for grabs date the script instantly to a jollier time for publishing, but it's more of a bummer that Lesley Manning's direction is of the plonk-the-camera-anywhere variety.
This won't go down as much of a success story for Mendes, but, unlike his more grandiose projects of late, it's not a complete dead end.
This is an addictive and stimulating experience all round.

The movie's keen to show off its period threads and craft solo acting moments, all of which it does entertainingly, but we can't quite see the ties that bind: these feel like five characters in search of a common gene pool.
movie_title: Le Premier Jour du Reste de ta Vie (The First Day of the Rest of Your Life) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A bizarrely tasteless pet-euthanasia subplot -- clumsy parallels with the Holocaust abound -- is merely the wackiest turn the wildly unconvincing script takes: it's well below Poliakoff's more intelligent TV work.
Blokey whimsy can work, but when it's misfiring there's a high risk of being left down in the dumps.
Wants to be a Sex and the City for the Soho queen scene, only without the sex.
For all that's wrong with Nativity!, there's something apt and endearing about how this sketchy, second‑rate production pulls its socks up for the climax.
A little long, but quietly rewarding.

Kelly's obsessions are not entirely like anyone else's, which is a recommendation of sorts, and he shoots more beautifully than ever, which is another. I won't give up on him when his films are still this richly textured and high on their own ideas.

The last half-hour is a tense team scramble to get out, and stay out, but the best move in this above-par shocker is digging right back into the claustrophobic emotional traumas which made Part 1 so thrilling.
It's a faithful adaptation, but one that's been indifferently shot by director Steve Jacobs, whose blunt technique tends to flatten the book's morose charge. Still, the acting is often excellent.
Steven Soderbergh is very much in experimental mode with this chilly, downbeat Manhattan drama.
In a word: awful.
Sadly it loses track of its own best ideas, pledging itself to a dreary set of surviving characters whose choices carry no charge.
If you need a working definition for bad Jarmusch, look no further than The Limits of Control, which functions more as a wilful act of self-pleasuring than worthwhile experiment.
A keen, scruffy, colourful and buoyant film.

The pace rarely slackens throughout, the set pieces are explosive, the score relentlessly thunderous. Victorian London is recreated - relying on copious use of computer effects - with an eye for the grimy reality.
The film does a fair amount of squirming itself, but not before giving honest and hilarious thought to the carnal intricacies of the whole project.
Nine proudly luxuriates in its perfumed idea of Cinema Italiano, but it would be a lot easier to recommend if there were any decent tunes to whistle on the way home.
Quote not available.
For anyone on the outside looking in, the insulation of the characters from real danger makes it a bit of a drag.
It could be the least erotic thriller ever made, unless die-you-bitch catfights through broken attic floorboards constitute some sort of kinky subgenre.

Emmerich's vision of global huddling and new-dawn optimism has a harebrained naivety you almost want to treasure, but that's this idiot behemoth of a film all over: dim, dim, dim, and so absurdly overscaled that we're not supposed to mind.
The movie's winsome artificiality may drive you bananas.

The odd thing is that Love's version feels so bright and breezy, as if he's cosying back up to a wider audience who were turned off by Outlaw's grimy nihilism. If that's the case, it's a wacky choice of subject, but the effort's appreciated.
The line between worthy and pompous is a tightrope right the way through, and the filmmakers don't have the shoes for it.
A sad, searching piece of work about the reluctant labour of a great idea.
Cabin fever in space is a durable idea for horror, but the main feeling this one from the Resident Evil gang is likely to inspire is cosmic déjà vu.
It's muscular, dumb entertainment, edited like gangbusters and with villains who want to blow up the entire Parisian underclass.
It's fitting that Zombieland ends up in an amusement park, because it basically is one. You get your money's worth.
It's not a comedy. It certainly isn't funny.
This fervid extravaganza is easily Park's best film since Oldboy.

Gilliam's imagination rubbing up against his constricted budget, and CGI showmanship is not on any level his forte. You miss the hand-made charm and extravagant matte-work of Brazil, even Baron Munchausen.

The pleasingly goofy personality of the first film has hardened dismayingly. This one's all rain, mud, blood and grim jungle duels, the balance tipping firmly towards bone-crunching fisticuffs rather than acrobatic stunt-work.
Tight as a drum and the most inventive spin on a zombie-plague premise in years.
The film reminds us of a tactile, cut-and-paste subculture that's still alive and well in the internet age.
The absence of that free commodity, narrative surprise, makes it a movie whose resourcefulness you can applaud -- I wish Price well -- while secretly being glad you didn't pay to see it.
I found it hard to warm to this overlong documentary about new trends in reggae, perhaps because of the sense that all the less savoury aspects of that culture were being softballed.
Where it needs emotive magic, it lays on a vague and maudlin religiosity -- we're never quite sure what Acker thinks he's preaching. 9? I'd give it a 6.
A lot of valid points are scored in passing against the celebrity-industrial complex, but there's not enough real news here.
At its best, this revamp gets the eerie oppressiveness of London fog and Marley's rattling chains just right -- we all know the moral, but Zemeckis does remind us what a spine-chilling yarn it is.
Woolcock doesn't strictly glamourise this guns-'n'-babymothers lifestyle, but her shortcuts to gritty pathos are nearly as questionable.
Either someone missed the memo about other people's LSD trips being a colossal drag, or else they fed it to a goat.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Daniel Barber's luridly brutal debut goes quickly way over the top.
The kind of passable in-flight entertainment you could watch half-asleep.
There's enough vitriolic bitching among the bullying contingent to make Jon Wright's movie trashily entertaining up to a point.
Godard and his great cinematographer, Raoul Coutard, translate the ideas into some of the most visually exuberant French cinema of the Sixties.
movie_title: Pierrot le Fou (Pierrot Goes Wild) (Crazy Pete) (1969)

movie_review_blurb: I didn't hate Max Payne, but it's hard to summon up strong feelings of any kind about something so slick, remote and vacuum-packed you barely feel you've seen it.
it's a close-to-definitive example of how to make a great play work on film, for all the very slight air of Hollywood compromise.
I could call the film an important document, but it's far more rowdy and vital, and amazingly unpretentious, than that makes it sound.

A quiet film to inspire quiet admiration, Kenny Glenaan's wistful character piece has a lovely asset in Robert Carlyle - often a careless chooser of parts, but a gentle, sensitive actor in his element here.
A tidal wave of corn syrup hardly mars this old-style, populist entertainment.
Jacques Maillot's enjoyably retro crime drama, which fits itself out with enough period bangers and bad moustaches for an entire Jean-Pierre Melville retrospective.
Dean Spanley, adapted from a shaggy-dog tale by Lord Dunsany, is a decidedly odd business, a rummage in mothballed obscurantism for its own sake.
movie_title: Dean Spanley (My Talks with Dean Spanley) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Soderbergh directs like a tactician at the map-table, ever assessing the importance of the next ridge. This is of some interest, but he has overthought it, and muddled the importance of Che himself, who cuts an aloof and reproving figure.
The movie makes a ridiculous ass of itself, but as a run-for-the-hills endurance test for straight men everywhere, it's almost fascinating.
Zwick's films (Glory, The Last Samurai, Blood Diamond) are always well-mounted, in their pedigreed and worthy way. But they nag away at us like pious busybodies, and this is no exception.

Langella is the reason to see the film, smuggling his lugubrious Tricky Dicky well past the script's limited grasp. It's a superb performance, looming like a spectre over the words and deeds of "misunderestimated" politicians everywhere.
It's not Demme's most polished film, granted - but dysfunction is all the more piercing when you don't put a gloss on it.
Pompous and dour attempt at a psychological horror movie.
It's an amusingself-portrait which you want to indulge, but the film around it is so brash, manic and pleased with itself it may be difficult.
We allow the movie its fantasy of first love, if not its pretence of indie credibility.
Wittier by the reel, Bolt is can't-miss family entertainment, and a glad relief from the solemnities of award season.
Vicky Cristina Barcelona, Woody Allen's latest comeback, is nothing like the return to form his apologists claim, but it's not terrible, which is a mercy after his grim trio of British projects.
It's good, at best, for a drunken DVD night, with a script that's amazingly witless when it isn't lazy, and a climax that criminally wastes the gory possibilities of a large shredding machine.
This team have smoothed over the details of Biggie's rags-to-riches ascent, they haven't succeeded in making it terribly interesting.
There are antics with fake ghosts and fish sausages - rather too many, but you've got to laugh.

Gervasi's film may be too slight to launch an assault on the genre's Citizen Kane, the amazing Metallica: Some Kind of Monster, but it's still immensely entertaining, and its nostalgia for an era of big crowds and bigger hair has a pleasing tenderness.
Patrick Creadon's film is a lucid history lesson in the failures of successive Republican presidents to put a stopper in the country's leaking fiscal hole.
A village-pillaging extravaganza whose music and pitched slaughter compete to ruin your inner ear.
Where most pictures about families end with huggy closure, this one ends in splinters, in pain, and with five different kinds of sudden, desperate hope.
It's twisty, provocative and impressively grim, a sort of Asian-extreme Manhunter for the strong of nerve.
It's a glum and amateurish business on the three-in-one subject of adoption - being adopted, having your child adopted, and adopting one.
Beautifully-drawn Japanimation about a time-hopping schoolgirl, by turns wondrous and a little too hyper.

Although the film features some hair-raising footage and striking location photography, there's far too much dust and not enough glory in Dust to Glory.
While it's deeply disturbing and often difficult to watch, Downfall is a towering achievement that shouldn't be missed.
The D in the House of D refers to Detention -- which is where David Duchovny should be sent for writing, directing, and starring in this earnest, self-consciously quirky coming-of-age mess.
Pure, unadulterated sentiment served up with a straight face, The Game of Their Lives is a middling depiction of one of the all-time great underdog stories in sports history.
It's a gripping, frequently infuriating story of greed, hubris and 'creative' accounting that unfolds as a tragedy laced with scathing black comedy.
movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's an amiable enough diversion that unfolds like a bland cross between When Harry Met Sally and Serendipity.
Schrader's Dominion: Prequel to the Exorcist may be slightly more literate than Harlin's dopey schlockfest, but this deadly dull and pretentious film is ultimately just as bad.
There's precious little of the wonder and charm of the original Stars Wars films in this big, loud, and mostly empty spectacle.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Leanly muscled British actor Daniel Craig gives a star-making performance in Layer Cake, the latest in the recent wave of stylish and ultra-violent gangster films from across the pond.
The redoubtable Ms. Fonda is the main attraction in Monster-in-Law, which generates just enough laughs to raise it a notch above serviceable.
Tell Them Who You Are has a powerful emotional resonance that transcends its Hollywood setting.
Kingdom of Heaven is often stunning to behold. Regrettably, the director's grasp of narrative and pacing is far less assured on this film.
Offers viewers an extraordinarily revealing portrait of the soldiers' lives in Baghdad, and how they weather the stress of being under constant siege.
This beautifully made and haunting film is ultimately explicit without being exploitative.
It's impeccably acted, handsomely produced and far too leisurely paced, with little in the way of narrative intrigue or genuine emotional tension.
A remarkable and compelling film you won't soon forget.
'Screenwriter' Wayne Conley's idea of side-splitting dialogue is to have characters repeatedly tell King to "kiss their black ass." Or announce that they just "pooted."

A lively blend of epic silliness and very droll British humor, The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy is that rare sci-fi comedy where the special effects complement, rather than overwhelm, the story and characters.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Unfolds on an abstract, almost dreamlike level outside the bounds of traditional narrative.
Unless Solondz can break out of this freakish rut he's created for himself, he may become the directorial equivalent of a palindrome himself.

A provocative urban morality play, wherein archetypal characters give voice to the seething anger and bitter disappointments people usually keep to themselves, and people make sweeping generalizations about each other based on race or class.
Genuinely frightening and tightly constructed thriller, which holds you till the final frame.
An offbeat charmer.
Zatoichi: The Blind Swordsman is ultimately so entertaining, with its oddball mixture of tongue-in-cheek humor and exciting fight sequences, that you're more than willing to overlook its flaws.
An absorbing courtroom drama well worth watching.
The filmmakers' morbid preoccupation with the grim circumstances of Plath's downward spiral throws Sylvia off balance and into the realm of highbrow melodrama.
A poor man's version of a David Lean-style romantic epic, Beyond Borders has reportedly been in development for years. Perhaps it needed to stay there a little longer.
While there are certainly laughs to be had, and the backgrounds are frequently ravishing, Brother Bear is frankly a bore.
A wickedly funny parody.
Widely imitated but never surpassed.
Intriguing, frequently confusing, but mostly entertaining, Matrix Revolutions wraps up the trilogy's narrative loose ends in a reasonably satisfying fashion.
A bloodless, clumsily told drama that stubbornly refuses to come alive.

Director Joe Dante ... and screenwriter Larry Doyle have achieved the impossible: they've actually managed to drain every last ounce of irreverent wit and joyful silliness out of the classic Warner Bros. cartoon characters.
In this era of loud, frenetic and frequently moronic would-be epics, Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World is the hugely entertaining exception to the rule.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Consistently engaging and intelligent.
A balanced, insightful portrait of the provocative hip-hop icon.
Whether you regard 21 Grams as an audacious work of art or a maddening exercise in cinematic pretension, one thing is certain: you won't forget it.
The cinematic equivalent of a lump of coal in your stocking.
Although the film's episodic structure sometimes relies too much on contrivance to propel the narrative, In America's charms ultimately outnumber its flaws.
Every so often, a film comes along that is so original, imaginative, and just plain flat-out wonderful that you can do little but marvel at the filmmaker's artistry.
A poignant and thoughtful depiction of the need for forgiveness and reconciliation.
Although truly painful to watch at times, Monster nonetheless deserves to be seen, if only for Theron's startling tour-de-force performance.
It should be required viewing for all political and military leaders.
movie_title: The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara (2003)

movie_review_blurb: For all its flaws ... House of Sand and Fog is a quietly devastating film.
This handsomely mounted and beautifully filmed drama sustains your interest for most of its running time and features fine performances across the board.
A cringe-inducing mixture of tired slapstick and gooey sentimentality.
You leave Paycheck feeling as if you've just watched a big-budget version of a made-for- television movie.
A satisfying and believable portrait of a rock and roll band's struggles to succeed.
[Minghella] has, to a considerable degree, succeeded at bringing Frazier's Civil War-era version of Homer's The Odyssey to the screen with remarkable fidelity.
Almost completely devoid of narrative tension or intriguing characters, The Statement is the surprisingly bad work of a normally reliable director.
This sweeping and marvelously entertaining adventure is the work of a prodigiously gifted filmmaker operating at the very top of his creative powers.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Predictable hijinks ensue between the mismatched couple en route to the sappily romantic fade-out.
More labored than inspired.
One of the most profoundly moving and inspiring documentaries in recent memory.
Despite strong performances by leads William H. Macy, Maria Bello, and Alec Baldwin, this romantic drama about a perennial loser beating the odds in Las Vegas is predictable and unconvincing.
For Burton, it ranks with Ed Wood and Edward Scissorhands (1990) as one of the director's most emotionally satisfying films.
For all its flaws, Japanese Story gives Collette a welcome chance to shine in a lead role.
Uneven but ultimately absorbing adaptation of Dennis Lehane's best-selling novel.
An understated and quietly moving drama.
A frustratingly uneven film that's alternately compelling and clumsily handled.
A lyrical coming-of-age story that casts a potent spell.
Despite the breathtaking visuals and Lee's obvious reverence for the source material, The Hulk ultimately rates as a disappointment.

Packed with enough intrigue, bloodletting, poisonings, and betrayals to fuel a half dozen melodramas, The Legend of Suriyothai is the kind of rousing, old-fashioned historical epic that Hollywood rarely makes nowadays.
A breezy, largely enjoyable 'fish-out-of-water' comedy that lacks the zip and freshness of the first film.
A smashing example of bravura filmmaking.
Horror-movie fans looking for a good scare won't be disappointed in 28 Days Later.
A sunny, wonderfully romantic alternative to the special-effects driven summer blockbusters, I Capture the Castle is the essence of charm.
While certainly not a bad film, Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl nonetheless rates as somewhat of a disappointment, given the talent involved.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Strip away the music video-style imagery and eighties-flavored rock soundtrack from Garage Days and you're left with a forced, self-consciously 'wacky' comedy that's more frantic than genuinely funny.
A goofy, pratfall-laden guilty pleasure.
An entertaining summertime diversion that doesn't assault the senses.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A caustically funny alternative to the overblown epics now playing the multiplexes.
Short on belly laughs.
Although there are welcome moments of humor and warmth, The Magdalene Sisters is frequently painful to watch.
The cinematic equivalent of a three-car pile-up, this stupefyingly unfunny romantic/mob comedy is DOA from the opening credits to the bitter end.
The Princess Blade boasts some of the most dazzling fight choreography in recent memory.
A one-joke horror comedy that rarely capitalizes on its wacky premise.
Alternately frustrating and disappointing, Casa de los Babys is truly one of Sayles' lesser efforts.
A charmless and almost completely witless endurance test that demonstrates once and for all that it's time for Allen to take a very long sabbatical from filmmaking.
There's not one moment in Secondhand Lions that feels genuine or heartfelt.
Lost in Translation's artful blend of romance and cross-cultural comedy is just the tonic for audiences weary of big, dumb, loud summer blockbusters.
An entertaining addition to the caper comedy genre of films.
A moving and frequently haunting story of loss.
Too shallow to work as either a nasty black comedy or an emotionally compelling drama.
A drab, would-be romantic comedy that plays with the archetypes and imagery of the western to little or no effect.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the Midlands (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A deadpan social comedy, idiosyncratic love story, and provocative meditation on life and art all rolled into one entertaining package.
A rousing addition to that most American of film genres, the western.
A saccharine and shamelessly manipulative piece of fluff.
There's no there there.
Demonstrates that the filmmaking duo should perhaps confine themselves to English period dramas.
There's no emotional pay-off to The Battle of Shaker Heights, which doesn't so much end as trail off into the credits.
You leave the theater impressed but unmoved by Winterbottom's arresting vision of the bleak near-future.
2004's barely begun and already we have a prime contender for the year's worst movie.
A middling effort that should have been much better given the caliber of the cast.
A nonsensical and overwrought update of The Bad Seed.
One long action sequence that leaves you spent, rather than exhilarated.
Quite possibly the worst movie of Levinson's career -- and that's saying something, considering he also directed Toys, Jimmy Hollywood, and An Everlasting Piece.
The snappy one-liners, stereotypical characters, and labored narrative contrivances are all here in this episodic romantic comedy -- all that's missing are commercial breaks.

Although the sheer scale of this production is undeniably impressive, there's little grandeur or sweep to this would-be epic, which lacks both the visceral power and genuine pathos of Ridley Scott's Oscar winner Gladiator.
At times shocking in its brutality, Carandiru is also a humane and profoundly moving film about men struggling to hold onto their humanity in hellish conditions.
A film that deftly captures the offbeat wit and empathy of Tyler's prose.
Frequently exciting.
A sharply written, directed, and acted character piece brimming with good-natured laughter and real affection.
A cheerfully subversive comedy send-up of fundamentalist religion.
Torjan has absolutely zero grasp of pacing or narrative structure.
movie_title: Carlos Castaneda: Enigma of a Sorcerer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A snoozer.
A colorful, fast-paced, and enjoyably old-fashioned adventure comedy.
A tedious schmaltz-fest that feels more like the work of the cinematically challenged Ephron than the supremely gifted Spielberg.

Shamelessly manipulative, utterly predictable and often laughably maudlin, this earnest tearjerker is also strangely watchable, like one of those afternoon soap operas that hook you, even though you know it's a glossy piece of hokum.
An invaluable record of the media's role in a war that some analysts have likened to the 'quagmire' of Vietnam.
A stunning achievement, an emotionally charged period drama that unfolds with the tragic inevitability of a Joseph Conrad novella.
The Village is a film wherein the whole is sadly less than the sum of its eerie parts.
It leaves you hungry -- for a better movie.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A bittersweet and wryly funny coming-of-age film of considerable charm and perceptive intelligence.
An entertaining spy thriller thankfully free of the campy, tongue-in-cheek excesses of the recent James Bond films.

Farrell and his equally fine co-stars Wright and Roberts comprise an embattled but fiercely loving trio whom you care about deeply, even if A Home at the End of the World ultimately fails to realize the promise of its absorbing first half.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Depicts potentially sensational material with intelligent restraint and gritty verisimilitude.
Not even Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn at their peak could salvage Laws of Attraction.
While I, Robot is consistently entertaining and considerably smarter than your average summer action flick, it's never particularly exciting or emotionally compelling.

The SNL veteran's willingness to do anything for a laugh, no matter how humiliating or juvenile, keeps the laughs flowing pretty steadily in this fast paced send up of seventies era news anchors in all their blown dry, polyester glory.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A straightforward action film that's slightly more literate than the usual Jerry Bruckheimer production, but ultimately just as bereft of real emotion and bona-fide tension as the uber-producer's other films.
Intelligently written, sumptuously produced, and dramatically inert.
After a taut and involving beginning, it gradually degenerates into an awkward and unconvincing blend of character study, marital drama, and kidnapping thriller.
Exceptionally smart and tenderly romantic.
Compelling and relevant documentary.
One of the better adaptations of a John Irving novel.
A small-scale charmer that gives audiences a healthy dose of silliness.
Ultimately commits the cardinal sin of never being very frightening.
What should have been a tight, crisply told narrative becomes a lumbering bore under Scott's self-impressed direction.
If you have the stomach for it, this engrossing documentary sheds additional light on a controversial figure whose case continues to incite debate.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An overheated melodrama that plays like an art-house version of the gloriously awful Wild Orchid.
A must-see for anyone interested in one of the most turbulent periods in recent American history.
A fast-paced compendium of Jerry Bruckheimer-style clichés.
A surprisingly watchable B-movie thriller with its fair share of nifty twists.

Although it lacks the flair and edgy wit of Miami Blues, The Big Bounce is an unpretentious and funny caper comedy that gives you far more bang for your buck than most of the dreck currently playing at the neighborhood multiplex.
There's not a moment in the film's belabored 115-minute running time that feels emotionally authentic.
Resorts to tired shtick and soap-opera-level tensions to drive its points home with all the subtlety of a brick flung through a window.
A profoundly moving story that demonstrates the power of art to enlighten and entertain.
A gripping account of men braving the elements, Touching the Void, is not to be missed.
It's doubtful that anyone involved in Catch That Kid ever considered this anything more than a paycheck.
It's not even as funny as National Lampoon's European Vacation, the worst of the four Chevy Chase films.
A highly personal and deeply satisfying look at an enigmatic and often maddening genius.
To see The Passion of the Christ is to feel brutalized.
You may not have the time of your life, but Dirty Dancing: Havana Nights is a perfectly serviceable date movie propelled by some electric dancing and tangy salsa music.
Although Hidalgo is frequently exciting and has been handsomely produced on a grand scale, you can't help but wonder what either Spielberg or Cameron could have done with this material.
Starsky and Hutch is a rarity: a big-screen parody of an old television series that's actually pretty good.
There are a couple of decently staged fight scenes, but there's no visceral charge to this visually undistinguished and monotonously formulaic action film.
As if we need further proof that Perry is not cut out for movie stardom -- either Almost Heroes or Three to Tango would suffice -- The Whole Ten Yards confirms it.
An understated charmer inspired by true events.
An apt name for this inconsequential effort: You'll definitely want to take a break from watching it.
A much smarter and more engaging film than its smutty premise would suggest.
Squanders the comic potential of the source material through poorly timed gags and hit-or-miss one-liners.
Modest in the best sense of the word, this traditional animated film adheres closely to the gentle, easygoing tone of the hugely popular PBS series.
A belabored, obvious comedy that's only good for a chuckle or two at most.
An extremely routine entry in the Disney animated canon.
This handsomely produced historical drama never fully engages your attention.
Although very young children may enjoy its garish blend of splashy visuals and sophomoric humor, viewers over the age of eight will find this sequel to 2002's Scooby-Doo a crushing bore.
I'll take Manhattan.
An engrossing, densely plotted thriller.

What had been an intriguing, character-driven narrative steeped in gritty period detail like The Name of the Rose degenerates into the art-house cinema equivalent of C.S.I., without that series' narrative drive and economy.
There's not one moment that's even vaguely fresh or original in the screenplay, which blithely dispenses with anything resembling logic or plausibility, not to mention wit and heart.
Asylum proves that even the most talented actors can't always transcend inferior material.
Well worth seeing on the big screen, Memoirs of a Geisha is ultimately a film you admire, rather than embrace.
An intense, viscerally charged thriller that stays with you.
The Fountain is not an unmitigated disaster -- just a disappointment from an undeniably talented filmmaker.
Beautifully shot, but dramatically inert.
The humor feels forced -- there's a smug, jokey quality to most of it -- and it rarely cuts deeper than your average sitcom quip.
The film's ultimate descent into laughable implausibility is regrettable, for there's so much that's otherwise genuinely impressive about the boldly realized, yet wildly uneven Apocalypto.
An impassioned synthesis of concert film and political exposé about the rock group System of a Down's intensely personal campaign to stop genocide.
The Yacoubian Building is a flawed, yet ultimately illuminating film worth seeing.
The filmmakers have the taste and good sense not to trash White's classic by lacing their narrative with pop culture references.
Dreamgirls is undermined by its stop-start pacing and sketchily developed characters.

What should be a ripping good yarn, powered by high voltage stars, instead comes across as another of the director's audacious but unsuccessful experiments -- a cinematic curio where form takes unfortunate precedence over narrative.
The third and best cinematic adaptation of W. Somerset Maugham's 1925 novel, The Painted Veil is a beautifully mounted and incisively acted period piece, bristling with intelligence and caustic wit.
Handsomely crafted and impeccably acted by an all-star cast, this quietly riveting and meticulously detailed film presents a fascinating portrait of Cold War-era espionage.
Spanish writer/director Joaquin Oristell brings 2006 to a mostly delightful close with Unconscious, a clever and sweetly risqué period farce brimming with frothy charm and tongue-in-cheek wit.

Painfully devoid of charm, wit, and ingenuity, this interminable, tongue-in-cheek slough through Fairy Tale Land is so jaw-droppingly awful, the executors of the Brothers Grimm literary estate should consider taking legal action.
Unlike Spike Lee's School Daze, Stomp the Yard barely explores the social dynamics of its university setting beyond the fraternities' 'step' competition.
A heartfelt work of radiant simplicity and plainspoken eloquence, Sweet Land offers viewers a lovely reprieve from overproduced, marketing-driven studio schlock.
A monumental achievement.
movie_title: Verdict on Auschwitz: The Frankfurt Trial 1963-1965 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Graced with honest performances by the entire cast, The Italian is nevertheless a frustrating disappointment that promises much more than it ultimately delivers.

Miller bears an uncanny resemblance to Sedgwick and gives a striking, emotionally raw performance that deserves a much more richly imagined and vividly rendered narrative backdrop than the superficial one provided by Factory Girl.
What should be a zippy, good-natured parody of genre elements instead becomes a labored, almost oppressively stylized cinematic pastiche that's only sporadically engaging.
movie_title: Fah talai jone (Tears of the Black Tiger) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: For all its many virtues, not the least of which are its ambition and its obvious intelligence, Seraphim Falls is an honorable disappointment.
Incredibly powerful -- and never more so than when the filmmakers turn their cameras on the Yokotas and other victims' families, many of whom channel their pain and anger into political activism.

You could almost overlook the chemistry vacuum between Bruckner and Dancy, but the shots of actors leaping and morphing into wolves are so cheesy that they make the bargain-basement special effects in Teen Wolf look Oscar worthy in comparison.
A substantive and fairly balanced overview of 'Citizen Nader's' decades-long rise and sudden, precipitous fall from liberal political grace.
Playing a ditzy control freak of a mother with serious boundary issues, Keaton comes across as such a screeching, flailing flibbertigibbet that you want to give her costars tranquilizer dart guns.
Bleak yet never completely despairing, this superbly acted and richly atmospheric film has a gravitas and thematic complexity that's sadly absent from most contemporary American films.
Any film celebrating the power of imagination is always welcome. Due to its rather pedestrian execution, however, The Bridge to Terabithia ultimately comes up short.
A solid feat of filmmaking across the board, Breach brings a long-awaited end to the drought of good movies at the multiplex.

For a film touted as a lurid, blues-themed Southern Gothic melodrama evocative of William Faulkner at his most decadent, Craig Brewer's Black Snake Moan turns out to be a disappointingly tame and rather conventional morality play.
While Pinkston does a serviceable job and makes an all-too believable nerd, he's neither charming nor funny enough to give the material the extra spark it so desperately needs to engage us.
Dissipates the series' smart blend of satire and slapstick with its threadbare plot, excessive running time (even at 84 minutes), and pedestrian direction.
An important and timely film that may make you think twice before downing your next cup of joe.
An artful, quietly moving hybrid of documentary and narrative cinema.
movie_title: The Cave of the Yellow Dog (Die Hohle des gelben Hundes) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: While longtime admirers of the brothers' animated shorts and music videos will undoubtedly love it, there's an airless, oppressively stylized quality to the film that ultimately proves more wearying than exhilarating.

There's so much that's very right about Casino Royale -- from the knockout opening action sequence in Madagascar to the sizzling chemistry between Craig and Green -- that you leave the theater happily shaken and stirred.
Although Feast will never be mistaken for a masterpiece of the horror genre, on its own 'grindhouse cinema' terms, it mostly delivers the gory goods.
Riveting, profoundly unsettling yet remarkably even-handed.
There are a couple of bravura, action scenes that crackle with ingenuity and excitement, but all too often, Renaissance plods when it should sprint.
In the end, there's so very much that's charming and inventive about Gondry's highly personal film that you're willing to forgive its storytelling lapses and immerse yourself in The Science of Sleep.
No more than mildly amusing, save for a handful of scenes that hint at what it could have been.
A sweetly old-fashioned, tail-wagging charmer of a family film.
[Director Frank] Flowers seems more interested in playing with narrative chronology than developing an emotionally and thematically coherent storyline populated by multi-dimensional characters.
Featuring vivid supporting performances from Simon McBurney and Gillian Anderson, The Last King of Scotland is one of 2006's best films to date.
All hail, Dame Mirren!
One can only imagine the smart, satirical spin that Mike Judge (Office Space) could have put on this run-of-the-mill comedy, which is surely destined for the 'reduced for quick sale' bin at Costco.

Despite its jazzy energy and many stunning set pieces, Scorsese's latest film is a regrettably uneven addition to the director's canon, paling in comparison to such classics as Taxi Driver, Raging Bull, and Goodfellas.

Expertly juggling the film's quicksilver shifts in tone from pitch-black comedy to domestic drama to emotionally acute character study, Field directs with an assurance that belies his relative inexperience behind the camera.
Hopefully, 49 Up won't be the last chapter in this bittersweet, elegiac, and profoundly insightful documentary series.

Happily, there's Walters, a terrific character actress who keeps Evie convincingly life-size, even when she's carrying on in full grand dame mode. Thanks to her, Driving Lessons never stalls to a halt.
There's no cinematic Wonderland awaiting the unfortunate moviegoer who follows Terry Gilliam down the rabbit hole into the drearily awful Tideland.
A humbling and inspiring chronicle of one man's tireless efforts to save the life of his terminally ill younger brother.
A towering achievement for Eastwood and his cast and crew.
Copying Beethoven is all too reminiscent of those glossily ersatz biopics that Hollywood used to crank out in the 1930s and '40s.
F**k ultimately has little that's substantive to say about the most polarizing expletive in the English language.
Fur barely scratches the proverbial surface of its complex subject. You'll ultimately learn far more about Arbus by studying one of her photographs than by sitting through this pretentious bore.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Flaws aside, Wrestling With Angels: Playwright Tony Kushner is still worth a look for its glimpse at one of the leading voices of 21st century American drama.
A delightfully silly and laugh-out-loud funny animated comedy, Flushed Away bodes happily for future collaborations between DreamWorks Animation and Aardman Features.

Fans of the first two films in the series can expect more of the same in this serviceable yet unduly bland G-rated comedy that's all too reminiscent of those by-the-numbers Sixties-era Disney films that usually starred either Fred MacMurray or Dean Jones.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: One of the casualties of all this digital-effects wizardry is a sense of emotional immediacy. There's a conspicuously remote quality to much of the movie that drains the film of the visceral energy it so desperately needs to make an impact.
A stomach-churning gore-a-thon pandering to viewers' basest appetites for violence, Saw III is a repellent piece of schlock that manages to disgust and bore you, often simultaneously.
...A richly nuanced, at times shattering film that brings Inarritu's Death Trilogy to a stunning close.
While it's a bit haphazardly organized and offers only a cursory analysis of the drug war's impact on the city, Billy Corben's second documentary is ultimately as compelling as any pulp yarn.
In the end, it comes across as more of a gimmick than a bona fide film.

An entertaining and smartly paced blend of concert footage, media clips, and behind-the-scenes interviews, Shut Up and Sing is a provocative and insightful documentary of lives under very public fire.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Wafer-thin -- it has about as much depth as your average sitcom -- Sleeping Dogs Lie mixes standard dysfunctional family comedy with sappy romantic moments, albeit none too successfully.
A frequently dazzling display of cinematic sleight-of-hand from writer/director Christopher Nolan, The Prestige is an entertaining, handsomely produced period thriller.
Unfortunately, Salazar's cinematic skills do not extend to the musical realm, for the song and dance numbers in 20 Centimeters are charm-deprived, uninspired, and ineptly directed and choreographed.
An unfocused and overly episodic drama that emotionally truncates what could have been a richly textured saga of an Indian family torn between assimilation and tradition.
Pride is a watchable if overly superficial film that nonetheless builds to a genuinely stirring conclusion.

Journey From the Fall deserves commendation for its intelligent and nuanced account of the Vietnamese refugee experience. Kudos to Tran and his fine cast, many of whom had never acted before, for making this moving and artfully crafted film.
Aside from a handful of scenes, the fourth version of Finney's pulp novel may induce drowsiness, rather than goose-bumps.

An audience favorite on the film festival circuit, The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters is a laugh-out-loud funny and rousing documentary that's far more compelling than the would-be summer blockbusters crowding the multiplex.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A breezily funny showcase for the rubbery-faced Atkinson's signature character, a near-mute buffoon partly inspired by the similar antics of Jacques Tati.
What could have been a galvanizing and all-too timely account of religious fanaticism turning violent has instead been reduced to the banal level of an Romeo and Juliet-type love story.
A passably entertaining hodgepodge of sword-and-sandal film clichés and Arthurian romance.
A top contender for the summer's worst comedy...
For anyone bored silly by the formulaic drivel churned out by the studios, Exiled is like a blast of cinematic adrenaline.
Freshman Orientation barely rates a passing grade.
A strong argument for birth control and 2007's worst comedy to date.
A terrific, old-fashioned western, proof positive that sometimes, they do "make 'em like they used to."
A former storyboard artist, Davis orchestrates the film's nearly wall-to-wall action sequences with breakneck precision and exhilarating verve -- the more outrageous the mayhem, the better.
The analogies drawn between the Ishkanani and the Osborne social circle come off as insufferably precious, rather than thoughtful.
A captivating fable, told with heartfelt eloquence and restraint.
In the end, Kohn's one-note approach diminishes, rather than intensifies, the impact of Manda Bala.
This intermittently riveting and atmospheric film nevertheless ends on such a bewilderingly abrupt and unsatisfying note, you wonder if there's a missing reel.
It's overlong, exhaustingly so, and barely held together by the flimsiest of narratives.
Except for the breathtaking Australian landscape, there's little to recommend about December Boys.
As refreshing as a tall glass of iced tea with mint on a hot summer's day, Junebug is one of the year's most beguiling films.
Dramatic tension and narrative momentum are MIA.
For a narrative that's positively overflowing with dramatic intrigue, Elizabeth: The Golden Age is only fitfully compelling.
A brilliantly shrewd and maddeningly elusive figure, controversial lawyer Jacques Vergès alternately fascinates and repulses in Barbet Schroeder's gripping documentary.
movie_title: L' Avocat de la Terreur (Terror's Advocate) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: So relentlessly earnest and maudlin it makes Hoosiers look like a Martin Scorsese film, The Final Season is the latest and worst sports-themed underdog story to get the big screen treatment.
A smart, low-key charmer.

Yet another misbegotten live-action remake of a beloved Saturday morning cartoon, Underdog is a negligible family film that's so blandly formulaic, it makes the original, '60s-era cartoon look downright edgy in comparison.

A monumental achievement, 17 years in the making and financed by Kaye himself, Lake of Fire reveals Kaye to be a far more thoughtful and mature filmmaker than his loose cannon public persona suggests.

The ridiculous and the sublime collide, with tragicomic results, in Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea, Chris Metzler and Jeff Springer's lively, fascinating chronicle of "Paradise Lost" in the Southern California desert.
movie_title: Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Alternately gripping and frustrating, Trade is a regrettable disappointment.
Although The Darjeeling Limited pales in comparison to Anderson's best film, Rushmore, it's still a vast improvement over the director's last and worst film, The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou.
No better or worse than its video game-derived predecessors, hack-for-hire Russell Mulcahy's tired schlockfest blatantly rips off other, infinitely better sci-fi chillers.
A poor man's version of a Judd Apatow-style raunchy romantic comedy.
Engaging but overly glossy.
That Bar-Lev takes such care to depict them as complex, foible-laden individuals who can't be pegged either good or bad is one of the great strengths of this intriguing and provocative documentary.
