Although it paints a somewhat idealized portrait of the legendary rocker/political provocateur, The U.S. vs. John Lennon is nonetheless a fascinating, richly detailed documentary.
About the best that can be said for this clunky mixture of tired stereotypes, obvious gags, and on-the-nose social commentary is that it's relatively short, clocking in just less than 90 minutes.
A vivid and impassioned chronicle of unwavering moral courage under extreme duress.

A beguiling, deceptively simple slice-of-life drama, shot cinéma vérité style, Offside reaffirms Jafar Panahi's preeminence as one of the most humanistic and socially progressive filmmakers in contemporary Iranian cinema.
It's got wit, heart, and razzle-dazzle to spare.
A wisp of a film, dramatically threadbare, and saddled with a brittle and affected performance by Williams.
A real waste of time.

There's not a whiff of freshness in all of Are We Done Yet?, which goes for the very lowest common denominator in terms of laughs -- and still misses that broad mark 99 3/4 percent of its seemingly interminable running time.
A jazzy, whip-smart, and mischievous account of the one of the great literary cons of the twentieth century.
A fascinating and eye-opening chronicle of work and class issues in contemporary Mexico.
By and large, the characters in Disturbia do all the dumb, reckless things we've come to expect -- and rightly mock -- in cheesy suspense flicks.

More silly than suspenseful, this sleekly produced, high gloss piece of trash isn't quite in the so-bad-it's-good category of schlock films, but it comes mighty close, thanks to a gonzo twist of an ending.

Stephanie Daley ultimately stays with you is chiefly due to Tamblyn, late of television's Joan of Arcadia. She gives a penetrating, stunningly unaffected performance that should be remembered, come award season.
Only the third feature film Lawrence has directed since the surreal black comedy cult favorite Bliss (1985), Jindabyne marks yet another triumph for the director.
This cruddy-looking, Rip Van Winkle-esque slough through 1980s-era pop culture detritus joins an already crowded field of contenders for Razzie recognition at year's end.

[Goyer's] reliance on pointless montage sequences to push the dawdling narrative forward reduce an eerily intriguing idea for a character-driven supernatural thriller to just another mopey wallow in teen angst.
Wind Chill suffers from an underdeveloped screenplay, which feels like a first draft, erroneously deemed ready for production.

Normally appealing actors Eric Bana and Drew Barrymore generate zero sparks as the unlikely couple, whose low-wattage romance apparently bores Hanson as much as it does the viewer, for he devotes far more screen time to poker than their relationship.

Frankly, it's a wonder that stars Jane Fonda and Felicity Huffman didn't belly up to the bar alongside Lohan, once they read Mark Andrus' screenplay, an atonal, ersatz mix of garden-variety family dysfunction and rank 'chick flick' clichés.
The narrative momentum and comic energy begin to flag right about the point Shrek and his sidekicks begin their quest for Artie, who's an exceedingly bland addition to the cast of characters.
One of the year's best films to date.
Sunshine is also an atypically humorless entry from Boyle, who's never made a film this oddly devoid of personality.
Stodgy rather than sweeping, with precious little of the wondrous excitement conjured by Alfonso Cuaron in Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This stylish and sophisticated film loses its way in a frustratingly vague third act that's more unsatisfying than unsettling.
Danes, radiant with intelligence, warmth and common sense, captures your heart. Sadly, the same cannot be said of Evening.
A galvanizing, infuriating and sometimes heartbreaking look into the red tape-snarled morass of the American health care system.
A resoundingly mediocre film that commits the cardinal sin of tedium.
One of the year's most compelling films to date.
Overly long and often listlessly paced.
See it if you're a fan of serious, literate drama and virtuoso acting.
Hollywood's reigning auteur of raunchy romantic comedy, Judd Apatow, scores a near-knockout with Knocked Up, his extremely funny and sweetly endearing follow-up to The 40-Year-Old Virgin.
Bug holds you in its disturbing grip until the genuinely shocking denouement.
Alternately exciting and exhausting, Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End may occasionally sail off course, but it never runs completely aground.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Robert Tannen's first-produced screenplay certainly doesn't lack for story -- or clichés, for that matter. Nor does Tannen skimp on trite, predictable plot twists, or well-worn, stock characters in his pedestrian script.
Corneliu Porumboiu's drolly witty black comedy 12:08 East of Bucharest is an understated gem, infused with gimlet-eyed humor, weary pathos and surprising tenderness.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Fine acting distinguishes Aurora Borealis, a moderately affecting seriocomic character study marred by a weak, tidily resolved third act.
Absurdly overlong skit masquerading as a feature film.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's a shame that Yimou didn't spend more time honing and refining his awkward narrative into a film that's ultimately greater than the sum of its many, emotionally engaging parts.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A likable, low-key charmer that has 'crowd pleaser' written all over it.
Sumptuously produced and terrifically acted, this lively and pricelessly funny depiction of a fiery romance in Regency-era England is an across-the-board triumph.

Known most for his 2003 Oscar-nominated Foreign Language Film Evil, Hafstrom does no more than a perfunctory job of guiding his attractive stars through the overly methodical paces of Derailed, which builds to an implausible climax.
The zingy wit and ingenuity of the film's early scenes gradually fades, as Zathura becomes an increasingly repetitive series of action sequences, each noisier than the last.
Swiftly paced and wonderfully atmospheric, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire will satisfy both the most ardent Potter-philes and newcomers to the Rowling franchise.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A crisply acted and occasionally exciting ensemble film undone by murky plotting and thin character development.
Unless you're dying to see a pale imitation of the Farrelly brothers' brand of broad romantic comedy, just say no to Just Friends.
A surprising misfire on all counts ...
An emotionally powerful record of a remarkable little boy's fight to live.
Manages to be cloying, insulting, and self-serving in equally dire measure.

To her vast credit, Brown doesn't attempt to psychoanalyze Van Zandt, or linger over the dark times in his short life in Be Here to Love Me. She instead keeps the focus where it should be: on the lasting gift of Townes Van Zandt's 30-year career.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A hokey, post-apocalyptic jumble of clunky storytelling, tin-ear dialogue, and ineptly staged action sequences.
It's not that we don't like the 2nd Earl of Rochester; it's that we simply never come to understand the man known as The Libertine.
An exhilarating, stupendously produced example of old-fashioned movie magic by a filmmaker working at the very height of his creative powers.
A richly compelling and challenging film that ultimately transcends its weaknesses.
An unexpectedly endearing comedy.

The famously elusive filmmaker transforms the legendary story of Captain John Smith and Pocahontas into a poetic, ravishingly beautiful meditation on the collision of two cultures in 17th century Virginia.
While not a complete fiasco, this Screen Gems release mostly fails to get your pulse racing -- a cardinal sin for a thriller.
It's a visually arresting and intermittently compelling parable about racism and self-determinism that's ultimately too arch and pedantic for its own good.
The third and very least of the films based on Lady Windermere's Fan, A Good Woman proves itself to be downright bad.
To describe Annapolis as formulaic would be a gross understatement.
One of the most deeply affecting movies ever made about the Holocaust.

It's a slight film, to be sure, but this understated and plaintive depiction of a romantic triangle gone fatally awry in rural Ohio is much more involving -- and less annoying -- than the idiosyncratic filmmaker's past 'experiments.'
There's very little pay-off to this overlong and murky psychological thriller.
Derivative in the extreme, this labored snore of a supernatural-action film is a needlessly convoluted pastiche of tired elements from both The Matrix and Blade trilogies.
It ranks with The Fog of War as one of the best political documentaries of the last few years.
Almost everything about the film seems off, from the timing of the gags to the bland power-pop music score.
Filmed in breathtaking locations in Western Ireland and the Czech Republic, Tristan & Isolde is a disappointingly passion-free romance.
Even though Hostel is certainly better than last year's Saw II, it's ultimately not very frightening -- just plain gross.
Whatever else you may think of Boll's directorial 'skills,' you can't fault him for inconsistency -- his movies are always atrocious, and Bloodrayne is no exception.
This polished, impeccably acted and mercifully shtick-free morality play manages to come across as both overwritten and schematically rendered.
Smartly observed and good-natured, this political satire is Brooks' most winning film since Defending Your Life (1991).
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Through the Fire is a well-crafted and illuminating documentary.
These days, cinema doesn't get any more relevant than Paradise Now, Hany Abu-Assad's gripping and insightful drama about two Palestinian terrorists preparing for a suicide mission.
Wryly funny and refreshingly sophisticated for most of its running time.
Even a master fantasist of his daring vision and whimsical humor cannot turn a frog of a script into a prince of a film.
An exercise in predictability.
movie_title: De zaak Alzheimer (The Memory of a Killer) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Cannon's appeal is overshadowed by both his vanity and the dull, by-the-numbers quality of the filmmaking.
The misses ultimately far outnumber the hits.
While downright silly and often unintelligible The Transporter 2 moves so fast that you have just enough time to suspend disbelief and strap yourself in for the ride.
A sweetly engaging homage to the dizzy screwball charmers of Hollywood's golden age, The Baxter is a happy surprise enlivened by its cast's appealing performances.
This earnest and contrived story of an aging rancher estranged from his daughter-in-law meanders predictably towards the inevitable reconciliation, without ever feeling genuine.
The Man basically flatlines whenever Levy's off screen, becoming the most disposable buddy comedy in years.
Arrestingly beautiful.

An emotionally harrowing film that's probably too downbeat for general audiences. But for the more adventurous viewer seeking provocative fare, Kerrigan's third film confirms that he's a filmmaker of acute sensitivity and psychological nuance.
An entertaining, true-life 'fish out of water' story worth catching on the big screen.
This fast-paced and undeniably intelligent film still qualifies as a disappointment.
When it's not launching an all-out assault on your tear ducts, this calculated piece of supernatural fluff does have moments of real charm.

While scrupulously intelligent, literate, and sardonically funny, John Madden's reportedly faithful adaptation of David Auburn's Broadway hit never quite breaks free enough of its theatrical origins to feel like a bona fide film.
Etheridge-Outzts doesn't tweak the well-worn slasher formula enough, or generate any real scares, to make his film anything more than just a gay spin on a gore-splattered exploitation film.
Mind-numbingly awful.
Although it's certainly watchable and has some striking moments, Flightplan is ultimately a middling effort that lacks dramatic pay-off.

The film's few, scattered moments of honest grit and pathos are nearly drowned out by composer Trevor Rabin's incessantly syrupy score, which sounds calculated for maximum emotional uplift, just like almost everything else about Gridiron Gang.
A visually stunning and quietly moving film of rare beauty.
A family film that even adults may enjoy.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Domino is a convoluted and hyper-stylized bore, a frenetic pastiche of black comedy, bullet-strewn violence, and pulp fantasy. In short, a typical Tony Scott (Man on Fire) film.
An important film that should be seen by many.
The Squid and the Whale represents Baumbach's own coming-of-age as a gifted filmmaker. Put it on your must-see list.

Banderas and Catherine Zeta-Jones still sizzle as the crime-fighter and his equally fearless wife, but their playful banter takes a back seat to the convoluted narrative, an unwieldy amalgam of swordplay, tiresome family drama.
Waiting needs more scenes with true bite, rather than tired shtick about stoner bus boys, rude customers, and 'The Game.'
[There is] little to hold your interest beyond the surreal imagery and occasional flashes of droll wit.
A small-scale triumph.
Moore is such a warm and vibrant presence that she alone makes the movie worth seeing.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Into the Blue should be thrown overboard -- preferably somewhere in the Bermuda Triangle.
Ultimately more cloying than poignant.
A gripping film, cogently written and terrifically acted, that unfolds with emotional gravity and flashes of gallows humor.
Wallace & Gromit: the Curse of the Were-Rabbit is a visually dazzling wonder that will delight audiences of all ages.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Let's hope this movie hasn't come out too early in the year to be remembered for a well-deserved Razzie.
The film's one-note dialogue, insufferable characters and lack of scares make Saw II just a tedious exercise in explicit violence.
Nothing to write home about.

Peaceful Warrior begins promisingly, with welcome doses of quirky humor holding the syrupy bathos at bay, yet it ultimately becomes just another average inspirational, sports-themed flick, albeit with an overlay of New Age philosophizing.
A testosterone-driven, Jerry Bruckheimer-style action film as overblown as its title suggests.
Featuring an appealing cast led by Romain Duris, the film has a frothy charm that's hard to resist.
Masterfully restrained yet frequently nerve-wracking, with sequences on par with Hitchcock at his most tension-filled, this film is one of Melville's best.
A predictably gruesome compendium of splatter-movie clichés, See No Evil is a reprehensible exercise in lowest-common-denominator filmmaking that disgusts and bores in equal measure.
Genuinely inspiring and free of the drippy platitudes found in most sports-themed films, The Heart of the Game is an exhilarating triumph.
With affectionate humor and quirky, low-key charm, first-time documentary filmmaker Patrick Creadon leads us on an engaging tour of the world of New York Times/NPR puzzle guru Will Shortz.
All too often emphasizes tired, unconvincing shtick at the expense of substance and genuine wit.

This bright, fast-paced adaptation of Eric Orner's syndicated gay comic strip may not break any new cinematic ground, but its sharp, zingy wit and underlying sweetness deftly compensate for the occasional awkward patch or glaring narrative contrivance.
movie_title: The Mostly Unfabulous Social Life of Ethan Green (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Keenly observed and beautifully acted, Danny Leiner's The Great New Wonderful is a seriocomic gem of rare grace and psychological nuance.
A well-meaning but ultimately unsatisfying film.
Long thought to be impervious to everything except Kryptonite, the Man of Steel ultimately falls victim to another, even more insidious force: a frustrating, hit-and-miss screenplay.

If there's scarcely an original moment in this breezy lark of a quipfest/cautionary tale, it's a dead-on, pricelessly funny send-up of the cutthroat, back-stabbing fashion world, where a size-6 dress size is cause for alarm.
A haunting, frequently unsettling documentary about the blurry line between madness and genius.

While it has some spectacular set pieces and dollops of goofy, wisecracking humor, Monster House rests on such a flimsily constructed narrative framework that it starts collapsing in on itself, long before the predictably over-the-top conclusion.

This daring film may not completely hold together, but it has a bracing, off-kilter sensibility -- a mixture of mordant humor and melancholy -- that mostly compensates for the occasional lulls and clunky, obvious moments.

Currently shooting his third film in England, Allen has seemingly traded his beloved Manhattan for London. But as the appealing yet utterly forgettable Scoop shows, the change of scenery hasn't done wonders for his career.

Both poignant and stirring, Neil Young: Heart of Gold is a must-see for all fans of Young, the alt-country pioneer whose genre-spanning career has encompassed everything from folk to hard rock to electronica.
Burns simply doesn't delve deeply enough into his characters for them to have sufficient emotional resonance for the viewer.
An amateurish hodgepodge of drama clichés and tired music video-style techniques, Crossover is a baldly contrived narrative.
How to Eat Fried Worms is an innocuous, coming-of-age, 'gross-out' comedy that quickly fades from memory, almost before the final credits roll.
It may not be a complete success, but when Andre 3000 pays homage to Cab Calloway, Idlewild is hard to resist.
Insufferably glib and blatantly contrived, Bart Freundlich's Trust the Man is a witless, charm-free snore that manages to be puerile and condescending, often simultaneously.
The Lower City is a disappointing picture that's less than the sum of its sporadically involving parts.
The Illusionist is an enthralling, grandly old-fashioned example of storytelling magic well worth seeing.
Lackadaisically executed on every level.
Shimmering with beautiful imagery and heartfelt emotion, House of Sand is a triumph.
Quote not available.
The perfect tonic to this summer's bloated, special effects-driven extravaganzas, Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby crosses the finish line with flying colors.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There's barely enough of a story to sustain a short film, much less a feature.
... a visually inventive charmer that nimbly juggles slapstick comedy, action sequences, and coming-of-age 'life lessons' with a refreshing minimum of sap.
Although it's more amusing than laugh-out-loud funny, Accepted has a good-natured irreverence and ragged charm, thanks to a spirited ensemble cast of newcomers led by Justin Long.
X-Men: The Last Stand brings the mutant superhero trilogy to an immensely satisfying conclusion.
Filmmaking lapses aside, this is an impassioned and generally persuasive film that rings all too eerily true.
A labored pastiche of familiar dystopian motifs that beats the same, totalitarian-themed drum over and over again.

And therein lies the chief problem with Winter Passing: there's very little nuance to -- any of the characters in Rapp's meandering narrative, which the first-time director wraps up on an emotionally pat note that doesn't feel earned.
A hypnotic, ruminative examination of class, religion, and sexuality in contemporary Mexico, Carlos Reygadas' Battle in Heaven is cinema at its most polarizing.
While it may be too oppressively downbeat for some viewers, Little Fish nonetheless represents another triumph for Blanchett.
Sorry, Haters fails to register as anything but a hollow piece of cinematic provocation.
Without ever getting strident or sanctimonious, the film vividly demonstrates the potential hazards of trying to export American-style democracy overseas.
Aquamarine touches on tried-and-true coming-of-age themes -- developing self-esteem and overcoming fears -- but does so with a winning light-heartedness.
Flat-out awful in almost every respect, Ultraviolet will hopefully drive the final nail in the coffin of the sci-fi/action-babe genre.
You don't go to The Shaggy Dog expecting anything more than what it delivers -- an innocuous family comedy enlivened by some winning slapstick gags. Man's best friend would approve.
There's not a false note in the film, which unfolds with a casual grace similar in tone and feel to the work of David Gordon Green.
While it's sometimes obvious, Hafstrom's film is so emotionally satisfying on a gut level -- like Rebel Without a Cause -- that it holds you from start to finish.
An acutely observed study of a man haunted by the looming prospect of failure, Game 6 turns out to be a small-scale triumph.
V for Vendetta is ultimately worth seeing, if only for its adamant refusal to play it safe and the passionate commitment that Weaving and Portman bring to their roles.
A tonally inconsistent coming-out story that wavers between earnest drama and dopey teen sex comedy.
Aside from a few moments of quiet pathos that ring true, Avelino's directorial debut is a calculated piece of cinematic outrage marred by on-the-nose dialogue and melodramatic contrivance.
A touching and gently funny testament to the resilience of the Afghan women, many of whom share harrowing stories of life under the Taliban.

Although it's handsomely produced on a grand scale and solidly acted by an international cast, The Da Vinci Code somehow manages to drain nearly all the intrigue right out of Brown's jigsaw puzzle of a religious conspiracy thriller.

Early in RV, the bratty kids take one look at the titular vehicle and pronounce it a 'big, rolling turd.' The same can be said for Barry Sonnenfeld's woefully unfunny family comedy, a scattershot mess that marks a new low for Robin Williams.
Nothing of real import transpires in 95 Miles to Go, which at times comes close to resembling a glorified home movie.
While it does have some sweet moments and a handful of zingy one-liners, the film all too often resembles a trite dinner theater play that's been minimally 'opened up' for the screen.

Despite a handful of quietly affecting scenes, the film mostly fails to delve beneath the surface of either its gritty narrative or the three protagonists, who mainly come across as cultural archetypes, rather than multi-faceted characters.
A slapdash female empowerment comedy that's crudely executed on every level.
An astonishing, fact-based story of sacrifice and courage in one of the world's most forbiddingly beautiful regions, Kekexili: Mountain Patrol exerts an almost mythic hold on your attention.

There's just simply not one iota of originality to this exceedingly superficial and charm-deprived ensemble film. It doesn't help that most of the characters come across as entitled, navel-gazing twits without a smidgen of depth.
... Clean comes across as a disappointingly shallow picture that pales considerably beside such similarly themed films as Little Fish and the harrowing indie drama Down to the Bone.
Don't be misled by the hyped-up trailers for Inside Man: This is not your average nail-biter of a heist flick, but a clever and witty throwback to the character-driven crime dramas of the 1970s.
... the film's flaws stem from 'TMZ' -- too much Zahedi.
An exhilarating, intensely moving film of bold, unwavering vision, Water brings Meehta's Elemental Trilogy to a triumphant close.
It feels a little churlish to pan an environmentally friendly film that presents kids taking a courageous stand, but Hoot is disappointingly lackluster from start to finish.
We get a fascinating glimpse into Gehry's design process, which always begins at his sketchpad.
The dogs are so compelling to watch that you're mostly willing to overlook the flaws in the picture, which, thankfully, never sinks to the jokey cinematic nadir of Snow Dogs.

Unfortunately, the absence of emotionally engaging characters, combined with the cast's thick, unintelligible accents, undermines what could have been a taut and provocative exploration on the moral price of vengeance.

The Dark Knight is probably the smartest and most stylish action movie since the "The Matrix." It thinks and philosophizes. The subject it thinks and philosophizes about, perhaps not surprisingly, considering the times, is the Iraq war.
Extremely entertaining and well-crafted, Crush The Skull promises a bright future in genre films for Nguyen.
Seoul Searching may be familiar in style to the films Benson Lee clearly loves, but it will tug at the heartstrings of a brand new generation of moviegoers.
For all its flaws, Endless Love's saving grace is that it is not in fact endless and that you will get to leave the cinema sooner or later.
This is a brutally honest look at ALS at every stage of the way, and thus becomes a fairly illuminating and heart-wrenching story.
The film is a big, stupid flop.
Ridley Scott's latest may be the most fantastical film he's ever made.

[Riley] supplements the film with footage and imagery from Brando's public life -- interviews, speeches, clips from his films -- which focuses the film on a central idea, that an actor's personal and private lives are never fully delineated.

The film tries too hard to sensationalize a real-life story that has already been sensationalized enough - the kind that's too strange for fiction - but in doing so undermines the narrative's own weirdness.
movie_title: A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Regardless of its flimsy emotional interior, Ricki is a worthy addition in this year's growing canon of strong female-centred films, and it would be wise to remember Streep's stunning performance come awards season.
As promising as this sounds, the filmmakers don't probe their subjects enough to get a nuanced perspective of these experiences.
Louder Than Bombs never manages to create something whole from its parts, but those parts are occasionally very intimate and well-executed.
Drunktown's Finest oscillates between servicing banal plot machinations and the beautiful, symbolic simplicity of the culture it's representing.
Blackhat works best when it's suggesting visual connections between people and things, cities and tech.
With a foregone conclusion in place, small gestures start to seem ridiculous, even bordering on melodramatic in their microscopic form.
Farewell, Herr Schwarz examines the psychological impact of the shocking news for all three generations through a series of simple conversations with Reuveny.
Though the film defines Paul's life by his relationships, Eden fails to muster the kind of emotional intensity its story dictates.
The result is a disorienting and disappointing experience that finds one thinking a bit too obsessively about how little Dano and Cusack look alike.
Tokyo Tribe is a perfect festival film, a feverish rhapsody that tempers the seriousness of other TIFF films with its astronomic silliness and pitch-perfect urban poetry.
With its pointed use of the present tense, Matt Shepard Is A Friend of Mine attests that his spirit lives on in American history.
movie_title: Matt Shepard is a Friend of Mine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Phoenix's premise is so questionable it's downright unbelievable.
The film feels as spontaneous and digressive as a Charles Mingus composition, and just as paradoxically light and dense.
The film is so labyrinthine it's scattershot -- introducing new characters only to forget about them until it's convenient to revisit -- which renders the film entirely forgettable.

While the more dramatic elements of the narrative aren't 100 per cent perfect in their thriller logic, Equity makes up for it with a multitude of intense, powerful moments in which, to steal a line from Beyoncé, girls run the world.

Farhadi has succeeded in underscoring universal impulses of his characters, despite their cultural backgrounds, and in the process he's also removed most of the socio-cultural context that characterized his previous films.
Café Society may enchant the viewer with its lush visuals and close-ups of Stewart's smouldering expressions, and it may prove sufficiently entertaining.
The final act turns Nerve from crime thriller/teenage drama into a banal morality play.
Our Little Sister does best in small, quiet moments.
It's a shame the Ice Age writers don't try to even out their storytelling efforts throughout the entire film. It might make a prehistoric franchise like Ice Age interesting for adults once again.

Some have called "Afternoon" more a "DVD extra" than a real film, but I disagree-like other Tsai films, it establishes its own slow representation of time and the way human interactions and performances play out.
Dunn's debut is a truly unique coming out story, not to mention a highly original Canadian film.
It's Veep or In The Loop brought to life! But even more absurd and titillating. Weiner proves that truth is stranger than fiction.
Neville is keenly aware of how to show the musicians' kinetic energy onscreen, and he relies on this talent to keep the film consistently alive and moving.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Wonderland is supposed to be some enchanting world. But it's hard to find delight or meaning when Lewis Carroll's original whimsy is treated as a half-forgotten backdrop in a self-serious story.

X-Men: Apocalypse seems to know exactly what it's doing and feels comfortable and confident in its retro, '80s-set world. The film balances its self-seriousness (featuring heartbreaking backstory side plots) with lighthearted humour.

If there's one criticism to be made about such a forward-thinking film, it's the explicit nature of such commentary, which makes Neighbors 2 seem like it's pandering to its 'woke' audience. There is no subtext here, but at least the jokes fill in the gap.
Sometimes a filmmaker's perception of a story's value strays so far from the original that it transmogrifies into something unremarkable, confusing, or dissatisfying.
The film [focuses] so much time on madcap hilarity that it forgot to flesh out its characters. As such, the performers are forced to rely on the superficiality of their natural personas.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Duke of Burgundy is mostly light and playful, an exploration into an unusual relationship that rarely borders on exotizing female sexuality.
This is barely a movie at all, mostly due to its structural similarities to SNL, but also because it acknowledges the fact that its own premises are inherently unfilmable.
...the satirical tone feels off-key and the narrative is disappointingly disjointed but seemingly aware of it, as if it's playfully reveling in its lack of cinematic coherence.
The film is impossible to take seriously as a commemoration of Moultrie's life or Allen's prolific status because of its plethora of contrivances.
Its main character's moral predicament with a woman inside a pit becomes a muddle of confused symbolism and trite psychoanalysis.
At heart a heist movie, snappy and dry in its humor, clever in its elaborate robbery scheme, and somewhat bloated and unspooled in its storytelling.
Susan Seidelman's attempts to provide positive, alternative representations of marginalized people and problems is overly ambitious.
Sergei Loznitsa occasionally writes his ideas too explicitly in the film's dialogue, though he makes up for this by deftly employing some ironic symbolism elsewhere.
The film is the cinematic equivalent of a teenager, making everything more melodramatic than it needs to be, and impatient with the subtle details of life.
It's a testament to Bruce Greenwood's acting that Adan never becomes entirely as insufferable as the words that come out of his mouth.
The film's structure as a character study helps to subtly underscore the flawed justifications of a privileged kid's thought patterns and unchallenged value system.
There's a distinct vein of misanthropic defeat coursing in this film that's encoded into empty gestures and portrayals of people who appear to only be going through the motions.
The film flirts with big ideas about adult relationships, but fails to locate any gravitas about its characters' existential or psychological crises.
A remarkable story made almost unremarkable in the hands of lazy filmmaking.
Given the film's garrulous multitude of characters, one wishes they would all just shut up and sing.
This is action-thriller feather preening, but all the wit in the world can't hide the narrative sprawl that rots from within.
Dominik Moll never addresses Matthew Gregory Lewis's original groundbreaking ideas in The Monk, nor does he rework the material for a contemporary audience.
The film seems to have forgotten, however, that it's still a movie, not a documentary - a detrimental misfire that cancels out its own charms.

Using his signature visual composition and deafening sound design, Steve McQueen portrays the harrowing realism of Northrup's experience and the complicated relationships between master and slave, master and master, slave and slave, and so on.
...it's a solid and well-made drama that avoids its genre's typical tear-jerking traps and hints at awards-season potential.

Using his signature visual composition and deafening sound design, McQueen portrays the harrowing realism of Northrup's experience and the complicated relationships between master and slave, master and master, slave and slave, and so on.
In Closed Curtain, Jafar Panahi has moved past only talking about his story ideas.
It's a genuine pleasure watching these two talented actresses engage on everything from boy troubles to the aesthetic considerations of superhero movies.
...it feels like a calculated articulation of what a serious prestige picture should like instead of an organic and rewarding drama.
The great Errol Morris returns with a slippery profile of the slipperiest of the slippery politicians, Donald Rumsfeld.
The film is so in love with its unoriginal premise that it can't see the forest for the trees, treating reality like an occasionally relevant prop and stalking as a sweetly romantic gesture.

This beautiful film is at its best when it so delicately underscores one of its major ideas, that of learning to let go of a past - a romantic way of life, a virtuous belief system, genteel traditions and rituals - in order to move on with the present.
A calculated prestige picture that never bothers to ask broader questions about the AIDS epidemic.

Network taps into the hysteria of the television business at a time when the medium was still important, a monolithic and competitive media industry hungry to tap into the next big thing and do anything for ratings.
The Thin Blue Line is proof that sometimes, though rarely, the political impact of a film can be as tangible as an innocent man being freed from prison.
It compellingly engages with the specific problems of a cultural group rarely represented in American film, but it too easily and abruptly resolves its main characters' problems.
The embarrassingly low production value of Bernard Rose's 2 Jacks works symbiotically with the film's botched performances.
With its compelling and original approach to its romance narrative, coupled with Paulina García's nuanced and intuitive performance, the film delicately balances an entire octave of emotions.
With Enemy, Denis Villeneuve confidently proves he's contemporary filmmaking's ultimate troll.
Ayoade is adept at toning down the wit when the film becomes more somber and focused on the psychology of its main characters.
The film undeniably deconstructs female sexuality in relation to masculine power, and the baffling nature of that relationship, which is unraveled via the perspective of an alien.
Devil's Knot spends the bulk of its time with two people whose straightforward backgrounds and motives make them much more palatable for a mainstream audience.
This unexpected directorial about-face is what Reitman needed to demonstrate that he's a director with true emotional maturity.
It's beautifully balanced between developing a slow-rising narrative that also takes its time to build characters, without ever veering into precious or sentimental territory.
It's not a complicated or original idea, but one that Table 19 manages to express on genuinely heartfelt terms. You can't hate a movie that courageously wears its heart on its sleeve.
Despite its historical subject, "Hitchcock/Truffaut" adeptly proves the timelessness of cinema.
A movie as forgettable as Nut Job 2 will quickly disappear into the summer haze.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a confusing fictional world to understand, and one that director Nikolaj Arcel fails to bring to life onscreen.
Theron makes Atomic Blonde stylish with her sheer presence.
Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets is colourful, multitudinous, often imaginative, but the lack of a hermeneutic world and internal logic lessens the stakes for the viewer to care about.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The documentary becomes increasingly chilling, because as gruesome as the blood splatters and bombed-out wreckage appear, the Iraqis appear quite normalized given the traumatizing amount of violence.
Think of The Book of Henry as a broken Rube Goldberg machine -- all the cutesy steampunk doo-dads are for naught without proper planning to make it function.

Bigelow's recent work is a cinema of big, difficult questions, but its cold treatment of trauma often leaves an empty impression, one that doesn't make the viewer understand or appreciate the moral implications of evil.
My Cousin Rachel is a damning feminist critique of the status of women in 1800s England, one that demonstrates how the impulsive emotions of men can easily influence the direction of their lives.

Paris Can Wait revels in its embarrassment of riches in the French countryside, but the mature perspective of the 81-year-old Coppola gives the film an emotional gravitas and a cliché-free depiction of a middle-aged affair.
Here we are with The Long Haul - which perfectly describes the viewing experience.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While Certain Women is focused somewhat on the nuance of dialogue and its intertwining with body language, it's a deliberately quiet and reserved little film.
The Lovers is a frank, playful romantic drama.
The Wall may be entertaining and masterfully directed - notable traits for a tiny budget - but it has nothing to say about war survival, other than a reductive depiction of its sheer difficulty.
Colossal may not have the marketing potential to make a billion dollars at the box office, but it might just teach you something and give you a good time in the process.
The zany, over-the-top tone of The First Epic Movie makes it pretty obvious that, like its protagonists, the series doesn't take itself too seriously.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's timely and relevant, given the increasing number of studies coming out that show the connection between social media use and depression in young users.

Katabuchi's distinct method in bringing the protagonist's free-floating, over-imaginative thoughts to life through animation help turn In This Corner of the World into an empathetic and colourful picture.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A beautiful narrative of self-discovery, elegant in its simplicity; Rohmer doesn't have to push hard on his basic premise to find extraordinary meaning.
We get such an intimate glimpse into their personal lives that the film loses momentum and becomes a kind of soap-opera-through-flashback.

Nostalgia has the kind of introspective dialogue that encourages its impressive roster of actors to inflect genuine emotion, and its variety of painful and common experiences lets viewers connect deeply with the material.
The film spends too much time trying to be as meaningful with its comedy as it is raunchy.
So, Steve is yet another useless male character who's hidden his flaws under the professional protection of his powerful white medical coat - so what?
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Professor Marston is a sharp and satisfying mix of film genres - biopic, character study and the sorely missed rom-com - that advance sex positivity in a way rarely seen in mainstream cinema.
The film tries pretty halfheartedly to make us sympathize with Chan's character, who isn't given many lines to show off his signature charisma, yet he's clearly the one we should be rooting for.
Happy Death Day underestimates the fun in Tree's experimentation, and gets there too late.
Rebel is authentic enough to acutely portray the personal minutiae of Salinger's life that made him into a hardworking writer.
A few brushes with satisfactory filmmaking craft is a moot thing to champion in a film this mucked up.
Woman Walks Ahead remains stagnant as a politically correct but enervating historical drama.
Gerwig has proven that she's equally adept behind the camera, allowing her personal experiences to inform this upbeat, charming coming-of-age comedy.
A film that fully understands the psychology of the German soldiers and offers unflinching, timeless truth.
No matter how heartening the performances are, how hard Hart and Cranston work to make us forget about the transparent blueprint design of the narrative, ultimately, the film makes one feel queasy.
It works best exploring the comedic, playful and tightly knit dynamic between the boys ... proving that King's strength really lies in depicting boys' clubs.

While it's all pretty straightforward and predictable, Patti Cake$ squeezes out a lot of charm from its cast, especially from the empathetic, defiant, and supremely talented MacDonald, whose real-life success should be inevitable after this film.

Outside of informing us about what's happening and gently asking us to stay aware about these global issues, Black Code doesn't have much else to say. It's a trait of televisual documentary storytelling.

Perfume War has real substance. The doc is smart enough to identify and provide compelling answers for how and why socially conscious business models are the only sustainable form of capitalism for the future.
Beach Rats is a careful character study, and with Dickinson, American indie director Eliza Hittman has hit gold.
God Knows Where I Am leaves only a trace behind of a dead woman's soul.

The post-apocalyptic zombie film The Girl With All the Gifts has one of those allegorical ideas that is half-interesting and half-gimmicky; regardless, considering that the sub-genre has eaten itself whole, the film's worth giving a chance.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Things To Come carries a surprisingly nuanced perspective on the sensibility in how to live life in spite of setbacks and discouragement of all forms: emotional, spiritual, intellectual, and physical.
Deliciously cheesy, pulpy, and trashy in all the right ways.
You won't be able to stop yourself from falling helplessly in love with this over-the-top rom-com.

Colossal is so beguiling in its strangeness that it still works, even though it's relying heavily on its comedy to make everything work. Don't think too hard about this one, lest you find the many plot holes.
This is a pretty straightforward drama and not much more. There's nothing wrong with that. Just don't expect much of a deep seabed in this one.
A perfect little film that doesn't need to try too hard to win us over.

Personal Shopper is an uncanny mix of ghost story and personal drama that never feels, even for a moment, like it's playing into any genre conventions whatsoever -- the film is entirely its own entity.

Because the film tells her complicated story through the eyes of her son, he has to have a staggering amount of intuition. Fortunately, his childhood innocence doesn't deter the audience from understanding the nuance of his mother's struggle.
movie_title: A Tale of Love and Darkness (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A film that lives up to its title and delivers something rarely seen in Indian cinema.
As it stands, the only thing London Fields has going for it is that it's messy and weird enough to hopefully provoke those who have never read Amis to consider trying him out.
Elevator to the Gallows married a new kind of jazz to a new kind of cinema, and created something altogether sublime.
movie_title: Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenseur pour l'échafaud) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: "The Hard Stop" is most successful when it shows the gradual changes that Duggan's death has caused in the men's lives, and its longitudinal focus helps the viewer sympathize with its subjects.
The most disappointing thing about Boss Baby is not its ridiculous premise and name, but something that Boss Baby would have surely learned in Marketing 101. Who is this movie's demographic?

The film's real success lies in having Jones as its primary subject, and that's because she's a wickedly funny, fierce, phenomenal force of nature, a positive, vivacious character whose generosity and charisma touches every single person.
Nocturama slowly but surely becomes a boldly explicit film that arouses the viewer's sympathies in these tragic, pathetic figures, with a shocking ending that guts a most powerful punch.
Its editing rhythm and tension-building is so off-key it makes something as exciting as a vault robbery torturous to watch.
The most salient point Moore makes in "Where to Invade Next" is that so many of the ideas explored in the doc are American, historically speaking.
Simply cannot keep up with the comedies it so clearly tries to imitate.
Painful to watch, and the first half of the movie is so unwieldy it fails to deliver any punches at all.
The follow-up to Fifty Shades of Grey should really be called Fifty Shades of Vanilla.
Like Farhadi's previous films, The Salesman consistently tries to show us the subtle difficulties Iranian women face in their day-to-day lives.

For a film franchise that is, in the words of the late Roger Ebert, more "theatre of the absurd" than "action thriller," such political acuity makes The Return of Xander Cage that much more fun and hard-hitting.

While the film seems to be asking the question of whether or not Leone can make it as a "real" actress, it does not illustrate her career trajectory. This is utterly confusing for viewers ignorant of her success.
For a dumb, R-rated comedy peppered with jokes about male genitalia, CHIPS, the remake of the '70s cop show, isn't terrible.
By manipulating this emotional vulnerability, A Dog's Purpose has no reason to be a good movie. It can suffice by making its audience cry through the simplest and crudest of gestures.
The casting is almost too good. The title could easily refer to Cranston: why would such a talented actor take on a humiliating, thankless role? Unsurprisingly, he nails the straight man.
Tampopo is a thriving, celebratory and delightful classic that will leave you ravished by the end, for ramen, Asian cuisine or really, any form of sustenance.
The message of Anatomy of Violence is an obvious one, but the film can only tell us, not show us.
It's a sheer delight to watch these two boys -- on their way to becoming men -- challenge and provoke each other, before they finally embrace.
It's a movie so powerfully told it has the potential to act as a gateway to greater acceptance and tolerance.
Gimme Danger, as incomplete and biased as it may be, offers the perfect template for Jarmusch's hyperbolic thesis. It presents a clear-headed and knowledgeable film that still knows how to have fun.
It's not insulting to highlight a female character's sexuality in her narrative, but the way Almodóvar does it feels tacky and objectifying.
Middle School is also more than just a comedy. It tackles that very difficult subject of childhood grief - not perfectly, but not carelessly, either.
movie_title: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Vallée has taken a contemplative book where, frankly, very little happens and transformed it into a gut-punching drama.
Like the book, it suffers from its creators' obsessive zeal. Only here, you can't page ahead to the next chapter.
In spite of its aspirations toward enlightenment, Naked in Ashes leaves its audiences bewildered.
If side-splitting laughter is what you crave, Waiting... will leave you hungry for a slice of American Pie.
Fear not ladies, forget any damning reviews you may have read - this is a must for anyone who loves the Manolo-wearing fashionistas, the hugely popular TV series and the 2008 hit film.
Despite its subject matter and harrowing scenes, Breathless is never depressing, partly because it is infused with the fervent energy of a deeply felt anger.
Let the Right One In, perhaps more subtly than its predecessors in the sub-genre, perfectly captures the nature of love as a delicate and dangerous balancing act.
What makes American Wedding click is that it doesn't pretend to be something it's not.

While Tupac: Resurrection includes some never-before- seen family photos and performance footage, and excerpts from the late rapper's journals, it offers little in the way of new information or insight into the rapper's world.
A lively, if at times juvenile, movie.
What an extraordinary dream it could have been.
Wait, haven't we seen this before?
An exhaustively researched - and, quite frankly, very exhausting - adaptation of journalist Mara Leveritt's book.
A dazzling documentary about an unsolved murder in an ad hoc community in the Galapagos islands in 1934.
movie_title: The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came To Eden (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A messy, shallow, muddled morass of a Philadelphia crime story set in 1978 ...
A fast-moving, lean killing machine that will delight genre fans.
Pulp fiction doesn't come much better than Cold in July, a gritty, grisly - and perversely giddy - crime yarn directed by Pottstown-born indie-film provocateur Jim Mickle.
Despite its many flaws, this is a major work that deserves attention.

Remarkably enjoyable, even joyous, the film chronicles Vidal's life from his privileged beginnings, his years at some of the country's most elite prep schools, and his shocking decision to join the Army instead of attend college.
movie_title: Gore Vidal: The United States Of Amnesia (2014)

movie_review_blurb: One of this year's true surprises, the superior animated sequel not only is infused with the same independent spirit and off-kilter aesthetic that enriched the original, it also deepens the first film's major themes.
Filled with surreal touches and shocking scenes of black humor, Borgman steams ahead with the power and inevitability of a nightmare.
There's very little that actually thrills in this well-constructed, if underwhelming film that works best as a how-to vid for nuclear war-minded DIYers.
A cross between a Woody Allen farce and a one-woman show by Sarah Silverman.
A warm, endearing, and surprisingly intelligent road comedy about a hopelessly dysfunctional family ...
A clever, fun, and affecting romantic dramedy about love and rock-and-roll.
In a series of expertly edited interviews conducted with infantrymen on their way home after a year in the Korengal Valley, Junger exposes us to the war's psychological toll.
A formidable, if perversely overlong epic, Snowpiercer is a dystopian moral parable about survivors of a second ice age that wipes out virtually all humanity.
Like other entries of its pulpish ilk, the picture packs lots of violence, a fair bit of gore, and plenty of cheap scares.
It's a perfect approach to Leduc, whose work is so grounded in the messy, fleshy realities of life, it scandalized critics with its frank treatment of taboo subjects such as lesbianism and incest.
An equally effective, deliciously disturbing movie.

An evocative, moody road movie through the Australian Outback that's as sparse and dry as the desolate landscape it traverses, its deliberate rhythm punctuated by short periods of shocking, bloody violence.
13 Sins is a smart, stylish picture elevated by fine performances by Webber and a superior ensemble of supporting players, including Richard Bower, Ron Perlman, and Pruitt Taylor Vince.
Walking With Dinosaurs is too good a visual treat to miss, especially if you catch the 3-D version. But don't expect to enjoy the predictable, paper-thin story.
It'll keep the kids content for a couple of hours, though it's likely to bore the grown-ups.
Lots of family tragedy, saccharine love, and high-impact tae kwon do.
A spare, lean, and decidedly unsettling account of the ugly reality of child labor and child abduction in India.
Slapdash, with dialogue and plot points that were cliches in Dickens' era, the pic sends up, then reaffirms, all the values the media sell us each holiday: compassion, forgiveness, tolerance.
A happy-smiley Christian fairy tale disguised as a hard-hitting shard of social realism.
A terrific low-budget indie romantic dramedy ...
What makes writer-director Yang Woo-seok's feature debut special is how it handles this shocking incident with verve, style, and humor.
A suspenseful, violent horror film that touches on the inner lives of sexual predators, the question of guilt and remorse in the human soul, and the practice of torture.
An endearing, witty romantic dramedy-slash-supernatural-thriller about a small desert town in California beset by demonic apparitions and a satanic cabal of deranged would-be mass murderers.
A small, intimate, bittersweet, and wonderfully crafted love story, it may very well add a spring to your step as you exit the theater.

A powerful, deeply moving drama about a young boy who comes to terms with the tragedies that have befallen his family by creating a thing of beauty - a gorgeous, high-flying rocket emitting triumphant bursts of color - out of refuse left by the war.
What makes Oculus ingenious is how Flanagan and co-writer Jeff Howard take this hackneyed storyline and twist it - round 'n' round - ad infinitum into a dizzying corkscrew of a narrative.
An inspiring, educational, highly enjoyable documentary from director Patrick Creadon, best known for 2008's I.O.U.S.A., which chronicled America's less-than-healthy fiscal condition.
An ill-conceived if mildly amusing comedy about middle-class ennui, sexual frustration, and drug abuse.

A stunning minimalist erotic thriller that explores with arresting photography and economical use of dialogue how human identity is defined, and sometimes imprisoned, by our desires, drives, and passions.
An uneven, mildly amusing, and highly derivative flick featuring a wonderful, quirky cast as a crew of art thieves who run a complex scam on the art world, and on each other.
An ambitious, if disappointing, period crime drama featuring Clive Owen and Billy Crudup as warring brothers on opposite sides of the law.

A rich, multilayered character study cleverly garbed as an action thriller, Bethlehem is a searing critique of the conflict and its toll - not just in human lives, but also in two peoples' gradual, overall loss of humanity.

Particle Fever explores with awe-inspiring precision, and in remarkably accessible language, how 10,000 scientists and engineers from around the world built what in effect is the ultimate test tube for particle physics.
An amateurish mess, with faltering direction and wooden acting.
We get little in response from Rumsfeld but a demonstration of his cunning at parrying, dodging, and twisting queries.
A droll if minor dramatic comedy about a woman who goes out for a pack of smokes and ends up on an odyssey of self-discovery through the back roads and tiny villages of rural France.
A brilliant, dazzling, and devastating 21/2-hour ballet of brutality that's more ordeal than entertainment ...
This is good, escapist stuff.
A grisly supernatural slasher that boasts a devilishly clever twist, Leyden's film lacks the sophistication to allow its unique idea to flower into much more than a gimmick.
Fanning's performance rescues the film from mediocrity.
Cahill is one of the most talented filmmakers to emerge in the last decade. His sophomore feature may disappoint, but it's clear he has much more to say.
Writer-director Justin Simien's searing, sharp-edged, and wildly intelligent comedy about race relations on an American college campus.
Nightcrawler savages the news media's ratings-driven ethic (a most unethical ethic) with such force, it brings to mind Paddy Chayefsky and Sidney Lumet's Network.
The Guest borrows from other genre pictures with such intelligence and clarity of purpose, it manages to feel fresh, exciting.
A dazzling deconstruction of the mystery genre that turns its conventions on their heads.
Filled with far too many contradictions and implausible situations.
A thoroughly enjoyable and fascinating documentary about Landis' amazing feats as a forger and con man.
An enjoyable, if uneven, adaptation of Laura Kasischke's coming-of-age novel about a teenage girl whose mother vanishes into thin air.
Östlund has an exquisite eye for the intimate, nonverbal communication between couples through their posture, gestures, their eyes.

Camp X-Ray raises quite a few fascinating questions about power, sexism, and war, yet fails to explore them in any real depth. More troubling still, it's a character study that does little in the way of character development.
The Way He Looks almost collapses at several points into a saccharine mess, but Ribeiro manages to keep the dramatic tension alive.
An ineffective, derivative, and awkwardly executed mash-up of ghost flicks and voodoo movies.

After a while it's hard to take Dosunmu's barrage of off-center compositions ... dialogue sequences that have the actor converse with empty space, and close-ups that reduce faces and objects to blobs of light.

Arestrup and Dussollier are mesmerizing as they attack and parry, argue and counterargue. They reminisce about their lives before the war and wax poetic about their families - then engage in battle again.
For all its problems, The Captive does try to hit the themes that have obsessed Egoyan for three decades: desire, death, memory, and time.
Despite terrific, witty performances by Williams and Goodman, most of the talent is wasted in this picture.
The film is not a dangerous weapon, or a tool for anti-Korean propaganda. It does kill, but with comedy.

Predestination is a hair-raising, emotionally resonant thriller that fleshes out Heinlein's minimalist conceptual piece with strong characterization and an absorbing story line about domestic terrorism and murder.
The film illustrates how the most powerful and welcome stabilizing forces in human life - history, family, geography - can turn so easily into deadly traps.
I almost passed out, hyperventilating after uncontrollable bursts of hyena laughs. It took a full evening's rest for the ache to dissipate from the belly.

At times, Spare Parts sails perilously close to the saccharine. But the film is a fine example of a message movie that does justice both to its important subject matter and to its characters' inner lives.
Little Accidents paints a vivid portrait of a community facing an imminent existential crisis.
Interminably long, dragging out its molasses heart through what seem like three different endings.
Hong, who makes his feature debut here, has a masterful command of rhythm, beautifully weaving each strand of the narrative around that momentous opening scene.
Kill the Messenger does a fine job of dramatizing Webb's reporting. The suspense reminds one of All the President's Men, if the structure and writing pale in comparison.
A weak Toy Story-esque animated film for preschool kids made with little imagination, little art, and even less soul.
Is this story compelling? Will it keep your attention for its 95-minute running time? Is it worth the ticket price? Sadly, the answer is: not quite.

Into the Storm has some seriously impressive, wicked special effects. Its rapid pace and thundering sound effects quite effectively ram you, wide-eyed, jaw agape, against your seat back. It has nothing else.
Goldberg buries the heart of the movie beneath several layers of pretentious film-school effects.
It's a visual treat, yet has little else to offer.
Instead of drowning us with statistics, they show us real lives, flesh-and-blood people.
Halfway through, the story loses momentum, becoming a listless, predictable Saturday Night Live skit.
Takes a machine-gun approach to filmmaking, spraying the audience with as many genres, storylines, themes, and cliches as possible, hoping one will stick.
A sweet, heartfelt, yet never maudlin story about an 11-year-old girl's coming to terms with the loss of her father.
The Last of Robin Hood feels stilted, a chamber piece for the stage rather than a dynamic piece of cinema.
Children will revel in Dolphin Tale 2 with its rapturous, lovingly filmed sequences of dolphins playing, swimming, and generally frolicking about with each other and with their human friends.
A dynamic melange of conflicting genres balanced on a high wire of pure irony.
A sly satire that's sexy, touching, and funny, if seriously flawed.
The Man on Her Mind, a mirthless, stagy romantic comedy about a pair of New York loners, isn't so much a story as a threadbare concept - a one-liner, really. An old, used-up one at that.
A schizoid horror comedy with an identity crisis, shifting uncomfortably between shocking body horror and puerile Jackass-level cringe humor.
An enigmatic, visually stunning, but uneven parable about the rape and attempted murder of a young girl in a tiny Alpine community.
The Green Prince is an extraordinary achievement. It has all the suspense of a great espionage yarn, but it's also a powerful moral document that calls into question the tactics of terrorism.
A rancid, insulting, and cynical dramedy about a man who travels around the world to reconnect with his soul.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A frothy little heist movie from Britain that starts off with great promise, only to devolve midway into an empty derivative shell of a film.
A bleak, despairing testament to the cruelty of war, and how it mangles and defaces everyone it touches.
Featuring strong dialogue and terrific performances, the film has moments of near-brilliance, but falls apart with a lame, conventional ending.

You know there's something fundamentally wrong with Drive Hard less than five seconds in: It opens on a shot of star Thomas Jane sporting an absurd mop of a hairdo that might have been borrowed from a Raggedy Ann doll.
As undistinguished, uninteresting, and unscary as the worst of the Chucky films.
Wetlands is one of the most daring, visually arresting, innovative, and imaginative examples of filmmaking to come out of Europe in recent memory.
Just call this movie The Hangover: AARP Strikes Back.
Elliot Loves is a terrific example of the best in microbudget filmmaking which will appeal to gay and straight audiences alike.
A terrible yet lovable take on the haunted-house yarn.
Peli is to be congratulated for pulling off such an audacious project, but he needs a sharper sense of timing: The film's pacing is uneven, which weakens the suspense.
Wait till the DVD release.
Formosa Betrayed, a ho-hum college history lecture about modern Taiwan awkwardly disguised as a political thriller, has its heart almost in the right place.
At a certain point, it actually becomes embarrassing to watch Heigl and Kutcher play at being in love.
A charming, richly textured fable that touches on fundamental questions of existence.
A movie that feels as if it should have been a masterpiece. As it is, it's flawed, uneven work but deserves careful viewing.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: One Aliens reference in this film had me welling up: A blood-soaked Sarah raises her torch, Sigourney Weaver-like, and lets out a banshee war cry.
Predator purists (is that an oxymoron?) have nothing to fear: This is a worthy follow-up.
Takes audiences on an awe-inspiring, nail-biting climb toward the world's highest peak, Mount Everest.
movie_title: The Wildest Dream: Conquest of Everest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An awe-inspiring, stomach-churning journey into blood, gore, and boobs directed by one of France's most talented horror auteurs, Alexandre Aja.
The Last Exorcism pulls off its sweetly scary magic trick with great style and panache.
It's hard to think of another film this summer that offers such sheer anarchic fun.
Resident Evil: Afterlife lacks the humanity -- interesting characters, funny one-liners -- that made its predecessors enjoyable B-movies.
Devil is guaranteed to keep you on tenterhooks from beginning to end -- and without much gore.
An accomplished, daring, even great film.
Cool It offers no new insights into the internecine debates in enviro-policy.
A not too funny, not too sad, largely improvised dramedy about two nice people who both succumb to the seven-year-itch and live to regret it.
This is The Twilight Zone as written by Jean Paul Sartre. What audacity! What vision! And, alas, what a failure.
Joffé is out of depth when it comes to Escrivá's religious experiences. It's clear he wants the film to show how faith works within us, but he does it by resorting to the most hackneyed imagery.

High production values and slick editing can't save this picture. Nor does its overbearing soundtrack music, which tries to strong-arm viewers into believing they're watching a pulse-pounding thriller.
The overwhelming sci-fi action spectacle is a merciless sensorial assault that leaves you with something akin to post-traumatic stress disorder.
It'll take all day to list all the things that are wrong with Whiteout.
Thirst begins with great intellectual and artistic promise, then devolves into a repetitious mess of teeth, blades, necks, bites, arterial sprays, sex, sex, sex and death.
One of the best entries in the cute-as-a-button-psycho-demon-child-from-hell subgenre.
A classic melodrama about thwarted desire, failed relationships, and unrealized dreams, Plain delivers solid turns from a stellar cast.
A charming, witty, gentle mix of live action and CGI that will delight children and parents.

Dillon and director Hamer manage to give us a real Bukowski by avoiding the overly dramatic histrionics that sometimes marred Barbet Schroeder's similarly themed 1987 booze-drama, Barfly with Mickey Rourke.
The Grudge 2, Takashi Shimizu's wildly uneven but ambitious new film -- his second American remake -- is one of the best entries in the Japanese director's Ju-On/Grudge series.
The question for moviegoers: Would you rather get your dose of existenz-philosophie from Dostoyevsky or a slasher flick?
[The film is] hampered by hauntingly lame performances by McDermott and Miller, who phone in their parts, and a screenplay that has the sophistication and complexity of a college dorm message board.
The Boss of It All is a wonderfully perceptive study of the use and abuse of power set in a concrete, everyday context ...
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: After nearly three decades of misfires, major and minor, William Friedkin, the creator of The French Connection, The Exorcist and Sorcerer, is back in true form with Bug.
The violence we see does not disturb or even excite, but, like porn, it anesthetizes us to our own humanity.

[Director] Andreas rescues A Four Letter Word from being merely a raunchy lil' romance by showing how his characters are steeped in a culture of therapy that has filled Americans with endless, compulsive self-analysis and self-doubt.
The film's Harold Lloyd-inspired slapstick may be infantile, but it has an innocent sensibility that is a nice counterbalance to the equally childish but prurient American Pie flicks.
It's quite funny at times and has some good performances. But it's so predictable it has no bite, either as social satire or as slapstick comedy.
[Director] Hawke's sincerity - especially in his terrific new film, The Hottest State -- is also his saving grace.
A flawed, sometimes goofy, but exciting and surprisingly clever adaptation of Stephen King's horror yarn.
An effective if redundant fright flick.

A startlingly original, smart indie film that so effortlessly mixes high-caliber gore, suspense and shocking violence with vaudevillian hilarity, it's clearly animated by the spirit of the classic Re-Animator films.
Myth and reality, past and present, tradition and progress go head to head in Yung Chang's remarkable documentary about China's longest river, Up the Yangtze.

Includes clever references to the straight raunchfests Porky's and American Pie. But his film feels more like a collection of skits than a cohesive story. His characters aren't even half-dimensional and, except for Nico, are boorish bores.
movie_title: Another Gay Sequel: Gays Gone Wild! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
As Jason sequels go, this is one of the best, though that's not saying much.
The Last House on the Left is the best in the latest crop of slasher remakes. Admittedly, that is faint praise.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Good performances and an eerie atmosphere can't save the flick: I'd wait for the DVD.
Boy Interrupted is a remarkable, deeply unsettling documentary about the life of Evan Perry, an uncommonly bright, talented boy from New York who committed suicide at age 15.
A truly terrifying hell-ride through darkness for grownups.
A mildly amusing, if ultimately pointless prison-break thriller from Mikael Håfström.
I'd venture to say it's the best Final Destination sequel - if you gauge success by overall shock value.
Colombiana isn't the last word in action movies, but it's a fun ride.
While it's impossible to surpass the original - so much of its fame is a function of its time - Alvarez's version still manages to measure up.
It presents us with a glimpse of the vastness of existence, of our inner nature, and of nature without that is as equally dreadful, enveloping, and terrifying as it is beautiful.
An ambitious, if deeply flawed, vampire love story ...
A brilliant, deliciously wicked, and thoroughly enjoyable road film ...
In its own clumsy, exaggerated way, The Purge takes a strong stand against our cultural obsession with violence and our tendency to conflate justice with vengeance.
Dirty Wars is essential viewing for all Americans, conservatives and liberals alike. It's intense and depressing. It'll make you angry.
Lyrical, full of visually enthralling fantasy sequences punctuated by moments of intense, bloody violence ...
If you're looking for quality prepackaged, predigested Hollywood family fun this summer, you could do a lot worse than Despicable Me 2.
A Hijacking is one of those perfect films that crop up every few years to prove that with true artistry, even the most exhausted genre can yield something new, rich, and strange.
A sly, richly modulated, emotionally engaging, and brutally honest film ...
V/H/S/2 is likely to be as popular with fans as its predecessor. It certainly earns that right.
Unexpectedly fresh, alive, and vibrant - and wonderfully traumatizing.
While Cowperthwaite's film opens with a simple question about the behavior of a single killer whale, it ends up mounting a persuasive ethical argument against keeping orcas in captivity.
A mescaline-alcohol-and-panic-fueled orgy of confessional dialogue, sex acts, arguments, confessional monologues, and more sex acts.
There are scenes of unutterable beauty in Europa Report, a low-budget space exploration sci-fi suspenser from Ecuadorian director Sebastián Cordero.
Drug War is a deeply intelligent, exhilarating and eminently satisfying adult crime story, one of the best thrillers you're likely to see this year.

A wickedly clever play on the genre that takes you by the scruff of the neck and drags you through 90 minutes of the most inventive mayhem, murder, and pitch-black comedy you're likely to see this year.
A remarkably pretty, if equally dour, portrait of the bored, oppressive life led by the provincial bourgeoisie.
Charlotte Sullivan looks really, really cute in blond dreadlocks. But she can't save the movie, nor can her impressive costars, Bill Paxton, Kevin Zegers, and Laurence Fishburne.

The cross-cultural rom com about a Korean American's search for true love is marred by serious overacting, broad characterization, flat comedic skits. It tries too hard, like a comic who's the one laughing hardest at his jokes.
We Are What We Are doesn't waste time with cheap scares. Mickle keeps his story on a steady, slow simmer, transporting us minute by minute into the very heart of dread.
The Host isn't very good as a romance. There's not very much passion on screen, which makes the film a poor cousin to Twilight.
The movie is well-edited and lean, a fast-paced, action-filled bit of froth that manages to be diverting and surprisingly fun.
Like its equally weepy predecessors, it's a pretty-looking, wonderfully facile bit of emotional froth that's likely to clean up at the box office.
Wake in Fright is essential viewing for anyone interested in the roots of male violence.
Viewers get very little about Madoff himself. While the film is primarily about Markopolos, it makes little sense without much insight into his nemesis.
It tries too hard to be eccentric, kooky. So hard, it can be downright annoying.
A delightfully strange hybrid creature.
Hillbillies of the world unite!
A delightful, if uneven, family romp about a group of movie-obsessed preadolescents who decide to make their own film.
The problem with the new film is that rather than explore the story from a fresh angle, it follows, virtually beat by beat, the events of the Carpenter film.
The film loses its charm with annoying sequences that have a narrator explain to us "The Meaning of it All" and then tell us "What Really Matters" in life: Love. Love. Love.
Lays bare the truth of war - its hellish quality - with such power, you're not likely to look at this, or any other conflict, the same way again.
Saleem developed Exit Strategy out of a Web series - and it shows.
[A] wonderfully realized and surprisingly understated dark satire...
An enchanting grown-up fairy tale about the redemptive power of love.
You may prefer spending your money on the book.
movie_title: Follow Me: The Yoni Netanyahu Story (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's likely to change the way you think about art and politics and the state of China today.
Layton's dazzling film is an exciting, edge-of-your-seat experience superior to any Hollywood mystery you're likely to see for a long time.
A harrowing, gut-wrenching fable about power and authority that shows that even the most well-adjusted, ordinary person could be tempted to degrade and dehumanize their neighbor.
Danish director Ole Bornedal has made some fine films in his career. The Possession isn't one of them.
An exquisitely crafted, brilliant, confusing, disordered, maddening, and wonderfully flawed film that tries to show life as it is lived.
A gritty, devastating melodrama that chronicles an intense, complex, and heartrending relationship over the course of a decade.
No one should be expected to endure 115 minutes of this nonsense.
It can feel inchoate, dropping the viewer in the middle of events without much context, and it exacts an emotional toll. But its raw quality also makes it compelling viewing.
A disaster as a film, Atlas also is laughable in its presentation of Rand's ideology.
Tai Chi Zero, the first film in a planned trilogy, will leave hard-core fight enthusiasts wanting. But it's a droll, pleasant diversion all the same.
Pared down and sparse, almost Bressonian in its formal rigor...
Starts off as a singularly strong slice-of-life drama before dissipating into thin air.
An achingly graceful, heartfelt, working-class story about loss, grief, and family obligations.
It sometimes reads as a cheap, sleazy horror film, but its heart seems to be in the right place.
Dominated by CGI effects, it's a soap opera better fit for basic cable.
An elegant survey of the origins of the information revolution and a shrewd analysis of how the internet has reshaped the world.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Kubo is a lovely, unforgettable film about creativity and storytelling - about creating one's own fate by taking charge of one's story. And about learning to love others by sharing in their stories.
A deceptively simple, remarkably lean, and well-paced indie pic about the young Barack Obama's first date with the young first-lady-to-be Michelle Robinson.
If ever there were a film that shoulda-coulda-woulda been great, it's Hands of Stone, an ambitious but disappointing biopic about Panamanian fighter Roberto Durán.
One of the most suspenseful, terrifying, and devilishly original horror pics in recent memory.
Pared-down, efficient, and easy to follow, Morgan dispenses with the long, complicated pseudoscientific explanations that bog down so many sci-fi movies.
The shift in tone is expertly managed by Aja, who brings it on with such subtlety that we're stunned to realize we've entered a profoundly unsettling mystery that grapples with taboo themes.

Swift, fleet-of-foot, and efficient, with clean lines and a sleek finish, the Norwegian black comedy In Order of Disappearance glides through the world like a perfectly engineered car or a gorgeous piece of modern furniture.
Opening with a promising first act comprising well-observed, edgy humor, the film ends with an overdose of treacle so syrupy, so pungent, it will unsettle the strongest tummy.
A chilling, eerie cautionary tale about the ghosts that continue to haunt Poland long after the war.
It's nothing more than a sophisticated clone of the original, and it really overdoes the shaky-camera thing - even more than in some of the worst found-footage movies The Blair Witch Project spawned.
It never feels tedious, thanks to Stone's tremendous sense of story construction, the film's razor-sharp editing - and Gordon-Levitt's masterful performance.
It elicited applause from adults and kids alike at a recent screening. I guess I must be allergic.
Ultimately, Queen of Katwe fosters a belief in the triumph of merit and talent. And that message is definitely applicable - to Western kids.
I'm sorely disappointed.
Berg's film works because it excludes anything that is not immediately involved in the actual explosion, including the full range of its causes or its long-term consequences.
I fear Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children is too uneven, too self-consciously cool to succeed either as art or as mass spectacle.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)
