movie_review_blurb: Masterminds is filled with the sort of idiotic bathroom humor that has become standard in big-screen comedies, but it is enlivened by the surreal slapstick touches that made Napoleon Dynamite so good.

A terrifying documentary that'll have your heart racing as fast as any Hollywood thriller, Kenner's film reveals that, due to a range of errors and accidents, we were very close, more than once, to detonating a nuke on our own soil.
A transcendent work from Ireland's Cartoon Saloon studio that's almost wasted on kids.
It's an exciting, smartly sexy, suspenseful little crime drama that evokes classic Hollywood film noir.
A Man Called Ove won me over - if for no other reason than Lassgård's formidable talent for playing such an utterly pitiless, nihilistic jerk.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: You're never too old to start falling in love with Meryl Streep all over again.
Don't Think Twice does a nice job of satirizing this corner of the showbiz world. More than that, it's a celebration of improv, a uniquely American art form.
Just because you can come up with names such as Azeroth, Durotan, Orgrim, and Grommash Hellscream doesn't mean you're J.R.R. Tolkien, people.
Much longer, more elaborate, more dramatic, and more packed with chilling moments and hair-raising visuals than one could anticipate, even from Wan.
Well-written, gorgeously shot, and expertly edited, the film is also an exasperating exercise in good intentions gone wrong.
Central Intelligence is actually funny.
Rühm has an ear for the absurd that reminds one of Monty Python. But his humor is as dry as they come - Therapy for a Vampire elicits ironic smiles, not belly laughs.
movie_title: Therapy for a Vampire (Der Vampir auf der Couch) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A bold visionary artist, Refn seems able to revel in the culture of instant gratification while also subjecting it to critique.
Mixing elements from documentaries, biopics, war flicks, and Hallmark romances, Ross' film is a living history tour, but with gory special effects and a smoldering smattering of sex appeal.
Hunt for the Wilderpeople magically taps into the logic, thought processes, and emotions of a child. It's a rich, strange, and wondrous world.
The violence is too tantalizing, too stylized, too fetishistic - the film features killers dressed in fanciful Halloween costumes who dance and sing as they dismember people.
It's fun, exciting, freakish filmmaking.
Viewers wary of the director's reputation as a savage satirist will be pleasantly surprised by the deeply felt humanism in Weiner-Dog.
A lesser entry, but there's much to recommend.
A cross between François Truffaut's sometimes-harrowing dramas about childhood and a Steven Spielberg fantasy, Gondry's film abounds with sentiment - without falling prey to sentimentality.
It seems another member of Clint Eastwood's brood is ready for stardom.
Sandberg ... spares us from the indignity of jump scares. When he sets out to frighten you, he means it.
The best I can say of Ice Age: Collision Course is that it has nice coloring and good picture contrast.
[An] insightful and disturbing documentary ...
Nerve gives moviegoers everything they'd want from a teen romance. It's a little less successful as a critique of life in the age of Instagram.
Phantom Boy will appeal to children who have the patience and imagination to immerse themselves in the film's wiggly animation.
Suicide Squad does have quite a few tremendously entertaining sequences of high action and low comedy. It's a shame it never rises beyond that.
Curran's script gives the actors too little substance with which to work their magic. The filmmaker's minimalist style is too sparse for the material.
Sausage Party is one of the funniest and most deeply offensive movies of the year (it's obscenely funny), which lambastes America's most sacred of sacred cows: religion.
A fast-moving, deeply absorbing, and thoroughly exciting directorial debut.
I'm not ashamed to admit that I had a lot of fun at this movie.
The first half had me in stitches of helpless hilarity, but by the time comic Kevin Hart wrapped up his latest standup concert film with a series of tasteless sex jokes, I wanted out.

The miracle lies in how the film gently touches on some of the most intractable social problems addressed by the civil rights movement, while maintaining an infectiously buoyant vibe - not to mention a bouncy soundtrack.
A Monster Calls is an engrossing tragic fantasy, sustained by genuine sentiment.
Scorsese's adaptation is overlong and at times insufferably self-indulgent but contains sublime moments of transcendent beauty and a wealth of beautiful performances.
It's intriguing enough to suck you in, but confusing, fragmentary, frustrating.

Paterson is easily one of Jarmusch's most accomplished films. He portrays the life of the mind and the workings of the creative soul as a kind of secret love affair, a deep, hidden well inside the most ordinary, mundane existence.
Boy, does Keaton's Kroc ever become mean, selfish, small-minded - though he's never less than fascinating.
Split is a deeply disturbing film that covers every evil human deed from kidnapping to cannibalism. But it's also wildly funny in parts.
Left me deeply traumatized and suffering from injuries to my eardrums, my eyes, my mind, my soul, my aesthetic sensibility, and my sense of decency.
A promising, if ultimately disappointing cautionary tale about the power of greed to twist the human soul.

Visually arresting, but never precious, it's filled with ideas that have relevance to actual life, ideas that are based on a moral conviction that a question well-posed is far more valuable than an easy answer.
Toni Erdmann is an immensely rich, deeply-felt exploration of human relationships that draws you in and holds you fast for nearly three hours.
There's just so much you can get out of this material and the filmmakers beat it to death.
Offers an accessible but no-less rigorous look at Baldwin's prophetic analysis of racial discord in America.

An exquisite, closely studied moral fable about our tendency to confuse love with ownership and our willingness in the face of felt humiliation to disavow empathy, understanding, and concern for our neighbor.
Offerings range from the cute to the transcendent, from love stories to probing political dialogues about immigration and racial identity.
Offerings range from the cute to the transcendent.
Offerings range from... love stories to probing political dialogues about immigration and racial identity.
A fact-based political romance about one of the most remarkable love stories you've never heard about.
The Red Turtle is a profoundly simple meditation on the many ways we've become alienated from nature and from the Earth.

An engaging, gripping fact-based drama starring Nicholas Hoult (Mad Max: Fury Road) as a young machine gunner in the U.S. Marines whose platoon is put in the impossible position of saving an Iraqi village.
A sci-fi-horror yarn stocked with a winning cast but hobbled by a lamebrained script and dull set pieces.
Tragic, beautiful, thought-provoking.
Like Meet The Parents on LSD, laced with rat poison.
As serious science fiction, Passengers falls seriously short.
It ... has great momentum, good set pieces, and so much frothy nihilism it's just plain fun.
As crime thrillers go, it's an inferior product with a predictable plot. It succeeds because of its memorable characters and their shifting relationships. There's some nice action and offbeat humor.
An inventive cross between a haunted-house mystery, a demonic-possession yarn, and a creepy murderous-child freak-out.

Howard seems to have forgotten that the Langdon stories are supposed to be puzzles, brain-teasing mysteries. Here, the symbology that Langdon does is so absurdly esoteric, and so beside the point, the audience stops following the clues.
Rich in dramatic detail and psychological insight, the film approaches its protagonist with genuine concern.

Despite the competent animation, the great tunes, and funny voice work by costars Russell Brand and John Cleese, Trolls is a lackluster entry. The story is clichéd and predictable. Overall, the film has no real magic.

If you think art should challenge us, then you will embrace writer-director Barry Jenkins' exquisitely crafted drama Moonlight. It's a true American masterpiece and one of the best films of the decade.
Far too good to be watched in one sitting.
Garfield melts into his Doss character in a performance that seems impossibly still and tranquil. He's mesmerizing.
While I'm tired of the wretched tyranny of comic book flicks, I admit I liked Cumberbatch's picture. For the most part.
Few filmmakers have portrayed the messy reality of human desire and sexuality as consistently, as elegantly, and as powerfully as André Téchiné.
Like Davies' best work, the movie employs classical rigor - perfectly symmetrical, painterly landscapes and interiors - with unexpected postmodern touches.
A resplendent and remarkably subtle, yet deeply affecting, drama about the 1967 U.S. Supreme Court decision that invalidated state laws prohibiting interracial marriage.
Overheated, existential melodrama or cool, sharp-edged satire? Despite his genius as a filmmaker, Lee simply can't give us both at the same time.
Moana 's great heart and great humor actively subvert the violent, egocentric, macho mind-set that dominates so many popular stories.
Allied comes off like a highlight reel that mimics the look and feel of a whole school of great films, from Casablanca to Hitchcock's Suspicion and Notorious.
Like its heroine, the film shocks by lunging back and forth between comedy and tragedy.
Biller's visual splendor is ... wasted on a mediocre script riddled with structural problems. Scenes follow another willy-nilly, as if moved around late in the process.
A tiresome but meticulously detailed and visually sumptuous Russian melodrama about romance and intrigue amid the nobility in 19th century St. Petersburg.

Madden's film offers up a banal truism - money has a corrupting influence on politics - as if it were some great dramatic discovery and trots out a fairy-tale ending that both repudiates the political process and undermines the movie ...
Lean, mean, and utterly compelling, Ma's beautifully paced and remarkably understated 80-minute thriller Old Stone is a Kafkaesque satire about the soul-crushing effects of bureaucracy.
It tries so hard to be an epic masterpiece - with self-important speeches and an insanely outsize orchestral score - that it ends up a laughable parody of itself.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Lion celebrates the human will and the human need to find meaning and connection in life. If the final scenes don't have you blubbering, your humanity may need some fine-tuning.

Yates and Rowling skillfully weave their bleak - and very blunt-edged - message into the fabric of the story. It might be wildly out of place in a fantasy aimed at tweens, but it's a welcome change from the usual vapid blockbuster.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An inspiring, enjoyable - and utterly stage-managed - documentary from Israeli director Ido Haar.
The Girl on the Train is a fun ride, despite its failings.

Americans seem uncommonly uncomfortable discussing our own class struggles. But, boy, do we love to watch the Brits do it. I think that's one reason the inspiring and joyful Dark Horse is such an appealing film.
It's not exactly a scary film, but it does provide an enjoyable ride. It's good fun. But it left me befuddled. A little sad. And a little angry.

Kidman seemed a natural choice to play Kelly. She manages to soar in several scenes. Hampered by the subpar material, she seems utterly lost, unable to master what could have been the role of her career.
Nightingale rages on at times with no real direction. At others, it hits us over the head with pretentious symbolism. Oyelowo's inspired performance keeps it afloat.
A schmaltzy, deeply sentimentalized drama about American slavery and the rise of the Underground Railroad.

There's a great deal of intelligent material here. Winterbottom mounts a harsh attack on our fascination with killers and our tendency to forget the victim. Yet it's overlaid with so much navel-gazing, it's hard to take.

For all its talk of death, The Farewell Party, featuring a terrific ensemble cast, is a story about life. Always honest, graceful and funny it explores with deep compassion its characters familial and romantic relationships.
Messy and confused, the film is a mishmash of tropes from Shakespeare, heist movies, family melodrama, and romance novels hastily thrown together.
A breathtaking, disturbing look at urban angst and the emptiness of youth culture ...
Its faults aside, The Suicide Theory is a truly touching story about our need for human contact. It's strange, goofy, surreal, and deeply gratifying.
The Gallows is one lazy film. There's no real effort or inventiveness here, whether we're talking about the character names, the jokes, the set pieces, or the predictable plot twist.
A stunning examination of teenage cruelty, exploitation, and crime that refuses to give us the satisfaction of identifying with the characters.
Does the world really need another indie film about lost souls living quiet lives of desperation in a heaven-forsaken one-horse town?
Williams does a terrific job portraying Nolan's ambivalence, the mix of fear, guilt, and excitement that grips him and the gradual change he undergoes in the ensuing weeks.
While it has considerable charms, Hippocrates is just too predictable.
movie_title: Hippocrates: Diary of a French Doctor (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The chemistry between Smulders and Bean is simply terrific. Their performances almost save the film from its earnest, if bumbling, attempts to make a statement about the social, economic, and racial differences that divide the two characters.
Fun to watch, if a little too cutesy for my tastes.
Unsullied was made by a director with real promise. It's a shame Rice picked this turkey to shoot as his first.
Epic in scope, yet at the same time intensely intimate in its handling of its protagonist's inner life, it's a unique wildlife tale that sets a tribe of humans against a majestic pack of wolves.
Phase II has some nice comic touches, but it's a forgettable B-movie.
Exceptionally graceful and accomplished, Ozon's film challenges our received notions of normalcy, intimacy, and love.
Velásquez is a remarkable individual, and her message should not go unheeded.
movie_title: A Brave Heart: The Lizzie Velasquez Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Apu Trilogy is a masterpiece no cinephile can afford to miss.
A fascinating, suspenseful story about obsessive love, money, the Mafia, and murder.
movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most insightful films about the War on Terror since 9/11.
5 Flights Up is a sweet film with a few nicely turned lines, some good jokes, and some very lovely dialogue. But it's not much more than fluff and air.
Great fun will be had by audiences, past and future.
A headache-inducing $135 million sequel to the 2014 blockbuster, TMNT: OOTS becomes intolerable after about 32 seconds.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It falls short of the mark, even as it hits every one of the genre's conventions.
A transcendent political poem as intellectually rigorous as it is beautiful.
Mildly enjoyable despite its basic mediocrity ...
A delightful, sharp dramedy that skewers the topic from every angle imaginable.

Carolla, who co-wrote and co-directed the picture with Kevin Henchis, has a way of making his remarkably stiff screen presence endearing. He plays Bruce with gentle self-mockery and a touch of genuine pathos.
A superbly researched and edited documentary about the women's movement in the 1960s.

Demange's feature debut miraculously distills the often Byzantine nature of the power politics behind The Troubles in a deeply intimate chamber piece about a single day in the life of a British soldier.
If too many filmmakers try to amp up the excitement in Shakespeare with movie magic, Almereyda goes to the opposite extreme in Cymbeline.
Overall, the effect is closer to a Monty Python skit or a Village People music vid than a serious film about civil rights.
An ambitious, if wildly uneven, character study that relies on a taut script, snappy dialogue, and a few well-placed plot twists ...

It's refreshing to see a film set amid the daily life of an impoverished, rural immigrant community. It's a shame the only aspect of the social world that is explored is the sexual exploits of a few teens.
The Salt of the Earth, has the power to draw you into its world, transfix, and perhaps eventually transform you.
Not a great film. Or particularly good. In fact, it's fairly bad as B-movies go.
It leaves behind a nagging feeling, a suggestion there's more to the story than its story.
A somber piece of film poetry about men so invested in a rigid notion of honor and revenge they become trapped in an endless loop of violence.
There's not much here: The characters are paper-thin, and the action is slow, at times agonizingly so.
A horror pic with a new gimmick that likely will spawn an entire subgenre of more substandard rubbish.

It fails to pursue any of the fascinating questions its premise raises. Instead, it dives headfirst into Nicholas Sparks territory and explores, though not without some charm, Adaline's romantic life.

At turns horribly funny and simply horrific, Piven's film suggests our therapeutic age has reduced us all to psychic cripples who resort to emotional exhibitionism in lieu of honest self-examination and self-expression.

Always, murmuring just beneath the surface, there's a political undercurrent to Farhadi's films, a gentle whisper of a critique aimed at the weight of Iran's combined cultural and political intransigence.
One of the most moving and intelligent of the recent glut of films and TV specials about teenage bullying.
It is hampered by weak writing and a badly executed story line.
The film tries so hard to be a clever, deconstructive meta-tale, forever winking at the audience about its silly story, that it metas itself into insignificance.
While its message is a little simplistic, Knock Knock is shot through with a brilliant, gleefully anarchic dark humor that's equally fun and disturbing.
A thrilling, gorgeous actioner about a massive tsunami that wipes a tourist town off the map.
A brilliant, funny morality tale that examines the transformative effects of martial-arts training.
movie_title: The Boy And The Beast (Bakemono No Ko) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film is surprisingly likable, if entirely predictable.
While it hits some of the usual sci-fi tropes, Creative Control's center of gravity isn't tech itself, but the relationships of those who use it.
The Confirmation is a powerful directorial debut from 59-year-old writer Bob Nelson, who received an Oscar nomination for his first screenplay, Nebraska.
Predictable, tired, formulaic, it makes up for its lack of originality with a bigger budget, louder jokes, louder costumes, and louder music.
For about 90 seconds, the novel first-person-shooter point of view hits our bodies with an unexpected flood of adrenaline, in a heart-pounding rush. Trouble is, the chemical high doesn't last.
A loopy, off-the-wall tragicomedy that chronicles a particularly stressful day in the life of a miserably unhappy couple whose marriage is on its last legs.
April and the Extraordinary World will have your imagination doing somersaults and cartwheels.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of offering easy answers, Barbershop: The Next Cut raises important, difficult, and timely questions.
A ponderous, overwrought meditation on grief, loss, guilt, and memory that prods and probes its characters more like lab rats than living, breathing creations.
My Big Night bears the stamp of Pedro Almodóvar's romantic comedies, and it's worthy of his best.
Dough's formulaic structure is made up for by the dynamic chemistry between its leads. Pryce and Holder play off each other with all the bluster and awkwardness of a real-life father and son.
Dragon Inn delivers pure cinematic pleasure. I'm not sure it can be overpraised.
It touches on serious - and ridiculously complex - ideas but always cuts them down to manageable, middle-brow morsels.
I admit I fell victim to many a belly laugh watching The Angry Birds Movie. I loved Sudeikis' and Penn's performances.

A well-crafted work that features a powerful performance by former child actor Nick Robinson (Jurassic World), Being Charlie is far too predictable, relying too often on all-too-familiar drug-story tropes.
A dull, formulaic theme-park ride whose only purpose is to make more pots of money.
Fans of Abu-Assad's earlier films may be puzzled by his subject matter, but they needn't worry that he has gone soft.

Neither bad nor particularly good, but just there, which may prove to be its biggest selling point in a season front-loaded with Oscar contenders.

Gridiron Gang isn't just distinctive, it's downright exceptional - the kind of film that not only sustains its genre, but sets a legitimate benchmark if not a high watermark for future entries to aspire to.
It's safe to say that V may be the most political movie released by a major studio since JFK (which was also distributed by Warner Brothers).
The most mature and unsentimental movie Steven Spielberg has ever made.
Not awful enough to be bad, nor ambitious enough to be good.
An exotic film that feels abbreviated.
There are few movies released by major studios these days possessed with as much intelligence and purpose as Gaghan's.
Vertiginous, virtuoso filmmaking that dovetails into palpable emotional conflict, and vice versa.
Open Season is one of a handful of recent computer-animated movies that actually stands out in this crowd.
Works as a smarter version of those John Hughes movies we all watched as kids because it aims for the center of that surreal, satirical dart board of 'teenage experience.'
A satisfying trio of twisted tales.
If, as the film suggests, true greatness is defined by the willingness to fail, fail big and still stick around afterwards, then consider Elizabethtown a sweet, melancholy paean to that sad truth.
A film like few others that truly celebrates the journey itself, not the destination, and offers sights enough to behold that you feel like you've already arrived even before you've been anywhere.
[Not] merely one of the best animated films of the year; it's the best, and further, ranks among 2005's most satisfying cinematic experiences.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A psychological thriller in a category by itself.
Outranks any other animated film in recent memory if only for its dedicated avoidance of any and all lessons imparted or learned.
Brokeback Mountain offers a long-overdue road map into territory often traversed but seldom properly documented -- namely, the human heart.
There is truly nothing to enjoy about Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning, from its disappointingly unoriginal opening to the absurdly violent, equally disappointing cop-out ending.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Returning to more intimate filmmaking after helming Batman Begins, director Christopher Nolan manages to make The Prestige's complex story as easily understandable and effective as he made the outwardly straightforward comic book adaptation

Flags of Our Fathers is an elegant, sensitive tribute to the men and women who give their lives to preserve our way of life, but unfortunately it also errs on the wrong side of the dichotomy between military propaganda and paying proper homage. Ult
Disturbia isn't merely full of characters who make stupid decisions, but made by filmmakers who did the same.
No matter how entertaining the gorefests of folks like Eli Roth are, there will always be an entertainment value in films that are more into spooking people than making them sick.
Evan Almighty is the latest, terrible family film, and a chronicle of the reductive way in which mainstream comedy directors seem to inevitably lose their edge.

Ultimately, Mr. Brooks is a little bit like one of the murders in an actual serial killer case: an object of passing fascination for most people who see the broad strokes or statistics, but of lasting or more profound impact only to those affected by or d

Ocean's Thirteen feels mostly like just another job -- not only for the cast and crew, but for critics as well. Audiences will likely find it to be superior to its immediate predecessor, but as in most of the games the Ocean's guys are trying to rig, the
Even if it's not quite "Dynamite," Eagle vs Shark is still pretty good.
As an integral part of movie history, the only legacy that Pirates seems poised to leave is the distinction of it being the first major series about seafaring swashbucklers to succeed financially.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: What truly is most amazing about Spider-Man 3 (no pun intended) is that all objections are answered and all developments are resolved, even if at times it feels like they will never converge.
Robert Rodriguez and Quentin Tarantino return with a rousing tribute to the genre movies that inspired them.
We Are Marshall is the kind of movie that not only believes in the goodness of humankind, but makes you believe it, too.
TMNT is a fun, action-filled adventure that will satisfy longtime fans and generate a legion of new ones.
The Departed is nothing short of brilliant -- complicated, ambiguous and ambitious, executed with a virtuosity shared only by a handful of other American filmmakers.
Will Smith gives the performance of his career in a movie for which phrases like "heart-warming" and "life-affirming" were made.
No matter what your interest is in the film -- entertainment or information -- Apocalypto delivers the goods, and then some.
There's nothing worse than a movie that knows it's important, and Bobby reminds its audience of that fact in almost every scene through character development, dialogue and plot.
Déjà Vu is one film that you'll be happy to revisit %u2014 whether it's to deconstruct the plot, pore over the science or just rerun as a great, engaging, adult adventure.
Bridge to Terabithia is a real anachronism in today's family-movie landscape, if for no other reason than it simply and accurately portrays the interior life of adolescents.
Director Zack Snyder adapts Frank Miller's graphic novel with passion and creativity, proving that classical storytelling will never go out of style.
Almodovar delves deep into the darkness of a woman's maternal instincts, finding alternate humor and harrowing emotion in one of the year's most fascinating films.
Flushed Awayarrives at the wrong time with the wrong cast and unfortunately without the right sort of alchemy that won Aardman both audiences and critical adulation.

In his latest film, Babel, director Alejandro Gonzalez intertwines four stories that are overripe with nail-biting potential and then unleashes them on the audience without mercy. And while this may actually rank as the most challenging, difficult,

The Science of Sleep, his latest effort, continues in the same singular direction as its predecessors; simultaneously confounding, fascinating and enchanting, the movie does not quite find the populist pulse that did its predecessor, but as the fir
A worthy remake and companion piece to the Reynolds film.

Director Sofia Coppola transforms what would otherwise be described as a costume drama into a subtle dissertation on the vagaries of our too-much-too-soon culture. But at the same time, Coppola's general approach to moviemaking seems to produce this kind
Jennifer Hudson makes her acting debut in Bill Condon's Dreamgirls, and it's safe to say the phrase "star-making turn" was invented for performances like hers.
A terrific little fantasy that will arouse one's childlike curiosity.
The most satisfying film of the year.
A perfectly worthy entry to close, or perhaps resuscitate, cinema's greatest zombie series.
Hilton is the cinematic equivalent of a stray dog, an untrained extra that accidentally wandered into the shot and quickly began making love to the camera.
Truly terrible for plenty of reasons, not the least of which being Damon Dash's barely competent directing.
Now, rather than looking tough, former NWA badass Ice Cube simply seems constipated, and rather than being intimidating he is strangely ingratiating.
Unlike the postmodernism and half-formed words of Lucas' universe, this world functions without needing a handbook on the history of cinema, much less a toy store catalog.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Rumor has it that the original title for this romantic comedy was When Harry and Sally Joined the Mile High Club.
It is at once a coming of age story, a gangland epic, a martial arts melee, a romantic comedy and dissertation on spirituality.
Then again, women still swoon with lust whenever McConaughey steps in front of the camera, no matter how rancid is the project he deems fit to appear in right now.
A colleague of mine recently described Jimmy Fallon as the perfect romantic comedy 'best friend'- that is, the guy who cracks wise at all of the romantic lead's shenanigans.
Rodriguez again densely packs the story with multiple narratives, but wisely realizes this time that he doesn't have Tarntino's facility with inverting formula.
Charlie's Angels written as a teen comedy and re-enacted by Barbie dolls.
Captivating while it lasts, and exceeds the majority of the year's lackluster cinematic offerings in terms both of ambition and execution.
Director F. Gary Gray (The Italian Job) has none of the facility with story and characters that Barry Sonnenfeld displayed on the original picture.
Mild, middle-of-the-road and formulaic.
A creative misstep that will likely pay off commercially.
Like the swift blow of a hammer to the skull, the film shocks with blunt violence, and leaves a lasting impression.
While most audience members will cringe at the inevitable showdowns and reconciliations, Bullock makes the female-bonding angle seem not only believable, but compelling.
Closer in spirit to Meet the Parents than Guess Who's Coming to Dinner, this comedy further confirms - for those who care - that Ashton Kutcher is no Ben Stiller.
Falls on its butt as often as it lands a perfect turn, but its perseverance ultimately pays off with a win not only for the film, but the audience as well.
Cruz gives a daring performance, for more reasons than her willingness to adopt a look that resembles a beat-up Chihuahua.
A sequel that not only matches but exceeds the horrific power of its predecessor.
While the intelligence level is definitively family-friendly, it only occasionally manages to rise to the heights of current Pixar benchmark The Incredibles.
Tommy Lee Jones and five cheerleaders; Vin Diesel and five toddlers. What's next? Harrison Ford and five crazy out of control nursing home patients?
A sweetly-rendered story that also happens to look terrific.
This film needs a hero, and Bloom isn't him.
The appeal of the film comes from Haggis' ability to reveal prejudices by forcing us to confront them on an inescapably human level.
Suggests that Wes Anderson may have become too immersed in his own meticulous and idiosyncratic world to quite realize that he's left ours far behind.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: [Unleashed] may not be the year's best dramatic film, but it is a great piece of popcorn entertainment.
A triumph from every angle.
Works more effectively as a collegiate dissertation than a fictional dissection of people caught in events beyond their control.
Inspired, serendipitous and unfinished all at once.
The film combines the sublime and the mundane in ways that previously went unimagined.
Inconsistent and painfully rote.
A failed nostalgia trip that chronicles the kitschy highlights of 1970s pop culture without actually ever capturing the personal or social atmosphere of the era.
We feel sympathy, fear and revulsion for Keane ... and it's to Lewis' credit that the subtle build of Keane minimalist plot adopts such weight and depth by the final scene.
The film itself could stand an extra dose or two of something special; what it achieves falls far short of what it aims for.
Releasing a film about sex in an age of pornography is akin to opening a four-star restaurant down the street from a McDonald's.
Stealth is about absolutely nothing, and pretty much everything at the same time: terrorism, technology, warfare, grungy alt-rock, conflicted choices and cool flying footage.
To say that The Island is Michael Bay's best movie to date is more than a backhanded compliment, particularly for discriminating moviegoers
A movie for kids, by kids, even if Rodriguez was there for a little bit of technical supervision.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This tops my short list of 2005's best films thus far.
To say that the film feels old is a compliment to Romero... He quite literally cuts to the chase and bypasses anything resembling character or story development.
The hardware, relationships and story all feel fully real, and that's a rare achievement for a comic book adaptation aimed squarely at the pocketbook of the American public.
The (remake) honeymoon is over, people; if more movies like this come out, I may ask for a divorce from the whole medium.
Pitt lends just the right amount of bemusement to make the proceedings seem, well, if not quite credible, then at the very least charmingly farfetched.
Scorsese's Raging Bull initiated the stylistic flourish of flashbulb punctuation for a flying punch, but Howard turns it into virtually his entire mise-en-scene.
What does not feel authentic, to either Asian audiences or simply those familiar with rom-com formula is Wu's indelicate efforts to help Wil avoid talking about her feelings.
Ranks as perhaps the most violent PG-13 movie I've seen in years. I began to fear I'd be sprayed by blood, cartilage or other bodily fluids.
One instance of a CGI overlay looks as if the VFX crew added hand-drawn temp animation and then forgot to go back for a final polish.
Remarkably, Lucas solicits even worse performances than in pictures past; the Mace Windu-Palpatine confrontation ranks amongst the worst acted scenes I've ever seen.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Calm and collected, even when going stark-raving mad, Fonda has the veneer of a true movie star and sells her title character through the sheer virtuosity of her performance.
A one-off jaunt, a burly brawl buried in genre topsoil but possessing no deeper root in a franchise or some other such anchor.
The balancing act between pleasing crowds and evoking larger human truths eventually escapes Spielberg's grasp, as it has occasionally in the past.
Blades of Glory is funny, and that's all that matters.
A film that will force you to recall every awkward feeling of rejection, alienation, and betrayal that you went through during your own high school years.
At a time of year when theaters are filled with flashy, fun, but empty offerings, Stomp The Yard is a surprisingly satisfying alternative.
Bill Paxton, longtime bit-player and significantly underrated character actor, makes his directorial debut with Frailty, a joyless tale of one family's psychotic cycle of violence.
Nolan's sequel surpasses the original with an intense, disturbing masterpiece.
This parody film plagiarizes Spider-Man to virtually laughless effect.
Schwimmer offers generic rom-com conventions in his feature directorial debut.
But the success of this documentary may ultimately qualify as faint praise since what it really confirms is that rock 'n' roll's greatest glories happened 40 years ago...
Jennings and Goldsmith's kid-fueled '80s film proves as inspiring as it is inspired.

Speed Racer is a masterpiece of its kind, and a definitive benchmark for film not only as a special effects extravaganza but as the moment when the Wachowskis went from wunderkind directors to true auteurs.
They just don't make them like they used to, and depending on which category you fall into, that's either a bad or good thing.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Cusack reminds audiences of one of his great films without quite making another one.
Sex and the City is not a painful experience for men (or even guys), just a predictable one...
McBride's smalltown satire offers minor martial arts-themed laughs.
It's this balance between real world stakes and superhero surrealism that makes Favreau's film such a success.
One of the more effective and chilling thrillers released this year.
Pete Travis' Rashomon retread reads more like a less funny Groundhog Day.
Rambo ranks as the overall series' second-best entry.
Save your money so you don't get mad that you spent it on this.
Not only is Dungeon Siege the best film of Uwe Boll's career, but it's also guaranteed not to be the worst one released in its year.
movie_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An engaging thriller that should thoroughly satisfy genre fans during a time of year when their choices are essentially between bad and worse.
Persepolis is a poignant tale, powerfully told through the simplest of means, that should resonate with viewers of all backgrounds.
The film is competently executed, occasionally scary and frequently fun to watch, no matter whether you choose to laugh at or with it.

There Will Be Blood is a brilliant film, a real, important work in a world that looks at art as a four-letter word, and another entry in a filmography that stands among the most important -- and yes, distinctive -- in modern movies.
Borrowing from this bottomless well, perhaps it's best to say that you should hang up, turn off your phone or even cancel your service should this film attempt to reach out and touch you.
Book of Secrets is a perfect family or holiday movie -- one that will keep parents' attention but not terrify their kids in the process.
David Fincher directs a nail-biter starring Jodie Foster about a mother and daughter who defend their house against a brutal home invasion.
Human Nature cleverly satirizes our most ridiculous- and in many ways, our most tragic- impulses, and finds a unique balance between light-hearted humor and abject farce.

The Rock, making his acting debut as the titular top dog (not counting his five digitally enhanced minutes in The Mummy Returns), turns in a slight, if promising, star turn as a reluctant savior of the free world, and leads an encouragingly multi-cultural

Spirit: Stallion Of the Cimmaron, which and is technically Dreamworks' first animated film since the monster CGI hit Shrek, as a hand-drawn film has quite a bit to live up to, but succeeds admirably at finding the heart that is often missing from technica
A thoughtful, compelling alternative to the genre tripe that's been occupying theaters of late.
Stanton finds more success with a tender, thoughtful and terrific-looking animated film.

A bloodsucker story that's rich with originality and feeling, this Swedish import is a terrific love story and vampire tome that not only rewards the genre's fans but rekindles interest in its virtually exhausted foundations.
This second Palahniuk adaptation offers oddball but inauspicious fun.

Baghead is at once a terrifically smart and scary piece of entertainment, an embodiment of the mumblecore aesthetic, and a sly commentary on the challenges aspiring and independent filmmakers face in finding an audience for their work.
This soldier's story proves interesting but insubstantial.
Freeland's film offers a poor man's Los Angeles opus.
This chronicle of Polanski's life, career and legal woes offers an engaging portrait of the artist.

A movie whose inspiration comes straight from the DNA of some of Hitchcock's finest classics, Anderson's latest is a languid, sometimes engaging thriller that unfortunately fails to elevate those existing clichés and conventions beyond the parameters of w

Carter has with The X-Files: I Want to Believe created a mediocre mystery that relies too frequently on coincidence and screenwriting convenience to elicit genuine interest, much less "belief" in its twists and turns.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Bishop's film is an exercise in style and tone that certainly takes much from the genre that inspired it, but it certainly contributes nothing to legitimize its artistic integrity or extend its historical longevity.

Admittedly it is bloody as hell, but there's something just stylish enough about the way it's executed -- pun intended -- that even viewers with weak constitutions should be able to stomach the violence.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Actress Salma Hayek portrays the famed Mexican surrealist painter in a biopic that neither mythologizes nor decries the artist's accomplishments on or beyond the canvas.
Knockaround Guys just doesn't deserve to get made, either literally or figuratively, and isn't worth the time needed to discover that this particular up-and-comer is yesterday's news.
Brown Sugar manages to take hip-hop's well-established history and make it digestible for audiences not necessarily tied directly into the core of that culture.

The Tuxedo is sort of like a film that might have been made from a song by Burt Bacharach; its central conceit is odd, implausible, even a bit silly, but one can hardly begrudge it those elements when the thing plays so beautifully.

Starring the likes of Susan Sarandon and Dustin Hoffman, filmmaker Brad Silberling delivers a personal movie that reassures us that that we will one day understand those terrible things that happen to us.

The Banger Sisters is not a terrible film but ultimately a missed opportunity, an opportunity to show the outcomes of those deluded Band-Aids from Almost Famous, or even as a demonstration of the inevitable paths of people whose experiences peaked when th
Filmmaker Micahel Caton-Jones serves up an edgy drama filled with tragically flawed characters portrayed by Robert De Niro, James Franco and Frances MacDormand.
Sporting a cast of up-and-coming actresses, John Stockwell's surfing flick offers up a slice of entertainment that acknowledges its roots and whose throw away pleasures arrive with no guilt.

In Miguel Arteta's quirky indie feature, Jennifer Aniston searches for meaning and passion in a swirl of suburban malaise and ironically may have finally found a character who can reveal the shades of her talent.
The Time Machine is harmless, if ineffectual fun.

With Windtalkers, the glaring refutations of time, space and reality impress upon viewers the simple fact that Woo is at his best when he isn't attempting anything more significant than the most emptily satisfying explosion you're likely to enjoy - a scat

Unfaithful is not so much about the conventions of a typical bored housewife falls for exotic foreigner with disastrous results story, but in fact plumbs the depths of what really constitutes intimacy, and how complacency, rather than the melodramatic ups

After creating the most addictive drug known to man, Samuel Jackson and Robert Carlyle go on the run looking for a buyer in what turns out to be a joyride of a movie that takes its inspiration from similar films that have come before it.
Lawrence's film is probably the most fun audiences will likely have during this holiday season. But it's also the emptiest and most calculated of efforts...
A film of deadly serious conviction but undeniable convention...
A work of stunning inertia and obtuseness, Francis Ford Coppola's return to the director's chair is a disaster of career-destroying proportions...

I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With, the modest romantic comedy Garlin wrote and directed, is transparently a product of the films that inspired him to become an actor, and yet it bears no trace of individual identity...
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An emotion-filled commentary on loss, revenge and redemption, The Brave One is a smart, well-acted, engaging thriller...
In the Shadow of the Moon touches on the tip of a great and still virtually unexplored iceberg, and one that not only can melt our hearts but our currently frozen imaginations.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Halloween is about graphic brutality and absolutely nothing more.
While it's entertaining, well-acted, and professionally mounted, better time could probably be spent with our own families than watching someone take care of someone else's.

The 11th Hour is a very good movie, and its message absolutely deserves to be heard; let's just hope that in his efforts to escape the media's attention, DiCaprio hasn't situated himself in a place that will not only overshadow his celebrity, but the far

One supposes that a start-to-finish interesting film could be made from this material, especially since this essential dilemma is so ripe with dramatic potential. But Gorak treats it like a vignette rather than a windfall event...
Director Justin Theroux takes what is otherwise a fairly straightforward romantic comedy formula and turns it into an elliptical meditation on the merits of actual human connection.

Unfortunately, El Cantante turns out to be much more of an Anthony and Lopez project than a Lavoe one. Shot with seeming disregard for any of his actual artistic importance, the film fails to answer some of the simplest and most important questions about

Not all comedies need to become instant classics -- especially not when they're in the SNL-related canon -- so this film's aim is overambitious but true, earning it a rank far above Superstar or Black Sheep but below Tommy Boy or Happy Gilmore.
If you're a moviegoer specifically interested in accurate portrayals of angst, pain and disappointment, then this will almost certainly be a film for you.
A fun, if messy, compilation of the most absurd action scenes ever put on celluloid.
A movie that not only depends on but demands you don't think in order to enjoy it.

Overall, Stardust is one of the better films I've seen this summer because it is by and large more wholesome and sincere than the relentless thrill rides and self-referential comedies with which it competes.
Overall 2 Days in Paris works because it offers awkward and real but ultimately hopeful observations about the way relationships work -- and again, sometimes don't work.
Death at a Funeral has almost no delightful machinations, no consistency of tone, no relatable characters, and worst of all, no funny jokes.
The Invasion is almost too muddled to be truly bad, as if everyone involved hoped that a bunch of half-assed potential ideas could add up to an even passable real one.
The critters themselves are pretty darn adorable, and watching them mature is probably the most engaging part of the film.
Talk To Me isn't really a bad film at all, but it's so overstuffed with self-importance that it never gets to be just a good one.

But in the end Goya's Ghosts is a far riskier and more provocative film than others released this summer, less because it targets relevant issues than the fact it refuses to take a stance on them on one side or the other.
While a little bit long, Hairspray is ultimately one of the more engaging and fun movies of the summer...
Michael Bay's best film to date offers plenty of fun, but not much more than meets the eye.
Curse of the Golden Flower is a tragedy in the classic sense which is as devastating as it is entertaining.
A lackluster teenage true-crime tale.
Thanks to Knoxville and co., there is no stunt left untested, no boundary unbroken and no gag reflex left unprovoked in Jackass: Number Two - and this, resolutely, is a great thing.
Fincher creates a righteous epic about San Francisco's Zodiac killer and in so doing offers a cathartic close to the exact kind of serial tomes that made his name as an a-list moviemaker.
Michael Clayton's only real shortcoming is its name -- seldom has a more complex and interesting story been given a simpler, less appealing title.
This Spanish horror film slowly intoxicates the audience with suspense.
Chris Weitz' film is a well-executed, but not especially warm adaptation of Philip Pullman's novel.
Beowulf is like nothing you've ever seen, but not for the reasons you think.

Most audiences will look at the film and see only the simple plot of a fugitive and his two pursuers, but is there more being said and more being asked within the wide open spaces of No Country for Old Men? Indisputably.
It may not be brilliant, but it's easily the best holiday movie since Elf...
Lumet's latest proves as riveting and ambitious as any of his best work.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Seinfeld's animated feature flies a little too fast to leave a lasting impression.
Carell can't rescue this sometimes-charming romantic comedy from its real problems.
Smart and self-aware but also disjointed and discordant.
Rendition offers a reprieve right when it should really be tightening the screws.

Control is that rare greatest-hits package that makes you want to go back and explore a band's entire discography, and moreover, that razes the cliches and renders their history as new, fresh and interesting as when it originally happened.
A movie without a single redeeming quality that we highly recommend.
Gere and Howard elevate a reality-based thriller into a dynamic character study.
The main reason that I didn't like Justin Lin's new film Finishing the Game is because I wasn't sure at any time what he was trying to make...
A transcendent rather than merely tragic film...
Feast of Love is just smart, sensitive and very good -- and at a time when "success" is measured by the size or scope of a project, that's enough to distinguish it from what it is not.
The Darjeeling Limited, by comparison, feels like a more comfortable fit than its predecessor...
To paraphrase David Spade, I liked this movie the first time I saw it -- when it was called Kindergarten Cop.
December Boys is good, but not great; and as far as coming of age stories are concerned.
Fierce People, for all its ambitions, is ultimately a little too discombobulated to be truly fierce.

It's as if the (supposedly) innate hilariousness of the title justified pretty much any and all "creative" decisions, and once the actors were cast everyone hoped that the film would figure itself out. They were wrong.
It's true and even good that some movies can be about two or more subjects, but King of California can't really figure out what even one of those is...
Bad really is too delicate a word to describe the film.
Into the Wild shows you the way, but lets you choose for yourself. And hippie or no, this trip is absolutely worth the effort.
Lee's latest takes the Taiwanese director to China for a searing, sexy tale of espionage.
Kathy Baker deserves and Oscar nomination for juggling so many different feelings during her slow, reluctant acquiescence to the drugs that may likely save her life.
Suppressing laughter when I first heard about this film may rank among the most difficult challenges I have ever faced in the line of duty. And I've interviewed Vincent Gallo.

Chicago is, even for the most disavowed theatre enthusiasts, a terrifically entertaining film based on a terrifically entertaining stage musical, that exists solipsistically as an entity for entertainment. . .
Not the movie audiences anticipate, even when it acquiesces to convention.
A girthless, mirthless, Clearasil-embossed retread of the Audrey Hepburn/ Gregory Peck classic Roman Holiday.
Sadly, the once glowing Hollywood promise of Ben Affleck and director John Woo has gradually given way to good paycheck hunting.
A film from another time and place, when patience and atmosphere transcended the need for gear-shifting plot points or exaggerated characterizations.
New Zealand prodigal son Peter Jackson vaults past The Matrix and second Star Wars trilogies with the final episode of his Middle Earth saga.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A miserably dark and sluggish picture to endure. Helgeland and his stars have hopefully observed last rites on this and moved on to bigger and (especially) better things.
Wildly uneven, rife with a virtual checklist of human tragedies that build to easy emotional crescendos but fail to engage the audience well enough to evoke any meaning.
Perhaps Party Monster's limited distribution will keep this clunker from interrupting Seth Green's rise to the top of the Hollywood food chain.
A fascinating study of the '80s not merely captivated by leg warmers and shoulder pads, but by the tenor of our cultural obsessions at the time.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: As its $6.5 million take at the box office this weekend proves, even the equivalent of a bad TV movie can't keep teenagers away from movie theaters.
Even though it features a pair of conjoined twins and the one and only Cher, the Farrelly Brothers' latest comedy offers kinder, gentler laughs.
Unfortunately for the audience, what gives is the film's second half, stranding a phenomenal pair of performances by Diane Keaton and Jack Nicholson.
Proving that he is indeed the right man to remake Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, director Tim Burton envisions a world of pure imagination.
Without a conflicted Tony Manero, a blowtorch-wielding Alex Owens, or even a self-mocking Michael "Boogaloo Shrimp" Chambers, this Honey just ain't sweet enough.
Thanks to Favreau, even the film's most ridiculous detours carry a certain plausibility; he shines his indignities on and perseveres, and we can't help but sympathize.
Inarritu establishes himself beyond the ranks of one-hit wonders eager to make the big time in Hollywood and proves that Amores Perros was no fluke.
Although the ads make it sound like Zombie Day Care, Disney's $90 million thriller-comedy is not necessarily the right film to take your kids to this weekend.
Howard continues to show versatility as a director, although his steady progress through various film genres has minted a style that is more workmanlike than spectacular.
Although it tries valiantly, Hollywood's latest horror film is nowhere near as scary as the pitch meeting that is likely responsible for its existence.
For many devoted Wachowski Brothers fans, this trilogy-ending film inspires nothing more than the whispered words "I'm out."
For reviewer Todd Gilchrist, puberty began in earnest when he witnessed Sigourney Weaver getting physical aboard a doomed spaceship.
Long before plastic surgery became the vogue in Beverly Hills, a 1960 horror classic proved its power to destroy the relationship between a father and daughter.
Despite a pair of spectacular characterizations by Mel Gibson and Robert Downey Jr., the film version of Dennis Potter's BBC miniseries plays a little offkey.
The only thing scarier than the opening weekend box office of this horror spoof trequel is the body count of unfunny jokes.
A mirage, or perhaps fever-dream, designed to blind the senses and take audiences on a ride not unlike the one Keir Dullea endured once he ventured into 2001's black hole.
We all know how good Morgan Freeman is. But it's time to celebrate the impeccable comic timing of his easygoing co-star Owen Wilson.
The dialogue is almost a bit too conscious of its own wittiness and street-tough colloquialisms.
Sadistic: Gratuitous Vs. Arbitrary.
If movies like Bad Lieutenant and Spun are your idea of a good time, then DMX has the film for you.
Dawn of the Dead is scary as hell.
Much like the Flintstones movies, this sequel is better than the original but still falls far short of the post-modern genius of its original cartoon series.
As a Coen brothers movie competing with their own masterpieces, The Ladykillers can only be considered a near-miss.
Promises a glimpse into a world that few have yet been able to explore, but fails to deliver on much more than the basest levels of entertainment.
movie_title: Red Trousers: The Life of the Hong Kong Stuntmen (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Jim Carrey finds a muse who combines the subversiveness of Andy Kaufman, the imagination of Dr. Seuss and the fearlessness of the Farrelly Brothers.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Sadly, nothing in this thriller comes close to the intensity of last year's media coverage of star Ethan Hawke's alleged infidelities on location in Montreal.
I can honestly say it's the funniest movie I've seen this year, and a great reminder of what dumb, fun movies are supposed to really be about.
It's almost refreshing to watch a film that acknowledges it's just a plain old 'R'-rated comedy, with adult but not distasteful levels of nudity, violence and profanity.
The problem with being asked to name the worst Hollywood thriller starring Ashley Judd is that you first have to be able to tell them apart.
By turning the Greatest Story Ever Told into the Goriest Story Ever Told, director Mel Gibson breaks the filmmaking commandment Thou Shall Not Overkill.
Hoffman's presence as a familiar face gives us a personality to latch onto, that of the man whose support in countless fictional films we relied upon.
In a comedy that could just as easily have been titled Grumpy Middle-Aged Men, Ray Romano and Gene Hackman are forced to make do with so-so material.
Barbershop 2 is that rare exception of a sequel that actually surpasses the original.
Russell as Brooks is the year's first truly great performance, giving up nothing but what is necessary to convey the coach's legendary determination.
A welcome, entertaining, and fun ride.
The elements of tragedy aren't life and death issues in this movie, and Anderson's film wisely contains itself to the microcosm of this one man's beleaguered existence.
The addition of just enough original ideas, has been, and hopefully will remain the key to keeping the franchise fresh, original and exciting.
Minority Report is a film for the critical cognoscenti as much as it is for the Goober-munching masses, and succeeds for all audiences.
Enjoy this film they will.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A gripping and well-made thriller that preserves Shyamalan's winning streak and shows us, as all the best films do, a world that we're familiar with and believe in, and yet we've never seen, and by which we're endlessly fascinated.

XXX seems like a missed opportunity -- not a commercial one, mind you, because the flick will no doubt make a mint -- but as an honest-to-goodness re-evaluation of spy flicks and their relevancy to an ever more youthful audience.
Its thrills fall with metronome-like precision, exactly when they are expected, and the clues complete the puzzle without surprise or personality.

Too celebratory of Woo's good guy-versus-bad guy, buddy-buddy ethos of action movies to rise above the limitations of the genre, and too obsessed with its own seriousness to be a truly 'serious' film.
Maybe Bernardo Bertolucci should have stuck with his original plan to make a sequel to his epic 1900, because his latest film is a major disappointment.
Gooding Jr.'s dexterous avoidance of attention as Radio puts him among today's most formidable actors, previous bad movie choices be damned.
In The Cut falls short on execution, with Campion's unique and powerful vision undermined by the conventions of a traditional genre.
Pieces Of April is no good and no amount of Sundance catfights for its distribution rights will convince me otherwise
Spike Lee's most compelling and resonant picture in years.
. . .its exploration of ambition, loneliness and passion is amongst the most emotionally resonant in many years.
. . .one of the year's most insightful and evocative films.
Biker Boyz spins its wheels, makes with the smoke and the noise, but never really gets very far - and for a movie about motorcycle racing, that's like coming in last place.
Shyamalan's latest is an improvement, but a full-fledged comeback ain't happening.
Confessions Of A Dangerous Mind is the latest, and most promising evolution of Clooney's career. . .
. . .a noble effort to bring the thrills of Bollywood to America, but this magic carpet never quite gets off the ground because it traffics in too many cinematic clichés. . .

. . .weighted with such dramatic heft that one can do little more than marvel at its seriousness, embrace the tragedy that lies within, and then, once all of the crying is finished, never see it again.
. . .the film ends as a nonentity, arriving at a conclusion that is not satisfying and completely nonsensical because it preys on our stupidity rather than that of the characters.

Admittedly, one might be reticent to embrace the film's subject matter, but Caro's sensitivity to the characters and the magnetic realism of the performances behind them will win more than most audiences' sympathies.

The film's spectacle outweighs the character or story elements that truly evoke audiences' attentions in the lasting or memorable ways that did the incipient franchises which no doubt inspired it. . .
Spielberg. . .supersedes even himself with one of the most enjoyable and compelling films of his career.
LThe Life of David Gale goes quietly into that good night during the doldrums of February, when studios discard their noble failures. . .
. . .one of the most singularly ambitious big-budget studio movies to crash cineplexes in several years.

Amiel's film is a messy, speculative chamber piece augmented by indistinct visual effects and performances that seem to be playing directly to the blue-screen backgrounds instead of to the actors who were hired to make the highfalutin conceit plausible.
Carrey's latest is a return if you will - albeit only a slightly more mature one - to the slapstick that made his the biggest name in big-screen comedies.

. . . a film designed for dispassionate enjoyment, a summer distraction that doesn't quite leave you feeling like you were thieved of your nine bucks but also feels like a shallow return on your investment.
. . . a mishmash of B-movie clichés and horribly shot sequences assembled as a pre-emptive strike on the summer movie season which instead lands clumsily in theatres as a forgettable diversion. . .

Ghosts Of the Abyss is an interesting experiment which fails to take full advantage of the real opportunity granted in its inception - to utilize emerging technology to explore terrain that has never been witnessed by humans. . .
Malibu's Most Wanted absconds with a simplistic but imaginative plot and elevates it beyond the realm of sketch comedy into legitimate cinematic territory - for real, y'all.
People I Know rests not at the bottom of that pile, not at the top, but just out of range of significance, to be forgotten the minute the audience's back is turned.
. . . few audience members will find something in the mélange of clichéd and clever ideas that doesn't personally resonate at some level. It Runs In the Family knows the words, but not the music. . .
The Matrix Reloaded proudly lives up to the hype and expectations of a world full of fans waiting for nothing less than the second coming of cinema itself.
Let the gauntlet be thrown: Spider-Man may be the best comic adaptation of all time.
The Hunted is as generic and unspecial a movie as its title suggests, a loose bundle of filmmaking formulas that leaves the viewer disengaged. . .
Perlman's natural gruffness lends depth to the character's one-liners as moments of levity rather than calculated quips from a screenwriter's pen.
Gangs Of New York is a magnificent film, and is challengingly about more than the sum of its' parts.

Maid In Manhattan ultimately leaves nothing whatsoever for the viewer to grasp. . .leaving another dead carcass of Hollywood convention packed away and frozen for reheating by audiences who can find nothing else in the cupboard to eat.
Sylvia follows in the footsteps of such recent biographical films as Pollock and the superlative Frida, but fails to capture the elements that made the author's work.
With Runaway Jury, Grisham is finally able to do justice on screen to the unspoken, external forces that no doubt undermine our justice system.
McCarthy's impressive directorial debut reflects, like few other films in recent memory, the feeling that we aren't alone, no matter how much we might think we want to be.
Kill Bill is, at long last, the revolution Pulp Fiction fans hoped Jackie Brown was going to be ... leaves the stomach turning, the tongue lolling and the mind reeling.
Director David Leland crafts an evocative and entertaining concert film that captivates the heart and mind, regardless how familiar you are with the incredible repertoire of the "quiet Beatle."
After nearly four dozen films and acclaim for his real-life band Tenacious D, one-man dynamo Jack Black finally hits the jack-pot with, of all things, a family-friendly comedy.

A sadly appropriate follow-up to DeVito's Death To Smoochy debacle, Duplex reveals not only the actors' and filmmakers' narcissism, but the studios' arrogance that such a calculated combination of proven talent will necessarily result in box office glory-
Lost In Translation inspires a unique feeling of optimism, a sense that there are more people than we expect who understand our lifelong conundrums.

Wasting little time on unnecessary setup or character development to concentrate on blistering and brilliantly-executed action, The Rundown is an Indiana Jones-style movie that embraces the secular pleasures of a good, swift kick in the cojones.
A forgettable import, a film that possesses too much style by half but unlike the films of John Woo or Tsui Hark never knows well enough to abandon the action for a moment of simple, cogent thought.

A thrilling, entertaining spectacle which easily lives up to the legacy of its predecessors and proves that the director's time spent with the Spy Kids franchise hasn't diminished his ability to create effective adult-level thrills.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The Two Towers is riveting entertainment - few films could cover such distance (in both narrative and geographical senses) with such assurance - but it remains hard to explain with great certainty the details of the plot.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: . . .no adult, and certainly no parent, should have to endure the attention-grabbing temper tantrum that is Thirteen.
. . one of the year's best. . it celebrates the unique rhythms of the individual, and reminds us how those reverberate in the whole of human existence.
Open Range is not the Western's last hurrah, but it may be Costner's.
How To Deal eventually folds because it stacks its deck against a true belief in the possibility of love. . .
It's a trainwreck of a film. . .too little substance, too long in the telling, and too bad too many opportunities were squandered in its making. . .
A well-executed conclusion to one of the better comedy series of recent years, American Wedding is a last great hurrah for the characters. . .
With such strident resistance to hyperbolic, risk-taking absurdity, such a film can hardly ever aspire to rise above the ranks of the merely ordinary.

The film's elaborate, high-tech chase and fight scenes are deliriously entertaining. . . but those hidden gaps in continuity, story and pacing reveal what's truly missing from this effects-laden behemoth: a soul.
Full Throttle is a movie that could be a preview for itself: a sad reminder of what was, a hint of what might be, and with any luck, the foretelling of what will never be again.
. . . a death rattle for movies that emulate Woody Allen's formula but slip in and out of theatres without the twinge of emotional resonance that the master seemed to effortlessly evoke.
. . .megaplex masterpiece. . .the summer's best film so far, and a front contender for year-end top ten lists with six months still left to go.
Dumb And Dumberer is like a punch line without a joke - confusing, unfunny, and ultimately worthless.
movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Hard to believe as it must seem, Chan has made a terrifically entertaining film, an action movie that delivers exactly what its audience wants, and a superlative entry into his growing canon of stateside films.
As a critic, I've often been bored and offended by the movies I've watched, but Cursed may be the first time I can remember being outright insulted by one.
The Prince & Me proves that the "opposites attract" genre of romantic comedy is an all but dead convention.
Willis gives head cases a bad name, never quite letting even his fellow actors in on the joke that he took this particular job for the paycheck.
Godard has made a film whose title translates into Our Music, but he fails to realize that the band is playing only for him.
Fits snugly into the 'Christmas movie' canon by tapping into familiar problems, tugging at the heartstrings and stirring your tired soul.
What makes Depp so incredible as an on screen presence is his generosity. He hardly commands the screen as much as he shares it with his co-stars.
Isn't likely to be branded as either Bruckheimer's best or worst; but his latest bit of Cage carnage is well-acted, well-directed and full of interesting ideas.
I can hardly recount the many scenes of inspired madness, including the sight of David Hasselhoff shooting across the water like a human hydrofoil.
The edge of reason is clearly broached when Renee Zellweger's character starts teaching Thai prison inmates the words to Madonna's "Like a Virgin."
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The first spectacular surprise of this holiday season.
Delves deep into the creative process, unlike almost any film before it, to show where and how producers and rappers come together to make a hit song.
A precedent-setting concert doc.
Unlike other preternaturally attractive male stars, Law doesn't seem to carry that instantaneous, off-putting smugness that necessitates a thorough comeuppance by film's end.
There's no way to approach this mess other than to evaluate who's been naughty and who's been nice. Guess which half of the list has way more names on it?
Like a perfect Pinot Noir, Payne's latest film is an intoxicating mix of adult bitterness, lush Santa Barbara vineyards and the year's early standout male performance.
An embodiment of everything Affleck should be fighting against  a completely sanitized, uncomplicated and bland effort.
Eulogy is about one half of a really good movie.
Buries more characters and plot lines than it has screen time for, and fails to put to rest many of the questions it raises.
Lopez has the simultaneous gift and curse of being exactly as good as her material; she fully inhabits the solemnity of Paulina without overshadowing the central conflict.
Annette Bening finally finds a role that will ease her into advancing age with style but grace.
Annette Bening finally finds a role that will ease her into advancing age with style and grace. If only the rest of the movie could keep up with her.
Forget about Fahrenheit 9/11; this is the most incisive political film of 2004.
The images are hypnotic and unnerving, elevating what might have been a masturbatory exercise into something transcendent and genuinely moving.
Black is positively riveting to watch; who would have expected the gangly kid who befriended Carl Childers in Sling Blade to now be muscling his mentor out of the picture?
If you're planning to see Raise Your Voice, lower your expectations. Then lower them some more. Even then, you'll be disappointed.
Russell continues to be able to write to Wahlberg's strengths, steering him towards a believable mania encompassing some of the movie's best and most touching comedic moments.
The literal translation of Zhang Yimou's latest is Ambush from Ten Sides, which pretty much sums up how the filmmaker has recently taken hold of the American imagination.
Even Parker Posey's turn as a campy vampiress feels phoned in, as if she is making bank in order to stomach the deferred or minimal pay of her next ten indie pet projects.
It's the new recruits - Catherine Zeta-Jones, Vincent Cassel, Robbie Coltrane and comedian Eddie Izzard - who really steal this show.
One of the year's most ambitious and richly entertaining pictures.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Whether or not he becomes the next Jet Li or Van Damme, Jaa can at least lay claim to not only having the martial arts moves, but also the haircut to match.
Hitch isn't the 'cure for the common man,' as its tagline suggests; but it's definitely the cure for the common.
No matter how far you think it will go, it keeps probing deeper, until it turns your perceptions inside out.
The magnetic chemistry of the actors ... elevates the story's familiar rhythms above leagues of imitators.
A memorably digestible piece of entertainment that will wow fans of Jet Li, Jackie Chan and DMX.
The audience develops a growing disconnect between the two stories of Tony the swimmer and Tony the son, lessening the impact of the overall film.
The Woodsman is a difficult movie to watch, but it's one that cannot be turned away from.
As fantastic a filmgoing experience as you're likely to have this year or next.
Sam Bicke ... is the role Penn was born to play -- if only because it's different than any others he's ever done -- and makes the film the triumph it is.
It's never good when the audience starts laughing as soon as the movie begins -- and nothing has happened.
A sweaty bit of smut disguised as high-class suspense.
A brilliantly crafted comedy with multiple layers.
A distillation of so many rom-com formulas and conventions it's hard to know whether the filmmakers even realized what they were actually doing.
Once Emily Deschanel, older sister of Elf's Zooey, steps on screen to provide Tim with a formidable female co-star, the film finds its rhythm.
Mulroney contributes virtually nothing save a convincing profile and makes the transition to lover-for-life feel about as shallow as a single-tiered wedding cake.
Cameron's extrapolation of undersea exploration into the realm of outer space amounts to little more than atomic age fiction for the layperson.
Tara Reid responds to the camera like she's just caught a paparazzo; every line of dialogue begins with, 'Hey guys,' be it ordering lunch or reacting to mortal danger.
If I hadn't spent the majority of the film's running time coming up with alternate titles (Is This Thing Over Yet?), I'd almost think that Cube had made a fruitful step.
It's both a romantic fable and a hell movie for wannabe players - each in all the wrong measures.
The filmmakers are too busy trying to justify their futuristic world, and not enough actually exploring it.
No matter how many times I hear about the actress' arresting good looks, I just can't get past the fact that she always comes across as slightly mannish.
A spectacle of understatement, a triumph of deference, and a cinematic snapshot as memorable as any real image captured in 2004.
Much like his adaptations of The Client and the French film Cousin, Cousine, Schumacher is able to fully embrace the spectacle of the source material.
Schumacher's never-surer hand helps his leading lady and her erstwhile suitors find the right emotional rhythms to accompany the musical ones.
Ultimately gets too caught up in its own current.
'Going yodeling in the canyon' was my particular favorite of film's sexual fetish euphemisms, but I could have done without 'Roman showers' and 'Plate job.'
Shark Tale feels like a modest step backwards [for CGI films], a regression not visually but conceptually.
Combines a hodgepodge of political, personal, and artistic expressions into one remarkable and moving motion picture.
The original was a movie for all those castaways who believe in unexplained phenomenon; the new version reads like a handbook on how to pick up women.
Filmmaker Alex Proyas finally finds the perfect balance between the real world and the one of his imagination, breathing humanity into a genre gleaming with artifice.
Not since last year's Old School have I actually laughed afterward at a film's gags, remembering each one as if seeing it for the first time.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Clive Owen fails to engender much sympathy from the audience when attempting to rouse his troops for the umpteenth time against seemingly insurmountable odds.
Finds the rhythm of your heart, plays it like a finely-tuned grand piano, and makes for the summer's most sublimely catchy moviegoing experience.
Plot developments are labored upon so heavily that I felt compelled to stand up in my seat during the screening and shout out, 'Okay! We get it!'
Once upon a time, great movies about American political conspiracies were the domain of Oliver Stone. Now, that cinematic realm clearly belongs to Michael Moore.
Precisely the horrible kind of heart-wrenching pabulum that's been milked damn near dry by countless other so-called "timeless" cinematic tales of passion.
Soars high above the low-level ambition of its competition and makes us anticipate subsequent installments rather than reminisce about their predecessors.
As a movie star, Garfield is a cat declawed and robbed of his essential, inscrutable charm.
With Riddick, audiences finally have the kind of movie for which terms like blockbuster were born.
The original was a movie for all those castaways who believe in unexplained phenomenon; the new version reads like a handbook on how to pick up women.
All you need to know about this movie is that 'I hate Mondays,' Garfield's memorable comic strip punch line, is way funnier when Puss-in-Boots utters it in Shrek 2.
While he doesn't quite make the same sort of giant leap his father made, Mario takes a small step with an expertise and enthusiasm anyone could appreciate.
Chris Rock, Rob Schneider, Sean William Scott ... Any one of these performers could have provided Emmerich's disaster with the comic relief it so desperately lacks.
The last two skits are the best; the first features Bill Murray, RZA, and GZA, and the second stage actors Bill Rice and Taylor Mead.
Foxx's latest film lives up to its title by deconstructing sex comedies and bringing a much needed dose of intelligence to a typically slow-witted genre.
Suspenseless, charmless, and humorless. A hybrid that manages to stitch together only the loosest frameworks of their imagination, creativity, or wit.
With Moore and Brosnan as the star-crossed pair, the sparks that fly are brighter than in your typical romantic comedy.
The irony of Man on Fire's success is that its premise sounds like just the kind of middle-concept idea that director Scott would normally bring low.
