an effectively intense and moody horror film that rests on its writing and acting rather than subscribing to rote depictions of violence.

operates as actively on a metaphorical level as a visceral one, provides commentary in addition to compelling visuals, and ultimately exceeds the value of its central conceit thanks to execution that seamlessly merges form and content.

An engaging, well-made action comedy that benefits from the talents of its decidedly mature cast members, even if it unspools with a pace better suited to their generation than the moviegoers that grew up watching their earlier movies.
a successful film for newcomers to the material, but it fails to justify its existence to those familiar with its previous incarnation.
a movie that operates with a certain, charming simplicity, but doesn't dig up much else of interest than gore delivered by the gallon.
as engaging as it frequently is, Hartley's latest offers only a tourist's-eye view of its subject matter, crafting a unique, interesting documentary that fails to feel truly immersive.
A colossal misfire that offers nothing to viewers but unimaginative, distasteful brutality.
a fascinating true-life story that suffers only from trying too hard to be completely true to life.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: the kind of film that you can't take your eyes off of, even though it never seems to call attention to itself.
It's like a sweater that's been pulled at from the top and bottom - it's so spread out that you can't see anything any more but the holes, even if you really wanted to admire the design.
an ambitious, one-of-a-kind, fully-realized, smart, sensitive and satisfying work of cinema
the dance sequences are as unique and imaginative as any storytelling form any filmmaker's attempted this year.
one of Ferrell's all-time best performances, probably McKay's most cohesive film to date, and one of the most all-around satisfying comedies in years.
destined to become a cult classic that actually also deserves to be seen.
It's interesting that Tales From Earthsea was originally released in 2006... especially since it seems like in four years, someone could have found a way to make it more interesting.
Red White & Blue succeeds because it shows you the devastating violence that can be wrought against others, as well as the depths of humanity that its perpetrator can possess.

Monsters feels a little bit like the end result of an adaptation of War of the Worlds that Steven Spielberg might have made back when he still had the limited resources and boundless inventiveness of his Jaws days
no matter how pretty it looks, it provides little reason to care about what happens while you're looking at it.
an almost-great film whose cultural significance unfortunately outweighs its emotional substance.
a knuckle-headed action movie that has less creativity or ambition than it does money and star power
Pretty much what you would expect from the screenwriter of disappointing films such as Scream 3, Reindeer Games and Arlington Road.
It starts with a bang, but ultimately, the wheels come off this covered wagon.
Director Kerry Conran hasn't just mimicked his favorite serials and comic books. He's written a love letter to the full scope of 1930s and '40s films by basically making one.

movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Saved! could have been a challenging but affirming movie about the evangelical subculture -- if handled with the same love, acceptance and tolerance it preaches.

movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_title: In the Name of the Father (1993)

movie_review_blurb: A gritty and gratifying cheap thrill, Rob Cohen's high-octane hot-car meller is a true rarity these days, a really good exploitationer, the sort of thing that would rule at drive-ins if they still existed.
A very vulgar pro-faith comedy rather than a sacrilegious goof, Dogma is an extraordinarily uneven film that significant cutting might be able to transform into a playable one.
Setup promises a sort of modern Three Stooges takeoff that, unfortunately, is only haphazardly delivered.

Cute, rambunctious, generally amusing rather than outright funny, this clever mix of live action, highlighted by the unequaled skills of basketball superstar Michael Jordan, and animated Looney Tunes antics will be a must-see for kids.
A deafness-inducing but otherwise ho-hum would-be expose of shady recruiting practices by college basketball programs.
This transferral of the tragedy of the Moor to a contempo American high school is something that never should have gone further than a class assignment to see if it could be made to work.
Intermittently engaging but dramatically slack.
Aims only to please and proves perfectly amiable, but ultimate effect is one of much energy expended to minimal payoff.
Although it exists primarily to send an audience into a bloodthirsty frenzy and has major credibility problems in the bargain, Unlawful Entry is still a very effective victimization thriller.
An irresistible treat with enough narrative twists and memorable characters for a half-dozen films.

Although too simplistic in its good-guys/bad-guys approach to morally and emotionally ambiguous material, Cop Land emerges as an absorbing and dramatic yarn about exposing the evil doings of some of New York's finest.
When working in genre territory before, the idiosyncratic Kaufman has shown a marked tendency to debunk or subvert conventions. Playing it straight here, he brings little to the table.
The far-fetched plotting eventually goes so far over the top that pic flirts with inventing a new genre of film noir camp.
The picture easily snatches from Revolution the prize as Al Pacino's career worst.
Despite excellent lead performances and numerous memorable scenes, this still feels like two different movies in one.
A tailor-made girls' night out movie, Baby Mama is a tidily wrapped package the contents of which you can easily guess before opening it.
Washington's steely grip on his impersonation of Frank Lucas holds the film together.

Conveying an astonishing array of information across a long narrative arc while still maintaining dramatic rhythm and tension, this adaptation of Robert Graysmith's bestseller reps by far director David Fincher's most mature and accomplished work.
Amiable but no more.
Far more infatuated with its own cleverness than audiences are likely to be.
Jarrod and Horsley, odd as they are as screen subjects, undeniably make an indelible impression, but result is still innocuously mild and inconsequential.
Just as somber as The Good Shepherd, the most recent domestic spy drama, but more tightly focused, Breach absorbingly zeroes in on how the FBI nailed the most damaging turncoat in American history.
The amusement inherent in watching Hugh Grant play a washed-up '80s boy-band pop star angling for a comeback provides Music and Lyrics with its catchy hook.
A blustery, bombastic, visually arresting account of the Battle of Thermopylae as channeled through the rabid imagination of graphic novelist Frank Miller.
Insidiously engaging low-budgeter employs a literate sensibility, breezy tone and warm performances.
Undeniably impressive pic grabs the viewer by the lapels and shakes hard, but it also is about nothing other than a bunch of macho guys and how big their guns are.
A spectacularly entertaining piece of pop culture.
The excitement, majesty and extraordinary human accomplishment of the American lunar program of the '60s and early '70s is rousingly captured in In the Shadow of the Moon.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Offers an abundance of pleasures, especially in the realm of characterization and atmosphere.
A prodigious achievement that conveys the fabric of modern American life, aspirations and incidentally, sports, in close-up and at length, Hoop Dreams is a documentary slam dunk.
Its skeptical, disillusioned take on big government and official deceptions should strike a vibrant chord with a wide range of audiences.
Enormously entertaining.
Awesome and harrowing.
A sharp-minded, plenty entertaining toon that will keep children of all ages wide-eyed and on their toes.

The 1970s exploitation movie gropes, bites, kicks, slugs, blasts, smashes and cusses its way back to life in Grindhouse, a 'Rodriguez/Tarantino double feature' that lovingly resurrects a disreputable but cultishly embraced form.
[The] result is a travesty that will please no one, least of all Welles enthusiasts.
The pic oozes the charm and personality of an industrial film.
Prefontaine gets to the finish line in reasonable shape despite plenty of sloppy running along the way.
A game, disarming lead performance from Jess Weixler, who won a jury acting prize at Sundance, goes some way toward making palatable this mish-mash.
Theroux doesn't maintain firm control of the tone, particularly going astray in attempts at comic interludes as well as in the ending.
A well-executed, handsome-looking film that runs perhaps 20 minutes longer than it should given its storyline.
Lacking the drama of Jesus' trial and the passion, as well as the substance of his teachings, (actor Jean Claude) LaMarre's turgid take has very little to offer dramatically or inspirationally.
Impressively crafted and acted but far too narrowly and benignly conceived to satisfy even on its own terms.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, Che doesn't feel epic -- just long.
Casino Royale sees Bond himself recharged with fresh toughness and arrogance, along with balancing hints of sadism and humanity, just as the fabled series is reinvigorated by going back to basics.

George Miller's long-in-the-works dive into full-blown computer animation drapes a relatively conventional story, about a young penguin's struggles over being 'different,' in striking visuals, invigorating songs and lively characterizations.
Memories of dreary Sunday school classes come flooding back courtesy of The Nativity Story.
Mel Gibson is always good for a surprise, and his latest is that Apocalypto is a remarkable film.
The Good German has little of the luster, sheen and pictorial nuance of a top-flight Hollywood picture of the old school.
Taken together, Flags and Letters represent a genuinely imposing achievement, one that looks at war unflinchingly -- that does not deny its necessity but above all laments the human loss it entails.
This highly polished picture is superficially faithful, even reverential to its source, but evinces neither imagination nor a personality of its own.
Intelligent scripting, solid thesping and eye-catching location shooting aren't enough to make a compelling modern film of The Painted Veil

The self-centered brat at the center of Prozac Nation spends most of her time making life miserable for everyone around her, but there's little reason the public should have to pay for the same privilege.
Not even the considerable talents of lead thesps Catherine Keener and Ellen Page can alleviate the artistic nullity that is An American Crime.

Brett Morgen's agit-prop documentary augments its excellent assemblage of archival footage with capture-motion animation to rep the courtroom antics, all in the service of an ideologically loaded approach.
Tamara Jenkins excels more at maximizing individual moments here than at developing a meaty storyline. But a great many of the moments are choice.
Hounddog is an indigestible gumbo of Southern Gothic ingredients seasoned with snake oil, biblical hash and thoroughly unpalatable spice.

Although clearly coming from an antiwar perspective, the story's emotional effectiveness and family grounding give the film a real shot at connecting with general audiences across the political spectrum.

Writer-director Martin Hynes takes advantage of the vast possibilities of the open road and what can only be refashioned personal experience to invigorate The Go-Getter, an unusually fresh-feeling indie with a nice sense of style.
Boasts enough in the way of sharp acting, as well as visual and musical smarts, to give the psychological twists and turns a respectable aesthetic context.
A seamless, pulsating, dazzlingly visual revenge fantasy that stands as one of the most effective live-actioners ever derived from a comic strip.

Where Burton's ideas end and those of his collaborators begin is impossible to know, but result is a seamless, utterly consistent universe full of nasty notions about societal deterioration, greed and other base impulses.

The villains, Arnold Schwarzenegger and especially Uma Thurman in this instance, remain the highlights here, as the rest of the gargantuan production lacks the dash and excitement that would have given the franchise a boost in its eighth year.

After the significant improvement of the second installment over the first, new entry reps a roughly equivalent dip in quality and enjoyment, with Spidey now giving off the faint odor of running on fumes.
Lacks a narrative and a center, much like the "ghost" at its core.
A capable but modest directorial debut by Alison Eastwood.

Dialogue and pic overall are saved from cloying glibness by the fact that Juno is not only a smarty-pants, but also genuinely smart and self-possessed, even if her condition occasionally threatens her composure.
A mostly engaging compilation of 33 three-minute films made by leading international auteurs on the occasion of the Cannes Film Festival's 60th birthday.
movie_title: Chacun son cinéma (To Each His Cinema) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Even Witherspoon, normally the most spirited of performers who can inject even limited characters and blah scripts with her own spark, can do little but mope around and search for different ways to look worried.
Eastern Promises instantly takes its place among David Cronenberg's very best films.

Overall, pic takes a small-minded view of history and, in its rush to proceed from one tumultuous event to the next, lacks any sense of occasion relative to the significant pageant it attempts to depict.
The early, pre-fame days of the Beatles are a great subject for a film, but the potential has been only partly realized in Backbeat.
Vacuous, arid and terminally dull.
Nothing Is Private is transgressive without being effectively subversive, gutsy to no particular end. It simply lacks style, which counts for so much in this sort of thing.
A dramatic situation that should be wrenching is mostly tedious in Reservation Road.
A mismatched marriage of offbeat character study and unimaginative horror riffs.

The juiciest part is Hopkins,' and he makes the most of it. Helped by some highly dramatic lighting, actor makes the role the personification of brilliant, hypnotic evil, and the screen jolts with electricity whenever he is on.

Wholly absorbing and inspired in parts, this carefully crafted curio dares to suggest that Murnau made a Faustian pact with an actual vampire to play the title role in exchange for the neck of the film's leading lady at production's end.
Made with care, authenticity and attention to detail.

Pic is dramatic but lacks a dynamic; one can sense the director's intent and affection for the form, but also see that working in this stylized vein does not necessarily come easily for a filmmaker of his hitherto more naturalistic tendencies.
Overall, this Dracula could have been less heavy and more deliciously evil than it is, but it does offer a sumptuous engorgement of the senses.
A live-wire performance by Benicio Del Toro sparks an otherwise morose study of loss, addiction and catharsis.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A bloodless comic resurrection of the undead that goes serious just when it should get wild and woolly.
Margot at the Wedding is a circus of family neuroses and bad behavior that perhaps a therapist could make sense of better than Noah Baumbach can.
Boldly and magnificently strange, There Will Be Blood marks a significant departure in the work of Paul Thomas Anderson.
It's a magnificent throwback to a time when filmmakers found all sorts of ways to refashion Hollywood's oldest and most durable genre.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The bawdy jokes score big points, but it's the rueful acknowledgement of adolescent embarrassment and humiliation that most distinguishes Superbad.

A riveting, thematically probing, richly atmospheric and just occasionally troublesome work, a deeply inquisitive consideration of the extent of trust and mutual knowledge possible between a man and a woman.
While still mirthful and eccentric enough to amuse his hordes of admirers, the irascible green ogre begins to show signs of encroaching middle age in Shrek the Third.

... while the actors' dialogue delivery is perfectly natural, the aphoristic philosophical nuggets Wong favors sound banal and clunky in this context, leaving the film thematically in the shallow end of the pool.
A scorching blast of tense genre filmmaking shot through with rich veins of melancholy, down-home philosophy and dark, dark humor.
Through immaculate use of picture, sound and time, the director adds another panel to his series of pictures about disaffected, disconnected youth.

Although overall impact of Tarantino's homage to chick-driven actioners and auto demolition derbies remains about the same, pic's second half, in particular, benefits from the further detailing it's now received.

As smooth as a good mojito, as stylish as an Armani suit and as meaningful in the grand scheme of things as yesterday's Las Vegas betting odds, Ocean's Thirteen continues the breezy good times of the first two series entries without missing a beat.
The third feature by Iranian emigre Ramin Bahrani follows the lead of his last pic, Man Push Cart, in tightly observing a protag on the most invisible margins of U.S. life.

Adequately acted and flecked with the required quota of action to satisfy genre fans, pic recalls numerous good police dramas of the 1970s, but mostly in superficial ways that bring nothing new to the table.

A must-see among genre fans, especially guys in their teens and 20s, for whom the script's pretentious mumbo-jumbo of undergraduate mythology, religious mysticism and technobabble could even be a plus rather than a dramatic liability.
Donnie Darko has plenty of problems. But most stem from a young filmmaker overswinging on his first time up to the plate and hitting a deep fly out rather than a home run.
Slightly overlong effort is full of striking, fresh visual interludes showing cars, speed and the sensations surrounding the scene.
If it's true that there's an 8-year-old boy inside every man, Transformers is just the ticket to bring the kid out.
Tone careens madly from serious peril to action camp and everything in between, but the sheer quantity of often outrageous stunts should help overcome franchise mustiness.

The metaphors are all implicit and have a lot to do with just growing up and facing unpleasant realities, but they increasingly contribute to the feeling of nervousness and unease creeping into the series.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A wickedly funny high school comedy for most of its running time, Rushmore is a bracingly fresh and original outing.
A super-smart black comedy about high school politics and teenage suicide that showcases a host of promising young talents.
Agreeably prepared and attractively presented.
The third and purportedly final installment in the mountingly exciting series is a pounding, pulsating thriller that provides an almost constant adrenaline surge for nearly two hours.
Reinforced by a strong central premise, James Mangold's remake walks a fine line in retaining many of the original's qualities while smartly shaking things up a bit.
Kaufman's venturesome dramaturgy and compelling writing scene-by-scene are enough to keep one's curiosity piqued.
Although perhaps familiar in its outer trappings, Pacino's fine work is the key to the film succeeding to the extent that it does.
A smooth adaptation of John Grisham's giant bestseller that is destined to be one of the summer's strong audience pleasers.
A terrific cast of exciting actors socks over this absorbingly complicated yarn that's been spun in seductively slick fashion by director Bryan Singer.
Higher Learning has a great many things on its mind, which immediately places it in a rather exclusive category of American films these days.
A quiet work with Ozu-like structure and concerns, but remains more an intellectual exercise than one from the heart.
movie_title: A Thousand Years of Good Prayers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An intense study of sibling rivalry set in the Seattle music world, Georgia excels at the expression of painfully unresolvable family conflicts.
An adroitly and tenderly observed account of the life of Harvey Milk.
A notable improvement on its predecessor in every department.
A potentially exceptional story is told in a flatly unexceptional manner in Defiance.
Has a verve and cheekiness that's partly a smart wedding of such influences as Sergio Leone, George Miller and south-of-the-border noir.
The same histrionic fireworks that gripped theater audiences will prove even more compelling to filmgoers due to the star power and dramatic screw-tightening.
An OK Disney animated entry enhanced by nifty 3-D projection.

A deliriously trashy, exuberantly vulgar, lavishly appointed exploitation picture, this weird combo of road-kill movie and martial-arts vampire gorefest is made to order for the stimulation of teenage boys.
Embracing grand old-school melodrama while critiquing racist old-fashioned politics, Baz Luhrmann's grandiose Australia provides a luxurious bumpy ride.
Plot is overloaded with hard-to-take factors.
Close to an ideal jumping-off point for Carrey, who spends the better part of an hour grotesquely physicalizing his scummy lawyer's struggle with being obliged to utter cold, hard facts.
A richly satisfying serving of deep-dish Hollywood storytelling.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [An] oddly misanthropic, occasionally amusing but thoroughly cheerless holiday attraction.

The dynamic between Daniels' vigorous, if self-involved, artist father and Paquin's initially sullen, eventually self-discovering teenager is warmly and believably conveyed, with both thesps doing strongly individualistic work.
Basically a one-joke farce that plays around with a once-delicate subject that by now is a mainstay even on TV.
Revolutionary Road is a very good bigscreen adaptation of an outstanding American novel -- faithful, intelligent, admirably acted, superbly shot.
A fine cast makes sure Noel Coward's champagne remains bubbly in Easy Virtue, an effervescent entertainment.
With the relatively untested Black coming on awfully strong, the lack of directorial finesse lets the enterprise down, creating some clunky scenes and dead air where laughs might have been expected.

Earnestly presented and well acted, particularly by newcomer Nicole Beharie in the central role, the film shares with many other such agenda-driven dramas a complete lack of narrative surprise, merely connecting the dots.
Clocking in at 160 minutes, this is a sloppy stew in which the ingredients of battle action, murder mystery, little-kid sentiment and history lesson don't mix well.

Just as the characters' motivations are mostly crude rather than complex, and the view of class politics superficial and romantic rather than acute or intelligent, so is the film's treatment of the novel's magical realism on the mundane side.
How to lose friends and alienate audiences is the lesson taught by this cleverly titled but noxious British comedy.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Among the better of the 17 Bonds and, perhaps more important for today's audience, a dynamic action entry in its own right, this first 007 adventure in six years breathes fresh creative and commercial life into the 33-year-old series.

Neither the location-based verisimilitude of Ridley Scott's shooting style nor the estimable Middle East expertise of source-material author David Ignatius can disguise Body of Lies as anything other than the contrived phony-baloney it is.
Dialogue, much of it lifted straight from Parker's novel, proves mostly engaging.
Beguiling rather than thrilling, oddly charming instead of transporting, meaning that Disney will have its work cut out for it with what is at heart a cult movie and a film buff's dream.

Poorly made indie production has a script that feels like a list of ripostes collected over the last several years to liberal criticisms of the U.S.: The whole enterprise feels far more agenda- than entertainment-driven.

The film is unable to achieve any aims higher than as a sort of engaging pop-history pageant and amateur, if not inapt, psychological evaluation, due to the unavoidable lack of perspective and a final act that has yet to be written.
Although it has its share of implausibilities, A Time To Kill is generally the most satisfying of the John Grisham screen adaptations to date.

[An] extremely well-made message picture about tolerance, justice and discrimination is pitched at mainstream audiences, befitting its position as the first major Hollywood film to directly tackle the disease.
Emotionally powerful and stylistically sure-handed.
Heat occupies an exalted position among the countless contemporary crime films.
Bridges is fine, especially in the ethereal early moments, and manages throughout to convey an altered state of mind that rivets the viewer.
Although it all pays off in a potent and revelatory final act rife with insights into the psychology and calculations of power players, the initial stretch is rather dry and prosaic.

Even more than with most of Michael Crichton's concoctions, this one conveys the overwhelming impression of a mechanical entertainment, a very high concept in which the characters and their problems seem like utterly arbitrary creations.
An astonishingly good and daring film that richly develops several intertwined thematic lines, The Crying Game takes giant risks that are stunningly rewarded.

Artistically on a plane with or near the vet filmmaker's best work, this period drama about a woman slowly discovering her metier is an artisanal creation par excellence that will be appreciated by discerning arthouse patrons worldwide.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Although it increasingly succumbs to a tendency toward conventional movie heroics, John Singleton's fourth film tells a story of rare interest and tragedy...
The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie takes on rather too much water during its extended feature-length submersion.
Pic receives an incalculable boost from Ricci.
Truly beguiling romantic comedy is one of the hardest things for a modern film to pull off, but a winning British team has done it in Four Weddings and a Funeral.
The actor-director's second release of the season is his most stripped-down, unadorned picture in many a year.
The artistic veneer Stone applies, along with the simpy narration provided for Sheen in the way of letters to his grandmother, detract significantly from the work's immediacy.

Executed to near perfection in all artistic departments, this superior adaptation of the perennial favorite novel will find its core public among girls , but should prove satisfying enough to a range of audiences.
Smart, droll and dazzling to look at and listen to, writer-director Tony Gilroy's effervescent, intricately plotted puzzler proves in every way superior to his 2007 success Michael Clayton.
Pic never surmounts a deeply lame central premise that makes most of the action seem fraudulent and thoroughly unnecessary.
A big new talent arrives on the scene with Sin nombre. Writer-director Cary Joji Fukunaga's enthralling feature debut takes viewers into a shadow world inhabited by many but noticed by very few.
Like dramas by Pinter and others, what seems trenchant and perfectly pitched in the theater can come off as arch even when skillfully transferred to film.
Agripping, impressively detailed account of one harrowing voyage by a German U-boat during World War II.
A not-bad supernatural-tinged sci-fier that has more on its mind than the run-of-the-mill effects-driven extravaganza.
A host of minor issues, none of them too debilitating on its own, combine to create a feeling of moderate underachievement.
In all respects, this is a full meal, as it deals with the things of life with intelligence, truthful drama and rueful humor.

This very loose adaptation (acknowledgement of the sources is buried in the end credits) attempts to goose things up here and there, but original's essentially meditative nature is left quite unfulfilled by the new approach and glamour cast.
This whacked-out road comedy about a young man's search for his real parents takes any number of unexpected turns, most of them bitingly funny.
What seemed like a dubious proposition on paper plays even more dubiously onscreen, as "Cutthroat Island" strenuously but vainly attempts to revive the thrills of old-fashioned pirate pictures.
Director Wolfgang Petersen sends the story efficiently down its straight and narrow track, deftly engineering the battle of wills between two desperately committed men.
Color of Night is a knuckleheaded thriller that means to get a rise out of audiences but will merely make them see red.
A Summer's Tale is vintage Eric Rohmer, his most richly satisfying film in a number of outings.
A tepid fourth entry in the popular 1980s series that is decidedly showing its age.

To call this the best horse-and-kid picture since The Black Stallion a quarter century ago is true but misleading; it's not really either an animal or a kids' film but rather a young adult drama that rings emotionally true.
Many of the lines and the shadings brought to them by these expert performers are good for some laughs, and pic has plenty of energy, but it can't be taken as seriously as it wants to be.
An overweeningly deterministic mosaic of U.S. immigration case studies.
A vital regeneration of a filmmaker's talent as well as a bracing and often very funny dramatization of urgent sociopolitical themes...
This Friday the 13th Los Angeles vanity release isn't even fun in a bad-movie way.
An involving, ultimately touching romantic drama about a young man's struggle deciding between the two women in his life.
A lark for everybody concerned, including the audience.
This botched remake of The Day the Earth Stood Still seriously dishonors the seriously fine 1951 sci-fi landmark on which it's based.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Bryan Singer's long-awaited account of the near-miss assassination of Adolf Hitler by a ring of rebel German army officers on July 20, 1944, has visual splendor galore, but is a cold work lacking in the requisite tension and suspense.
Intricately constructed so as to infuriate anyone predominantly guided by rationality and intellect.

This perky, episodic film is as broad and obvious as it could be, but delivers on its own terms thanks to sparky chemistry between its sunny blond stars, Owen Wilson and Jennifer Aniston, and the unabashed emotion-milking of the final reel.
The deceptively modest Cookie's Fortune may or not be Robert Altman's best film in years, but it is certainly his most pleasurable.
A relentless immersion in combat strikingly realized but none too pleasurable to sit through.
A stylish Hollywood remake of the Japanese horror sensation that unfortunately has little personality of its own.
A shrill, mechanical comedy dedicated to the proposition that a wedding that doesn't take place at the Plaza Hotel is scarcely worth having at all.
Adventureland unspools as a rather ordinary account of youthful summer misadventures that goes down easily thanks to a sparky cast.

Intelligent, enormously accomplished and seriously problematic, Neil Jordan's ambitious account of the activities of arguably the central figure in Ireland's painful, bloody fight for independence from the British Empire has a great deal to offer...
It's a small, peculiar film, one unlikely to appeal much to women, non-sports fans and mainstreamers, but its uncomfortable comic insights should win it a loyal following.
Thompson's script manages the neat trick of preserving the necessary niceties and decorum of civilized behavior of the time while still cutting to the dramatic quick.
Unavoidably fascinating, especially for fight fans, due to the participation of Frazier and other survivors of the era.

Crudely made, somewhat overlong and larded with plenty of things that don't work, pic stands as proof positive that a comedy can be far from perfect and still hit the bull's-eye if it delivers when it counts in its big scenes.
This new Sabrina is more fizzle than fizz.
The International scampers all over the place, but it's alternately frantic and a little slack, with a hole in the middle where some interesting characters ought to be.

A drab, pale-looking affair without a trace of visual style, this cross-country pursuit yarn fights a losing battle to sustain viewer attention via narrative alone, so much does it flounder for lack of imagistic flair.
Serves up enough goofy pranks and fractured wordplay to keep the series purring along.
Strains far too hard for comedy that seldom erupts with full force and inevitably betrays a free-spending mindset that now feels gone with the wind.

Kingsley shrewdly tantalizes the viewer about his identity, and gets to deliver the text's most riveting monologue at the end. The lesser-known Wilson may be the first among equals, impressing strongly as the equivocating husband.
[Randle] holds the film together as best she can with her luminous presence and dignity, but can't supply the lacking subtext, past history and motivation.
A crackling thriller that feels unusually attuned to its lowlife characters.
It's a stunning starring debut, one that should decisively put Watts on the Hollywood and international map.
Like it or not, Wanted pretty much slams you to the back of your chair from the outset and scarcely lets up for the duration.
Given the intelligent restraint of the treatment, this is about as fine an adaptation of this material as one could hope for...
This misguided attempt to wring a novel twist on the superhero genre has a certain whiff of The Last Action Hero about it.

Pixar's ninth consecutive wonder of the animated world is a simple yet deeply imagined piece of speculative fiction...it has plenty to say, but does so in a light, insouciant manner that allows you to take the message or leave it on the table.
One of the truly bizarre careers in recent American cultural life provides the source of tart and tasty amusement in The People vs. Larry Flynt.
A sporadically funny romantic comedy with all the dramatic plausibility and tonal consistency of a TV variety show.
Continuously enjoyable from its action-filled opening to the dazzling final shot...
Too ill defined to emerge from the pack of box office also-rans.
movie_title: Why Do Fools Fall In Love (1998)

movie_review_blurb: A handsome, agreeably performed rendition that fails to ignite much laughter or any real emotion.

The third collaboration between director Jim Sheridan and actor Daniel Day-Lewis, The Boxer is an involving but rather prosaic report from the Belfast front with a melancholy undertow of romantic yearning.
Matchstick Men never really casts off its cloak of artificiality and calculation; its pleasures are minor, however distracting they may be.
Bruce Willis saves the world but can't save "Armageddon."
The bombs explode brilliantly but the story is a bust in "Pearl Harbor."
As richly conceived as the novel it pretends to be...
Very young children may find the numskull, by-the-numbers gags here amusing, but teens will consider this kids' stuff and adults will be pained.
A crudely made, sometimes funny bit of porchfront humor from the 'hood.
A solid but somewhat by-the-numbers entry in the James Bond cycle.
A wild knuckleball of a movie that keeps dancing in and out of the strike zone.
As lively and amusing as the film is in some ways, it does set up expectations at the outset that are never really delivered upon.
Hayao Miyazaki's exceedingly imaginative, beautifully realized animated epic adventure has been adapted into English with tact and talent...
Sees 007 undone by villainous scripting and misguided casting and acting in a couple of key secondary roles.
An outstanding version of Louisa May Alcott's perennial, one that surpasses even the best previous rendition, George Cukor's 1933 outing starring Katharine Hepburn.
Party Girl aspires to be cinematic champagne but comes out tasting more like sparkling cider.
Nicely acted but excessively bland.
Well-mounted and very traditional, Of Mice and Men honorably serves John Steinbeck's classic story of two Depression-era drifters without bringing anything new to it.
Turn-Off would be a more appropriate title for Attraction, an irritating study of sexual obsession and voyeurism.
Brother Bear is a very mild animated entry from Disney with a distinctly recycled feel.
Coppola has never been particularly known for his comic touch, but here he seems bent on leavening the melodrama with as many laughs as possible, and they are generally honest and well-earned.
Mamet reveals his exceptional talent for writing almost poetic working-class vernacular, scores his major implicit thematic thrusts against the nature of the way business-at-large is conducted.

A study of the urban dope-dealing culture and its toll on everyone who comes in contact with it, the picture has an insider's feel that is constantly undercut by the filmmaker's impulse to editorialize.

Levinson and Attanasio don't ignore the basics of the tale, but don't indulge them either, subjectively approaching Tom's character to maximize dramatic involvement and treating the most explosive aspects of the story more rationally than emotionally.
A sort of political This Is Spinal Tap, Bob Roberts is both a stimulating social satire and, for thinking people, a depressing commentary on the devolution of the American political system.
An astonishing work of studio artifice, A Little Princess is that rarest of creations, a children's film that plays equally well to kids and adults.
Doesn't approach the emotional resonance of Franco Zeffirelli's immensely popular 1968 screen version.
There's nothing thrilling or new about the work here, but accomplished it is.
A first-rate thriller with grit and intrigue to spare.
What seemed, in theory, the least-necessary revival of a bigscreen superhero emerges as perfectly solid summer action fare.
A winningly confident snapshot of the nightlives of a bunch of young showbiz wannabes in a very upto-the-minute Hollywood.
A conditional victory.
Michael Crichton's story is underdeveloped and narrow in range, resulting in a tale more curious for its odd confluence of elements than for their edifying deployment.
A well-observed and deftly performed examination of upper-middle-class emotional deep freeze...

Overstuffed and fatally miscast, All the King's Men never comes to life.
A simple repast consisting of sometimes strained slapsticky comedy, a sweet romance and a life lesson learned.
It remains inventive and funny to the end, features fine performances from Will Ferrell and especially Emma Thompson, and offers enough to enjoy and dispute to make it a good B.O. attraction.
Layering the sense of dread with measured expertise, Range does a formidable job visualizing the circumstances surrounding the crime.
Stories of resistance to oppression will never become obsolete, but this feels like a picture that should have been made a long time ago.

A partly smart, mostly dumb addition to the teen horror sweepstakes -- smart in how it neatly catches the petty, hurtful, sexy and druggy aspects of high school life, dumb in how it makes absolutely no sense once its resolution is known.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Anthony Minghella's film is conspicuously thoughtful and civilized as it provides a close-up snapshot of particular aspects of life in London at this moment.
Aside from spasms of brutal violence, however, there's nothing rousing or new here.

A wonderful, serious-minded romantic comedy-drama about a film director's uncertain relations with two successive women while trying to write a script at an off-season beach resort, this is Korean buff favorite Hong Sang-soo's most accessible film.
Despite the brutal dogfights and inevitable deaths, there's little gravity or resonance.
Starts well, but trips over preposterous plot developments as it pushes toward its climax.
Genuinely funny, randy and moving by turns, breezily enjoyable throughout.
Instead of growing as an artist, [Hartley] seems to be treading water.
If only due to the access achieved, there has never been anything quite like Asger Leth's film; it's amazing it even exists and that the director is still alive.
The problem with the Pirates films, and with this one more than the first, is that there's not a genuine moment in them -- no point of human contact...they're baldly concocted, confected, engineered.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Couldn't be verbally filthier... but most will be amused by this unique, star-laden homemovie.
Streep single-handedly elevates this sitcomy but tolerably entertaining adaptation of Lauren Weisberger's bestselling 2003 roman a clef.
You've seen it all before, except that you haven't, not quite this way.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A comprehensive, personal and surprisingly engaging look at how film crews routinely work hours far beyond anything that can be considered safe, healthy or conducive to a balanced life.
While it does hold interest, the drama's deterministic negativity is not particularly rewarding or complex.
From the first, there is a refreshing absence of special pleading or under-the-microscope examination in Naess' approach.
Hayek is in full blossom as Camilla.
Rib-ticklingly funny at times and genial as all get-out.
A flashy cast, clever script and vibrant showcasing of New York City as the ultimate melting pot are strong plusses for Spike Lee's most mainstream studio venture.
The battle of the sexes is restaged to clever but inconsequential effect in Conversations With Other Women.

A tad crasser and pushier than its predecessor, Ice Age: The Meltdown is still an entirely serviceable follow-up to the 2002 hit that will thoroughly amuse kids and get a rise or two out of parents as well.
As outrageous, and sometimes outrage-inspiring, entertainment, This Film Is Not Yet Rated is a blast. As a fair-minded look at the MPAA, it's incomplete and rather off-balance.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The high-octane juice audiences crave in big-budget action films surges propulsively through Mission: Impossible III, in large measure due to Tom CruiseTom Cruise, who seems determined to give a persuasive human impersonation of a Ferrari.
A rather narrowly conceived tale that makes only modest hay from the overworked conflict between wildlife and encroaching humans.
An oppressively talky film that isn't exactly dull, but comes as close to it as one could imagine with such provocative material.

Playfully and provocatively entertaining for roughly the first half, but loses staying power thereafter when investment in the uncompelling characters' problems is requested.
... gripping nearly all the way.
Let them have eye candy pretty much sums up Sofia Coppola's approach to her revisionist and modernist take on the famous royal airhead who in the end lost her head.

Respectable piece of work is reasonably involving if not compelling.
As personally troublesome as they may be, the prickly dynamics keep the docu bobbing along.
A beautifully wrought account of the dawning of the social conscience of one of the 20th century's most romanticized revolutionaries.
There are lots of laughs for those who enjoy the sight of bottom dwellers doing stupid things that make them look even more idiotic.

This second bigscreen version of Jules Verne's 1873 novel takes plenty of liberties with the material and never generates much genuine excitement, but provides an agreeable ride without overloading it with contemporary filmmaking mannerisms.
Crackerjack entertainment from start to finish.
A character-driven suspenser that engages the mind more than the emotions, but neither grippingly.
Impressively made and well acted.
Modern footwear simply doesn't fit this perennial fairy tale heroine, who's been reborn as a Valley Girl in a rendition that stumbles in almost every conceivable way.
A failure of imagination.
Once again, Damon scores in the title role by never courting audience sympathy and playing his all-American good looks against the hard-shell brutality of the character.
This political thriller about a brainwashed soldier being positioned for the White House provides a delectable network of dramatic tripwires that teases the mind and quickens the pulse.
This intensely focused piece soars not only on the director's precision-tooled style but also on the outstanding interplay between leads Tom Cruise and Jamie Foxx.
Recognizably part of the energized Mexican new wave, though nothing to write home about artistically.

A rewardingly personal docu in which the filmmaker deftly uses his specific family legacy as a jumping off point for wry ruminations on American history, the tobacco business, public health and cinematic license.
A collection of intermittent pleasures than a satisfying emotional repast.
Impeccably made and genuinely moving.
A minor affair.
Hybrid of old Hollywood conventions and advanced digital technology is arresting at first but gradually trails off under the weight of its hyper-derivativeness and anxiety to please.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Story of an insidious stalker disrupting the lives of an intellectual London couple is handled in a bracing and distinctive manner.
Overfamiliarity extends to the story, jokes and music, most of which reference popular entertainment of about 30 years ago.
Fails to stir much involvement or sympathy.
A rangy, straightforward and entirely engrossing biopic.

Sustains interest most of the way, but combination of an unsympathetic central figure and patchy recreation of events involving numerous famous people makes for an ambitiously told life story that finally doesn't cut it.
movie_title: The Life and Death of Peter Sellers (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Keeping it all alive through all the dramatic ups and down, and limited psychological and emotional complexity, is Kline.
The sweep of the story will pull along most viewers, young and old.
Compelling, thoughtful and entirely involving.
movie_title: The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The casting is well-nigh perfect from top to bottom.

With concision and well-chosen detail, Peter Webber's exceedingly accomplished first feature beautifully evokes the world the artist inhabited 340 years ago while deftly and discreetly delineating the personal intrigue within his teeming household.
The imaginatively illustrated but precariously precious film offers up a string of minor pleasures but never becomes more than moderately amusing or involving.
A solid character piece that deftly probes the complicity of both sides in a morally dubious relationship.

Disappointingly content to recycle familiar attitudes about the nobility of ancient cultures, Western despoilment of them, liberal historical guilt, the unrestrainable greed of capitalists and the irreducible primacy of Hollywood movie stars.

Gravely intense and the work of a man as deeply committed to his subject as one could hope for or, for that matter, want.
If films about coping with memory loss and/or reverse-order storytelling now constitute a mini-genre, then pic is arguably the best of the lot.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Somber, absorbing thriller that treads familiar psycho serial killer terrain with style.

movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Falls so awfully flat.
It's gratifying to see Sony expending such effort on an important but admittedly second-tier picture.
As always, Pollack's polished professionalism reps a significant pleasure in itself, and the presence of the U.N. front-and-center is a spectacle to behold.

Genuinely spectacular and historically quite respectable.

Whatever one thought of the previous two installments, this dynamic picture irons out most of the problems, and emerges as the best in the overall series since The Empire Strikes Back.

movie_review_blurb: This shrill, undermotivated, feature-length catfight between Jennifer Lopez's demure prospective bride and Fonda's unhinged prospective mother-in-law makes sure to underline, boldface and exclamation-point every plot turn and line of dialogue.

Strikes some resonant chords but also hits notes that simply don't ring true and are borderline risible at times.
Tommy Lee Jones' bracing bigscreen directorial debut, which copped acting and writing awards from the Cannes Film Festival jury, connects with both the head and the heart.

A wonderful film, so accomplished that it looks effortless.

movie_title: Going Upriver: The Long War of John Kerry (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Tries like mad to get under the viewer's skin in its portrayal of gross medical malfescence, but never gets beyond recycling stale genre tricks and obvious characters.
movie_title: Qui a tué Bambi? (Who Killed Bambi?) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A breezy, sexy romp with a conscience that reflects in obvious but interesting ways on societal changes over the intervening 38 years.
An interesting life story told in a fun, disarming way.
Deliriously smart escapist fare.

Short on real drama and incident and long on tedium thanks to one irredeemably neurotic central character.

A truly gag-worthy comedy.

[Chandor] peels back the layers of his story and characters with the skill of an expert dramatist.

movie_review_blurb: Magician adopts a lively, energetic approach in the worthy service of engaging the interest of viewers perhaps unfamiliar with Welles' life and work.
movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

A fugacious bit of whimsy that can only be judged minor Woody Allen.

All hands on both sides of the camera do outstanding work.

This is a probing, inquisitive work of a very high order, although it goes a bit slack in the final third and concludes rather conventionally compared to much that has come before.

Viewers willing to embrace a purely visual experience without dramatic, emotional or psychological substance will comprise an ardent cheering section, but the film provides too little for even relatively adventurous specialized audiences to latch onto ...

Ronan is almost always worth watching, but not especially in this drippy outing, in which she morphs from sullen teen brat to can-do wilderness heroine under the influence of an attractive red-headed hawk trainer.
A wannabe outrageous gangster saga seems patched together from spare genre parts from a generation ago.
It should be remedial school, not an institution of higher learning, for Monsters University, an alarmingly lame effort from Pixar, the Oxbridge of animation studios.
Zack Snyder's huge, backstory-heavy extravaganza is a rehab job that perhaps didn't cry out to be done but proves so overwhelmingly insistent in its size and strength that it's hard not to give in.
A crude, low-brow audience-pleaser that will hit the funny bones of both performers' fan bases ...
This attempt for another Pirates of the Caribbean-scaled series tries to have it too many ways tonally, resulting in a work that wobbles and thrashes all over the place.
A better-and-smarter-than-average humans-vs.-monsters spectacular.
An attractively designed but narratively challenged, one-note film.

As a major undertaking with clear sequel ambitions, there's just not enough new and exciting here to cut it; when the brief 96-minute running time is one of its two or three only virtues, you know you're in trouble.
Cate Blanchett is neurotically golden in another memorable female character study from Woody Allen.
A lame, one-dimensional and ultimately dreary look at peripheral Hollywood types not worth anyone's time either onscreen or in real life.
A politically charged flight of speculative fiction makes an exciting launch, only to tailspin into an ungainly crash landing in Elysium.
We're the Millers is vulgar vanilla, a "family" comedy about a bunch of would-be golly-gee squares who talk dirty and get involved with Mexican drug dealers because it's 2013 instead of 1953.
Even with all contrivances and obvious point-making and familiar historical signposting, Daniels' The Butler is always engaging, often entertaining and certainly never dull.
Chain-smoking, guzzling booze and spouting worldly epigrams about love and life, Moreau fits into Croydon like a peacock in Antarctica, sashaying around and imposing her seductive will on everyone.

At once the most realistic and beautifully choreographed film ever set in space, Gravity is a thrillingly realized survival story spiked with interludes of breath-catching tension and startling surprise.
A nuanced, superbly acted love story with a most unusual genesis.
The lead actors shine in an engaging look at the two fierce rivals who battled it out for the Formula One championship in 1976.
Paul Greengrass and Tom Hanks team up for a pulsating account of the kidnapping of the captain of an American cargo ship by Somali pirates.
An odd, sometimes funny, other times touching, always modest look at a strange bunch of New Yorkers.
A winning comic romance with a wonderful regular guy performance by the late James Gandolfini.
Jason Statham squares off against poor white trash in an old Sylvester Stallone script that should have stayed on the shelf.
Nearly everything about The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug represents an improvement over the first installment of Peter Jackson's three-part adaptation of J.R.R. Tolkien's beloved creation.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Young actor Jack O'Connell is the main attraction in this tough British drama.
It's bawdy, on-target in its take on what's become of TV news, and packed with wacky performers.
A snappy, sharp-witted, graphic novel-inspired satire on the doings at the French Foreign Ministry.

Takes the bold (for Marvel) step of reducing CGI spectacle to a relative minimum in favor of reviving the pleasures of hard-driving old-school action, surprising character development and intriguing suspense.
Darren Aronofsky wrestles one of scripture's most primal stories to the ground and extracts something vital and audacious, while also pushing some aggressive environmentalism, in Noah.
A bizarre real-life drama of the 1930s is well told in this resourceful documentary.
movie_title: The Galapagos Affair: Satan Came To Eden (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An entirely conventional serio-comic sports world melodrama that pushes its buttons with undeniable professional finesse.
It would have helped if director Nick Cassavetes had something resembling a sure hand at comedy.
This rigorous beautiful black-and-white drama of early-'60s Poland is an art film in the best sense.

Superbly made but burdened by some dull human characters enacted by an interesting international cast who can't do much with them, this new Godzilla is smart, self-aware, eye-popping and arguably in need of a double shot of cheeky wit.
Marion Cotillard scores another triumph as a Polish woman whose welcome to 1920s New York could scarcely be more trying.
The Salvation is assembled of nothing but the most elemental components of the Western, which gives genre specialists a lot to recognize and analyze and newcomers something to enjoy for its own sake.
Comes off like a prank more than a coherent take on 21st century Hollywood, even if there are crumbs of truth and wit scattered throughout it.
A superbly modulated study of a twisted mind with a career-changing performance by Steve Carell.

Fusing a hybrid of quasi-apocalyptic influences into a work with a pungent character of its own, The Rover suggests something like a Cormac McCarthy vision of Australia halfway between today and The Road Warrior times.
A visual and aural sensory bath that shows some real flair but feels madly derivative at every moment.

Although the humor helps, the Groundhog Day-like repetition gets tedious; it makes you feel more like a hamster than a groundhog - or rather a hamster's wheel, going round and round, over and over again.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An engaging, if rarefied inside look at the private world of a star.

Raunchy humor laced with gradually revealed vulnerability makes for a winning combination in Obvious Child, a wildly funny and appealing female-centric comedy that launches very promising talent on both sides of the camera.
A stimulating and upsetting look at how high tuition and huge student loans have created a perfect storm over American colleges.
A boldly conceived and bracingly told political drama.
An oddly off-key follow-up to the generally amusing 2011 feature that marked Disney's relaunch of the late Jim Henson's 1970s-'80s childhood favorites.
In the annals of sequels, Dawn is to Rise of the Planet of the Apes what The Empire Strikes Back was to Star Wars -- it's that much better.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A timely and fascinating look at physicists' search for the Higgs boson.
A film that is almost invariably heavy-handed and obvious from beginning to end ...
This smorgasbord of talk and sex constitutes a very full meal.
The wages of greed and excess portrayed in grand, operatic, often very funny style.

If The Legend of Hercules were just a little more inept or over-the-top, it might have been ridiculous fun. ...Unfortunately, Harlin embraces the mediocrity of the screenplay with a dour straight face, draining it of any enjoyably camp possibilities.
Odd revenge genre low-budgeter keeps the tradition of revenge killing all too alive.

Instead of embracing dramatic complexities and setbacks, all the better to make the most of them creatively, screenwriters Adam Cozad and David Koepp are intent upon steamrolling right over them, to uninvolving effect.
Miles Teller and J.K. Simmons go toe-to-toe in a potent drama about an ambitious young drummer and his abusive teacher.
A bold, original and exceptionally fine second feature from former Sundance award-winner Mike Cahill.
This admirably textured thriller rooted in Eastern immigrant-laden Hamburg will prove absorbing to attentive audiences internationally who don't need everything spelled out to them ...
A fulsome appreciation of the life and work of the world's most famous film critic.

Perhaps never has the long arc of the journey from childhood to college been portrayed as cohesively and convincingly as Richard Linklater has done in a film that can be plain on a moment-to-moment basis but is something quite special in its entirety.

As the wages of addiction are awfully familiar, as well as sadly tedious to watch, there is little new the film has to say on the subject, leaving this obvious labor of love with a real struggle ahead to find much of an audience.

On a moment-to-moment basis, this smoothly made film can be incredibly trying, even annoying, to watch, due to the grueling repetitiveness of the scenes and dialogue and the claustrophobia of the paradoxically beautiful setting.

A work of rigorously disciplined eccentricity, Kumiko, the Treasure Hunter is at once entirely accessible and yet appealing only to a rarified crowd ready to key into its narrow-bandwidth sense of humor.
A captivating look at a high-tech inventor who presumes to replicate the work of a great painter.
[An] indisputably talented work for its risk-taking, dark humor and barbed portraiture of creative individuals ...

In a very appealing if outre way, its sensibility and concerns are very much those of an earlier, more elegant era, meaning that the film's deepest intentions will fly far over the heads of most modern filmgoers.
An ineffectual account of an eternal love.
A blah 1981 film becomes a bland one 33 years later in Endless Love.
A jerry-rigged terror-on-a-plane thriller with a premise so far-fetched as to create a degree of suspense over how the writers will wriggle out of the knot of their own making.
Although Gerard Butler's star has significantly fallen due to the 17 mediocre films he's made since 300, it must be admitted that he's missed here ...
The seemingly exhausted gross-out comedy genre gets a strange temporary reprieve with This Is the End, an unlikable but weirdly compelling apocalyptic fantasy.
Depp shines in a solid gangster biopic.

Racing in high gear from start to finish, Danny Boyle's electric direction temperamentally complements Sorkin's highly theatrical three-act study, which might one day be fascinating to experience in a staged setting.

There is no real wisdom imparted in these stories, only evidence of the weird variety of humankind and the imperishability of that most essential and elemental of human relationships, between a mother and child.
Loud, bombastic and thuddingly obvious, this is a vulgar movie for vulgar times.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This entry feels vital, freshly thought out and keen to keep us on our toes right up to the concluding scene.
Slight but charming.
A lovely addition to the long line of personal documentaries about French life at ground level that Agnes Varda has been making throughout her entire career.
More conventionally conceived than some of [Baumbach's] best work but benefits from sterling turns from a wonderful cast, most notably Dustin Hoffman and, no kidding, Adam Sandler.
Beautifully captures the way a handful of people stoically deal with the meager hands life has dealt them.
War Machine has trouble maintaining a steady tone, but its climactic, sobering assault ultimately hits the target.
Possesses an intensely realized physicality, but tedium outweighs suspense by a very large margin ...
Serious cinephiles will likely reject it as glib and disrespectful, while more mainstream viewers could be amused but not that interested.

Any documentary loaded with clips of Grant's work has half the battle won right there - few stars have ever appeared in nearly as many first-rate films as this actor did over the course of his 34-year career.
A grim view of post-Soviet-era life enlivened by a compelling actress.
A potent, disturbing work that explores the boundaries of political correctness, artistic liberty and free speech in provocative ways.

Almost as rare as winning the Triple Crown in horse racing is to make a film trilogy that clicks from beginning to end, but Fox has pretty much pulled it off with its refurbished Planet of the Apes trio.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Razzies don't need to wait until the end of the year to anoint a winner for 2017. The Golden Turkey Awards should be republished with a new cover.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Dunkirk is an impressionist masterpiece.

Intense and physically powerful in the way it conveys its atrocious events, the film nonetheless remains short on complexity, as if it were enough simply to provoke and outrage the audience. It's a grim tale with no catharsis.
This is a good-times film that doesn't put on airs, dress to impress or pretend to be something it isn't. It just aims to please and does a pretty good job of it.
Other than to place slightly more emphasis on the female empowerment angle ... it's hard to detect a strong raison d'etre behind Sofia Coppola's slow-to-develop melodrama.
Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 plays like a second ride on a roller-coaster that was a real kick the first time around but feels very been-there/done-that now.
Director John Scheinfeld's doc is a comprehensive, engrossing and, it's tempting to say, worshipful account of the life of the music titan.
movie_title: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary (2017)

movie_review_blurb: All the requisite elements are served up here in ideal proportion, and the time just flies by, which can rarely be said for films of this nature.
A fitfully funny quasi-farce that takes off promisingly, loses its way mid-flight and comes in for a bumpy but safe landing.
Smart and solid, with a smashing Chastain.
Offers enough dramatic meat, boisterous humor and lived-in performances to hook audiences of all stripes.

has flirted with and danced around the subject in many of his other films... but of his explicitly religious dramas, specifically including Kundun and The Last Temptation of Christ, this is, by a considerable distance, the most eloquent and coherent.

Loaded with more battle action than any of its seven predecessors, Rogue One: A Star Wars Story plays like a set-up for the events in the 1977 original and, for the most part, does so quite entertainingly.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Julian Barnes' short, penetrating novel about how we self-protectively edit our memories receives an intelligent, low-key, necessarily diluted big-screen treatment in The Sense of an Ending.
While Icarus technically doesn't break any news, it certainly scores many points by showing a diabolical wizard so surprisingly laying his secrets on the table.
She's got a lot to offer, the door's been opened, and now we'll see what she does with it.
Intriguing but unsatisfying.
An excellent novel about the Iraq War and its homefront fallout has been turned into a rather flat and disappointing film in The Yellow Birds.
A strong directorial debut.
Heineman offers up a double portrait of devastation, of a truly destroyed city and of partially decimated survivors, leaving the viewer with an empathetic sense of deep sorrow.
Jasper's dynamic debut crackles with energy and grass roots authenticity. But it wouldn't have worked at all without the right leading lady, which it found in Danielle Macdonald ...
A resourceful, if rather hyperbolic documentary that devotes 90 minutes to analyzing one of the most famous scenes in film history.

A comedy of embarrassment, discomfort and anxiety that just keeps getting funnier as it goes along, Lemon is a one-of-a-kind treat that, by ending almost too soon, follows the old showbiz principle of leaving 'em wanting more.
Reasonably well constructed as far as it goes, but there's nothing new here and the conceit of Hollywood scenesters as being uniformly vapid and creatively void is frankly rather tired at this point.
A workmanlike but unavoidably predictable yarn about the perils of college fraternity hazing.
Given its lack of incident and mostly grumpy and/or off-putting characters, this will not be the film that expands Perry's small audience. But it is something close to superb.

The only possible cure for A Cure for Wellness would have been for the horror film maestro Val Lewton to have been summoned from the grave to chop it down to no more than 79 minutes. And maybe not even then....

Captivating, funny and possessed of a surprise-filled zig-zag structure that makes it impossible to anticipate where it's headed, this is a deeply humane film that, like the best Hollywood classics, feels both entirely of its moment and timeless.
There's not quite enough oomph or style in the filmmaking to make you forget about the schematic nature of the dramatic construct.

A snappy and straightforward crowd-pleaser that focuses on new Prime Minister Winston Churchill's mighty efforts to rise to the occasion of rescuing his country from the appeasers and defeatists in Parliament and stirring the public to defiance of Hitler.

It's game, set and match for Battle of the Sexes, a massively entertaining account of the momentous 1973 tennis match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs that also deftly deals with the numerous social issues inherent in the carnival-like contest.
Estrada's debut feature brandishes a brash exuberance and stilted storytelling tropes in roughly equal measure, yielding a final result that stimulates just as it cheapens itself dramatically.

Juliet, Naked never truly achieves comic lift-off. Instead, it bumps around from one mild laugh, awkward encounter and bewildering decision to another without ever building up an exhilarating head of steam.
Actor Paul Dano has made a small gem in Wildlife, his first film as a director.
A crackerjack real-life heist thriller.
This low-budget indie is somber and dreary on a moment-to-moment basis and leaves its talented cast stranded with few opportunities to alleviate the sense of stasis.
The writer-director's inexperience behind the camera is all too evident, as the painful but ultimately cathartic tale bumps along for more than two hours without ever finding an aesthetic form.
A most welcome reassessment of one of the most important figures in 1970s Hollywood.

This vigorous, colorful and clever melodrama smartly rethinks both the play and the character, making her a far more proactive figure than Shakespeare did in addition to entirely re-imagining her fate.
A haywired second half cancels out a diverting first half in this comic Western.
In all respects, what Chaganty and his team have pulled off here is something both novel and accomplished.
A film that's pleasurable to engage with, even if the latter stretch doesn't come close to realizing some of the early promise.
movie_title: A Boy. A Girl. A Dream. (2018)

movie_review_blurb: It's directly due to the dramatic somnolence of the first half that what comes after hits with such blunt force.

This is one of those films that, if shown overseas, could potentially make people think that the U.S. is going down the tubes even faster than imagined. Everyone in it - adolescents and grown-ups, too - is beyond stupid and content to remain that way.
A densely packed documentary that earnestly and obsessively addresses campaign finance reform, its history and vital importance.
With uncanny timing, Marvel takes its superheroes into a domain they've never inhabited before and is all the better for it in Black Panther.
Mostly comprised of banal, drama-free, quotidian scenes that merely reinforce the men's status as regular Joes who, one day, had the opportunity for greatness thrust upon them.
Annihilation is a ferocious, feral, female-centric update of fearsome monster classics like The Thing and Alien.
Only the faintest glimmers of genuine, earned emotion pierce through the layers of intense calculation that encumber Ava DuVernay's A Wrinkle in Time.
This small-scale, putatively comic meditation on the anxieties and joys of the theatrical life says nothing fresh about the artistic process and manages to be coy and grating in doing so.
movie_title: In the Bleak Midwinter (A Midwinter's Tale) (1996)

movie_review_blurb: It's virtually all Hemsworth's show and he's entirely up to the task of carrying the film on his broad shoulders: He's charismatic, fearless, confident, jokey and a good old Kentucky boy who just wants to get the job done ...
An engaging, smartly cast and sporadically eye-popping addition to the studio's bulging portfolio.
It's a true-life yarn loaded with extremes, of wealth, personal eccentricities, grief, tension, daring, criminal means to political ends, maternal drive and luck, both bad and good.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While there is precious little overt "drama" per se, before you know it you've become happily ensconced in a peculiar world you've never visited or even imagined before.
A mournful, sorrowful, persistently powerful Western set in a world of beauty, tears and blood.
The Private Life of a Modern Woman shrewdly investigates how an accidental incident upends the equilibrium of a young woman who seems to have everything going for her.
movie_title: The Private Life of a Modern Woman (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A very Rosemary's Baby-like intimate horror tale that definitely grabs your attention and eventually soars well over the top to make the bold concluding statement that, for some creators, art is more important than life.
Snappy, spirited and shot through with the pangs and pleasures of leaving childhood behind, Lady Bird is a sharp-witted solo first feature by actress and now writer-director Greta Gerwig.
In his overdue directorial debut, Sorkin both entertains and makes you lean in to absorb every detail of this wild tale, which boasts a stellar cast to help tell it.
Exerts a certain pull due to its unblinking evocation of bare-bones working class American life and the slow-burn relationship sensitively etched by Ellen Page and Kate Mara.
A nicely filled-out look at different eras, one secrecy-ridden and dedicated to the preservation of illusion, the other wide open and blasé about personal predilections.
movie_title: Scotty and the Secret History of Hollywood (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Everything is methodical, it covers most of the bases, but passion and vitality are crucially missing from director John Curran's treatment.
Largely a comedy, one with quite a few strong laughs, many sharp perspectives and not a few things to say about adult foibles.

Despite the estimable talent on hand both behind and in front of the camera, the story never comes to convincing life and doesn't, in the end, have anywhere particularly surprising or interesting to go.
Considerable shrewdness is applied to the conception and execution of nearly every scene to make this old spy stuff feel fresh, which it mostly does.

A Svengali of the tennis world gets his close-up in the diabolically well-titled Love Means Zero, an on-its-toes documentary about the legendary and/or notorious tennis teacher and coach Nick Bollettieri.

The central premise is arresting, as is the style, but there's a lot more that could have been done with it than just show how one ill-defined individual instantly opts to join his country's lowest form of life.
It's interesting enough, but that's not usually sufficient recommendation to get audiences out to a theater.
A voluptuous mood bath that's impressively sustained from beginning to end.
An engaging account of a tragic real-life story.

Given the confined nature of the material as well as its period-specific aspects, this is a yarn that does not exactly invite radical reinterpretation. As such, its appeal is confined to the traditional niceties of being a clever tale well told.
This hodgepodge throws a bunch of superheroes into a mix that neither congeals nor particularly makes you want to see more of them in future. Plainly put, it's simply not fun.
Spielberg is now 70 but has scarcely lost a step; The Post possesses the same energy and vigor as the films he made decades ago.

Loaded with action and satisfying in the ways its loyal audience wants it to be ... generally pleasing even as it sometimes strains to find useful and/or interesting things for some of its characters to do.
Involving and moderately heartwarming here and there, even if doesn't reach the higher levels of psychological insight and emotional profundity to which it aspires.
By-the-numbers plotting, seen-it-all-before action moves, banal locations and a largely anonymous cast alongside the star give this a low-rent feel.
By the time push comes to kill, the ingenuity - or perhaps it's just cleverness - of the central concept has been reduced and abandoned for the sake of generic action moves.
Star Wars: The Force Awakens pumps new energy and life into a hallowed franchise in a way that both resurrects old pleasures and points in promising new directions.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This is the story of a fiasco, one made less so by the fierce and selfless commitment of a few good men whose old-fashioned kick-ass attitudes form the crux of the yarn's appeal.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Life may be as unfair and arbitrary as Solondz portrays it, but it is arguably more diverse in its moods and its ups and downs. The film may not be a dog, but nor is it likely to become anyone's best friend.
A quizzical, spry, modestly illuminating consideration of where human beings currently stand vis-a-vis the invention that is changing the world in as-yet unimaginable ways.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although it's difficult even by the end to entirely sort out who's related to whom and how, the actors acquit themselves nicely, and it's always good to have Stephen Fry around in this sort of tony affair ...
The film offers up more than enough in terms of intelligence, insight, historical research and religious nuance as to not at all be considered a missed opportunity ...

A cloying throwback to the Big Chill format of a cloistered reunion devoted to self-analysis and errant hanky-panky that in this case features mostly silly and annoying characters with whom it's no fun to be trapped.
A naturalistic coming-out story sinks into extreme melodrama.
As ever with Tarantino films, however, some of the performances are lip-smackingly delicious.
A pleasing visit with a keen-eyed pathfinder for American independent filmmakers.

The Coens' reimagining of a real Hollywood tough guy is interesting for insiders, but in their first order of business, that of making a rousing comedy about the Hollywood of 65 years ago, they've fallen rather short.
A really raunchy, very dirty and pretty funny goof on the entire superhero ethos, as well as the first Marvel film to irreverently trash the brand.
Without much investment, one just sits back with increasing detachment and bemused curiosity as to where and on whom the next shoe will drop.

After about 45 minutes, Vincent and Jessie have barely said anything to one another, and there are few plot-advancing elements other than Vincent's growing suspicion that Jessie's husband is mixed up in the arms business.
There are no surprises or hitherto untapped resources mined here.
Butler manfully dispenses justice here many times over, and even if the other main actors are in it strictly for the paycheck, they've all been in a whole lot worse in their time.
Accessible and informative.
The film may be imposing, but it's not fun.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A warm and surprisingly engaging account of the first date of Barack Obama and Michelle Robinson.

The splendidly dextrous cast ensures that this goofy success story, which could just easily be titled American Hustle 2, keeps firing on all cylinders in the manner of the writer-director's previous few outings.
both the behavior of the characters and the viewer responses sought are so repetitive and unchanging that it all becomes wearisome well before the far overlong feature wraps up.
