Director/co-writer Alejandro G. Inarritu, cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki and a vast team of visual effects wizards have created a sensationally vivid and visceral portrait of human endurance under very nearly intolerable conditions.
Damon provides comfortable company during the long stretches when he's onscreen alone, and the actor's physicality makes Mark's capability entirely credible.
The violence of the inter-American drug trade has served as the backdrop for any number of films for more than three decades, but few have been as powerful and superbly made as Sicario.
Heart of a Dog is an impressionistic meditation on death and its prelude by a thoughtful, free-ranging, highly idiosyncratic artist who enjoyed a very deep relationship with her dog.

It may be yesterday's news, but there's still plenty of juice left in Truth, a crackerjack journalism yarn in which big-name actors play big-name real-life characters who became embroiled in a controversy that still raises partisan hackles.
Youth is a voluptuary's feast, a full-body immersion in the sensory pleasures of the cinema.
A small story about two old estranged brothers and their animals gently morphs from gentle near-absurdist comedy to something close to tragedy.
Graced by the exemplary print condition of the many titles it excerpts, this documentary will be a top draw wherever films about filmmakers are welcome.
The actors all try hard to keep the energy up but never get convincingly in synch and, with the exception of Peter, the characters don't reasonably comport with one's pre-existing images of them.
An absorbing true-life espionage tale very smoothly handled by old pros who know what they're doing.
[It's] certainly unequaled in its field for the beauty of its camerawork, sets, costumes and effects. But it's also conventionally plotted and not surprising or scary at all.
Awash with ripe, voluptuous summertime imagery and brimming with aborning adolescent female sexuality, The Summer of Sangaile is an appealingly simple, poetically conceived teen coming-of-age tale.
Rock the Kasbah morphs into a pretty implausible feel-good movie that's nearly as maudlin as it is unconvincing.
David Gordon Green's latest unpredictable addition to his resume is offbeat and appealing on some levels but is neither as funny nor as trenchant as it might have been.
The film turns a welcome spotlight on a resourceful and singular artist who was forced to do everything from scratch in the absence of any local industry infrastructure.
Pervasively grim.
This languid piece of would-be art cinema will prove once again that even the biggest names in the world won't draw an audience to something that, in and of itself, has no reason for being.

Coogler makes the transition from the indie world to big-budget studio filmmaking with a result that's sturdy and smooth. Buffed into ring-ready shape, Jordan acquits himself well both in and out of the ring ...
Even if the now-veteran director lays everything on a bit thick... he's still found a lively and legitimate way to tackle an urgent subject matter that other filmmakers have found excuses to avoid.
Something less than a whale of a tale.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Visually stunning and entirely engaging.

Even if you've allowed yourself to hope that the redoubtable actors might tilt the proceedings in a positive direction, almost every choice made by director Ariel Vromen... sends Criminal spiraling toward overwrought silliness.

The two leading actors effectively enough express the simplistic perspectives they're meant to represent, but there's no subtext or nuance called for; they're more like action totems of diametrically opposed positions.

It's not the biographical film this stupendous, if mightily troubled, musical and political figure deserved, especially coming in the immediate wake of Liz Garbus' riveting documentary What Happened, Miss Simone? last year.
Fun enough, as late-summer studio comedies go.
What were they thinking?
For Chazelle to be able to pull this off the way he has is something close to remarkable.
This welcome return by Boiler Room writer-director Ben Younger can't help but hit some familiar boxing picture notes but still rates as a vibrant addition to the genre.
It would have been asking a lot from any actor to carry this film, and Cranston has done the heavy lifting and more.
An absorbing documentary about an unlikely survival story.
Always inventive and occasionally hilarious ...

Nothing particularly original or fresh has been injected into this competently made, violent but uningratiating remake of the star-studded John Sturges Western, which itself was a redo of Akira Kurosawa's imperishable 1954 classic, Seven Samurai.
Taut and vivid.
The filmmaking is prosaic when it should crackle with tension and disruptive undercurrents ...
The second good Obama movie of the year.
A concert film with something extra.
movie_title: The Rolling Stones: Olé Olé Olé! - A Trip Across Latin America (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For longtime fans of the filmmaker, this Canadian-made low-budget revenge yarn will be embraced as Hill's most entertaining and, on the terms it sets for itself, accomplished film in some time. It's an instant cult item.
All that counts here is that the film serve up a realistic, non-phony-looking, action-packed rendition of the worst oil spill in American history, and that it certainly does.
So comprehensively does the film fail to represent the labyrinthian literary wonders of Amis' book that it scarcely seems worthwhile to detail its universal shortcomings.

The heightened, fantastical elements of the story, coupled with the British wartime setting, put one in mind of Michel Powell, and one knows that, with him, the focus would have remained intently on the young lovers to the end.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The lead performances have power, whereas pictorially the film is pretty rough and ordinary.
DuVernay and Averick never stray far from the itinerary they clearly set for themselves, which was to illuminate the distance the country still remains from its ideal of equality for all.

The puzzle of how the various personal and narrative pieces will eventually fit together exerts a smidgen of interest, but the characters are so dour and un-dimensional as to invite no curiosity about them.
Woefully sentimental and maudlin.

A rare piece of contemporary classical cinema; its virtues of methodical storytelling, traditional style and obsessive theme are ones that would have been recognized and embraced anytime from the 1930s through the 1970s.
Perhaps the all-time strangest, most outlandish true-life story connected to the cinema and its practitioners is recounted in engrossing, if incomplete, fashion in The Lovers and the Despot.
Technically and logistically, Greengrass delivers everything you expect from him; there's no one better when it comes to staging complex, chaotic action amid the real life of big cities.
A disappointingly conventional career recap of the silent era's preeminent female star and businesswoman.
movie_title: Mary Pickford: The Muse of the Movies (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the undeniable presence of a huge amount of action, X-Men: Apocalypse is decidedly a case of more is less.
A small fiction of amiable appeal and vibrancy which goes down as easily as a fizzy cocktail.
An ordinary film about an extraordinary situation.
Weird and arresting.
The two-hour two-hander drags with too much dialogue during the first half and never truly achieves narrative lift-off.
That the film mostly falls flat has far more to do with the largely unconvincing material rather than with the co-stars, who are more than game ...
A mild-mannered, almost startlingly undramatic work that offers discreet pleasures to longtime fans of the New York indie-scene veteran, who can always be counted on to go his own way.
A socially conscious drama that admirably underplays its importance.
Even Kristen Stewart can't save this undernourished mystery.
A stultifyingly vapid, ponderously paced allegorical critique of the modeling world whose seethingly jealous inhabitants can't wait to literally chew each other up and spit each other out.

The film positively swills in its disreputability and all-around low-budgetness; sporting a healthy disregard for respectability, Schrader has just gone for it here with a highly focused recklessness that he turns to his creative advantage.
Its heroine may suffer from short-term memory loss, but viewers with any memory at all will realize that Finding Dory falls rather short of its wondrous progenitor.

A consummately individualistic document defined by a thousand tastes and as many enthusiasms but compromised by its creator's unfortunate decision to allow his own cinephiliac testament to be distorted and partly subsumed.
movie_title: The Thoughts That Once We Had (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A deliciously good time at the movies.
A compelling and little-known story of the Civil War period is studiously reduced to a dry and cautious history lesson.
This is certainly the best live-action Tarzan film in many a decade (which, admittedly, isn't saying much) and offers a well-judged balance of vigorous action and engaging-enough drama.
Szymanski, on his debut feature, desperately tries to keep a few laughs coming while navigating toward a resolution without getting too pat or sappy. A thankless task it was.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A wrenching family tragedy is dramatized with the depth of a high-quality American stage piece in Manchester by the Sea.
A puzzlingly confused undertaking that never becomes as cool as it thinks it is, Suicide Squad assembles an all-star team of supervillains and then doesn't know what to do with them.
Brad Pitt delivers a capable performance in an immersive apocalyptic spectacle about a global zombie uprising.
Too much of the time, The Monuments Men falls into a compromised middle zone, not urgent and only mildly amusing.
A bittersweet father-son road trip through an emotionally economically parched homeland.
Relentlessly sleazy but undeniably intriguing.
Nolan is a thinker, all right, a very busy explorer of mind functions, but capable merely of diagrams when it comes to the heart and soul.
Jolie herself is in her full glory here as a character born when Bond and Brezhnev ruled.

Now You See Me is a superficially diverting but substance-free concoction, a would-be thriller as evanescent as a magic trick and one that develops no suspense or rooting interest because the characters possess all the substance of invisible ink.

On a first viewing, it seems almost indecently smart, funny and sexy. The second time around... half the time I sat there marveling at the similarities of the story, themes and structure to Citizen Kane.
There could not be a film more timely or relevant to why the world is in the shape its in right now than this meticulously constructed analysis of the financial mess of the past couple of years.
[Public Access] is serious-minded and bounces around some provocative ideas, but is vague about such important matters as key story points, motivation and overriding theme.

Todd Phillips' follow-up to the most successful R-rated comedy of all time serves up its share of laughs while not actually providing a terribly enjoyable time because of a queasy undercurrent that never goes away.

As a study of stasis and of people conscious of not living the lives they had imagined for themselves, the picture offers a bracing undertow of seriousness beneath the deceptively casual, dramatically offhand surface.
The second big animated feature of the year, after Despicable Me, to center on an arch-villain who sees the error of his ways, Megamind is snappy good fun.
Delivers all the goods mainstream action fans could want.
Although involving, this remake of a recent French film never reaches the anticipated heights of excitement and suspense.
This grim beginning-of-the-end odyssey has a very different feel from any of its predecessors -- a development slightly more disconcerting than it is welcome.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Well-made and acted Coen Brothers remake lacks the humor and resonance that might have made it memorable.
It all ends up being a half-hour too much of a just okay thing.
This tedious third entry doesn't bode well for the continuation of the franchise.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This zero-chemistry pairing of Angelina Jolie and Depp stands as an object lesson in the perils of succumbing to the siren call of big-time Hollywood filmmaking for a foreign director with one art house hit behind him.
A low-impact romantic comedy-drama from James L. Brooks in which the central characters are strangely disconnected from one another as well as from the audience.
An old-fashioned Disney fairy tale gussied up in 3D for the holidays.
This engrossing account of the nation's most perilous moon shot embodies what many people consider to be old-fashioned American virtues in a virtually pristine state.
Yakin has put some powerful drama up on the screen, and he has been assisted by no one more significantly than young Nelson, who plays Fresh.
A enerally absorbing look at a slice of society normally taken for granted, both in life and onscreen.

Although too devoted to matters literary, theatrical, operatic and sexually outre to make it with general audiences, this adaptation of Jonathan Ames' novel exudes the sort of smarts and sophisticated charm specialized audiences seek.
As gooey and lacking in protein as a chocolate holiday bonbon, Valentine's Day plays like a feature-length commercial produced by the Friends of the Valentine Promotional Society.
"Why so serious?" would be an excellent question to direct at the makers of The Wolfman, a high-toned, bloody but otherwise bloodless effort.
Expert, screw-turning narrative filmmaking put at the service of old-dark-madhouse claptrap.

Alice in Wonderland has its moments of delight, humor and bedazzlement. But it also becomes more ordinary as it goes along, building to a generic battle climax similar to any number of others in CGI-heavy movies of the past few years.

So vivid and convincingly realistic is the physical depiction of Baghdad in the early days of the American occupation that the introduction of trumped-up thriller elements feels like an unwanted intrusion.
The modestly scaled film delivers some moving and affecting moments amid a preponderance of scenes of frequently annoying people behaving badly.
Sexual suspicion and game-playing spiral down from the exotically intriguing to outright silliness in Chloe.
A well-observed study of an affluent family's grief and rebirth after a tragic accident.

Rodrigo Garcia's reputation as a writer for and director of women will increase exponentially with Mother and Child, an insightfully observed and exceptionally acted ensemble piece precisely about what the title suggests.
The villains here chart new territory in one-dimensionality, the essential storyline is bereft of surprise and the picture ends where most Robin Hood tales -- sensibly, as it turns out -- begin.
Once it kicks in to unexpectedly become a prison-break thriller, it fires on all cylinders all the way to the finish line.
Taking advantage of a splendid cast, a sharply focused script and the fresh English setting, "Gosford Park" emerges as one of the most satisfying of Robert Altman's numerous ensemble pictures.
Stephen Daldry's film is sensitively realized and dramatically absorbing, but comes across as an essentially cerebral experience without gut impact.

Winning result, which reels off one riveting scene after another, stands as both a unique sort-of sequel and a film that requires no prior reference points; it's entirely satisfying either way, though even richer if you recall the antecedent.
A crackerjack thriller with some unusually tasty plot twists, Ransom pays plenty of entertaining dividends.

It stands as a unique film-within-a-film, of significance for the historical value of the raw images, the memories they spur and internal evidence of how the Nazis staged scenes long assumed to be real.
A dark comedy about sleaze, corruption and naughty behavior below the Bible Belt, Striptease doesn't quite come off.
Moulin Rouge is a tour de force of artifice, a dazzling pastiche of musical and visual elements at the service of a blatantly artificial story.
Unsavory hodgepodge from a franchise that has overstayed its welcome.
Admirable if fundamentally academic.
Predictable, cutesy and nowhere near hot-blooded enough for a story about two friends with benefits who can't keep their hands off one another.
Red State is cleverly contrarian enough to get a rise out of almost any audience.
Woody's in good form and Paris looks glorious in this droll time-traveling fantasy.

Brandishing an ambition it's likely no film, including this one, could entirely fulfill, The Tree of Life is nonetheless a singular work, an impressionistic metaphysical inquiry into mankind's place in the grand scheme of things.
Goopy doomed teen romance looks to appeal mostly to impressionable adolescent girls.
Negotiating a consistent artistic path as steadily as a drunk walking a straight line, This Must Be the Place is all over the place dramatically, tonally and thematically.
It all moves along briskly, with a degree of visual grace and a solid feel for 3D.
Audacious, confident and fueled by youthful energy, this is a surefire summer winner for a wide global audience.
An annulment is in order.
An engaging return trip to Steven Spielberg's youthful world of wonder courtesy of J.J. Abrams.
Robin Williams and Billy Crystal can each provoke a lot more laughs in a minute of standup than they jointly manage during the entire running time of Fathers' Day.
Serves up all the requisite elements with enough self-deprecating humor to suggest it doesn't take itself too seriously.
Too close to a TV dance competition show to go far in theaters.
A splendid performance by Jack Black distinguishes this overly mild look at a 1990s Texas murder.
Lightning and Mater mix it up with Formula 1 and spies in yet another Pixar winner.
Not a heady experience like many of the semi-experimental 1960s films he emulates. Instead, it's mostly a tedious chore, much akin to listening poetry you don't much like.
A less-than-bubbly teen comic romp aimed at little princesses.
An outstanding capper to the most lucrative film franchise of all time.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Beastly comedy for the lowest of brow.

Once you realize the film is just going to be a string of encomiums against a backdrop of frantically edited archival material... it's clear that no meaningful analysis of the woman's career or political agenda will be forthcoming
Scabrous, profane, violent, verbally adroit and often hilarious, this twisted and exceptionally accomplished variation on the buddy-cop format is capped by a protean performance from Brendan Gleeson.
Kristen Wiig scores in an erratic gross comedy that truthfully connects where it counts.
An intensely acted, minutely observed attempt to convey the arc of a romantic involvement.
The prospects, advisability and potential methods of prolonging human life are examined in an engagingly multifaceted manner in How to Live Forever.
Will please fans of Sara Gruen's best seller, but it lacks the vital spark that would have made the drama truly compelling on the screen.
Excellent lead performance tops a vivid but one-dimensional look at the double for Saddam's satanic son.
Frantic, numbing redo of the Charles Bronson original for hardcore Statham and action fans only.
Engaging, if straightforward and one-dimensional.
Fine documentary about one of auto racing's greats will please fans and make some new ones.
An aggressive look at men behaving badly will provoke strong reactions pro and con.
Predictable, overlong romantic farce has enough sass and sex appeal to get audiences to go with it.
The gross-outs stick out in the Farrellys' spotty new comedy.
Big Brother fantasy with style and real feeling, courtesy of an excellent Matt Damon-Emily Blunt pairing.
Madly clever animated sagebrush saga has style and wit to burn.
Young stars shine in gritty, low-key version of the Bronte perennial.
The deadening and sometimes laughable litany of shouted military-style dialogue eventually pummels into submission any hope for fresh creative angles on this well-worn format.
Adamantly refuses to provide any wit, humor or fun, concerning itself mostly with the heroine's taxing dilemma of picking between the rural village's two best looking boys.
Zack Snyder's storytelling skills remain in question in his latest CGI spectacular.
Wright has got plenty of moves, but they seem applied rather than organic, noticeable in their own right rather than an inevitable part of the overall fabric.

A brazenly efficient and articulate female assassin nearly worthy of a Tarantino or Coen Brothers movie sticks out from amidst the schlocky criminal muck of Cat Run, a self-consciously sleazy comic crime saga composed of facetious elements.
Little kids will enjoy it all, while parents, when not checking their cell phones, will be thankful for the thoughtfully brief running time.
Flubbed, under-produced representation of the first third of Ayn Rand's still controversial novel bodes ill for parts two and three.
A bizarre, meandering and, finally, maddening mystical oater that will find few partisans.

The film very quickly, and tediously, becomes more of the same old and Craven thing -- self-referential film buff gags accompanied by a clockwork killing spree that seriously reduces the population of a small town.
Hoodwinked is the way audiences will feel after this mercenary sequel.
This Killer lacks punch, dynamism and genuinely seedy atmosphere.
As it is, the pic is marked by a fleet editing style that skips from moment to moment while still allowing the story's meditative aspects to take hold.
Hoffman brings a sympathetic touch to a small dramatic piece that recalls the warm-hearted "little people" dramas of the '50s.
Cliffhanger lives up to its title as a two-hour rollercoaster ride that never stops.
Pic serves up a sensory overload without any compensatory reflection on the outlandish and irresponsible behavior on view.
movie_title: Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Might tolerably amuse the under-10 crowd, but will prove borderline intolerable for everyone else.
Like Jodie Foster's hopeful space voyager in the picture, "Contact" may not travel quite as far as it hopes to go, but the trip is worth taking nonetheless.
A very '90s take on a 1660s tale written in 1850, as a picture of early colonial life it's about as convincing as Pocahontas.
The goings-on seem lacking in wit and inspiration, tolerably entertaining but far from effervescent.
Provides enough solid, character-based amusement to put customers in the chairs and send them out content with services rendered.
"The Long Kiss Goodnight" has a jokey good time with its outlandish pyrotechnics and offbeat character interplay.
Selena surmounts its connect-the-dots approach to its heroine's life to create an appealing, energetic look at a too-briefly soaring musical star.
A thinking-man's women-in-jeopardy picture, Panic Room does about as much as humanly possible with its deliberately restricted one-setting premise.

This immaculately made first feature from noted musicvid and commercials director Mark Romanek provides Robin Williams with one of his creepiest, atypical roles, and the comic star responds with an unusually restrained performance...
A lower-echelon disaster thriller, in which the best character is knocked off early on and the leading man runs out of ideas with a third of the picture still to go.
By far the weakest entry of the four.

This efficient, admirably coherent thriller about reporters digging down to where politics and murder meet in Washington, D.C., has a wistful air about it as regards the fourth estate at a time when the profession is dangling by a thread.
Bigger and more ambitious in every respect, from its action and visceral qualities to its themes.
Neither rarefied art film nor widely accessible inspirational drama, The Soloist falls between the cracks both creatively and commercially.
Although straightforward in format, the film capitalizes on an obviously intense connection between filmmaker and subject with psychological acuity and emotional power.

It just feels tired and recycled -- the referencing of Rimbaud and Blake, the flagrant hipsterism that here falsifies rather than refreshes...the above-it-all attitude toward connecting on a human level.

[Up] could easily have been cloying, but instead proves disarming in its deep reserves of narrative imagination and surprise, as well as its poignant thematic balance of dreams deferred and dreams fulfilled.
The plot's hokey contrivances and the theatrical shtick tend to prevail over the sporadic moments of insight and emotional truth.
Blasting onto the screen at warp speed and remaining there for two hours, the new and improved Star Trek will transport fans to sci-fi nirvana.
A thunderous, unoriginal futuristic hardware show for teenage boys.
The Birdcage is a scream.
The Mask of Zorro stands as a pointed riposte to those who say they don't make 'em like that anymore.

Never generates a head of true excitement, partly because the characters remain constructs designed to perform defined functions, and partly due to the time-worn hokiness of the whole disaster-film format.
Wakefield's trenchant coming-of-age tale uses a classic pairing of utterly contrasting types to ground his exploration of innocence and experience, of complacency and the thirst for adventure...

Story was originally conceived as an episode of "Tales From the Crypt," and that is perhaps what it should have remained, as the thinness of the conceit shows throughout, painfully so in the first half.
The audaciousness that marked Todd Haynes' earlier work has been supplanted by self-important preachiness.
Scarcely represents a convincing, satisfying treatment of the intriguing subject matter.

Regardless of how far one chooses to buy into The Game -- and the ending ambiguously suggests that it could go on and on -- there is no doubt as to Fincher's staggering expertise as a director and his almost clinical sense of precision.
The stylistic fun Stone has in dramatizing this crime of passion thoroughly revitalizes the well-worked genre.

Sympathetic performances from Danny Glover and Matt Dillon somewhat compensate for the mildness of the material, but can't disguise the fact that the film has very little to say about a major societal problem.
A moodily malevolent, anything-goes revenge fantasy that relies more upon special visual and digitally animated effects for its intended appeal than any comics-derived sci-fier to date.
The yarn has its share of gaping holes and jaw-dropping improbabilities, but director Michael Bay sweeps them all aside with his never-take-a-breath pacing.
Feels too piecemeal and ultimately inconsequential to grab the public where it counts.

Fronted by a splendid performance from Paul Newman... Robert Benton's character-driven film is sprinkled with small pleasures; the dramatic developments here don't take place in the noisy, calamitous manner that is customary these days.
A highly absorbing but naggingly patchy look at the acerbic writer Dorothy Parker and her cohorts at the legendary Algonquin Round Table.
movie_title: Mrs. Parker and the Vicious Circle (Mrs. Parker and the Round Table) (1994)

movie_review_blurb: A powerful moral drama that tries to deal with the racism at the root of many problems in contempo American society.
Even when it's not particularly funny, their interplay is engaging, and their lively, raucous personalities keep the proceedings punchy and watchable for the slightly overlong running time.
While an agreeable enough effort in most respects, pic is a bit dark and somber to be terrifically appealing to kids, and could have used bigger doses of humor and music.
Dead Presidents may eventually box itself into a narrative dead end, but its muscular engagement of weighty themes and explosive situations makes it a powerful drama.
Most of the action is played for broad laughs, and Hogan demonstrates the ability to generate them, even if the humor is base and often cruel, making fun of people's looks and ineptitude.
Hush is gussied up by its classy distaff cast members, but remains trashy all the same.
Strong action, special effects and by far the most credible ape "performances" yet seen will spell box office to inspire chest-thumping in all markets.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A second-rate sex farce...mostly clunky and vaguely unsavory.
Breaking through any period piece mustiness with piercing insight into the emotions and behavior of her characters.
The pic showcases an excellent performance by a chubbed-out Matt Damon as a Midwestern executive who's so smart he's dumb.
A film about robots that might find its biggest fans among Luddites, Surrogates is an intense and eerily plausible sci-fi thriller.
A Serious Man is the kind of picture you get to make after you've won an Oscar.
An Education is a wonderful film.
Director Spike Jonze's sharp instincts and vibrant visual style can't quite compensate for the lack of narrative eventfulness that increasingly bogs down this bright-minded picture.
The film achieves a feel that is at once coarse-grained and elegant, antiquated and the height of fashion.

Shortchanging traditional animation by literalizing it while robbing actors of their full range of facial expressiveness, the performance-capture technique favored by director Robert Zemeckis looks more than ever like the emperor's new clothes.
On any level other than as sheer visual sensation, 2012 is a joke, for the simple reason that it has no point of view.
A high concept gets low execution in Planet 51, a lame-brained toon that even kids will recognize as an insipid goof on sci-fi conventions.
Jackson undermines solid work from a good cast with show-offy celestial evocations that severely disrupt the emotional connections with the characters.

Inspirational on the face of it, Clint Eastwood's film has a predictable trajectory, but every scene brims with surprising details that accumulate into a rich fabric of history, cultural impressions and emotion.

Playing a drunken, washed-up music legend reduced to playing small-town bowling alleys, Jeff Bridges is the whole show here as a cowboy-style crooner who wrestles with his demons in ways that easily engage an audience's sympathies.

Sophisticated, sexy and stylishly decked out, Rob Marshall's disciplined, tightly focused film impresses and amuses as it extravagantly renders the creative crisis of a middle-aged Italian director, circa 1965.
Cute and clever though the plot may be, everything is played out in the broadest possible terms without an iota of nuance or subtlety.
The King of the World sets his sights on creating another world entirely in Avatar, and it's very much a place worth visiting.

If you can get over the idea of Sherlock Holmes as an action hero -- and if, indeed, you want to -- then there is something to enjoy about this flagrant makeover of fiction's first modern detective into a man of brawn as much as brain.
Spike Lee has made a disappointingly conventional and sluggish film in Malcolm X.
Iconically effective as a single-minded messenger with a mission, Washington's Eli is ultimately too confined by the man-of-few-words movie norms he's saddled with.

The problem with the script by Susser and David Michod, working from a story by Brian Charles Frank, is that Hesher's uncouth behavior is so aggressively pushed to single-minded, crudely exploitative effect.
This latest bigscreen retrofitting of a vintage TV series (1968-73) feels like the most shameless effort yet in the renewed exploitation of the youth market.

The angst-ridden treatment of Oedipal issues makes the picture play out like a passably talented imitation of O'Neill, Williams, Miller and Inge, and thus it feels like the pale product of an over-tilled field.
A slickly engaging piece of lightweight existentialism highlighted by winning turns from George Clooney and Vera Farmiga.
The film is offbeat, silly, disarming and loopy all at the same time, and viewers will decide to ride with that or just give up on it, according to mood and disposition.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A sort of let's-put-on-a-show summer-camp lark for director Ang Lee after the dramatic rigors of "Brokeback Mountain" and "Lust, Caution," the picture serves up intermittent pleasures but is too raggedy and laid-back for its own good.

Lars von Trier cuts a big fat art-film fart with "Antichrist." As if deliberately courting critical abuse, the Danish bad boy densely packs this theological-psychological horror opus with grotesque, self-consciously provocative images.
The mother of all secular humanists fights a losing battle against freshly minted religious zealots in "Agora," a visually imposing, high-minded epic.

By turns surprising, nutty, windy, audacious and a bit caught up in its own cleverness, the picture is a completely distinctive piece of American pop art with a strong Euro flavor that's new for the director.
Immaculately crafted in beautiful black-and-white and entirely absorbing through its longish running time.
The helmer has made a pretty good thing out of a very bad situation in "The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus".
The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3 is an efficiently reworked version of a tense, ticking-clock suspense story.
Athough it hits any number of gaping credibility potholes on its careening journey around Los Angeles, Speed delivers the goods as a non-stop actioner that scarcely pauses to take a breath.

Overall impact is muted. Oddly, too, the film is somewhat shortchanged by its great star, Johnny Depp, who disappointingly has chosen to play Dillinger as self-consciously cool rather than earthy and gregarious.

There is also a pronounced nasty streak to the innumerable provocations staged by the title character that curdles the laughs and wears out the flamboyant Austrian fashionista's welcome within the picture's brief 82-minute running time.

Dazzlingly well made and perhaps deliberately less fanciful than the previous entries, this one is played in a mode closer to palpable life-or-death drama than any of the others and is quite effective as such.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Boy gets girl and boy loses girl in convoluted, sometimes cloying but ultimately winning fashion in 500 Days of Summer.

Virtually nothing that takes place here is believable for a moment, beginning with the idea that all these people would expend all their energies trying to shoot one another when they are so imperiled to begin with.

It's an odd, far-fetched twist on the Pygmalion story, with the modern angle of poking holes in political correctness, one that might have been made marginally convincing by a dollop of backstory or psychology.
A caustic but under-funny "expose" of the venality of the motion picture business.
movie_title: An Alan Smithee Film: Burn, Hollywood, Burn (1998)

movie_review_blurb: Teasingly enjoyable rubbish through the first hour, Orphan becomes genuine trash during its protracted second half.
Amusing and engaging yet lacking in snap and cohesion.
The pic reveals the palpable pressure to resolve matters pressing heavily on a screenwriter who opted for an unsatisfactory shortcut to an ending.
In the end, the picture's impact derives mostly from its design and assured execution.
Except for the physical aspects of this bleak odyssey by a father and son through a post-apocalyptic landscape, this long-delayed production falls dispiritingly short on every front.
Overly precious poetic examination of a couple's eccentric attempts to evolve their lives will appeal to a rarified few.

With Natalie Portman, in the demanding leading role, equaling her director in unquestioned commitment, the central issue for the viewer is how far one is willing to follow the film down the road to oblivion for art's sake.
This decent remake of the '80s vampire favorite should satiate horror fans.
A work of almost staggering iconographic, mythological, creative and simple emotional meaning, at least for American audiences, this is one vintage film that fully lives up to its classic status.
A lively and derivative 3D storybook spree for some unlikely action heroes.
If the novel Atlas Shrugged is ultimate libertarian porn, then the first two installments of the screen adaptation are soggy softcore.
Feels more seriously connected to real-world concerns than any previous entry, despite the usual outlandish action scenes, glittering settings and larger-than-life characters.
This absorbing drama provides Denzel Washington with one of his meatiest, most complex roles, and he flies with it.
You almost feel sorry for Tyler Perry, stepping out of his own universe for the first time to try to expand his range and finding himself in something as thoroughly dismal as Alex Cross.

It's all sufficiently well done and amusing enough to satisfy the appetites of fans who mainline this sort of thing, but it also sports a concocted, second-hand feel common to this sort of throwback homage ...
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An absorbing, densely packed, sometimes funny telling of the 16th president's masterful effort in manipulating the passage of the 13th amendment.
Hardly the high-priced spread, this condescending comedy about Middle America will score with some audiences and put off others.

Hitchcock might be a work of fantasy and speculation as much as it is history and biography, but as an interpretation of a major talent's inner life and imagination, it's undeniably lively and provocative.
The story of the hunt for Osama Bin Laden builds relentlessly to a powerful end result.

Even with all its ups and downs, there are more than enough bawdy laughs and truthful emotional moments to put this over as a mainstream audience pleaser during a holiday season short on good comedies.
There are elements in this new film that are as spectacular as much of the Rings trilogy was, but there is much that is flat-footed and tedious as well, especially in the early going.

Promised Land presents its environmental concerns in a clear, upfront manner but hits some narrative and character bumps in the second half that weaken the impact of this fundamentally gentle, sympathetic work.
As the enduring success of this property has shown, there are large, emotionally susceptible segments of the population ready to swallow this sort of thing, but that doesn't mean it's good.
Tom Cruise is in fine form.

The anecdotal, odyssey-like structure of this long, talky saga could be considered indulgent, but Tarantino injects the weighty material with so many jocular, startling and unexpected touches that it's constantly stimulating.
The shtick doesn't stick in this kvetchfest with few laughs.
The final installment of the immortal Bella/Edward romance will give its breathlessly awaiting international audience just what it wants.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A gorgeous and accomplished rendering of the massive best-seller.
An enjoyably snarky campus romp that's both wildly nerdy and somewhat sexy.
Imaginative in a highly familiar and ultimately tedious way.
A bold rethinking of a familiar old story and striking design elements are undercut by a draggy mid-section and undeveloped characters in Snow White and the Huntsman.
Appreciative but undramatic look at the young woman who was vital to the Renoirs, father-painter Pierre-Auguste and son-filmmaker-to-be Jean.

A film that starts off big and promising but diminishes into a rather wee thing as it chugs along, with climactic drama that is both too conveniently wrapped up and hinges on magical elements that are somewhat confusing to boot.

As overcranked as it is -- the film is directed as if it were an action drama, with two or three times more cuts than necessary -- People Like Us has a persuasive emotional pull at its heart that's hard to deny.
Allen the writer-director has gone tone-deaf this time around, somehow not realizing that the nonstop prattling of the less than scintillating characters almost never rings true.
A beguiling romantic fantasy about the creative process and its potential to quite literally take on a life of its own, Ruby Sparks performs an imaginative high-wire act with finesse and charm.
Not too many films serve up laughs that just keep on rolling with regularity from beginning to end, but Seth MacFarlane's directorial debut does so and without any feeling of strain.
Savages represents at least a partial resurrection of [Stone's] more hallucinatory, violent, sexual and, in a word, savage side.

Big-time Hollywood filmmaking at its most massively accomplished, this last installment of Christopher Nolan's Batman trilogy makes everything in the rival Marvel universe look thoroughly silly and childish.
The series's legacy is lessened by this capable but uninspired fourth episode.
It's not a film one particularly expected to be made but it's a vastly welcome one.
movie_title: George Harrison: Living In The Material World (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The look, styles, dialogue and attitudes all feel more 21st century than 1968, but this new Sparkle still sparkles more brightly than its 1976 namesake, which was a sort of rough draft for Dreamgirls.
Argo is a crackerjack political thriller told with intelligence, great period detail and a surprising amount of nutty humor for a serious look at the Iran hostage crisis of 1979-81.
A bold, challenging, brilliantly acted drama that is a must for serious audiences.
Bill Murray as FDR? It takes a few minutes to get used to, but once he settles into the role of the 32nd president, the idiosyncratic comic actor does a wonderfully jaunty job of it ...
However accomplished Malick's technique might be in some ways, this mostly comes off, especially in the laborious second hour, as visual doodling without focused thematic goals.
Rian Johnson's third and most ambitious feature keeps the action popping while sustaining interest in the long arc of a story about a man assigned to kill the 30-years-older version of himself.
The weight of its intellectual distancing device presses much of the life and feeling out of Joe Wright's and Tom Stoppard's adventurous adaptation of Tolstoy's Anna Karenina.
The old pro scores with another hit right up the middle.
These are good actors, but aside from Brolin and Gosling, they're barely given any special moments of their own to make their marks here.
Arnold ain't all he used to be but still has a little punch left in this just passable violent action potboiler.
In essence, Mama represents a throwback and a modest delight for people who like a good scare but prefer not to be terrorized or grossed out.
Would have made for a fine film noir 60 years ago but feels rather contrived and unbelievable in the setting of contemporary New York.

Danny Boyle has great and plainly evident fun adding twists and curves and tunnels and endless style to his modern London noir Trance, but he makes so many left turns that the film turns in on itself rather than going anywhere.
Good if you're a 12-15-year-old boy, bad if you're just about anyone else.
There's something about novelist Stephenie Meyer that induces formerly interesting directors to suddenly make films that are slow, silly and soporific.
The story of a sympathetic fugitive who forges a bond with two teenage boys near a mighty river down south, Mud is shot through with traditional qualities of American literature and drama.
Rather than letting its hero's accomplishments and behavior speak for themselves, Helgeland hammers home every achievement and then puts a halo around it, as if anyone won't get it otherwise.
A terrific-looking sci-fier that loses steam in the second half.
A ham-fisted, thick-skulled comic caper about bodybuilders-turned-criminals which, like its three protagonists, fully lives down to its own potential.
Downey is at his superhero genius best here, rattling off dialogue both clever and boilerplate with non-repetitive aplomb.
A game cast and lots of gamey R-rated shenanigans can't compensate for the silly comic contrivances that dominate The Big Wedding.
The production gives the impression of a massive machine cranked up for two hours of full output; it efficiently delivers what it's built to do, but without style or personality.

The cast is first-rate, the ambiance and story provide a measure of intoxication and, most importantly, the core thematic concerns pertaining to the American dream, self-reinvention and love lost, regained and lost again are tenaciously addressed.
An exhilarating black-and-white New York seriocomedy from Noah Baumbach with a stellar star turn by co-writer Greta Gerwig.

This new entry will only add mightily to the good fortunes of Universal's biggest franchise; no matter how silly and outlandish the action gets -- and it does become ridiculous -- it also delivers the goods its audience expects.

Perhaps even more here than in her other films, Coppola's attitude toward her subject seems equivocal, uncertain; there is perhaps a smidgen of social commentary, but she seems far too at home in the world she depicts to offer a rewarding critique of it.
An outstanding fictional take on the early 1960s folk music scene from the Coen Brothers.
A startlingly effective adaptation of William Faulkner's challenging novel by James Franco.
A stylistic experiment that engages the interest for about a quarter of an hour.
This overlong and anemic drama features an impressive cast but is too inert to catch on with critics or audiences.
Robert Redford gives an impressive one-man show in this sea-stranded survival tale.
Generates a fair amount of tension and produces the kind of nationalistic outrage that rock-ribbed Americans will feel in their guts.
It does supply enough visual spectacle, tense action and sticky, slithery monster attacks to hit the spot with thrill-seeking audiences worldwide.
Philip Roth may be unmasked but is only partially revealed in this very personable documentary portrait of one of the leading American literary figures of the past half-century.
Paul Weitz betrays an erratic grip on the comic tone, and the misguided central characters emerge, in the end, as less likeable than they ought to be.
A sincere, refreshingly unaffected look at teenagers and their attitudes about the future.
A shrewd script and career-launching performances drive a tragic modern story that carries heavy social weight.
An edgy, disturbing and altogether first-rate crime drama that very much centers on women, though it does have a lot of daddy issues.
A dramatically obscure, technically brilliant experiment in speculative fiction from Shane Carruth.
An exceptionally beautiful, if a bit fuzzy-headed, romantic Texas outlaw saga that announces a considerable talent in writer-director David Lowery.
There's not much delightful about Afternoon Delight, an off-putting comedy about a too-idle Los Angeles woman that all of a sudden in the last few minutes decides it wants to be a serious movie.
A handsomely designed, occasionally funny but ultimately empty female vengeance yarn.
The world of Hollywood voice-over talent provides a ripe backdrop for Lake Bell's funny and engaging directorial debut.
Smartly done account of the trials and tribulations of the first porn star.

Director Drake Doremus confirms his knack for pinpointing subtle emotional tremors on fragile personal landscapes, even if some too-easy coincidences and pat dramatic moments chip away at the compressed story's credibility.

In trying to merge this alarmist theme with an old-fashioned murder mystery, the filmmakers throw at least one plot-twist sucker-punch too many, leaving the viewer with an "Oh, come on" reaction to the entire film.
Another rough comic movie road trip helps give car travel a bad name.
A concoction that makes highly calculated use of fantasy, fates, taboos, young love and visual hocus-pocus to ensnare an audience in a narrative web that's pretty darn ridiculous.
At 98 minutes, this is by far the shortest of the Die Hard films, the rest of which run more than two hours. But it ends not a moment too soon.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Sprinkles only a few highlights of real musical talent through an otherwise blatant pat-on-the-back montage.
Elle Fanning mesmerizes as a burgeoning teen radical in 1962 London.
Simply in terms of efficient storytelling, clear logistics and consistent viewer engagement, Jack is markedly superior to the recent "Hobbit."
A raucous boys' night comedy that goes for the outrageous and hits it often enough.
Quite the opposite of the great earlier film, the Oz here is a dull place to be. Given the choice, you might even consider going back to Kansas.
For the most part ... a tense, extreme-jeopardy thriller that delivers the intended goods.
An airless and inert expression of a capitalist kingpin's odyssey across a threatening New York City.
Unusual for this sort of thing, Snitch is a film for which you remember the characters and actors more than the big action moments.
This is a tale of murder, idealistic journalism, warped sexual desires, a slipshod legal system and inbred backwater types hostile to outsiders.

Ratner and screenwriters Ted Griffin and Jeff Nathanson use the financial mayhem as a plot trigger for an elaborate scheme that, however far-fetched, is all but irresistible in its criminal legitimacy and its promise for just desserts.
Tackles its trickiest challenges with plausibility and good sense, while serving up a simmeringly caustic view of its controversial subject's behavior, public and private.
The script makes no attempt to assert its plausibility or realism; it is, instead, refreshingly frank about what it is, a simple, workable framework for the melees and mayhem.
Visually stunning, but heavy-handed and lacking a single moment that evinces any relish for movie-making.
An eventful but bloodless first half of the smash series' finale.

A passionate brief for film preservation wrapped in a fanciful tale of childhood intrigue and adventure, Hugo dazzlingly conjoins the earliest days of cinema with the very latest big screen technology.
A mostly winning return for childhood favorites from a prior century looks to accomplish its goal of pleasing old fans and winning new ones.
Other than commercially, more is less in this antic, not so funny sequel to the 2006 blockbuster.

Unfortunately, as the film moves along, its brisk pace notwithstanding, too many issues come to weigh against it. As cleverly conceived as it is, the time-for-money substitution leaves a lot of questions unanswered.
A splendid comedy-drama about a father coping with his comatose wife and difficult daughters represents high points for George Clooney and Alexander Payne.
Wall-to-wall action in a spectacular, if repetitive, fourth series entry.

The wardrobe foolishness comes off fine thanks to Downey's deadpan unashamedness, while the action stuff, perhaps arresting the first couple of times you see it, already seems hackneyed, mannered and overworked, an affectation of diminishing returns.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Fine American version of the literary sensation delivers everything except that something extra.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An atmospheric, tear-jerking, highly cinematic melodrama.

Jolie deserves significant credit for creating such a powerfully oppressive atmosphere and staging the ghastly events so credibly, even if it is these very strengths that will make people not want to watch what's onscreen.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An emotionally potent, noticeably literary story of a precious boy's reaction to his father's death on 9/11.
A beguiling tale about Hollywood's silent movie days that is itself silent, this made-in-L.A. French feature will charm cinephiles with its affection for one of the movies' golden ages.
Everyone on view is so fundamentally decent and goody-goody that no real tension or unresolvable conflicts ever surface.
On a scene-by-scene basis, Young Adult entirely engages with its smart exchanges between characters who are well equipped with rough edges and raw nerves.
Colorful, clever enough, free of cloying showbiz in-jokes, action-packed without being ridiculous about it and even well choreographed...
The Rum Diary remains a relatively mild diversion, not at all unpleasant but neither compelling nor convulsive.

After the gradual build-up, for which director Heijningen relies more on inevitability rather than any demonstrable skill at generating genuine suspense, the payoff seems rote and completely out of step with everything that's come before.
The film's raw power and controversial content make it a good festival item and will ignite strong reactions among Jewish and Israel-minded audiences.
While corny at times, this sports drama -- based on David Cook's best-selling novel -- is sure to find a welcoming audience with its down-home Christian message.

Snappy, nasty, deftly acted and perhaps the fastest paced film ever directed by a 78-year-old, this adaptation of Yasmina Reza's award-winning play God of Carnage fully delivers the laughs and savagery of the stage piece...

Precise, lucid and thrillingly disciplined, this story of boundary-testing in the early days of psychoanalysis is brought to vivid life by the outstanding lead performances of Keira Knightley, Viggo Mortensen and Michael Fassbender.
Madonna's second foray into directing is pleasing to the eyes and ears, but lacking anything for the soul.
The pressure cooker plot calls for intense performances all around but first among equals are Winslet and Ehle.

Never less than watchable and loaded with trademark negativity so extreme it's sometimes funny, the new film is nonetheless saddled with a protagonist so narrowly and unlikably presented that, in the end, he doesn't seem worth the time devoted to him.
Harrowing, engrossing, claustrophobic and sometimes literally hard to watch...
Strives to be a genuinely good film, but unwilling to let go of proven formulas, it falls short.
Whereas Peckinpah managed not only to raise hackles but to get under the skin, Lurie manages only the former, which reduces the material to the level of sensation-mongering.
Strong stuff on the sexual wild side from bold director Steve McQueen and the extraordinary Michael Fassbender.
Tasty, if sketchy, modern noir with car chases and bloody action that should turn the trick for genre-seeking audiences.
Revealing, impressionistic peek at the creation of a new show at Paris's famed erotic dancing club.
The sheer goodness of it all might be too much to bear.
Taylor Lautner tries to hold his own in an action thriller too silly to give him much of a chance.
Serious-minded, thought-provoking animal documentary will have a lengthy life, mostly in ancillary markets.

This punishingly predictable tale will test whether sci-fi action fanboys can stomach having their cherished genre infiltrated by sentimental hokum about a down-on-his-luck dad and his spunky long-lost son.
It's startling how badly the dance numbers and action sequences are staged, shot and cut.
This film may not do for birds what Frankel's last film, Marley & Me, did for dogs, but there's a similar current of warmth and appreciation for the effect of animals on people to be felt.
The gritty style only accentuates the increasingly far-fetched dramatics in Contraband, an involving, atmospherically grungy mid-register thriller.
In the end, it's the flashy action and innate inspirational elements that make a measure of impact here. But you just know there's so much more to this story.
The end of the world, von Trier-style, is a middling thing as a film.
An unpalatable Franco-American entrée one would like to send back to wherever it came from.
A certain technical virtuosity is the signal virtue of Silent House, a creaky haunted house that, once the big twist is revealed, makes very little sense at all.
Although the result is quite a mishmash, dramatic coherence prevails over visual flair...
It makes sense that this Spanish-lingo farce plays very much like an SNL sketch. The only problem is that it packs about as many laughs into its 85 minutes as a good skit does in eight or 10.
Hunger Games has such a strong narrative structure, built-in forward movement and compelling central character that it can't go far wrong.
A relentlessly mechanical piece of work that will not or cannot take the imaginative leaps to yield even fleeting moments of awe, wonder or charm.
While it may not be as stylistically idiosyncratic as Memento Insomnia is a gripping, highly dramatic thriller that more than confirms the distinctive talent of young Brit helmer Christopher Nolan.
[A] funny, good-hearted resuscitation of Hollywood's beloved lowbrow lunkheads.
Some privileged nature footage from the African rain forest is dishonored by deeply silly narration in Chimpanzee.
There's no dramatic or visual scheme here, just random camera angles tossed and mixed.
Whedon pulls off a stunning feat in bringing balance to this superhuman circus, engineered to charm the geek core and non-fans alike.
Almost invigorating in its disreputability; it's both cheesy and striking, corny and bold, dismissible and yet strangely appealing for its singularity.
Dark Shadows sinks its teeth half-way into its potentially meaty material but hesitates to go all the way.
A credibly drawn central character is trapped inside a half-cooked dramatic stew in Hello I Must Be Going.
As in Fantastic Mr. Fox, Anderson is able to express sincere personal connection and compatibility while employing a highly artificial style.

[It] benefits from unvarnished, forthright performances from Marion Cotillard and Bullhead hunk Matthias Schoenaerts, as well as from the utterly convincing representation of the former's paraplegic state.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, it's a cartoon, but it's conspicuously unmodulated, with the volume set on high and the pacing all but pushed to fast-forward.

This reflection on the past, love and death through the prism of layers of theatrical endeavor is both serious and frisky, engaging on a refined level but frustratingly limited in its complexity and depth.
A juicy, bloody, grimy and profane crime drama that amply satisfies as a deep-dish genre piece, Killing Them Softly rather insistently also wants to be something more.
While the film's dramatic impact is variable, visually and aurally it is a constant pleasure.
Have teenagers always been this idiotic or does Project X move the goalposts?
An intensely claustrophobic, gut-wrenching thriller.
Cohen employs a comic range that ricochets between wicked political barbs and the lowest anatomical farce, to often funny and occasionally hilarious effect.
Everyone's creative burners were on low heat for this woeful outing.
Like a loud guest at a party who's amusing for a while, until you just have to escape to the next room.
The clash of fundamentalist Islam and Western values as encapsulated by the "blasphemous" Danish cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad is examined at length in It's Hard Being Loved by Jerks.
movie_title: It's Hard Being Loved by Jerks (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With the possible exception of Aguirre's performance, there's little here to stick to the ribs and the film's ultimate impact is slight.
At once entirely frank and downright cuddly in the way it deals with the seldom-visited subject of the sex lives of people with disabilities...
Mary Elizabeth Winstead rules in a small, solid study of alcoholism and recovery.
A tantalizing Franco-American stew for audiences with a taste for bawdy humor and nutty characters.
Notable performances by Glenn Close and Janet McTeer mark this carefully made but muted story of women passing as men in 19th-century Dublin.
A wacky, sometimes hilariously esoteric deconstruction of the subliminal messages and hidden meanings in Stanley Kubrick's The Shining.
A hoot of an old-fashioned British horror film in which being under 10 years old is not a good thing.
Although it dog-legs into silly mayhem in the homestretch, for a good portion of its quick 83-minute running time Chronicle is a quite clever boys-gone-wild-on-telekinetic-powers fantasy.
An exceptional American independent feature that deserves the best efforts to tap audiences that would surely embrace it.
Dramatically, the film hangs together well enough but the repetitive nature of the action and lack of stylistic shadings and nuance ultimately prove rather grinding.

This perfectly dreadful romantic action comedy manages to embarrass its three eminently attractive leading players in every scene, making this an automatic candidate for whatever raspberries or golden turkeys or other dubious awards may be given...
A young woman's arrival creates sexual upheavals in a cool, artistic L.A. household, in an unsatisfying drama that might have worked better as a comedy.
Basic, efficient little horror item scares up a few little shocks, possibly enough for a modest commercial career.
Robert De Niro and writer-director Paul Weitz find the most congenial material either of them has had in quite some time in Being Flynn, a fractious father-son drama with a soul-warming gentle core.
Life is too short for Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A self-important psychic thriller may attract indiscriminate fans of all things paranormal but becomes increasingly incoherent and infuriating.
Earnest hokum of this nature has become increasingly rare. And for a reason.
The First Time feels slight and pretty ordinary by the end, with no edge or compelling insights.
Repeats the same old stereotypes of 'artistic greatness,' and ends up feeling a little bit worn out.
Overly long, or perhaps just ploddingly paced and unnecessarily repetitive.
Much to my own surprise, the newest installment of the Pokémon cartoon franchise gets my begrudging respect.
It slaps us in the face and asks us to hate it at every turn. Mission accomplished.

Keep the River on Your Right is not only the fascinating story of one man, but it is also about the cultural changes engendered by (post)modernity that have differentially affected 'us' (that is, humanity in all its varieties) all over the world.
movie_title: Keep the River on Your Right (2000)

movie_review_blurb: The lack of any girl power, or even any real girl presence, in AP2 contributes to a ratcheting up of the boys' piggy behavior as the film tries to out-do its own previous gross-out humor.
A sprawling affair, filled with bad accents ... tired cliches about studly horsemen and young girls' sexual awakenings, and really bad lip-syncing to Italian opera.
The film suffers from a distinct lack of urgency or intensity, largely because of the predictability of its plot.
The nostalgia infusing Hearts in Atlantis often makes the film infuriating, as well as just plain dopey.
Mitchell and Trask clearly strive to bring back into vogue gay (or at least sexually ambiguous) boys who know how to rock! And how to look fabulous while doing so.
The film tells us, we all have, or would like to have, a little Monkeybone inside of us. Well, hopefully not.
Mines the twentieth century to construct a musical extravaganza totally out of time with its narrative world. And it works, most of the time.
Stuffed to the gills with sacchariney melodrama meant to tug at all the requisite heartstrings and get us to contemplate 'the bigger questions.'
As his immense popularity suggests, there is something about Lecter that appeals to 'us', there appears to be some level on which 'we' all wish we could be a little more like him.
Contributes to the same commodification of the holidays it tries so desperately to criticize.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Dungeons & Dragons takes itself far too seriously and ends up being just plain stupid.
Moves along rather herkily-jerkily, bouncing from one special effect to another, from one character or scene to another, with seemingly little connection between them.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: That the film doesn't hold that much appeal to me is hardly surprising, and in the end immaterial.
Such dreck!
An ambitious and enjoyable piece of work.
An unmitigated flop!
Clearly, Lurie is no better a writer than he is a director.
What is actually scariest about Valentine is the film's tacit attitude that these girls had it coming.
I hope that Paul Thomas Anderson's absolutely brilliant Magnolia receives the accolades that it so richly deserves.
A ballsy piece of filmmaking that at every turn defies expectations.
For all its shortcomings, there is a sort of guilty pleasure.
The cast generally turns in fine performances.
To my surprise Dracula 2000, wasn't all that bad and I actually found myself largely enjoying it.

The success of Malèna lies in how both Renato and Malèna's bodies and stories become national bodies and national stories, and in its negotiation of a delusional nostalgia for an Edenic, pre-Mussolini Italy in a post-Auschwitz world.
Largely makes good on this imperative to freshness.
What in the world ever made Smith think Morissette's involvement in this film would be a good thing? Oh, wait, but isn't it ironic?
An ambitious and generally enjoyable film, especially for those who might desire a little more narrative coherence and depth than Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone has to offer.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing new.
An affecting film that leaves you wondering long after the credits roll.

Resists depicting WWII in easy blacks and whites, and in doing so, challenges the national ideologies, nostalgia, and idealization that have become so commonplace in popular cultural imaginings of the 'great war.'
Bromances like Funny People do a disservice to the friendship capabilities of straight men, making them seem stunted.
In Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, complicated teenaged sexual desires are the counterpart to the sacrificial love oft touted by Dumbledore.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A Harvard professor is an unlikely candidate for the hero of a summer blockbuster, and Angels & Demons demonstrates exactly why. The film is filled with talk, talk, talk.
Scary as Hugh Jackman's vascular body may be, it's also perfectly appropriate as a visual extension of the weaponization of Wolverine.
Every Little Step is all about repetition, documenting the casting of the 2006 Broadway revival of A Chorus Line, a musical about the casting of a Broadway musical.
Alien Trespass won't let our knowledge of the stereotypes it incorporates do the work and make the critique.
That the boys are so earnest in their dedication to the Star Wars oeuvre signals their stunted adolescence.
For Rorschach, there are clear lines between good and evil, and in this he is the most traditional of the superheroes in Watchmen.
Despite its title, "The Women" is not an update of George Cukor's diva smackdown of the same name.
Your faith and your patience won't fare well for sitting through the slow-moving, lackluster Henry Poole is Here.
The Happening features an effectively stylized physical environment: rarely have clouds drifting overhead and wind blowing through trees and a sunny day been filmed so ominously.
The film's real pleasure is in the connections it makes (whether intentional or not) to current 'real world' questions about the beneficence of institutional authority.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It's corny, clichéd, and often an absolute hoot.
Even though the film does come down on Batman's 'side,' it raises as many questions about fear as political weapon as it answers.
In timing, delivery, and charisma, Tina Fey and Steve Carell are exactly who they always are, and this is a good thing.
It is precisely Jackson's pandering to fans' expectations that repeatedly drags The Return of the King to a halt.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Sure, Crossroads and Brit herself may be silly, superficial, and bubbly, but so what? She and the film are also fun, sexy, and playful.
... the story doesn't make a whole lot of sense ...
Never quite rises to the level of self-conscious parody, but merely replicates the same old stereotypes.
A second-rate recycling of any number of recent lowbrow comedy flicks.
Here the problem is compounded by the fact that few members of the target audience (kids) are even aware of the original series.
Attack of the Clones will likely be remembered as cluttered with inconsequential character and plot details and excessive special effects.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: As a kid, I always wanted to be Spider-Man. I still do.
Hardly 'romantic,' not a 'comedy,' and downright nasty to women.
It's surprisingly good, spooky, fun, and stylish.
The film is muddled by its slavish dedication to the minutiae of events and at the same time, erases those aspects of the book that gave it real social and political urgency.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The good news is that Johnson's Daredevil follows Marvel's disability politics.
It's a treat (and necessity) not only for youngish gay boys, but for anyone who enjoys campy good fun with the added bonus of watching dominant cultural values self-destruct.
Whereas the original Hulk (and King Kong, for that matter) fought against injustice, intolerance, and abuses of power, all that this Hulk has to fight is his Big Bad Daddy.
It also insists there be a physical correlate to that internal turmoil, that we be able to see the mark of his degeneracy on the surface of his body.
It's about something we think of as "boring," but it aims to code that boring story with the most exciting filmmaking techniques imaginable.

The story is compelling. The acting is great. The technical aspects are solid. But it's hard to escape the idea that the film is a remix of something else, an attempt to rework story elements that felt more original elsewhere.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If there's one thing Kumiko the Treasure Hunter proves beyond the shadow of a doubt, it's that Rinko Kikuchi is a movie star in the making.
Ant-Man has its charms, but they're frequently lost beneath a story that feels like a patchwork job. It's a fun watch, but also a frustrating one.
What makes Phoenix so remarkable, then, is director and writer Christian Petzold's marvelous command of tone.
It wasn't until the final shot of Carol that I realized how tightly the film had wrapped me in its web.

It's just a story of four characters in a secluded location, shot on an obviously small budget. But deep inside of it is a fully imagined idea of where humanity is headed -- and what evils we're capable of.
Krampus is ultimately that rare thing -- a potentially really good movie undone by one glaring Achilles heel.

It's the best movie Lee has made in ages, possibly since 2002's 25th Hour (which is still the best post-9/11 movie), and it demands that you pay attention at all times, whether you agree with it or not.
This is a movie you need to see right now.
The film's biggest sin is that it never moves past its influences to become its own thing -- it's trapped in a kind of netherworld, where it feels like a cover version of other, better movies.

Rogue Nation is terrific fun, the best action movie of the summer without Mad Max in the title. It's also, arguably, the best Mission: Impossible movie, impressive for the fifth installment in any movie series.
Feig is great at writing big, obvious gags that nonetheless succeed. It made me think I was in for a good time - and Spy is definitely that.
It's hard to shake the thought that The Revenant is very, very good at being one thing, yet wants desperately to be another and never quite gets there.
The Cobbler is the rare movie so terrible that it's hard to figure out why it even exists, why somebody didn't run in front of the speeding train of its production yelling, "Stop!"
A good story can cover up all manner of sins. But that ball gown is indicative of the film's whole approach - covering a thin, needlessly bloated story with beautiful surfaces.

LaGravenese doesn't seem to have a particular vision for how to shoot or tell this particular story, so he just aims for the most straightforward method possible most of the time, and that ultimately cripples the film in ways it can't recover from.
It's basically Harry Potter with spies.

The film is quietly radical not because it dares to rattle cages so much but because it doesn't. This is a story of huge emotions and big moments, told via intimate gestures and tiny power shifts. It's a gem.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: As it stands, The Hateful Eight is a beautiful film, filled with images and ideas that will stick with me for days. However, it never quite clears the bar it's trying to jump over.
Thick with potential and irony, and could make for a tremendous film. When Joy embraces that side of itself, it almost gets there. When it doesn't, well, it's just plain bad.
The stuff onboard the Pendleton is the only part of the movie that remains compelling throughout - and it only accounts for a third of the running time.
Hail, Caesar! is a big, Looney Tunes confection of a movie.
[A War] is not a masterpiece. It's as messy and uneven as real life. But messiness is inherent to why A War works.

The Witch isn't a horror film where the scares come from big spooky jolts, or from gore. No, The Witch is a horror film that creeps up on you, spreading its tendrils slowly across the landscape of your mind.
I've never seen a movie quite like Embrace of the Serpent.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The best thing about The Hunger Games: Mockingjay - Part 2 is how unconcerned it is with what we expect in terms of closure of a happy ending.
