A little bit of sentiment is one thing, Steven. But this is simply labourious.
You'll have questions regarding the ending - I certainly do. But "was it worth it?" won't be one of them.
On some very basic levels, Hugo just isn't very good.
Even the combined charisma of Denzel Washington and Ryan Reynolds can't make Safe House seem like anything other than the derivative and unengaging nonsense that it is.
[Coriolanus] makes some questionably antiquated statements about class, but nevertheless captivates.
With a narrative as flat and barren as the red martian landscape, John Carter is a big-budget sci-fi spectacle that fails to excite or entertain.
A few good performances here and there do nothing to prevent this sappy, doe-eyed production from falling head-first into tedious territory.
An unwanted sequel to one of the worst comic book films ever made blasts onto the screen with such assaultive energy that memories of its predecessor are incinerated from your brain.
It's hard to imagine any action fan walking out of The Raid feeling in any way unsatisfied.

Gary Ross' first foray into action filmmaking is occasionally hampered by wobbly camera-work, but is successful in the way it communicates the horror of violence without threatening the teen-friendly rating.
Even when the action is unintelligible, it's at least better than listening to the characters talk.
This Pie's taste - simple, crass, but funny and genuinely heartfelt - is at least as good, if not better, than it's ever been before.
It's little more than repetitious conversation - conversation that uncovers little new or titillating on the topics of sex, madness or the process of psychoanalysis.
The latest, loudest and stupidest example of the hyper-jingoistic, military-fetishising, intellect-lowering alien invasion movie.
Streep's got my vote.
There's pun-laden dialogue and slapstick violence aplenty, but the meta element feels sloppy.
The biggest criticism of What We Do In The Shadows is that it's so unrelentingly funny that you'll miss half the jokes through laughing
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's thanks largely to the simple, accessible chemistry between Rudd and Hirsh that film is, for the most part, a success.
This infectious jazz doco will leave you feeling a little more content than Whiplash.
Andre 3000 makes an A-grade Hendrix, but this biopic sees the legend's legacy fall into a bit of a haze.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Sexy, scary and fearlessly subversive.
movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

movie_review_blurb: You may not have heard of this Hollywood legend, but you definitely know a few of his famous friends.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Contains no shortage of great actors, none of whom can do anything to distract from the film's horribly awkward pacing or the apparent visual indifference of its director.
Ebert had a way of finding the good in things. Friends. Family. The joy of going to the movies. In capturing his passion and generosity of spirit, this doco earns two thumbs up.
[Murray] proves he's lost none of his caustic charm. In St Vincent he's vinegar, adding just enough acidity to a screenplay that without him would have been sickeningly sweet.
Flailing handheld camerawork, frantic over-editing and claustrophobic close-ups make it basically impossible to distinguish Mills from his enemies, or to decipher the geography of a given scene.
Reveals in stark, day-to-day exchanges the inequality faced by women living in conservative Iran. And yet somehow, the film leaves you feeling inspired.
Tales of wartime valour have been done to death, and frankly Unbroken brings nothing new to the table.
Sensitive, compassionate storytelling.
Vaughn shoots the film with the giddiness of a 12-year-old, one who just stepped out of his very first spy movie with dreams of saving the world.
A ridiculous, juvenile, funny-ish dick-and-fart comedy that should be taken seriously by absolutely no one.
Enthusiasm alone doesn't excuse derivative storytelling. Nor does it make the film's casual racism and leering misogyny any less unpleasant to watch.
Why doesn't it work? Perhaps it's the feeling that Levring is ticking boxes, trying to include all the typical hallmarks of a Western without ever giving them the time to properly develop.
A powerful true tale told with grace and endless compassion.
Not even the proven chemistry of its cast can redeem this formulaic comedy con-job, one that's totally unworthy of your time and, perhaps more importantly, your money
With more disciplined writing and editing, Folman's cartoon menagerie could have resembled a masterpiece. As it stands, it's an admirable and thought-provoking failure.
Part live performance, part abstract nature doco and part Space Odyssey-style psychedelic mindf*ck...as a one-off big-screen experience, it's definitely a trip.
While the stakes of the film may not be particularly high, you can't help but feel invested in the journey.
movie_title: Living Is Easy With Eyes Closed (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Compelling, and unwaveringly human, Two Days, One Night is among the best films of the year.
Basically one big, 100-minute promotional video, specifically designed to make the exhibition look amazing and convince people to buy a ticket.
Mark Twain by way of Jimmy Neutron, this oddball family film lays the syrup on thick, only to cut through the sweetness with a biting critique of America's cultural foibles.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Tonally disastrous, the movie attempts to depict gruesome violence as serious one moment and hysterically entertaining the next.
A simple and surprisingly affecting love story set against the stunning summery glow of rural New South Wales.
Stephen Lance takes your typically angst-ridden, po-faced Australian teen drama, and dresses it up in a full-body latex suit.
Plays into false myths about sexual assault.
There's an unshakable sense of menace throughout the low-key mob movie The Drop that lifts it above the outward cliches of its story
There's something deliciously twisted about watching cops, crims, judges and lawyers all awaiting the outcome of a single, stubborn s***.
Heavily indebted to the collected works of Jane Austen...distinguishes itself via a purposeful sense of cultural specificity within a more broadly relatable story.
Glides out of the darkness and seizes you by the throat.
Shows a more optimistic side of the filmmaker than audiences may have come to expect
A film so stuffy and slow-moving that it makes its geriatric headliner look positively spritely by comparison.

The single worst date movie to come out of the European arthouse circuit since Charlotte Gainsbourg become intimately familiar with a pair of rusty scissors in Antichrist...at once brilliant and impossible to bear.
The writing here feels like vintage Rock: free-flowing, profane and absolutely hilarious.
a lively and eye-opening documentary on a subject that needs as much attention as it can get...That Sugar Film attacks its subject from every conceivable angle.
In an era of increasingly reluctant and angst-riddled crusaders, [Deadpool] makes being a superhero look fun.
A mystery, a farce, a treatise on religion and a sly interrogation of cinemas so-called golden age masquerading as the ultimate Hollywood love letter.
While the film's gnawing brand of terror may not be particularly immediate, its lingering effects are also far less easily dispelled.
Rarely has a film captured the terror of imminent bloodshed with this kind of frenzied, animalistic intensity.
It's one of the savviest Australian comedies in years. Which isn't to say that it isn't also incredibly stupid, because it most definitely is. And that's the entire point.
With snappy dialogue aplenty, the work of the cast is paramount, and thankfully the whole team knocks it out of the park.
Timely social satire of the most scathing and cynical kind.

Demolition unfolds with all the narrative and intellectual nuance of a bulldozer being driven through a house. Which, incidentally, is something else we get to see happen in this terrible, terrible film.
While it's a stretch to call the film a reaction to a Trump presidency, his ascension makes the film's rebellious spirit and multicultural flavour that much more appealing.
Taking the glamour, if not the glee, out of violent big-screen gun battles, Free Fire draws more on slapstick comedies than it does Hollywood shoot 'em ups.

[It's] isn't necessarily Coppola's best film... And yet, with deliciously pulpy sensibilities, a surprisingly wicked sense of humour, and a cast stacked with talented women at the tops of their game, it might just be her most squirmingly entertaining.
An entertaining gonzo-style doco about the history and meaning of the southern hemisphere's most iconic constellation.
The film contrasts the heavy stuff with a healthy dose of deadpan Kiwi humour.

This simple but intensely confronting documentary offers an unprecedented look at the appalling conditions in Australia's refugee detention centre, and the day-to-day lives of the men our government has imprisoned there.
movie_title: Chauka, Please tell us the time (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A sexy, stylish, surprisingly intelligent thriller that demands to be seen at least twice.
Three films into his career, Blomkamp has proven himself as a storyteller with a lot on his mind.
Despite its grim subject matter, Room never wallows in darkness, but instead stares defiantly into the light.
Mixes the meta elements of his recent output with the shrewd social commentary of his pre-arrest work, all buoyed by a cheekiness that makes it accessible to audiences beyond the arthouse.
Never quite comes together as a compelling whole.
Kind of like the Avengers, only more racially diverse, and marginally less bound by the laws of physics or common sense.
Dolan fully embraces his melodramatic tendencies...this is a gaudy, exuberant film, as messy as it is astounding.
How much you like the movie will largely depend on how much you like the art. For the record, we like it quite a bit.
A stark and strangely mesmerising take on contemporary silent cinema... for anyone interested in the language of filmmaking itself, The Tribe is a movie that demands to be seen
An intriguing piece of understated science fiction.
Without characters to latch on to, or much in the way of deeper thematic content, the novelty of Inarritu's formal work eventually begins to wear off.
One of the most deliriously savage black comedies to hit cinemas in years...as sharp as a corkscrew and every bit as twisted.
Plenty of Pixar movies have the capacity to make people cry, but Inside Out is about *why* we cry.
If even half of what is alleged in [Going Clear] is true, then it's not just an incredible doco, but a first-rate horror movie as well.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A loud, stylish, ultra high-energy romp...both uproariously funny and unexpectedly poignant.
One of the most cinematic Shakespeare adaptations ever put to screen...as compelling in its moments without dialogue as it is when the characters are speaking.
See Love. See it in 3D. For the craft, and for the arguments you'll have with people once it's over.
It is perhaps the most compelling film yet made about the global economic downturn and the everyday people whose lives it tore apart.
For the most part the humour is fairly broad and sweary...still, as with Feig's previous films, the material is elevated considerably by the performances.
A smart, candid, foul-mouthed and thoroughly charming subversion of sugary romantic fantasies and stereotypical representations of women on screen.
Whether or not you can justify viewing Maier's work without her consent, it's pretty clearly not okay to rummage through her personal life just to satisfy a tawdry curiosity.
One of the year's most emotional documentaries
Accelerates from one over-the-top set-piece to the next. It's ridiculous, juvenile and very, very funny.
An amusing and, at times, genuinely revealing doco - albeit one with distinctively niche appeal, and cloaked in an air of unmistakable self-satisfaction.
Despite the miserable subject matter, writer-director Felix Van Groeningen manages to mostly strike the right chord, eschewing unchecked histrionics for honest, bittersweet emotion.
As bold and intriguing as it is cluttered and confused. In the end, it contains just enough interesting elements to justify the cost of a ticket.
Stock characters and clunky, heavy-handed storytelling keeps Healing, the new Australian drama from Peaches director Craig Monahan, well and truly tethered to the ground.
The pacing is unyieldingly slow, while also missing that sense of creeping escalation that makes the better films of the Romanian art house moment so dreadfully effective
There's nothing even remotely new about this self-conscious little indie, one in which the seeds of dramatic sincerity are smothered by constant affectation.
Director Hiner Saleem takes the trappings of an old-school American Western, and infuses them with a distinctively Kurdish feel.
There's not a hint of melodrama here, and the tale is all the more compelling for it. For a film set half a world away, Siddharth hits very close to home.
Blockbuster effects can't mask bland storytelling.
It's a story designed to play the heartstrings like a fiddle, extracting sighs and sobs from willing viewers with surgical precision.
Blending the tepid romanticism of a made-for-TV biopic with the most tedious political drama this side of The Phantom Menace, Arash Amel's screenplay is suffocatingly dull.
Should come with a warning: may cause optic nerve damage as a result of excessive eye-rolling
A pervasive sense of bleakness soon swallows the movie whole.

Featuring both a gripping lead performance by Essie Davis and one of the most creepifying monsters to ever stalk your dreams, The Babadook sets a bar by which future local horror films will be measured.
An earnest and technically confident piece of filmmaking but noticeably lacking in stakes
Honest, insightful and bravely against the grain, 52 Tuesdays is a magnificent debut for cast and filmmaker alike.
For all its moments of depravity and violence, the most shocking thing about Cheap Thrills may be the realisation as to where we would draw the line for ourselves.
Grim, absorbing, emotionally exhausting...[writer/director Lance Edmands] demonstrates a natural understanding for character and tone.
David Lowery's richly woven, beautifully photographed Ain't Them Bodies Saints wears its dramatic sincerity on its sleeve.
As the story reaches an anguished kind of climax, so too does Wheatley go full Kubrick, abandoning narrative entirely for a sequence of full-blown psychotropic madness.
Short Term 12 hits hard at times, yet despite its potentially melodramatic subject matter, never once feels manipulative or overwrought.
Updating the premise and themes of the original, this sleek new model, although lacking Verhoeven's audacious black humour, has brains beneath its metal skull.
A tender, at times devastating portrayal of the lifespan of a relationship, one that's as convincing and intimate as any you've ever seen on screen.
As with the previous films, Klapisch keeps the tone buoyant, livening Xavier's voiceover musings with plenty of visual whimsy.
This is the most compelling tale of nautical peril since Steven Spielberg's Jaws.
Admirers of Vidal's work will find much to like in this entertaining biographical treatment, one that will also no doubt inspire a whole new generation of fans.
movie_title: Gore Vidal: The United States Of Amnesia (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Comedy of the most risk averse and unimaginative kind.
Noah is the first film in Aronofsky's body of work to feel unmistakably watered down.
The entire cast operates at the top of their game. Yet it's Bell who is undeniably the main attraction.
It may even inspire you to draw up some floor plans of your own.
movie_title: TINY: A Story About Living Small (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Mixing traditional vampire mythology with the director's distinctively aloof brand of cool, Only Lovers is a handsome, compelling, meditative take on the lives of the eternal undead.
Trades the raw, taboo-shattering violence of its predecessor for a cheaper, more predictable yet somehow nastier kind of carnage.
Archambault tackles potentially uncomfortable subject matter with both empathy and frankness.
A cold, disturbing, impenetrable piece of filmmaking, it's a movie that will understandably alienate mainstream audiences, even as it carves a place for itself as a modern-day cult classic.
As with the best films from Swanberg and his mumblecore brethren, the joy of Happy Christmas comes from the authenticity of its characters.
The Hundred-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared can hardly disappear from cinemas soon enough.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's fascinating watching Cage play a man who is constantly trying to restrain himself, when as an actor he's best known for throwing caution to the wind.
While her behaviour will frequently have you hiding behind your hands, Helen's unshakably non-conformist attitude makes her an easy protagonist to like.
The Immigrant is a bleak film, at times a little cold. But thanks to the magnificent work of Gray's cast, it's difficult to forget.
The narrative and visual minimalism, initially such an asset, eventually leaves the audience feeling numb.
A masterpiece of framing and composition, Diao Yinan's Black Coal, Thin Ice is a rare kind of film in which no shot feels unconsidered or out of place
movie_title: Bai ri yan huo (Black Coal, Thin Ice) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: An indie film epic the likes of which have never been seen before. And yet, as with Before Midnight, it's the project's emotional authenticity that ensures that it really hits home.
Captures the dynamics of adolescent friendship to perfection. Funny and full of bluster, it's an exuberant tribute to punk rock spirit, and to the experience of being thirteen.
Certainly, The Grandmaster is far from Wong's best. But it's a beautiful creation all the same.
Sin City 2 isn't a particularly inferior film to its predecessor. It's just that, after all this time, the novelty is no longer there.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Contrived and pretentious from title card to end credits.
A gripping, single-location thriller...plays simultaneously like a psychological horror story and an examination of abusive relationships, homophobia and gay self-loathing.
Once again, Fincher is dressing up trash as serious art, wanting to have his cake and eat it too. And frankly, we wouldn't take it any other way.
A delicate, relatable portrait of domestic minutiae.
The year's must-see doco for movie buffs.
There are plenty of intriguing concepts beneath the movie's stylish surface, although often their delivery leaves a lot to be desired.
What The Infinite Man lacks in size it makes up for in brains and heart...the rare sort of film that feels invigorated, rather than hamstrung, by its obvious financial constraints.
A tense and thoughtful look at guilt, obsession and revenge.
A masterful performance from Tom Hardy ensures this one-man show is enthralling from beginning to end.
So bland, conventional and boring that it barely registers as a movie at all
Tonally, emotionally and spiritually complex, Calvary comes highly recommended.
A lively, intriguing look at the line between artist and inventor, one that challenges the very notion that the distinction should be made at all.
The sorts of visuals the filmmakers capture are nothing short of astounding...yet while the imagery is beautiful, its implications are often dire.
In what is shaping up to be a banner year for Australian cinema, this wild and powerful doco has officially stolen the lead.
It's difficult to think of a supposed romantic comedy with two less sympathetic protagonists.
A charming portrait of two lonely hearts who connect across a city of more than 20 million people.
A confronting think piece wrapped in a bizarre and bloody thrill ride.
What the film is really missing, though, is a character like Malcolm Tucker. Without an angry Scotsman threatening to punch people into paralysis, the humour feels decidedly toothless.
If more filmmakers entrusted their projects to actors like Marsan, their movies would be all the better for it.
Zak Hilditch makes a scorching debut feature with this emotionally explosive apocalyptic drama.
A cliched and frequently stodgy affair...pales in comparison to [Corbjin's] previous effort, or indeed, other recent le Carre adaptations.
Carney's script suffers from more than a few contrivances, but the charm of the performances - both spoken and sung - shines through
The moral murkiness of the Israel-Palestine conflict sets the scene for a blistering espionage thriller.
De Heer's slow narrative defies traditional arcing, the rewarding if occasionally directionless sense of realism enhanced by his naturalistic camerawork.
The kind of film that children may find amusing but their parents will wish that they didn't.
If you are ready to thrill to the fall of civilisation (for the third time in this series), then there are worse ways to spend an afternoon. Just don't expect much humour.
movie_title: Conquest Of The Planet Of The Apes (1972)

movie_review_blurb: It works fairly well as the central movie of the franchise but will have little to offer non-devotees.
movie_title: Escape from the Planet of the Apes (1971)

movie_review_blurb: The Planet of the Apes series started well, and gradually decreased in budget and quality. By Battle the budget is all but gone, and all the believability and excitement has gone with it.
movie_title: Battle For The Planet Of The Apes (1973)

movie_review_blurb: Mars Attacks! wants to be the Dr Strangelove of alien B-movies, but isn't up to the challenge. Instead it's a paceless, overlong, and campy film partly redeemed by a number of hilarious and gruesome alien invasion skits.
You're left wishing the film had a little more faith in its audience, for then this well-put-together movie might have provoked more thought, and slightly less irritation.
There's no shortage of innuendo, action, exotic locations, or casual misogyny. Unfortunately it's too camp and cruel an adventure to raise more than a Moore-like eyebrow.
movie_title: The Man with the Golden Gun (1974)

movie_review_blurb: While Scream 3 is only an above-average film in its own right, as the conclusion to the trilogy it works more effectively than anyone had a right to expect.
A lightweight, slight movie which only looks savagely convincing.
The plot holes are obvious and disconcerting, the sub-plots feel tacked-on, and the characters are both thinly-drawn and badly-played.
A pure back-to-basics action-adventure spy drama which mostly delivers.
Substantial credit should also go to Terence Stamp's casually menacing General Zod, who transcends his terrible costume and make-up to appear a convincing threat.
There are just too many main characters for any of them to develop any depth, too many shots of casino signs sparkling in the night, and too little pace and plot to pull the whole thing together.
The Texas Chainsaw Massacre doesn't try anything funny, there are no winks to the audience. And it's all the better because of it.
By far the best part of the trilogy, Empire is a classic that completely transcends its genre, with a reputation that can only grow and grow.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode V - The Empire Strikes Back (1980)

movie_review_blurb: Retains the freshness of an original -- exploring the difficulties and corruptions of working stiffs with a realism, sensitivity and intelligence that has seldom been matched since.
